73 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


October 21, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Letters: Obama fairness a two-way street


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; P-com Opinion; Pg. 22


LENGTH: 650 words


IN A RADIO ad, Sen. Obama declares that he wants his daughters to have the same opportunities as our sons. This seems fair - but I just wonder, if he is elected, will he end affirmative action programs so that my son can have the same rights as his daughters?

Robert Patrick McNulty, Philadelphia 

Thomas Vernon begins his letter by saying, "Sen. McCain has chosen Gov. Palin, who is clearly unprepared to be the vice president . . ."

As if Sen. Obama, with four years of Senate experience (two of which have been spent running for president), is anywhere near prepared to run our country!

Palin is a governor, the top exec of a state in the union. Obama has never been in charge of anything. In fact, of the 29 leadership positions in his own party, he was not even considered for one.

Dan Rooney, King of Prussia

Blame Fannie, Freddie execs, too

I agree with columnist Elmer Smith on how greedy and arrogant it was for the execs at Lehman to award themselves millions while workers got nothing but a pink slip.

But Elmer doesn't seem to mind that the execs at Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and Countrywide made millions while common shareholders got wiped out and many workers were laid off. At least Lehman's collapse was the result of greed and stupidity, not fraud.

John Sullivan, Philadelphia

N. Philly: Students & dealers

Why are North Philly residents up in arms about Temple students renting in their neighborhood? How about giving the same attention to slumlords renting to crack dealers who decimate their neighborhood? There are zoning laws that prevent law-abiding students from living in their neighborhood, but nothing to deter drug dealers?

William Cullen, Hatboro

Who's getting stopped?

I can't understand the logic behind putting the blame for the recent death of a Philadelphia police officer on the shoulders of Judge Jacquelyn Frazier-Lyde or the parole board. As a judge, Frazier-Lyde must follow the sentencing guidelines.

From the beginning, I wondered why this officer stopped Daniel Giddings in the first place. If he was wanted for an assault a month before, they couldn't have been looking for him very hard.

It's really disturbing when I hear that someone has been pulled over by a cop because that driver is almost always a black person. Why is that?

Charlotte Mears, Philadelphia

We all suffer for bad parolees

It appears that every time a paroled prisoner commits another crime, the blame is placed on all prisoners.

Every prisoner, like every citizen in society, has different value systems. We've all made mistakes somewhere in life - some were more serious and warranted stricter punishments.

Having and showing remorse and redeeming themselves for what they've messed up should be the main focus placed on individuals. We are all unique and should be evaluated on our individual merits, not held accountable for others' bad behavior. Stop blaming all prisoners for the wrong things a few ex-cons do while on parole.

Larry Stephenson

Graterford (Pa.) State Prison

Many articles have been printed about Officer McDonald's tragic death, which has affected all of society, including the prison population here at Graterford.

Many prisoners are waiting to go home, and want to do the right thing. But now they are depicted as being like Officer McDonald's killer. When do we as a humane society stop punishing others for the crimes of a few?

Punishing all prisoners for this tragic event is not the answer. When an officer kills an innocent person, do we punish the whole police department?

Alonzo L. Garwood

Graterford (Pa.) State PrisonSymbolic hypocrisy

Re Stu Bykofsky's recent column "A Complaint vs. Bryant & the Public Goode":

How does holding up a KKK sign fundamentally differ from holding up a noose?

They're two sides of the same coin. Yet one action is defended as harmless by an elected official, while the other draws condemnation from all corners of the country.

Michael T. Kalada

Philadelphia


LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



74 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


October 21, 2008 Tuesday
REGION EDITION


Race tightens, focuses on swing states THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE


BYLINE: Joe Sobczyk Bloomberg News


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 862 words


WASHINGTON -- Democratic Illinois Sen. Barack Obama is holding onto his lead in national and state polls as he and Republican Arizona Sen. John McCain focus on a handful of states that will be crucial in deciding the Nov. 4 presidential election.

The race has tightened with a little more than two weeks to go before Election Day. Mr. Obama was ahead of Mr. McCain by 5 percentage points in the average of seven of the most recent polls compiled by the Web site Realclearpolitics.com. That's a 2-point decline from a week ago, when Mr. Obama led by an average of 7 percentage points.

In two polls released yesterday, from CNN-Opinion Research and Hotline-Diageo, Mr. Obama had a 5 percentage point lead. Mr. Obama got 51 percent support to Mr. McCain's 46 percent in the CNN survey; the Hotline-Diageo poll put Mr. Obama's support at 47 percent to Mr. McCain's 42 percent. A Gallup daily tracking showed Mr. Obama leading 52-43 among registered voters who say they plan to cast ballots on Election Day. All three were conducted Oct. 17-19, after the last presidential debate.

Mr. Obama, bolstered by record fundraising and an endorsement yesterday by retired Gen. Colin Powell, is challenging Mr. McCain in what had been Republican territory, including Virginia and North Carolina.

Mr. McCain is focusing on the traditional swing states of Florida, Ohio and Missouri, where he was campaigning yesterday.

"We think the race will tighten," Mr. Obama said this morning in an interview on NBC's "Today" show. "In each of these battleground states, you've got a lot of close races. One of the messages that I've had to my team is that we don't let up."

Mr. Obama has at least a narrow lead in polls conducted in Colorado, Nevada and Virginia. All were won by Republican George W. Bush in the last two elections.

Mr. McCain, meanwhile, was ahead in the Republican strongholds of Georgia, Texas, Mississippi and Wyoming.

Two surveys in Florida came up with opposite results as to who is in front. Polls in Ohio, Missouri and North Carolina show the race in a dead heat.

Florida began early voting yesterday, and Mr. Obama was spending the day there -- his sixth trip since clinching the Democratic nomination. He campaigned last night in Orlando with New York Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, his chief rival during the Democratic primaries.

Mr. McCain campaigned in Missouri yesterday before heading to Pennsylvania for the night. The Republican is still competing for Pennsylvania's 21 electoral votes, even as polls here show Mr. Obama widening his lead. The Realclearpolitics.com average puts Mr. Obama's advantage at 13 percentage points in Pennsylvania, up from 8 points at the start of the month.

Mr. Obama may get a boost from Gen. Powell's endorsement among swing voters who have expressed concern about the first-term senator's ability to deal with foreign and national security affairs.

Gen. Powell served in three GOP administrations, most recently as secretary of state during President Bush's first term. He called Mr. Obama a "transformational figure" yesterday on NBC's "Meet the Press" program.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said the Powell endorsement was significant. "What that just did in one sound bite -- and I assume that sound bite will end up in an ad -- is it eliminated the experience argument," he said Sunday on ABC's "This Week" program. Mr. Obama said on NBC yesterday that if he wins the presidency, he would lean on Gen. Powell as an adviser.

The Democratic candidate's campaign also reported raising $150 million in September -- the most ever brought in by a presidential candidate in one month -- and is on pace to spend as much as a half-billion dollars. That would be almost double the amount available to Mr. McCain.

The campaigns are focusing on the state-by-state battle and collecting enough support to win majorities in enough states to reach the 270 electoral votes needed to gain the White House.

In Virginia, with 13 electoral votes, three polls taken in the past week show Mr. Obama with an average lead of about 6 percentage points. The state has gone Republican in the last 10 elections.

A Research 2000 poll conducted Oct. 14-15 in North Carolina found Mr. Obama leading Mr. McCain 46 percent to 44 percent, within the survey's margin for error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The state, with 15 electoral votes, has gone Democratic three times in the last 12 presidential elections.

The two are essentially tied in recent polls in Missouri, which has gone with the winning candidate in 25 of the last 26 presidential elections. A Suffolk University poll conducted Oct. 17-19 and released yesterday shows Mr. McCain with 45 percent and Mr. Obama with 44 percent statewide, with a margin for error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The state has 11 electoral votes.

Another major battleground is Ohio. The two most recent polls, by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research for NBC and Rasmussen, show the race is a dead heat. A poll there by Boston-based Suffolk gave Mr. Obama a 9-point lead, 51 percent to 42 percent. No Republican candidate has won the presidency without also winning Ohio, which will award 20 Electoral College votes.


LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: The 2008 presidential election is 14 days away. Go to post-gazette.com for an interactive voter guide, breaking political news, the Early Returns blog, candidate videos, polls and ad watch, and PG endorsements.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



75 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


October 21, 2008 Tuesday
REGION EDITION


Race tightens, focuses on swing states THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE


BYLINE: Joe Sobczyk Bloomberg News


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 862 words


WASHINGTON -- Democratic Illinois Sen. Barack Obama is holding onto his lead in national and state polls as he and Republican Arizona Sen. John McCain focus on a handful of states that will be crucial in deciding the Nov. 4 presidential election.

The race has tightened with a little more than two weeks to go before Election Day. Mr. Obama was ahead of Mr. McCain by 5 percentage points in the average of seven of the most recent polls compiled by the Web site Realclearpolitics.com. That's a 2-point decline from a week ago, when Mr. Obama led by an average of 7 percentage points.

Mr. Obama has at least a narrow lead in polls conducted in Colorado, Nevada and Virginia. All were won by Republican George W. Bush in the last two elections.

In Virginia, with 13 electoral votes, three polls taken in the past week show Mr. Obama with an average lead of about 6 percentage points. The state has gone Republican in the last 10 elections.

A Research 2000 poll conducted Oct. 14-15 in North Carolina found Mr. Obama leading Mr. McCain 46 percent to 44 percent, within the survey's margin for error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The state, with 15 electoral votes, has gone Democratic three times in the last 12 presidential elections.

The two are essentially tied in recent polls in Missouri, which has gone with the winning candidate in 25 of the last 26 presidential elections. A Suffolk University poll conducted Oct. 17-19 and released yesterday shows Mr. McCain with 45 percent and Mr. Obama with 44 percent statewide, with a margin for error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. The state has 11 electoral votes.

Another major battleground is Ohio. The two most recent polls, by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research for NBC and Rasmussen, show the race is a dead heat. A poll there by Boston-based Suffolk gave Mr. Obama a 9-point lead, 51 percent to 42 percent. No Republican candidate has won the presidency without also winning Ohio, which will award 20 Electoral College votes.


LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: The 2008 presidential election is 14 days away. Go to post-gazette.com for an interactive voter guide, breaking political news, the Early Returns blog, candidate videos, polls and ad watch, and PG endorsements.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



76 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Public Opinion (Chambersburg, Pennsylvania)


October 21, 2008 Tuesday


Franklin County area college students weigh in on campaign issues


BYLINE: By KEITH PARADISE, ROB LUFF and MARCUS RAUHUT Staff writers


SECTION: LOCAL


LENGTH: 954 words


Students on local college campuses are concerned about the nation's economy and the ongoing wars in the Middle East as the presidential election draws near.

With the presidential election two weeks away, some area college students are still undecided on who they will vote for, or if they will vote at all. Others, however, have made up their minds and, in some instances, have already voted. Most said they have concerns about the economy and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and aren't sure which candidate would be best to address the issues. Austin Cromartie, a junior elementary education major At Shippensburg University from Fayetteville, said the election is "pretty serious" to him because the war in Iraq changed his life plans. He had planned to follow his father into the U.S. Army, but decided against it when the war in Iraq continued.

"It affected my future," Cromartie said. "I didn't feel we were there for the right reasons."

His father retired from his Army career earlier than he had planned, concerned he could be placed on the ground in Iraq after more than two decades of service. He discouraged his sons from joining the military, instructing them to at least choose the U.S. Air Force instead of the U.S. Army.

"It definitely affected my family," he said, which has a military tradition.

Cromartie will vote for Barack Obama because he wants a change from the politics of the last eight years, he said, and feels John McCain is too much like President George W. Bush. He wants to see the armed forces leave Iraq and change what the future will look like for the United States.

"I think we need a little more change than McCain can offer," Cromartie said.

Obama's stance on education was especially appealing to the elementary education major, who hopes to see him change different aspects of No Child Left Behind.

"I just want change in general," Cromartie said. "He's not the white Christian Republican that everyone's used to."

Laura Feliciani, a freshman at Shippensburg from Newtown, said she isn't sure if she's going to vote at all in the election and her friend Sarah Styer from Lancaster said she's already voted for Obama, but isn't entirely sure why.

"Barack, just because," she said, but added that there are no major issues of importance to her. She also said she did not follow politics much during the election.

"I have, but I haven't," Styer said.

Meanwhile Cheryl Taylork, a senior at Wilson College from Frederick, Md. also voted by an absentee ballot for Obama because she likes his stance on wars and because he represents change.

"The big thing for me is the economy and the war. I'm a Democrat, so I do side with Obama a lot because he wants to get us out of the war and has better ideas on the economy. He's a big change and we need someone totally different,"

Edward McCauley III, senior sociology major from Philadelphia said the country needs a great representative to take it in a new direction for the future.

"I believe in what Obama is preaching," McCauley said. "He seems more genuine, (unlike the) political games on the commercials."

McCauley's fraternity, Iota Phi Theta Fraternity, Inc., has run voter registration drives on the Shippensburg campus and off campus, encouraging anyone who is 18 or older to vote.

At Wilson, the entire college has become more politically active. Jill Hummer, faculty advisor for the Political Science Association at Wilson College, said the college is planning a mock election on Oct. 28, one week before the actual election. The college hosted a debate-watching party and discussion during the debates and will host an election returns party on the night of the general election.

McCauley believes Obama can improve the American economy by eliminating the outsourcing of jobs to other countries. He also likes Obama's anti-war stance, and would like to see him hand over control of Iraq to its government.

McCauley does like Republican vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin, because of her youth and her new attitude, though he disagrees with her conservative politics.

"I'm not conservative at all," he said.

Mark Laird, a freshman history secondary education major at Shippensburg, said his political awareness was enhanced by his college classes, with professors who have assigned election-related assignments for homework and forcing students to watch the presidential debates. The ill stock market has Laird concerned, so he hopes to see a president who can improve the economy and be a good representative of the country on the international scene.

"I think this is a very important election," Laird said

Many students, however, are still undecided. Steph Metzler, a freshman at Wilson from Fayetteville, is registered to vote, but she is not fond of either candidate.

"Obama is young and doesn't seem to have a set plan. McCain is a lot like Bush," she said.

Mike Wagaman of South Mountain is a student at Penn State-Mont Alto and can relate to Metzler's sentiments. Wagaman said he won't be voting for either candidate on Election Day and will more than likely be casting a ballot for third-party candidate Ron Paul. He has concerns that both candidates are out of touch with most residents and doesn't like the direction that either party has led the country in.

"I don't think either of them know what Americans want," He asked.

Ross Miller, a student at Penn State-Mont Alto, said that he's doesn't know who he will be voting for in November but has every intention of casting a ballot. He said that he has concerns about the nation's economy along with personal rights and is against gun control. Mostly, however, he's interested in seeing the economy rebound.

"It's a good time to be in school because I don't have to worry about a job," Miller said.


LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Public Opinion
All Rights Reserved



77 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


October 20, 2008 Monday


Stop The Hate And Try This Debate


BYLINE: Joe Vulopas; Life Apparent


SECTION: A; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 742 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


They talked directly to Joe Six Pack.

They talked directly to Joe the Plumber.

Now it's time they talk directly to Joe the Dad.

That's me.

My name is Joe, which officially qualifies me as an Everyman of sorts. According to the McCain and Obama campaigns, I am an expert on the typical, average, middle-class dad.

Like the plumber and the six pack, I am one angry Joe. My anger stems not from how the candidates stand on the issues. It's how they present - or should I say, "mispresent" - their stands on the issues.

I am tired of the lies. And I'm tired of the negative campaigning.

My kids are listening. My kids are watching. And I want this political madness to stop.

Through Sept. 7 alone, the candidates aired more than 150,000 negative ads against their opponents, according to Nielsen Media Research. The breakdown is almost 50-50 - McCain's 76,238 to Obama's 75,246.

And I'm certain almost all of the negative commercials were rife with lies. Search any legitimate fact-checking website monitoring this campaign. It is appalling on both sides. Lies dominate.

The debates are over. But if there were one more ...

Just One More Debate

Walter Cronkite: The audience behind me has promised to be quiet, except at this moment, when we welcome Barack Obama and John McCain.

Gentlemen, are each of you tonight willing to sit at this vegetable stand and say to each other's faces what your campaigns and the people in your campaigns have said about each other? Senator, you first.

Senator: You know, just a few minutes ago, I was looking at eggplants over there. I met Joe the Dad, who was also looking for an eggplant to feed his two kids. Nice guy. He asked me why my opponent is running such a negative campaign. I agreed with him.

Senator: I am not running the negative commercials. You are.

Senator: I am not. And Joe said it.

Senator: You're the one running a negative campaign.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Cronkite: Ummm. Gentlemen. Please.

Senator: Sorry, Mr. Cronkite. Sorry, Joe. But my opponent started it.

Senator: Did not.

Senator: Did too. And you know you're lying. You don't even like eggplant.

Senator: Do too.

Senator: Do not.

Senator: Do too. I also like lettuce. Joe likes lettuce. But Joe doesn't like lies.

Senator: You're the liar.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Senator: Am not. You know it. And Joe knows.

Senator: Liar.

Senator: Loser.

Senator: Loser liar ...

Walter Cronkite shakes his head, as the senators begin flinging lima beans at each other. Chaos ensues.

***

Anyway, the debate would end, and I - Joe the Dad - would be famous for a few minutes. Until they find another Joe to pick on.

This year, the campaigns promised to leave their children out of it, and that is understandable. But I can't leave my own children out of it. They're exposed daily.

Palin is a mother. Obama is a father. McCain and Biden are fathers and grandfathers. It's time they start acting the parts. It's time they start being honest with the American people.

An honest politician who can win by running a clean campaign?

Maybe that's just Joe the Idealist talking.

Maybe. But it wasn't that long ago that the thought of an African-American president or a female vice president seemed idealistic, too.

Someday we'll have the first candidate whose campaign was won on truth, not cheap assaults and lies. I would vote for that candidate, hands down.

Just recently, my son was running for student council at his school and had to write a speech. He brought home a checklist, which included, among others, three requirements:

nBe positive in your speech.

nDo not put down your opponent.

nDo not make unrealistic promises.

As I watched the 11-year-old write and later practice his speech, I couldn't help but think about our own presidential candidates.

What checklist do they use when they write their campaigns?

From all accounts, the candidates and their running mates are good people. They seem like caring citizens who want to make a difference. That gives me comfort.

I only wish the atmosphere of their campaigns would reflect the atmosphere of their hearts.

Joe the Idealist again? No, Joe the Dad.

Anyway, Joe the Dad is tired of the lies. Joe the Dad is tired of the negative campaigning.

Believe what you want about the candidate you support. I, for one, think it is a pitiful day when those campaigning to lead the most powerful nation in the world don't meet the minimal requirements necessary to make student council at my son's elementary school.


LOAD-DATE: October 21, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Joe Vulopas Life Apparent


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



78 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


October 20, 2008 Monday


Stop The Hate And Try This Debate


BYLINE: Joe Vulopas; Life Apparent


SECTION: A; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 742 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


They talked directly to Joe Six Pack.

They talked directly to Joe the Plumber.

Now it's time they talk directly to Joe the Dad.

That's me.

My name is Joe, which officially qualifies me as an Everyman of sorts. According to the McCain and Obama campaigns, I am an expert on the typical, average, middle-class dad.

My kids are listening. My kids are watching. And I want this political madness to stop.

And I'm certain almost all of the negative commercials were rife with lies. Search any legitimate fact-checking website monitoring this campaign. It is appalling on both sides. Lies dominate.

The debates are over. But if there were one more ...

Just One More Debate

Walter Cronkite: The audience behind me has promised to be quiet, except at this moment, when we welcome Barack Obama and John McCain.

Gentlemen, are each of you tonight willing to sit at this vegetable stand and say to each other's faces what your campaigns and the people in your campaigns have said about each other? Senator, you first.

Senator: You know, just a few minutes ago, I was looking at eggplants over there. I met Joe the Dad, who was also looking for an eggplant to feed his two kids. Nice guy. He asked me why my opponent is running such a negative campaign. I agreed with him.

Senator: I am not running the negative commercials. You are.

Senator: I am not. And Joe said it.

Senator: You're the one running a negative campaign.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Cronkite: Ummm. Gentlemen. Please.

Senator: Sorry, Mr. Cronkite. Sorry, Joe. But my opponent started it.

Senator: Did not.

Senator: Did too. And you know you're lying. You don't even like eggplant.

Senator: Do too.

Senator: Do not.

Senator: Do too. I also like lettuce. Joe likes lettuce. But Joe doesn't like lies.

Senator: You're the liar.

Senator: Am not.

Senator: Am too.

Senator: Am not. You know it. And Joe knows.

Senator: Liar.

Senator: Loser.

Senator: Loser liar ...

Walter Cronkite shakes his head, as the senators begin flinging lima beans at each other. Chaos ensues.

***

Anyway, the debate would end, and I - Joe the Dad - would be famous for a few minutes. Until they find another Joe to pick on.

This year, the campaigns promised to leave their children out of it, and that is understandable. But I can't leave my own children out of it. They're exposed daily.

Palin is a mother. Obama is a father. McCain and Biden are fathers and grandfathers. It's time they start acting the parts. It's time they start being honest with the American people.

An honest politician who can win by running a clean campaign?

Maybe that's just Joe the Idealist talking.

Maybe. But it wasn't that long ago that the thought of an African-American president or a female vice president seemed idealistic, too.

Someday we'll have the first candidate whose campaign was won on truth, not cheap assaults and lies. I would vote for that candidate, hands down.

Just recently, my son was running for student council at his school and had to write a speech. He brought home a checklist, which included, among others, three requirements:

nBe positive in your speech.

nDo not put down your opponent.

nDo not make unrealistic promises.

As I watched the 11-year-old write and later practice his speech, I couldn't help but think about our own presidential candidates.

What checklist do they use when they write their campaigns?

From all accounts, the candidates and their running mates are good people. They seem like caring citizens who want to make a difference. That gives me comfort.

I only wish the atmosphere of their campaigns would reflect the atmosphere of their hearts.

Joe the Idealist again? No, Joe the Dad.

Anyway, Joe the Dad is tired of the lies. Joe the Dad is tired of the negative campaigning.

Believe what you want about the candidate you support. I, for one, think it is a pitiful day when those campaigning to lead the most powerful nation in the world don't meet the minimal requirements necessary to make student council at my son's elementary school.

79 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


October 20, 2008 Monday
CITY-D Edition


Letters to the Editor


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Inq Opinion & Editorial; Pg. A14


LENGTH: 668 words


Conspiracy theoryWith John McCain against the ropes, the GOP is relying on the old Punch and Judy Show formula. When the audience's attention lags, bring out the big stick. How else to describe the timing of the announcement of the killing of al-Qaeda's No. 2 operative in Iraq on the same day as McCain's final debate?

So what if No. 2 was actually killed 10 days earlier. The Bush team had no problem keeping him on ice if it would gain points for their desperate candidate. Don't be surprised if they pull Osama bin Laden out of the deep freeze just before Election Day. The GOP Show must go on!

Stacia FriedmanPhiladelphiaCampaign adviceWith Barack Obama the heavy favorite to win as Election Day nears, John McCain needs to make a bold move, one that could make up for the Sarah Palin selection.

He must revert to his maverick ways and tell the truth to the American voters. Many of us would welcome real straight talk that contained common sense and a respect for the intelligence of the electorate. Tell us the country must live within its means. Tell us there should be shared sacrifice - not just by military families. Tell us we're not "entitled" to free health care, long retirements, or college education. In short, tell us there is no "free lunch." It sounds crazy, but what have you got to lose?

James P. BurkeBroomalljpburke66@comcast.netDebt-based economyAm I the only person alarmed by the house of cards - credit cards, that is - that is the basis of our economy? If injecting lots of money into our banks will allow consumers to borrow and keep spending, then aren't we continuing to stake our economic health on indebtedness? Vast indebtedness is the thing most responsible for this economic failure, albeit "easy credit" caused it. No one wants to admit it, though. Our lifestyles should be based on wages, not credit limits.

Bonnie MasonCollingswoodFellow humansRegardless of where one comes down on policy questions related to the homeless, none of us should refer to giving them food as "public feedings" ("Decorum on the Parkway," Tuesday). We are talking about fellow human beings, not sea lions at the zoo.

Jeff SilverPhiladelphiajeffmsilver@yahoo.com

Care prescriptionRe: "Health-care plans familiar," commentary, Monday:

Yale Professors Marmor and Mashaw are correct on several points, including the compelling need to address health-care costs over more discussions on the mechanisms to finance an obviously broken health-care system. They are also correct in calling for restraining salaries in the health-care industry.

While the data may not be evident yet, they should not, however, give up on prevention. Also, they omitted the huge economic factor of compassionate and ethical rationing of health care, especially for the elderly and the dying. But politicians are even more loathe to address prevention and rationing than reining in salaries in the health-care sector. So we citizens must lead the way.

Richard A. Lippin, M.D.SouthamptonBarnes battleThe Barnes Foundation unveiled its expensive and unnecessary showpiece commercial on the Parkway last week ("Barnes makes its presence felt," Thursday). Where did the money come from to erect this giant ad? There is a shuttle bus at the Philadelphia Art Museum every day to bring a few people across the street to the Perelman Building. Why couldn't it be used to take people to the Barnes six miles away in Merion instead of moving the art to the city. And the new Please Touch Museum in Fairmount Park: That's regionalism! At a time when the Library has to shorten its hours and schools are falling apart, how can the city, the state, and local philanthropists possibly waste precious dollars on this money pit?

Nancy HermanMerionMisguided policyRe: "Schools to expel violent students," Thursday:

How will expelling a child who obviously has mental and emotional issues make him or her a more productive student and citizen? Imagine if parents were allowed to throw their kids away like that.

G. Djata BumpusPhiladelphia


LOAD-DATE: October 20, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



80 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


October 19, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


Inqlings: Ruggles shares his cancer fight


BYLINE: By Michael Klein; Inquirer Columnist


SECTION: PHILADELPHIA; P-com News Local; Pg. B02


LENGTH: 1166 words


In a three-night series starting tonight on NBC10's 11 p.m. news, morning anchor Terry Ruggles will talk about his battle with testicular cancer.

This is a story without a clear ending.

Ruggles, who has worked for WCAU for 34 of his 62 years, told me that he had discovered a lump late in the summer while showering. The testicle was removed, and doctors are weighing chemo or radiation, he said.

He said that he had considered keeping quiet about it, but that a network program on early cancer detection had made him want to speak out.

"It's a personal thing," he said. "It's just part of the body, and it's a cancer. If I can tell my story and convince someone to take action, that's the right thing."

Smerconish's surprise Talk-show host Michael Smerconish lit up the phones and filled his in-box Friday morning after the lifelong Republican disclosed that he'll vote for Barack Obama - the first time since he registered to vote 28 years ago that he'll pull the D lever for president.

Smerconish's GOP ties are deep. He was Philly's administrator for the Department of Housing and Urban Development under George H.W. Bush and introduced George W. Bush here in 2004.

Smerconish, making his case in his column in today's Inquirer Currents section (Page C3), told me he was aware that this "coming out" might hurt his career nationally. He has been a frequent fill-in for big names such as Glenn Beck and Bill O'Reilly - both of whom wear their conservatism proudly. Smerconish, whose deal with CBS's Big Talker (1210) is up at the end of the year, is being courted by MSNBC.

Smerconish, who said he had gotten heat in the spring for allowing Obama to appear on his show, said the talk industry was dominated by ideologues. "Nobody who straddles [the local and national scenes] like I do has success at a national level unless they work at the ends of the political spectrum," he said. "I'm never going to be Rachel Maddow or Keith Olbermann."

He agreed that making his decision public might not have been "in my professional best interest, but it's how I see it. Mine is an opinion, purely based on a lot of circumspection. I'm fortunate that I've chatted with both [Obama and John McCain], been in their presence, so this is not an uninformed decision."

That said, "I'm not telling people what they ought to do. Do whatever you want."

Doses of reality Thomas Jefferson University Hospital gets star treatment on Wednesday's episode of Dinner: Impossible (10 p.m., Food Network) as onetime patients Andrea Gillespie of Linwood, N.J., and Gaeton Sgro and Marquita Cunningham of Philadelphia help chef Michael Symon and his assistants prepare a thank-you dinner (carrot soup, tuna, pork ragout, bone-in rib eye, cheese polenta, and something called sexy banana pudding) for 230 Jeff nurses. Among prep cooks was hospital chief operating officer David McQuaid.

The Food Network will be at the Embassy Suites Hotel on the Parkway on Oct. 29 to scout contestants for The Next Food Network Star. Last season's winner, Aaron McCargo Jr., is from Camden (and coincidentally was catering chef at Jeff before he struck it big), and runner-up Adam Gertler of South Philly got his own show. Info: www.foodnetwork.com/star.

Reps of Playboy will be in Philly Oct. 28-29 to audition prospective models at an undisclosed Center City hotel. Besides photogs and assistants, models Shelly Riley and Mary Alejo will be on hand. Info for the casting call (it's $49.95) is at www.playboycastingcalls.com.

Phillies, Phillies everywhere Phils centerfielder Shane Victorino is due to sign autographs from noon to 2 p.m. today at the ShopRite at 307 W. Route 70 in Marlton; it's a breast-cancer benefit cosponsored by Skinny Water. At 6 p.m. today, he is scheduled to sign Phils gear taken to the Forman Mills store at 2500 Grant Ave. in Northeast Philly. And Victorino, manager Charlie Manuel, and the Phanatic show up on tomorrow's episode of Jon & Kate Plus 8 (9 p.m., TLC), shot at a Phils game.

Alfa, the restaurant-lounge at 1705 Walnut St., last week started up a charity program on its bar chalkboard. Patrons can "buy a drink" for a particular Phillies player ($5); proceeds will go to Project HOME after the World Series. Leftfielder Pat Burrell walked in Thursday night and plopped down a hundred to "buy" 20 drinks for pinch-hitter Matt Stairs, hero of Game 4 of the National League Championship Series, says owner Joe Beckham.

"Brad Lidge! You just won the National League pennant. What are you going to do next?" Disneyland at the Wachovia Center. The pitcher, with wife Lindsay and daughter Avery, sat unrecognized in the front row at Thursday's Disney on Ice Disneyland Adventure. Saw the show from the start, not just the finale.

Musically noted Actor Alec Baldwin, straight from taping 30 Rock in New York, dropped by the Kimmel Center this month to catch the Philadelphia Orchestra. Baldwin, who told attendees that he is a huge Charles Dutoit fan, got a 10-minute sit-down after the performance with the maestro, who was celebrating his 72d birthday. Speaking of Dutoit, on nice days he's tooling around in a new gray Porsche Carrera, eschewing his orchestra-provided Lincoln Town Car.

Kenny Chesney's new CD, Lucky Old Sun, has a bonus disc featuring four live songs, including "Crazy Last Night," recorded at his July 19 Lincoln Financial Field show.

Brooklyn music producer Vito Bruno, who will bring his annual "Disco Ball" and "Freestyle for All" parties to Atlantic City's Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort on Friday and Saturday, says he's looking for a home for a piece of disco history: the Odyssey 2001 nightclub's dance floor that was used in Saturday Night Fever. Bruno, 52, who worked at the Brooklyn club in the 1970s, bought the 16-by-24-foot light-up assembly at an auction. "It's the single-most recognizable piece of feel-good history in America," says Bruno, who has it in storage. He sees it going to Las Vegas or to booming Dubai in the Middle East.

Institutions At Thursday's unveiling of his caricature at the Palm restaurant in the Bellevue, Mayor Nutter called the image "totally hilarious" and asked, "As I get slimmer and the goatee shrinks down, you will make adjustments?" Nutter told The Inquirer's Peter Mucha that he hoped to get it to look more like Denzel Washington.

The Union League has survived time, wars, fads and the admission of women. But Steven Grasse? The name of the edgy ad man and Bikini Bandits creator was spotted last week on the new-membership roll in the lobby of the exclusive civic organization. Grasse - whose kids go to school with those of his main sponsors, Bob and Darlene Cavalier - summed it: "There comes a time in every man's life when they have to put on a suit and tie and grow up a little. I'm just lucky no one Googled me before I was made a member."

Contact staff writer Michael Klein at 215-854-5514 or mklein@phillynews.com. "INQlings" also appears Tuesdays and Thursdays. See his recent oeuvre at http://go.philly.com/michaelklein.


LOAD-DATE: October 19, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photograph by: Feed Loader


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



81 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


October 19, 2008 Sunday
Correction Appended
TWO STAR EDITION


Democrats in unusual battle to win Jewish vote


BYLINE: Mackenzie Carpenter, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 1817 words


The Democrats have Sarah Silverman, mouthy comedienne, urging young Jewish voters in a video to "schlep it" to Florida to persuade their grandparents to vote for Sen. Barack Obama, the "goodest person I know."

The Republicans have Jackie Mason, mouthy comedian, who, in his own video, supports Sen. John McCain and calls Ms. Silverman -- while pictures of Barbra Streisand, Sen. John F. Kerry and other Democrats flash across the screen -- " a sick yenta," and asks, "What has Obama done? Nothing!"

All attempts at humor aside, the battle for the Jewish vote this year is no laughing matter.

In fact, it's gotten pretty tense out there. Democrats are complaining about Republican-sponsored "push" polls, rumor-mongering and attack ads that, they say, smear Mr. Obama.

Republicans, citing Mr. Obama's willingness to talk directly to leaders of Iran, are trying to sow doubts about Mr. Obama's support for Israel even though he has the same approval score -- 100 percent -- that Mr. McCain does from AIPAC, the influential America-Israel Jewish Political Action Committee.

The stakes this year are huge -- especially in a battleground state like Pennsylvania, where Jewish voters make up about 4 percent of the electorate and, in a tight race, could tip the balance either way.

While Mr. Obama has been moving ahead in national polls, his support among Jews lags behind past Democratic candidates, at 57 percent to 30 percent according to one recent poll by the American Jewish Committee.

In 2004, Mr. Kerry's share of that vote was 75 percent, a number that has ranged from 64 to 90 percent since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt -- with the notable exception of Jimmy Carter in 1980, whose share of Jewish support hit rock bottom at 45 percent.

Since that poll's release in mid-September, the Wall Street crisis may have boosted Mr. Obama's numbers among this group. But the question remains: Why is Mr. McCain getting more traction this year among less religiously conservative and secular Jewish voters who might ordinarily vote Democratic?

"He's independent-minded," said Sen. Joe Lieberman of Mr. McCain, a longtime friend and fellow foreign policy hawk. "He's a restless reformer with no patience for the partisan politics that pass for public service these days."

The Connecticut senator, a former Democrat re-elected as an Independent and the Democratic candidate for vice president eight years ago, spent a recent Friday touring synagogues and appearing at "Bagels with Joe" events in Philadelphia and its suburbs, stressing the Republican nominee's maverick image and citing Mr. McCain's break with the Bush administration on climate change and his support for closing Guantanamo Bay's detention center.

Today, Mr. Lieberman will introduce Mr. McCain at a tele-town hall with Jewish leaders from across the country.

Obama supporters say it's not just Mr. McCain's positives that are resonating with Jewish voters.

b>Dirty tricks charges

/b>

"I think a lot of it is due to the smear campaign that's out there," said Naftali Kaminski, 48, a physician and researcher at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. A staunch Obama supporter and a native of Israel who lives in Squirrel Hill, he has seen anti-Obama ads running on English-speaking Web sites of Israeli newspapers "trying to feed the suspicion that he is a Muslim or pro-Palestinian or anti-Israel."

"Besides being terrible distortions of the truth, these vile, hate-filled, Swift-Boating ads are everywhere in Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Florida," he frets.

Mr. Lieberman says he doesn't like those ads, either, "but I think ultimately people have enough common sense to separate out fact from fiction," he said in a recent telephone interview.

Besides stressing Mr. McCain's independence from Mr. Bush, Mr. Lieberman and other Republicans are hammering away at Mr. Obama and Iran -- repeatedly citing his statement that he'd meet with "appropriate" Iranian leaders after extensive diplomatic preparations. Republicans insist that means he would talk to Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, a Holocaust denier who has called for the annihilation of Israel. The Obama campaign says that's not the case.

"That was the last straw, but not the only straw," said Richard Heideman, a Washington, D.C. attorney. Mr. Heideman spoke on behalf of Mr. McCain at a candidates forum last month at the Jewish Community Center in Squirrel Hill, describing him as "the most experienced hand available to make judgments about life and death issues."

Mr. Heideman delivered a forceful brief for Mr. McCain to an audience of about 80 people -- most of whom appeared to be supporting Mr. Obama.

Opposing him was Gary Ackerman, an acerbic Democratic congressman from Long Island, who told the crowd that, on Iran and other issues, Republicans "are going around pushing our buttons. It's not as though Obama is going to sit down with [Iran President] Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and say, 'How about I give you all the Jews, serve them up on a silver platter.'

"Sen. Obama didn't say he would talk to Ahmadinejad. He said he supports discussions with Iran, and so do I. Didn't we talk to Krushchev or Anwar Sadat without preconditions?"

b>Ground games in high gear

/b>

While these debates go on, both sides are vigorously working to target voters. The Obama campaign has set up Jewish "leadership committees" in various communities to hold training sessions with volunteers, who then go out and talk to their neighbors.

"Jewish voters go out and vote," said Clifford Levine, a Squirrel Hill attorney who has been active in those efforts, which include bringing in surrogates such as Anthony Lake, former national security adviser for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Lake appeared at Rodef Shalom Temple in Shadyside last month.

Mr. Levine nonetheless acknowledged that "this is election is closer than a lot of people think it should be. Older, traditional Democrats aren't quite there yet, even as their children are enthusiastically working for Obama."

"There are lots of older people there are going to work on folks living in the Squirrel Hill high-rises," added former radio talk show host Lynn Cullen, who is now campaigning for Mr. Obama. "One lady sitting next to me said, 'I'm targeting the bubbes.' "

Republicans have been relying on surrogates like Mr. Lieberman and the Washington, D.C.-based Republican Jewish Coalition, which is not affiliated with the McCain campaign but runs Republican advertising and organizing efforts.

"Up until now Democrats have been able to take the Jewish vote for granted but not this year," said Matt Brooks, executive director of the coalition, whose ads in Jewish newspapers have described Mr. Obama as "pro-Palestinian" and "anti-Israel." That ad campaign, along reports of telephone surveys suggesting that Mr. Obama had given money to terrorist groups, has enraged Democrats.

"Do these guys have any shame?" asked Ira Forman, executive director of the National Jewish Democratic Council, who held a news conference last month claiming that the RJC was behind the surveys.

"I test messages," he said. "The Republican Jewish Coalition is testing lies."

"I can assure you we never asked any questions about Obama donating money to the PLO," Mr. Brooks said, noting that his group's survey was not a "push poll" -- short phone calls to thousands of voters which masquerade as surveys but are really designed to pass along negative messages.

Rather, the coalition's most recent poll of 750 voters -- in Florida, Michigan, New Jersey, Ohio and Pennsylvania -- featured 82 questions on a wide range of issues, about 10 percent of them involving questions designed to test negative messages about Mr. Obama.

Deb Minden, a Squirrel Hill psychologist, said she received a call a few weeks ago from pollsters "who asked me how I would feel if I knew Barack Obama was giving money to Hamas or spoke to Hezbollah. It actually sounded like a real poll at the beginning. They wanted names, demographics, were asking generic questions about the candidates," she said.

But when the questions turned to Mr. Obama's associations with terrorists, she felt disgusted.

"It was just garbage," she said. "I hate to think that people think you can scare somebody off and that Jews are only single-issue voters and the Jewish community is so flat in its outlook."

Nonetheless, the single issue of Israel remains paramount for many, and Mr. Obama's surrogates have been working hard to dispel the notion that Mr. Obama is somehow weaker on the issue than Mr. McCain.

"What I've been asking people, when I speak at synagogues, is to ask themselves is not just which candidate would be stronger friend of Israel, but which America would be," said Mr. Lake. "An America that is coming together, that is more unified, that puts aside divisive tactics would be a stronger friend to the Jewish state. That, along with direct talks with Iran to back off its nuclear program, and negotiations with the Syrians would result in our having a stronger standing in the Middle East."

There's also the complex, delicate issue of racial bias, says Jessica Emerson-Fleming, founder of Jewish Grandchildren for Obama, which, like Sarah Silverman's TheGreatSchlep.com, is trying to mobilize younger voters to persuade older relatives to vote for Mr. Obama.

Those younger voters are having to talk about race much more than they expected, she added, a task requiring some diplomatic skill.

"You can't have grandchildren calling their grandparents racist. On the other hand, we think it's very important to call out racism, especially when it's an undercurrent. A lot of people don't realize how what they're saying sounds until they're called out on it."

Even McCain supporters say they're uncomfortable with the ads and e-mails that have been circulating.

They're "unfortunate and blatantly not true," said Daniel Berkowitz, a former Department of Defense employee who is opening a kosher bakery in Squirrel Hill, "and that's a shame because there is so much we can talk about on the issues that support Mr. McCain's candidacy."

Given their relatively small numbers, though, it's not clear if Jewish voters like Mr. Berkowitz will engender a big enough shift toward the Republican to make a difference -- even as emotions on both sides are running high.

"My entire street is Obama," said Cheryl Moore, 43, of Squirrel Hill, and a staunch McCain supporter. Her congregation, Rodef Shalom, "is about 90-10 for Obama, and that's fine, it doesn't bother me at all. This is America.

"But I had a sign out for McCain and it was taken down. What's hard for me is the assumption that there is something wrong with my character and intelligence if I'm voting for McCain. I really do feel a little isolated."

Dr. Kaminski said he's never seen such interest in politics in his dozen years in the U.S. "You never knew what the next person thought. Now, you go to the 61C Cafe in the morning, and you know what everyone thinks."


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Mackenzie Carpenter can be reached at mcarpenter@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1949.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 2008



CORRECTION:  The American Israel Public Affairs Committee does not rate or endorse political candidates. A story in Sunday's editions on Jewish voters said incorrectly that AIPAC had given both Sen. John McCain and Sen. Barack identical 100 percent approval ratings.

82 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


October 18, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


IN AD WAR, OBAMA HAS EDGE


BYLINE: Jim Rutenberg, The New York Times


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-6


LENGTH: 550 words


PHILADELPHIA -- Sen. Barack Obama is days away from breaking the $188 million advertising spending record set by President Bush in the 2004 general-election campaign, having unleashed an advertising campaign of a scale and complexity unrivaled in the television era.

With advertisements running repeatedly day and night, on local stations and on the major broadcast networks, on niche cable networks and even on video games and his own dedicated satellite channels, Mr. Obama is now out-advertising Sen. John McCain nationwide by a ratio of at least 4 to 1, according to CMAG, a service that monitors political advertising. That difference is even larger in several closely contested states.

The huge gap has been made possible by Mr. Obama's decision to opt out of the federal campaign finance system, which gives presidential nominees a dollar for every dollar they raise but limits to $84 million the amount they can spend between their party convention and Election Day. Mr. McCain is participating in the system.

Mr. Obama, who at one point promised to participate in it as well, is expected to announce in the next few days that he raised more than $100 million in September alone -- a figure that would shatter previous monthly fundraising records.

Kenneth M. Goldstein, director of the University of Wisconsin's Advertising Projec, said, "We've certainly seen heavy advertising battles before. But we've never seen in a presidential race one side having such a lopsided advantage."

While Mr. Obama's decision to forgo the matching funds -- and the limits with them -- has given him a spending advantage throughout the election, his broadcast dominance has become most apparent in the past few weeks, as he has gone on a buying binge of TV time that has allowed him to utterly swamp Mr. McCain's campaign with concurrent lines of positive and negative messages.

The Obama ads come as Republicans began a blitz of automated phone calls attacking the Democrat.

The Obama campaign's advertising approach -- which has included ads of as long as two minutes, in which the candidate positively lays out his agenda, and even ads in video games like "Guitar Hero" -- has helped mask some of his rougher attacks on his rival.

"What Obama is doing is being his own good cop and bad cop," said Evan Tracey, CMAG's chief operating officer, who calls the ad war "a blow out" in Mr. Obama's favor.

The disparity has come to the frustration of Mr. McCain, who traded accusations with Mr. Obama over the advertising battle during this week's debate, with the Democrat telling him, "Your ads, 100 percent of them have been negative," and the Republican saying, "Senator Obama has spent more money on negative ads than any political campaign in history."

The University of Wisconsin's most recent analysis of the presidential ads available before the debate -- based on a one week period from Sept. 28 through Oct. 4 -- found Mr. McCain's commercials had been "nearly 100 percent negative," and that the same could be said for 34 percent of Mr. Obama's ads, which were more focused that week on promoting his own agenda.

That finding reflected the McCain camp's strategy of trying to make Mr. Obama an unacceptable choice in the eyes of undecided voters and his rival's goal of making undecided voters comfortable with him.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

83 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


October 18, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


McCain has been scrupulous in eschewing the race card


BYLINE: CHARLES KRAUTHAMMER


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. B-6


LENGTH: 761 words


WASHINGTON

Let me get this straight. A couple of agitated yahoos in a rally of thousands yell something offensive and incendiary, and John McCain and Sarah Palin are not just guilty by association -- with total strangers, mind you -- but worse: guilty according to The New York Times of "race-baiting and xenophobia."

But should you bring up Barack Obama's real associations -- 20 years with Jeremiah Wright, working on two foundations and distributing money with William Ayers, citing the raving Michael Pfleger as one who helps him keep his moral compass (Chicago Sun-Times, April 2004) and the long-standing relationship with the left-wing vote-fraud specialist ACORN -- you have crossed the line into illegitimate guilt by association.

Moreover, it is tinged with racism.

The fact that, when John McCain actually heard one of those nasty things said about Mr. Obama, he incurred the boos of his own crowd by insisting that Mr. Obama is "a decent person that you do not have to be scared [of] as president" makes no difference. It surely did not stop John Lewis from comparing Mr. McCain to George Wallace.

The search for Mr. McCain's racial offenses is untiring and often unhinged. Remember Mr. McCain's Berlin/celebrity ad that showed a shot of Paris Hilton? An appalling attempt to exploit white hostility at the idea of black men "becoming sexually involved with white women," fulminated New York Times columnist Bob Herbert. He took to TV to denounce Mr. McCain's exhumation of that most vile prejudice, pointing out Mr. McCain's gratuitous insertion in the ad of "two phallic symbols," the Washington Monument and the Leaning Tower of Pisa.

Except that Mr. Herbert was entirely delusional. There was no Washington Monument. There was no Leaning Tower. Just photographs seen in every newspaper in the world of Barack Obama's Berlin rally in the setting he himself had chosen, Berlin's Victory Column.

Mr. Herbert is not the only fevered one. On Tuesday night, Rachel Maddow of MSNBC and Jonathan Alter of Newsweek fell over themselves agreeing that the "political salience" of the Republican attack on ACORN is, yes, its unstated appeal to racial prejudice.

This about an organization that is being accused of voter registration fraud in about a dozen states. In Nevada, the investigating secretary of state is a Democrat. Is he playing the race card too?

What makes the charges against Mr. McCain especially revolting is that he has been scrupulous in eschewing the race card. He has gone far beyond what is right and necessary, refusing even to make an issue of Mr. Obama's deep, self-declared connection with the race-baiting Jeremiah Wright.

In the name of racial rectitude, Mr. McCain has denied himself the use of that perfectly legitimate issue. It is simply Orwellian for him to be now so widely vilified as a stoker of racism. What makes it doubly Orwellian is that these charges are being made on behalf of the one presidential candidate who has repeatedly, and indeed quite brilliantly, deployed the race card.

How brilliantly? The reason Bill Clinton is sulking in his tent is because he feels that Obama surrogates succeeded in painting him as a racist. Mr. Clinton has many sins, but from his student days to his post-presidency, his commitment and sincerity in advancing the cause of African Americans have been undeniable. If the man Toni Morrison called the first black president can be turned into a closet racist, then anyone can.

And Mr. Obama has shown no hesitation in doing so to Mr. McCain. Just weeks ago, in Springfield, Mo., and elsewhere, he warned darkly that George Bush and John McCain were going to try to frighten you by saying that, among other scary things, Mr. Obama has "a funny name" and "doesn't look like all those other presidents on those dollar bills."

Mr. McCain has never said that, nor anything like that. When asked at the time to produce one instance of Mr. McCain deploying race, the Obama campaign could not. Yet here was Mr. Obama firing a pre-emptive charge of racism against a man who had not indulged in it. An extraordinary rhetorical feat, and a dishonorable one.

What makes this all the more dismaying is that it comes from Barack Obama, who has consistently presented himself as a healer, a man of a new generation above and beyond race, the man who would turn the page on the guilt-tripping grievance politics of Jesse Jackson and Al Sharpton.

I once believed him.

CORRECTION -- Last week I wrote that in 1995 Bill Ayers gave Barack Obama a fund-raiser in his home. I should instead have called it a campaign event.


LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Charles Krauthammer is a syndicated columnist for The Washington Post (letters@charleskrauthammer.com).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

84 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)


October 17, 2008 Friday


Russia's Putin's a macho kind of guy


BYLINE: By Mary Lou Kelsey Body ... wanna feel my body? "Body ... such a thrill my body "Body ... wanna touch my body? Lebanon Daily News


SECTION: COLUMNISTS


LENGTH: 788 words


"Body ... it's too  much my body

"Check it out my body, body.

"Don't you doubt my body, body.

"Talkin' bout my body, body,

"Check it out my body. ...

"Hey! Hey! Hey, hey, hey!

"Macho, macho man

"I've got to be a macho man

"Macho, macho man.

"I've got to be macho!"

I don't know if I could picture Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin as a member of the Village People, but that ensemble is such an electric group, I don't see how a Russian prime minister could ruin the mix. I would go see him if he went on tour. He might be a little weak on "YMCA," but he would fit right in with "Macho Man."

Putin has a six-pack and he is one mean dude. I am not referring to his politics. I do not approve of his politics or his use of military force. I am not about to get into his invasion of Georgia or his other political power plays, but the dude is one mighty macho man.

He has proved that on countless occasions. He has been seen shirtless on a fishing expedition. He was at the wheel of an immense racing truck. He has flown in a Russian fighter jet.

A few months ago, dressed in camouflage, he was walking through the woods of a Russian wildlife preserve. He spied a Ussuri tiger intimidating photojournalists and confronted the animal, reportedly the largest cat on the planet, and saved the journalists by shooting it with a tranquilizer gun. He put a tracking device on the big cat's neck and petted it like it was a house pet. "She will remember us." He was quoted as saying.

Now, like any celebrity, Putin has gone commercial. He has released a video as a judo master. This instructional DVD is entitled (in translation) "Let's Learn Judo with Vladimir Putin" I think the title could have a bit more pizzazz. I believe it could have more strength, but it isn't "Judo for Idiots" or "Let's Go Beyond Pilates." "Let's Learn Judo with Vladimir Putin" is a bit on the juvenile side. But then Barack Obama has expanded his advertising to put roadside billboards on the Xbox racing video game, "Burnout Paradise."

Putin wants his people to get physical. Putin is a black belt and a former judo champion of his home city, St.

Petersburg. The DVD was produced in collaboration with other judo experts and Olympic judo champion Yasuhiro Yamashita. It pictures Putin talking about the history of the martial art and later has him demonstrating moves with his practice partner. He shows his prowess by throwing his partner onto the mat several times. The Russians love to see their virile 56-year-old prime minister in action.

The DVD has taken off. French President NIcolas Sarkozy is a martial arts fan and would like to take some lessons. In the future Putin and Sarkozy will be training together. I wonder if our next president will be invited to the judo klatch?

It's a shame that "Walker, Texas Ranger," is no longer in production. Chuck Norris could either put Putin on his team or have him as a long-running foe. Putin could be in the next Jackie Chan movie. Then we wouldn't be able to understand either of the main characters.

I think it's time for a Vladimir Putin action figure. Every politician has an action figure. Sarah Palin has three action dolls out. One depicts her as an executive. Another shows her as a school girl and still another has her as Sarah Palin, Super Hero. It is rumored that there is another Palin action figure dressed in a black bustier and sporting a Miss Alaska sash. I particularly like the Beach Blanket Obama action figure. Talk about broad shoulders and a six-pack stomach. I bet Michelle Obama wishes that he could look like that. John McCain has an action figure. John Edwards has an action figure. Even Elliot Spitzer has an action figure.

I searched the Net and couldn't find a Joe Biden action figure. Osama and McCain have Pez Dispensers. Biden doesn't even rate one of those, but he does have a bobble head doll. On that same sale offering I noticed that the John McCain bobble head doll was sold out. Now what does that say to the pollsters?

I began to wonder what instructional DVDs our fearless leaders could offer the voters? I am referring to instructional DVDs on their unique nonpolitical skills. Could Sarah Palin put one out on log-rolling? How about an instructional bowling DVD from Obama? It seems that Joe Biden likes Ping-Pong. That would make a great DVD. He also likes slip-sliding. I thought that is what he did at the debates. McCain likes hiking and fishing. That is not quite as exciting as judo. He also is a great barbecue grill chef. He could put out a cooking DVD.

Vladimir Putin does not have a bobble head doll. I'm sure that suits him just fine, but after his judo DVD he certainly does deserve an action figure or even an Xbox game. I wonder if Obama would advertise on that one?

85 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


October 17, 2008 Friday
CITY-D Edition


McCain keeps up tax attacks;
In Chester County, he pressed a debate theme. In N.H., Obama warned against complacency.


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; Inq World & Nation; Pg. A24


LENGTH: 1097 words


Attempting to build on his performance in the final debate, underdog John McCain traveled to Chester County yesterday and hammered Barack Obama over the Democrat's plan to raise taxes on high-income individuals and small businesses.

Obama warned his own supporters against overconfidence. He did so during a visit to New Hampshire, where Hillary Rodham Clinton upset him in that state's Democratic primary in January.

At the GOP rally at the United Sports Training Center in Downingtown, McCain told several thousand cheering supporters that the real winner in the debate Wednesday night was neither himself nor Obama but "Joe the Plumber," a man whom McCain made a focus of his debate performance.

That man, Samuel Joseph Wurzelbacher, had a conversation with Obama in Holland, Ohio, last Sunday about taxes. Obama's tax plan would raise rates on families and small businesses making more than $250,000 per year while also proposing middle-class tax relief.

Obama told Wurzelbacher it was a good idea to "spread the wealth around." McCain said it was not a good idea.

Obama "wants the government to take Joe's money and give it to someone else," McCain said. "His hard-earned dollars. We're not going to stand for that. America didn't become the greatest nation on earth by spreading the wealth. We became the greatest nation on earth by creating new wealth."

The McCain campaign also launched a "Joe the Plumber" Web ad, reprising the original Obama-Wurzelbacher conversation and calling the Democrat's proposal "welfare" at the expense of "hardworking families."

In New Hampshire, Obama suggested that McCain's concern was disingenuous and that most plumbers would do better financially in a Democratic administration.

McCain is "trying to suggest that a plumber is the guy he's fighting for," Obama said. "How many plumbers you know that are making a quarter-million dollars a year?"

Wurzelbacher said he wasn't one of them. So he would get a tax cut from Obama. But in an interview on ABC's Good Morning America, he called Obama's approach "a very socialist view" and "incredibly wrong."

McCain was using the episode to help frame the presidential race as a contest between a small-government, low-tax conservative and a tax-and-spend liberal.

"Raising taxes makes a bad economy much worse," McCain said. "Keeping taxes low creates jobs, keeps money in your hands, and strengthens our economy."

Last night, McCain and Obama both appeared at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel in New York to address the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner, a generally lighthearted annual event hosted by the New York Archdiocese that raises money for medical causes. Smith was a Democrat who ran, unsuccessfully, for president in 1928 as the first Catholic major-party nominee.

McCain joked to the dinner attendees that he had replaced his entire team of senior advisers with a man named "Joe the Plumber." Obama said there was no other crowd in America he would rather be "palling around with right now."

Polls show McCain trailing nationally and in Pennsylvania, the only state the Democrats won four years ago in which he and the Republican Party appear to be waging a full-fledged campaign.

Some analysts look at the Pennsylvania numbers - Obama leads by an average of 13 percentage points - and wonder how long McCain, who has visited the state three times in the last nine days, will keep pouring his limited resources into the battle.

There are no signs of retreat. Tomorrow, Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin will be in Lancaster while McCain's wife, Cindy, visits Wilkes-Barre.

"Nothing is inevitable here," McCain told the crowd in Downingtown. "We never give up."

Brian Wadiak, 31, a stay-at-home father from Exton, wasn't feeling too optimistic.

"Pennsylvania might be almost impossible; he's definitely the underdog," Wadiak said. "But I always like the candidate who talks about lower taxes and smaller government. And I don't trust Obama, both because of his past associations and his views. I think he's a huge liberal."

Obama, at his rally in Londonderry, N.H., had two prime goals in mind.

One was to reinforce, once again, the link between McCain and President Bush, which is the topic of a new Obama campaign ad. 

"I'm not running against George Bush," Obama acknowledged yesterday in response to McCain's comments during the debate. "I'm running against all those policies of George Bush that you support, Sen. McCain."

The other was to battle complacency among his supporters.

"We are 19 days away from changing this country. Nineteen days," Obama said. "But for those who are getting a little cocky, I've got two words for you: New Hampshire. I learned right here, with the help of my great friend and supporter Hillary Clinton, that you can't let up or pay too much attention to the polls."

Today and tomorrow, Obama is to campaign in Virginia, Missouri and North Carolina, states once assumed to be safely in the Republican column. Obama leads in Virginia; Missouri and North Carolina are close.

The fact that he is spending time in those places implies that his strategists believe a decisive, national victory for Obama is a realistic possibility - and that they have the money to try to make it happen.

His campaign also is reportedly launching a television campaign in West Virginia, which Bush won handily in 2004 and where Obama was beaten badly in the primaries.

McCain's next stops are in Florida, Virginia and Ohio, all states the Republicans won last time around.

Finally, a Visit to Letterman

John McCain, on CBS's Late Show With David Letterman last night, told the host "I screwed up" by canceling an earlier appearance on the show, then faced a sharp round of questioning about Sarah Palin and his campaign tactics.

"Can you stay?" Letterman asked after McCain sat down. "Depends on how bad it gets," McCain said.

Letterman seemed to ridicule McCain about the implication that Barack Obama and former radical activist William Ayers had a relationship. "Are they double-dating? Are they going to dinner? What are they doing?" he asked.

"Maybe going to Denny's," McCain replied.

Letterman had kept up a relentless comic assault

on McCain ever since the GOP nominee canceled his Sept. 24 Late Show appearance, saying he had to deal with the economy.

McCain rented a helicopter to fly to New York in time for yesterday's show after a weather delay grounded his plane in Philadelphia.

- Associated Press

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.

This article includes information from the Associated Press.

86 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


October 17, 2008 Friday
FINAL Edition


Clout: ACORN says it falls far from the fraud


SECTION: LOCAL; P-com Biggie News Update; Pg. 08


LENGTH: 943 words


PHILADELPHIA IS smack in the middle of what presidential candidate John McCain calls "one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country, maybe destroying the fabric of democracy."

Or maybe not.

McCain's dramatic charge came midway through Wednesday night's debate with Barack Obama. The Republican was referring to ACORN, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, which has been running massive voter-registration drives across the country.

In Philadelphia, ACORN has registered thousands of new voters - 78,376 applications here in just the past six months, according to Tim Dowling, a veteran in the City Commissioners Office.

The number includes thousands of applications for voters who already are registered, living in the suburbs or other states, or too young to vote. And there are hundreds that are missing some essentials - home addresses, dates of birth, or the voter signature that's supposed to help identify voters when they go to the polls.

McCain's charge was based on a relatively small number of cases, here and in other cities, where officials suspect that some ACORN workers intentionally submitted bogus voter applications, making up names and addresses or copying material from phone books. Deputy City Commissioner Fred Voigt said he'd sent about 1,500 suspicious-looking applications - about 2 percent of ACORN's submissions - to federal prosecutors.

ACORN organizers say that they flagged many of these forms themselves and fired any workers who were implicated in submitting bogus applications.

"Every person we register, we have a quality-control staff that calls that person three times to verify the information," said Ali Kronley, head organizer of Pennsylvania ACORN. "If we can't verify, or believe there is a problem, we flag it and we put the form in a separate batch that we call 'suspicious.' But we're required to turn in every card we get, even if it's 'Mickey Mouse.' . . . Occasionally we do have a problem with an employee. But they're not trying to commit voter fraud, they're trying to get paid for work they didn't do."

Greetings from Vegas

Democratic State Committee has printed 15,000 copies of what purports to be an oversized postcard from state Rep. John Perzel, sending his greetings from Las Vegas.

It's a bid to publicize a series of Vegas trips financed by payday-loan companies and Perzel's own campaign treasury, disclosed in Perzel's finance reports.

"You're not going to believe this, but I'm here in Las Vegas with my lobbyist buddies for the fifth time!" says the faux postcard. "Nothing beats living high on the hog in Harrisburg and then getting to blow off some steam in Vegas - on their dime. What a ride!"

Perzel's spokesman, Marty O'Rourke, had nothing to say about the gag.

Palin puckers in Delco

When John McCain and Sarah Palin visited Media last month for a rally at the Delaware County courthouse, the Alaska governor left something behind for GOP congressional candidate Craig Williams: a radio spot.

Williams, a former federal prosecutor, attended high school in Anchorage, and his brother Scott was one of Palin's speechwriters. He says he's the only congressional candidate whom Palin has blessed with a personal campaign ad.

"The only thing that separates me from Craig Williams on reforming Washington is, well, lipstick," Palin says in the one-minute spot, which debuted this week.

Williams, a veteran of the first Gulf War in the early 1990s, is facing Democratic U.S. Rep. Joe Sestak, a retired admiral who knocked off 10-term Republican Curt Weldon in 2006.

This week, Sestak's campaign sent out a breathless fundraising appeal, worrying that the Palin ad could be a "game changer."

Campaign-finance reports show that the congressman already had $3.2 million cash on hand at the end of last month, compared with Williams' $263,000.

Veteran ward leader steps downCongratulations to former state Rep. Norman Berson, who has survived 36 years as Democratic leader of Center City's 8th Ward and is giving up his post the day after next month's election. "The job requires a certain amount of physical energy, and the years are catching up with me," said Berson, who turns 82 next month.

Berson became a ward leader in 1972, as Frank Rizzo took office as mayor and fought for several years to take control of the Democratic Party machinery. Rizzo never managed to control Berson or his wife, Lenore, who were among the leaders of the Stop Rizzo movement that blocked Rizzo's bid for a third term.

Michael Stack Sr., who'd spent 37 years as Democratic leader of the Northeast's 58th Ward, gave up his post last year to his son, state Sen. Michael Stack Jr. That leaves state Rep. Frank Oliver as the party's senior ward leader, 38 years and counting.

Obama wins a lawn sign

A Clout confederate spotted an Obama lawn sign at the Mount Airy home of Sam Katz, who has run for mayor three times and governor once, always as a Republican.

"We have six voters in the house, a lot of points of view," Katz said yesterday, seeming to ponder how much candor to include in his explanation.

"In all honesty, it will probably be a unanimous vote in the Katz household . . . I was undecided and wanted to stay undecided. But the collapse of the economy and McCain's performance through that process pushed me a little bit over the other side. I tell people I don't think Obama's ready to be president and I don't think McCain should be. But I always try to vote for the guy I think will do the best job." *

Staff writers Bob Warner and Bill Bender contributed to this report.

Have a news tip? Gossip? Suggestion? Contact Bob Warner at warnerb@phillynews.com, call 215-854-5885, or fax 215-854-5910.
