Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 28, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


GOP SOCIALISM


BYLINE: J.W. SMERSKY West Newton


SECTION: EDITORIAL; ISSUE ONE; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 64 words


Hallelujah! President Bush and his "compassionate conservatives" in Washington have a solution to all of Wall Street's woes. Whenever a large corporation is in self-caused financial trouble, the federal government will buy it! Forget "Obama and his liberal allies" (as the McCain campaign ad labels them) -- the Republicans will lead us into socialism long before the November elections!


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: WALL STREET BAILOUT


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



169 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 28, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


THE AYERS CONNECTION;
OBAMA IS HIDINGHIS CLOSE RELATIONSHIP WITH A '60S RADICAL


BYLINE: Jack Kelly


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 742 words


It's hard to put out a fire by pouring gasoline on it, so many are amazed the Obama campaign is employing this technique.

The fire that Sen. Barack Obama wants to douse was small until his aides arrived with gas cans. For months, conservatives have been trying to direct attention to the relationship between Mr. Obama and William Ayers.

Mr. Ayers was a leader of the Weather Underground, which planted bombs in the U.S. Capitol and the Pentagon during the Vietnam War. He went on the lam after a nail bomb his group was building to kill soldiers and their wives at a dance at Fort Dix went off prematurely, killing three of the conspirators.

Mr. Ayers was never prosecuted because of FBI misconduct. He became a professor of education at the University of Illinois-Chicago.

"I don't regret setting bombs," Mr. Ayers told the New York Times in an interview published on 9/11. "I feel we didn't do enough."

When asked about Mr. Ayers during a Democratic debate in Philadelphia, Mr. Obama responded: "This is a guy who lives in my neighborhood, who's a professor of English (sic) in Chicago, who I know and who I have not received some official endorsement from. He's not somebody I exchange ideas from on a regular basis."

This was disingenuous. When Barack Obama ran for the Illinois Senate, the first fund-raiser for him was held in Mr. Ayers' living room. They served together on the board of the Woods Charitable Trust and on the Chicago Annenberg Challenge. Mr. Ayers was a founder of the challenge, co-chaired its principal operational arm and may have helped pick Mr. Obama as the organization's board chairman in 1995.

The Chicago Annenberg Challenge spent $110 million between 1995 and 2001 to promote "radical" school reform. A report issued by University of Chicago researchers in 2003 indicated that it had no impact on improving the education of school children. It was more successful in providing lucrative employment to otherwise unemployable radicals.

As board chairman, Mr. Obama's principal job was to monitor how CAC funds were spent. Since this was the only significant managerial responsibility Mr. Obama has ever had, one would think journalists would be more curious about how he performed it. But journalists have been remarkably incurious about anything that may reflect poorly on The One.

Since Mr. Obama and his aides are aware of this incuriosity, their nuclear response to the efforts of an independent group to call attention to the Obama-Ayers relationship is puzzling.

An ad on the relationship produced by the American Issues Project likely would have been ignored by the news media if the Obama campaign hadn't rushed out an ad in response and asked the Justice Department to investigate whether the project had violated campaign finance laws. (The Justice Department refused.)

The Obama ad falsely linked the American Issues Project ad to the McCain campaign.

"With all our problems, why is John McCain talking about the 1960s, trying to link Barack Obama to radical Bill Ayers?" the Obama ad says. "McCain knows Obama denounced Ayers' crimes, committed when Obama was just eight years old."

Would you excuse a friendship with a Nazi war criminal on the grounds his crimes were committed before you were born? Many Americans feel the same about maintaining a friendship with an unrepentant domestic terrorist.

Because of the Obama campaign's aggressive response, it's now difficult for the news media to ignore the relationship. Why would the Obama campaign do something that seems so stupid?

Stanley Kurtz of the Ethics and Public Policy Center discovered that 132 boxes of CAC records had been donated to the library at the University of Illinois-Chicago. He was going to review them until a library official told him he couldn't. After the library was forcefully reminded it's against the law to deny access to the files, they were made available.

The Obama campaign described Mr. Kurtz, a mild-mannered academic, as "a slimy character assassin," but was unable to point to anything Mr. Kurtz has said that is untrue.

When Mr. Kurtz appeared on a Chicago radio station, the Obama campaign declined an opportunity to have a spokesman appear with him. Instead, the campaign urged Obama supporters to barrage the program with complaints. The Los Angeles Times described this as "a surprising attempt to stifle broadcast criticism of its candidate."

I don't know what's in those files, but the Obama campaign doesn't want us to find out.


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Jack Kelly is a columnist for the Post-Gazette (jkelly@post-gazette.com, 412 263-1476).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



170 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 28, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


BYLINE: Compiled by Greg Victor.


SECTION: EDITORIAL; CUTTING EDGE NEW IDEAS SHARP OPINIONS; Pg. G-4


LENGTH: 679 words


O'Neill speaks

Former Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill told ABC News that President Bush seems out his depth in handling the financial meltdown: "I don't think he understands or knows much about any of this and it shows."

Mr. O'Neill also said that neither Mr. Bush nor John McCain nor Barack Obama has handled the crisis well. He thinks bailout negotiations got bogged down in side issues -- such as executive pay -- and ought to have focused on providing government insurance for bad mortgages instead of having the government purchase them. As for the cause of the mess:

"We suspended disbelief and said we can take people with no known source of income or wealth generation and we can give them a $500,000 mortgage. ... When you violate fundamental principles of economics you can get away with it for a while, but eventually it's going to get you."

(abcnews.com)

Blogus interruptess

The Angry Drunk Bureaucrat took a break on Wednesday:

"I would like to announce at this time that I am suspending this blog so that I can concentrate on the ongoing financial crisis that has gripped this nation.

"Thank you and God bless America."

Like John McCain, he returned to the fray on Friday.

(angrydrunkbureaucrat.blogspot.com)

Pouncing on Palin

Bloggers are all over Sarah Palin's interview with Katie Couric. John McIntire spoofs Ms. Palin's explanation as to why living near Russia gives her foreign-policy credibility. First, Ms. Palin:

We have trade missions back and forth, we do. It's very important when you consider even national-security issues with Russia. As Putin rears his head and comes into the air space of the United States of America, where do they go? It's Alaska. It's just right over the border. It is from Alaska that we send those out to make sure that an eye is being kept on this very powerful nation, Russia, because they are right next to, they are right next to our state.

Mr. McIntire's version:

Where do they go? Those Rooskies? They go over my land and stuff. Sometimes we send those out to spy on those foreign folk. Sometimes those have to be sent. You know. The White House depends on me to keep an eye on that big land mass over there and everything. And stuff. 'Cause you know ... it's next to our state. Like, right next door and everything.

(macyapper.blogspot.com)

Alaska as welfare queen

Then there's this from David Morris at Alternet: "[Sarah] Palin might be campaigning on an anti-government, do-it-yourself platform, but her state is the most dependent on the federal government of all 50 states. Washington sends Alaska more money per capita than any other state. Alaskans receive back from the federal government almost $2 for every $1 they send to Washington. It's a sweet deal."

Syonara Seagate

414 Grant Street laments the pending departure from the Strip of the computer hard drive giant: "Seagate Technologies abandoning Pittsburgh and the brand new building they just built is bad news for Pittsburgh. Just a few years ago Pittsburgh was on a hot streak of attracting new, cool tech companies ... FreeMarkets, Seagate, etc ... It's been at least 2 years ... Maybe this is what happens when you politicize your economic development agency?

(414grantstreet.blogspot.com)

Checking facts

This is a plug for the Truth-O-Meter and Flip-O-Meter at PolitiFact.Com.

The Truth-O-Meter measures the veracity of claims made by the presidential candidates, their surrogates and independent groups, rating them from true, to barely true, to false, to pants on fire (as in liar, liar). For instance, barely true: John McCain opposed an Obama bill aimed at limited executive pay. Pants on fire: The NRA's ad claiming that Barack Obama wants to prevent homeowners from buying guns to protect themselves.

The Flip-O-Meter measures flip-flops, ranging from no flip, to half flip, to full flop. It gives a full flop to Sarah Palin for supporting the Bridge to Nowhere as a candidate and opposing it as governor. Mr. Obama got a full flop on tapping the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

(politifact.com)

Perhaps the gold standard of political fact-checkersm, though, is factcheck.org


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



171 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 28, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


DOES ROCKERS' SUPPORT COUNT AT THE VOTING BOOTH?


BYLINE: Scott Mervis, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: ARTS AND ENTERTAINMENT; Pg. E-1


LENGTH: 1218 words


As the candidates make a last dash toward the White House, there's one question that is not ringing out across America: "Are you going to the Rock for McCain concert?"

While the polls reveal a tight race with the voting public, Sen. Barack Obama has the liberal pop music world in the tank.

But that's hardly a break from tradition. Right on course, the sound of the Republican campaign is country stars such as John Rich and LeAnn Rimes spiriting a message of down-home values. Meanwhile, Obama is not only inspiring a reunion of the Grateful Dead, he's actually the first presidential candidate with a CD soundtrack, "Yes We Can: Voices of a Grassroots Movement," featuring the likes of Kanye West, John Mayer and John Legend.

"The campaign's use of music is another example of the 'enthusiasm gap' between the Obama and McCain campaigns," said Obama spokesperson Allison Price. "Sen. Obama's events, from small community gatherings to larger town halls and rallies, are pulsing with enthusiasm, and that is reflected in the campaign's choice of music."

Fortunately for Republicans, if pop stars could make or break a campaign, George W. Bush never would have survived the Vote for Change concerts, the Dixie Chicks and the Rock Against Bush tours in 2004.

Nonetheless, with Obama sporting a rock-star appeal John Kerry never mustered, Democrats and their supporters clearly think musicians can rock the base.

Locally, Rock for Obama concerts have been popping up. On Saturday, the Democrats will target the Carnegie Mellon campus with a voter registration drive headlined by Vampire Weekend, one of the year's hottest new bands. "We support Barack Obama because on every issue we care about he is more logical, sensitive and unbiased than John McCain," the band told the Post-Gazette in a statement. Thousands of first-time voters will likely be lured by the Afro-pop and then leave with the impression that Obama is cooler.

Nine days later, on Oct. 13, the living members of the Dead will reunite for Deadheads for Obama at State College. Meanwhile, Carole King, not one of the hottest acts of the year, is on an Obama conversation tour in the swing state of Ohio.

Price says Obama uses music as a tool to "attract more people to this campaign that might not have tuned in to the issues yet." In May, the Illinois senator drew an estimated 75,000 to a rally in Portland, Ore., prompting conservative Web sites such as The National Review to wonder why it wasn't mentioned in the liberal media that the rally was preceded by a popular hometown band -- The Decemberists.

Obama rallies are rocking with Bruce Springsteen's "The Rising," Stevie Wonder's "Signed, Sealed, Delivered," Jackie Wilson's "Higher and Higher" and Earth, Wind and Fire's "Shining Star," among others.

Musical support has been tougher for the Republicans, so McCain can be awfully grateful to Rich, who wrote him a tribute song called "Raising McCain." Rich jammed at the Republican Convention, along with Rimes, the Charlie Daniels Band, Joe Nichols, Clay Walker and the Bellamy Brothers.

When McCain running mate Gov. Sarah Palin had a whirlwind of meetings with world leaders at the United Nations, much was made of U2's Bono being on her dance card. Bono, a noted activist for global causes, doesn't play partisan politics.

As for recorded music, McCain's daughter Meghan has a blog where she posts playlists filled with everything from cool-trendy bands like Wolf Parade and, yes, Vampire Weekend, to classic artists Dylan and Joni Mitchell. Not that her father's campaign would or could use much of that, not with all the left-leaning artists who have just said no:

* In February, John Mellencamp asked the McCain people to stop using "Our Country" and "Little Pink Houses," songs with obvious heartland appeal.

* Last month, Jackson Browne filed a lawsuit against Republicans in Ohio for use of his 1997 hit "Running on Empty" in an ad attacking Obama's energy policy. Browne's lawyer said its use was "entirely reprehensible."

* Heart sent a cease-and-desist order to Republicans after their song "Barracuda" was played at the convention in honor of Sarah "Barracuda" Palin. When Republicans continued to use it, co-writer Roger Fisher said, OK, he would donate royalties to the Obama campaign.

McCain spokesman Paul Lindsay declined to offer a playlist from the campaign but said, "Music plays an important role in motivating the audience, but the record crowds are an indication of the growing excitement and enthusiasm for John McCain and Sarah Palin. We appreciate supporters who take time out of their day to come to these events, so we make every effort to provide an entertaining and family-friendly environment."

There are rockers who lean right, but they tend to be problematic. There's not much you can do on the campaign trail with Ted Nugent and Alice Cooper, unless they can figure out how to use "Cat Scratch Fever" or "I'm Eighteen." While "I'm 18 and I don't know what I want" might actually speak to the zeitgeist, it doesn't exactly uplift a crowd. As for conservatives Jessica Simpson and Britney Spears -- not exactly the philosopher-poets of pop music.

How much does the musical imbalance weigh on the election? Kevin Madden, a Republican strategist, says: not much.

"I'm a fan of Springsteen's music. I also have Pearl Jam on my iPod. Both are big supporters of Democrats and liberal causes, and yet I keep listening to them because, like most people, I separate my music and my politics. When the data breakdowns arrive after every campaign is over, the empirical evidence proves that voters are motivated by how the candidates talked about the issues affecting them, rather than the endorsements they received."

Despite the "rock" in the name, one group that doesn't take sides is Rock the Vote. It asks its performers on its tour to limit their comments to the importance of voting.

Heather Smith, executive director of Rock the Vote, thinks musicians do have an influence on young voters.

"The artists pique their interests," she says. "Sure, they look at what groups support what candidates, but in the end I think they make up their own mind."

As this campaign has heated up, there's been one firecracker not going off: the war of words between the Dixie Chicks and Toby Keith. Not this time. Keith, who wrote the post-9/11 revenge anthem "Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue," is actually a lifelong Democrat, but after supporting Bush, he's said nice things about Obama. For now, he's keeping his choice to himself.

"I don't think anyone should listen to what stupid celebrities say," Keith told the PG. "If someone endorsing someone is going to change the way you vote, then you're not taking advantage of your American right here."

Kid Rock, who leans Republican, agrees: "I truly believe that people like myself, who are in a position of entertainers in the limelight, should keep their mouth shut on politics."

One funny thing is happening on the way to the White House: Obama and McCain are trying to win votes with the same song -- Brooks & Dunn's "Only in America."

It's been a Republican anthem since 2000, but the country duo is letting Obama slide on it. Although the performers back McCain, the song's co-writer Don Cook happens to be a founder of an organization in Nashville -- it's called Music Row Democrats.


LOAD-DATE: October 1, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Scott Mervis can be reached at smervis@post-gazette.com or 412-263-2576. Read his blog, Pop Noise, at http://community.post-gazette.com/blogs/popnoise.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: LeAnn Rimes
PHOTO: Kanye West


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



172 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 28, 2008 Sunday
TWO STAR EDITION


DEBATE'S RESULTS DEBATABLE;
BOTH SIDES CLAIM VICTORY; PUNDITS' CONSENSUS IS THE SCORE IS STILL TIED


BYLINE: Mackenzie Carpenter, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-9


LENGTH: 1096 words


Minutes after Friday night's presidential debate ended, the McCain campaign had posted a video on YouTube.com enumerating the times Sen. Barack Obama noted that Sen. John McCain was "right" about something -- seven.

At 8 a.m. the next morning, the Obama campaign unveiled its own new ad: "Zero" -- the number of times Mr. McCain mentioned "the middle class" during the 90-minute matchup at the University of Mississippi.

Both campaigns scrambled this weekend to score political points after a debate that was full of substance and evasion, fumbling and occasional zingers -- but one, most pundits agreed, that lacked the crucial breakout moment needed to shake up a neck-and-neck race.

"There were no defining moments, no gotcha moments, no moments at all that could have moved things off script -- which means we still have a very close, competitive race that could be won by either candidate," said Terry Madonna, a political science professor and pollster at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster.

Based on his own polling and other surveys, Mr. Madonna said, "About 15 percent of the voters remain genuinely in play and I don't think last night moved very many of them."

Nonetheless, in what has become a predictable post-debate ritual, both campaigns deluged reporters yesterday with cherry-picked "reviews" from television analysts and newspaper editorial boards declaring their candidate the winner.

Those efforts to massage public perception and jolt the campaign out of its stasis has taken on particular urgency this year, given the closeness of the race and the fact that the actual pool of undecided voters is much smaller than many polls reveal, said Jeff Berry, a professor of political science at Tufts University.

"When pollsters push too hard, sometimes people say they're undecided when they really aren't," he said. Given this race's uncertainty, there may be a lot of that going on.

Still, while there may not be many wavering voters left, "the public clearly regards Sen. Obama as the winner," he said, noting that a series of instant polls -- by CNN, CBS, plus focus groups on Fox News and by Republican pollster Frank Luntz -- consistently gave the edge to Mr. Obama.

While the particulars of the debate itself may soon fade from public consciousness, "Mr. Obama achieved the one thing he had to do, which was convince viewers that he would be at least an adequate commander-in-chief," he added.

"And with Obama leading narrowly in national polls up until Friday, McCain now has to figure out how to take that lead away from him."

Of course, that's just one political scientist's perception. While Mr. Obama may have come out ahead simply by holding his own, said Ken Heineman, a political science professor at Ohio University, Mr. McCain won the expectations game -- an important plus, given that he had been in danger of losing it during last week's chaotic events on Wall Street and in Washington.

"He wasn't tired or grumpy, but conversational, smiling, and kept emphasizing his experience in bipartisanship, which was an effective play for independents," said Mr. Heineman.

Both candidates made strong points on foreign policy, and Mr. McCain skillfully focused on taxes and spending cuts rather than on the Wall Street financial crisis, he said, while Mr. Obama "should have scored a knockout on the economy, which is such a 'gimme' issue, and he didn't."

"I'd say McCain won on the margins, but he didn't stage a knockout punch," Mr. Heineman added.

Mr. McCain planned to remain in Washington over the weekend to work on the financial bailout bill, his campaign said.

Mr. Obama, on the other hand, hit the campaign trail, hammering away at his opponent's debate performance.

"The truth is, through 90 minutes of debating, John McCain had a lot to say about me, but he had nothing to say about you. He didn't even say the words 'middle class.' Not once," Mr. Obama told a crowd in Greensboro, N.C.

At the same time, David Plouffe, Mr. Obama's campaign manager, was busy lowering expectations for the next few debates. Republican vice presidential nominee Gov. Sarah Palin -- who faces Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. Thursday -- is "a gifted debater," he told reporters in a conference call, while Mr. Obama will also be "the decided underdog" in a town hall meeting Oct. 7 in Nashville.

"[John McCain] is the undisputed town hall champion, and he's done more of them than any president in history," Mr. Plouffe said, adding that he would be "thrilled," if Mr. Obama can "escape unscathed."

He also conceded, though, that these debates may not produce much movement in the polls in the near future. While voters are now becoming very focused, many "may wait until even after the third debate to make their decision," Mr. Plouffe said. "But for those who do, we're confident we put more in our column than in John McCain's."

Tucker Bounds, a spokesman for the McCain campaign, said Mr. Obama failed a key test: showing voters he was capable of being commander-in-chief -- because he "failed to utter the word 'victory' a single time" during the debate.

"Despite that fact, his campaign launched a mad-dash of damage-control this morning attempting to claim a debate 'victory' for Barack Obama when he was clearly struggling to defend his record of lavish new government spending, higher taxes and failed foreign policy judgment."

In the end, this fixation on how many words were uttered -- or not uttered -- by either candidate, not to mention the emphasis on who "won" or who "lost," may be for naught.

Some debates produce ineffable moments that resonate with the public and, ultimately, define the candidate -- from Vice President Al Gore's condescending sighs in 2000 to then Gov. Ronald Reagan's head-shaking, mock-regretful "There you go again" in 1980. But it's important to remember that Sen. John F. Kerry "won" at least two out of three debates in 2004 with President Bush -- and then lost the election.

"Kerry came across as a technician, while Bush came across as a regular guy, and people identified with him," said Mr. Madonna. "On that score, I'd say that McCain did a much better job connecting with the voters, while on debate points, Obama won."

Nonetheless, he added, "by next week we may have completely forgotten all about this."

"To a limited extent I don't know if debates ever change anyone's minds," added Gerald Shuster, a professor of political communication at the University of Pittsburgh's Department of Communications. "They tend to reinforce perceptions of one's own candidate. If you already like one, chances are you'll think he did a great job."


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Mackenzie Carpenter can be reached at mcarpenter@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1949.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



173 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 27, 2008 Saturday


Cranking Up Biden Gaffe Machine


BYLINE: Editorial


SECTION: A; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 594 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


The line on the upcoming vice-presidential debate in St. Louis: a young governor unaccustomed to the ways of Washington and the world against a 35-year senator so respected on the world stage that he was called to help Georgia when Russia attacked the former Soviet republic early last month.

Based on such calculus, one would expect Joe Biden, the veteran Democratic senator from Delaware, to handily defeat Sarah Palin, the two-year Republican governor from Alaska.

That is as long as Biden doesn't ... shoot too much from the hip ... say something insensitive that offends Palin's female fans or women in general ... fumble facts ... contradict Democratic nominee Barack Obama's position on an issue ... or invent some new verbal gaffe.

In other words, Biden looks to be a strong debater, if he can just avoid being his usual self.

His biggest recent head-scratching error came earlier this week on the "CBS Evening News."

"When the stock market crashed, Franklin D. Roosevelt got on the television and didn't just talk about the, you know, the princes of greed. He said, 'Look, here's what happened,'" Biden told news anchor Katie Couric.

Good point, senator, except that Herbert Hoover was president when the stock market crashed in October 1929. FDR took office in 1933. And Americans didn't have TVs in their homes back then, anyway.

The gaffes just keep on coming.

On a rope line in Ohio this week, a woman asked him why he and Obama support "clean coal" technology.

"We're not supporting clean coal," Biden replied, putting his hands on the questioner's shoulders. "Guess what? China's building two every week, two dirty coal plants, and it's polluting the United States. It's causing people to die."

Later in the exchange, he said: "No coal plants here in America. Build them, if they're going to build them, over there (in China). Make them clean, because they're killing you."

That might be good Democratic politics, looking pro-environment and all that.

But check his running mate's energy policy.

Under "New Energy for America," barackobama.com says: "Obama's Department of Energy will enter into public-private partnerships to develop five 'first-of-a-kind' commercial scale coal-fired plants with clean carbon capture and sequestration technology."

Biden was back on message Thursday in Wilkes-Barre, saying, "I am for clean coal."

Then comes the best part. A Biden spokesman denies the obvious contradiction.

In Ohio, you see, Biden was trying to convey that "even if we stopped investing in clean coal tomorrow, the reality is China is building dirty coal-fired power plants, which contributes to global warming," spokesman David Wade explained.

Got that? No, neither did we.

Biden also jumped ahead of Obama on Sept. 16, telling NBC News that "I don't think (AIG) should be bailed out by the federal government."

A week later, speaking on the same network, Obama was asked why he had criticized GOP nominee John McCain for opposing the government's bailout of the insurance giant when Biden had, too.

"I think ... that in that situation, I think Joe should have waited, as well," Obama said.

Unfortunately for Obama, that situation, and ones similarly embarrassing, are a Biden staple.

If Biden commits a gaffe in his debate with Palin on Thursday, Obama will no doubt agree with a recent comment the Delaware senator made to a Hillary Clinton critic during a town-hall meeting in Nashua, N.H.

"She's easily qualified to be vice president ... and quite frankly, might have been a better pick than me," Biden said.

Indeed. Palin's chances are looking better all the time.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



174 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 27, 2008 Saturday


Cranking Up Biden Gaffe Machine


BYLINE: Editorial


SECTION: A; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 594 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA

Biden was back on message Thursday in Wilkes-Barre, saying, "I am for clean coal."

"She's easily qualified to be vice president ... and quite frankly, might have been a better pick than me," Biden said.

Indeed. Palin's chances are looking better all the time.


LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



175 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 27, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


THE MCCAIN I KNOW;
HE'S A SERIOUS LEADER, NOT THE CAMPAIGN CARICATURE


BYLINE: David Brooks


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. B-7


LENGTH: 749 words


I've been covering John McCain for a decade. A few years ago, I worked on a book, which I foolishly never completed, on the U.S. Senate with Mr. McCain as the central character. So when I step back and think of Mr. McCain, even in the heat of this campaign, I still think of him first in the real world of governing, not in the show-business world of the election.

I think first of the personal qualities. He was unfailingly candid. When other politicians described a meeting, they always ended up the heroes of the story. But Mr. McCain would always describe the meeting straight, emphasizing his own failings.

He is, for a politician, a humble man. The most important legacy of his prisoner-of-war days is that he witnessed others behaving more heroically than he did. This experience has given him a basic honesty when appraising himself.

His mood darkened as the Iraq war deteriorated, but his accomplishments mounted. I don't think any senator had as impressive a few years as Mr. McCain did during this span of time.

He lobbied relentlessly for a change of strategy in Iraq, holding off the tide that would have had us accept defeat and leave Iraq to its genocide. He negotiated a complicated immigration bill with Ted Kennedy. He helped organize the Gang of 14 to save the Senate from polarized Armageddon over judicial nominations. He voted against opportunist bills like the pork-laden energy package and the prescription drug plan. He led a crusade against Jack Abramoff and the sleaze-meisters in his own party.

I could fill this column with his accomplishments during this period, and not even mention the insights. At a defense conference in Munich, I saw him diagnose and confront Russian hegemony. Week after week, I saw him dissent from GOP colleagues as their party lost its way.

Some people who cover the campaign seem to have no knowledge of anything but the campaign, but I can't get these events -- which were real and required the constant application of judgment, honor and courage -- out of my head.

Do I wish he was running a different campaign? Yes.

It's not that he has changed his political personality that bothers me. I've come to accept that in this media-circus environment, you simply cannot run for president as a candid, normal person. Nor is it, primarily, the dishonest ads he is running. My friends in the Obama cheering section get huffy about them, while filtering from their consciousness all the dishonest ads Sen. Barack Obama has run -- the demagogic DHL ad, the insulting computer ad, the cynical Rush Limbaugh ad. If one candidate has sunk lower than the other at this point, I've lost track.

No, what disappoints me about the McCain campaign is it has no central argument. I had hoped that he would create a grand narrative explaining how the United States is fundamentally unprepared for the 21st century and how Mr. McCain's worldview is different.

Mr. McCain has not made that argument, so his proposals don't add up to more than the sum of their parts. Without a groundbreaking argument about why he is different, he's had to rely on tactical gimmicks to stay afloat. He has no frame to organize his response when financial and other crises pop up.

Mr. McCain has no overarching argument in part because of his Senate training and the tendency to take issues on one at a time and in part because he has never really resolved the contradiction between the Barry Goldwater and Teddy Roosevelt sides of his worldview. One day he's a small-government Western conservative; the next he's a Bull Moose progressive. The two don't add up -- as we've seen in his uneven reaction to the financial crisis.

Nonetheless, when people try to tell me that the McCain on the campaign trail is the real McCain and the one who came before was fake, I just say, baloney. I saw him. A half-century of evidence is there.

If Mr. McCain is elected, he will retain his instinct for the hard challenge. With that Greatest Generation style of his, he will run the least partisan administration in recent times. He is not a sophisticated conceptual thinker, but he is a good judge of character. He is not an organized administrator, but he has become a practiced legislative craftsman. He is, above all -- and this is completely impossible to convey in the midst of a campaign -- a serious man prone to serious things.

Amid the stupidity of this season, it seemed worth stepping back to recall the fundamentals -- about Mr. McCain today and Mr. Obama on some other day in the near future.


LOAD-DATE: September 30, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: David Brooks is a syndicated columnist for The New York Times. Paul Krugman's column for today on the financial bailout was overtaken by events.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



176 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)


September 26, 2008 Friday


Face off about issues of poverty


BYLINE: Editor: Lebanon Daily News


SECTION: LETTERS TO EDITOR


LENGTH: 149 words


Sens. John McCain and Barack Obama are about to face off in the presidential debates, with media pundits focused more on possible gaffes than on good policy. I am tired of all the polarized political commercials and want answers to real issues.

I want to hear just one question about what each candidate would do to address extreme poverty around the world. More specifically, as a mother I want to know what the U.S. will do to lift up people who are hungry, who are drinking filthy water and suffering treatable, preventable diseases such as HIV/AIDS, malaria and even diarrhea.

As members of the ONE Campaign, many of us in Pennsylvania and across America are coming together to petition the moderator of the debate on foreign policy to ask this very important question. The debate is tonight. We hope the candidates address the issue of extreme poverty.

Melissa Sweeney

ONE Campaign Member

Jonestown


LOAD-DATE: September 26, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lebanon Daily News
All Rights Reserved



177 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


September 26, 2008 Friday
CITY-D Edition


The debate? Obama says yes; McCain is a maybe


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News for PC Home Page; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 731 words


The fate of this evening's presidential debate in Mississippi remained uncertain last night, with Republican John McCain saying he would not participate until a deal on a Wall Street plan was hashed out in Washington.

After a meeting at the White House, which he and Democrat Barack Obama attended, McCain said he was "very hopeful" an agreement could be worked out in time for the debate to proceed. But he made no commitment to attend.

Obama, who like McCain remained in Washington overnight, said that he planned to go to the Mississippi site regardless and that it was "important to have a debate."

The event - the first of three scheduled encounters between the major-party presidential candidates, and scheduled to begin at 9 p.m. - was supposed to be limited to issues of foreign policy and national security. But Obama said he expected that the financial crisis would be discussed.

At the debate site, on the University of Mississippi campus in Oxford, final preparations were proceeding yesterday despite the uncertainty. Officials of the university and the state of Mississippi have a lot at stake.

Although the debates are sponsored by the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates, the events themselves are financed largely by the universities and communities that win the right to host them.

The University of Mississippi, which has never hosted one before, had raised and spent about $5 million - much of it in private donations - to make the necessary preparations.

If and when the debate happens, it will set the stage for the final acts of the 2008 presidential race. And it could do a whole lot more.

History indicates that the first debate of a general election is the one most likely to affect public opinion, because the audience is usually the largest, and first impressions tend to be lasting.

Any shift in voter sentiment could prove significant in this close and historic race. At this point, Obama has opened up a modest lead in most national polls, in part because of the financial crisis.

Some analysts, though, expect undecided voters to wait until the final debate, scheduled for Oct. 15, before making up their minds.

"No event in a campaign focuses the minds of voters more than these debates," said Michael X. Delli Carpini, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. "When it comes to the lesser-known candidate, Sen. Obama, it's as much about the person as the issues."

According to the polls, voters see McCain as the more credible commander in chief, based in part on his years of experience in the military and the Senate. That, of course, figures into the expectations game for the foreign-policy debate and into the goals for both candidates.

Obama will be out to increase voters' comfort level with him and to make the case that his relative lack of experience in the national security arena will not hamper him in office.

"The expectations level for McCain has to be enormous, because national security is his campaign's reason for being," said Gov. Rendell, who is working for Democrat Obama. "If Sen. Obama shows he understands the issues, he wins the debate, regardless of what McCain does."

McCain wants to be seen as a hard-nosed realist whose command of world affairs makes him the better choice to protect the nation. If he can underline his differences with the Bush administration as well, so much the better for him.

"When the two candidates stand side by side, there'll be a decisive difference," Sen. Arlen Specter (R., Pa.) said earlier this week. "Sen. Obama is an able fellow, but he doesn't have John's experience and knowledge."

The big question last night was whether the two will be side by side before today is over. And if they don't meet tonight, how would that affect the rest of the schedule, which has the lone vice presidential debate up next on Oct. 2?

Meanwhile, the Obama campaign last night accused McCain of not really "suspending" his campaign in deference to the financial crisis, as he announced Wednesday he was going to do.

In a memo to reporters, Obama spokesman Bill Burton said that McCain aides were still attacking Obama on television and that some McCain commercials were still on the air.

McCain campaign officials said last night that all their commercials had been taken down.

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel

at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.

The Philadelphia Daily News


September 26, 2008 Friday
4STAR Edition


Online Letters: A very wrong move on casinos


BYLINE: byline w


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; P-com Opinion; Pg. MAIN03


LENGTH: 1595 words


ICAN'T believe the Foxwoods casino is moving to the Gallery.

Philadelphia is a place of history, especially Center City. A few blocks below the Gallery are the federal court house, the Constitution Center, Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell and many more landmarks. Our founding fathers certainly would not approve of a gambling Mecca so close to the sight of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

Also, there's talk of revitalizing the Gallery. Not many people frequent it due to the youths that continuously hang out there. An 84- year-old gentleman was assaulted and robbed there.

You want to revitalize the Gallery, how about having some security there and confronting the youth as to why they aren't in school, or why they are traveling in groups and not buying but antagonizing the shoppers who do frequent the Gallery.

Pat Walder, Philadelphia

Locating a casino in Chinatown is very bad, worse than the South Philadelphia site. Also, it's not true what the mayor and governor say about the taxes not neing used to repay Foxwoods for money they spent already. That is the joke of all jokes on the citizens of Philadelphia.

Domenick Lazarro Jr.

PhiladelphiaThey're lying

Almost every time John McCain and Sarah Palin open their mouths these days, they're lying. They say Barack Obama has never authored significant legislation - but check out his work on nuclear proliferation and government transparency

. They say Palin opposed the Bridge to Nowhere - but she campaigned in favor of it and even praised the strength of Alaska's corrupt congressional delegation. They say the economy is fundamentally sound - even as one financial institution after another collapses alongside home values.

Dave Thomer, Philadelphia

The sham war

Pardon my ignorance, but when did Iraq declare war on the United States? Why is it so important that we win a war where we don't know who the enemy is? Who are we fighting?

It seems to me the fight is between Shiite and Sunni.

I understand the fears of President Bush and Sen. McCain that if we don't pound somebody into the ground so that we can declare victory, we will lose face with the rest of the world and be considered weak. So we have to stay and rebuild their country and make them whole again, so we can save face at the cost of billions, which the president doesn't have to pay out of his own pocket.

Since he is president, let the American people pay the bill. Since the battle is not mine, it's the Lord's. I'll let Him handle it.

James W. Williams, Philadelphia

The 'racial litmus test'

Re Fatimah Ali's op-ed " 'Race War' in America":

The author's main qualification as a self-anointed expert on race relations is her color-blind upbringing in Mt. Airy.

And I quote:

"No, we're not anywhere near 'post-racial' times. If we were, the possibility that a black man may well become our next president wouldn't matter."

All evidence suggests that it doesn't matter. He won a major party's nomination for the office of president of the United States. But that apparently does not suffice as proof of our country approaching a place "anywhere near post-racial times."

Does the author recognize the ridiculousness of that statement? Liberals, black and white, in no uncertain terms, have decided that each vote in this election is a de facto "racist litmus test." Anyone who hasn't yet come to the obvious (in their minds) conclusion that Obama is our country's messiah, delivered to us in our hour of greatest need, is either racist or a fool, not sufficiently enlightened to even be entrusted with a vote in this election.

The author manages to lump all McCain supporters, as well as the undecideds who have not yet been willing to anoint Obama, in with the racists and radicals that responded to her column with invective. Many voters remain undecided. I was one of them until moments ago. At least Ms. Ali's column and its ill-considered opinion on race and this election was good for something.

George Nocito, Philadelphia

'Boondocks' Sarah

I cannot sit back any longer and hold inside my thoughts about John McCain's pick for a running mate, Sarah Palin.

How in the world did he find her? He must have gone to the "boondocks." How can people get excited about a person who talks too loudly, too much, and, says absolutely nothing? Except when she is trying to attack a man like Senator Barack Obama. Notice I said 'trying' to attack him.

Sarah Palin, just like McCain, has no clue what this election is truly about. It is about how the people, especially, the poor of this country have been suffering under George Bush for the last eight years. George Bush whom Senator McCain, out of his own mouth, voted with over ninety percent of the time.

I saw an old, white woman on the news the other day. On national television she had the audacity to say she wouldn't vote for Obama, "because I don't like his name". Talk about scary!

Charlotte J. Mears, Philadelphia

Electoral twilight zone

This will be the longest 40- something days of my mature life. After going through the worst seven something years under George W. Bush in my 60-something years, I shudder to think that there are folks out there who are actually enthusiastic about the Republican ticket.

McCain, who promises more of the same and is a known Bushie promises to shake up the Washington establishment after spending years in congress mostly going with the flow. He's known as a maverick yet voted with the administration 90 percent of the time.

His running mate was plucked from obscurity and her claim to fame is being a hockey mom, hunter and church lady. She's in the midst of trooper-gate and is being sheltered by McCain's handlers from serious discourse about global and domestic issues. One suspects that she doesn't have a clue. And this is a woman who is one heartbeat from a seventy something man who sometimes, in my opinion, displays symptoms of vertigo.

Am I crazy or, unknowingly, am I in the twilight zone?

Anthony J. Frascino, Cherry Hill, N.J.

Trusting the police

To those ignorant people who don't, or don't want to, trust the police:

People said they didn't trust cops who on the afternoon that Officer Patrick McDonald was slain first said they've kill him. They didn't consider that the criminal (and he had a list of convictions) had killed an officer who was there protecting them and was serving his city.

And then the father arrives and said "you might as well kill me too" (duh!). What kind of rationalization is this. And then someone said "he's a Muslim" which I assume made it OK to kill someone.

I don't condone killing of anyone, but the bum who fatally shot one officer and wound another got what he deservered.

As a former resident of Philadelphia and a police officer in that city for well over 20 years, one day the thugs will get it in their heads that a standoff with police offficers just won't get it.

Carl Branch, Cherry Hill

Ad-monition

So, John McCain feels like Barack Obama's campaign is "wasted pork" and will cause Americans to have to pay huge taxes on electricity and home heating oil.

Um, aren't we already paying exorbitant amounts of money for this stuff in the first place?

I love these political ads. It's like first-grade all over again. Funny, I was always taught not to rat anyone out or make fun of others. To see our possible leaders go back and forth and do this is kind of ironic.

Charlie Gagliardi, Philadelphia

Left out of the bailout

Isn't it incredible that the federal government (read: we the taxpayers) see fit to bail many high profile banks, brokerages and insurance companies out of their tough situations!

Many layoffs have occurred, but I'm willing to bet more lower income employees are let go, while the top dogs still get their bonuses, and multi-million dollar salaries!

But what about the poor folks that have had to declare bankruptcy, losing their homes and their savings due to the down sliding economy? Will our government come to their aid? Two chances of that ever happening! Slim and none! We're stuck with everything!

Ain't it just great?

William Palmer, Philadelphia

Right on, Christine!

I am the contact person for the Respect Life ministry of the parish of Christ the King in Hillside, N.J.

I read Christine Flowers' op-ed "Feminists Biggest Nightmare: Stepford Sarah" .

All I can say is: AMEN! Sarah Palin is indeed an embodiment of feminism correctly understood. Now when you think about it, the National Organization for Women members, for instance, should be trembling with excitement over her candidacy not only because, for the first time, a "sister" of theirs has a real chance of making it to the second-highest office in the land but also because she has it in her the true feminist ideals (a working woman who is able juggle successfully both career and family, and a woman public official who climbed her way up the political ladder through her very own merits, and not because she took the place of a husband or a father who predeceased her).

These past 25 years, when one speaks of "women's vote", it almost automatically means liberal, usually Democratic, women who are pro-abortion rights, pro-same sex unions, pro-condom distribution, and the like. Well, hello, there is another kind of "women's vote" out there who has always been here but is long ignor ed (purposely, I suspect) and just as significant and, dare I say, just as powerful: conservative, mostly religious, women who are pro-life, pro-traditional marriage, pro-premarital abstinence, and so on. ; Sara h Palin has ignited that other "powerhouse" so I can understand the trepidation of, say, NOW.

Apollo F. Salle, Hillside, N.J.

Public Opinion (Chambersburg, Pennsylvania)


September 25, 2008 Thursday


Letter to the editor: McCain to cut taxes, and that's enough


BYLINE: Public Opinion Online


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 310 words


I need to get a few things off my chest before it eats away at me.

Let's start with the Jim Taylor controversy. Mr. Taylor, like any other American, has a constitutional right to vote for who he wants. He didn't resign from his post of chairman of the Franklin County Republican Party when running for office because he wasn't sure that he was going to get elected.

He hasn't publicly endorsed Rich Alloway because maybe he is not going to vote for Rich Alloway. I don't know the circumstances, but I know that on Nov. 4 I'm voting for Jim Taylor.

Now, lets move on. I need to say that state Attorney General Tom Corbett is the first person in Pennsylvania to take a stand for our children. Because of Mr. Corbett's sincerity to protect our children, more predators and perverts are off our streets and in prison where they belong. Mr. Corbett, because of that, I will be voting for you in November and I hope to see you in the White House someday.

Now, Barack Obama has made another lie and doesn't even know that he did it. In a recent television ad by a company that endorsed Obama, they show him making a statement that his tax cuts would benefit the middle class three times as much as McCain's. The only problem with that ad is that Obama doesn't want to lower our taxes. He said that he will lower taxes on 95 percent of working Americans.

However, he also said that he will raise taxes on businesses and corporations.

My problem with that is that 99 percent of working Americans work for businesses or corporations, and those same companies will have to do something to pay their taxes.

I think that they will cut payroll! I don't know, I'm just taking a wild guess.

I don't know about you, but I don't want to take a 5 percent chance on tax cuts!

I will be voting for John McCain in November and I hope and pray that others will join me.

James Martin

Chambersburg

The Philadelphia Daily News


September 24, 2008 Wednesday

All about the campaign

RE CATHRYN Michon's hysterical, panicked op-ed, "Sarah: Fuggheddebout her":

Cathryn needs to sit down and take a deep breath as I explain something to her and all the other Obama fanatics who are living in "Denial, USA."

Sarah Palin is the governor of Alaska. She reformed Alaska's government and passed legislation that cut wasteful spending - in other words she has legislative experience.

Obama has no accomplishments, no bills, no legislation to attach to his name, unless you want to count his unwavering support of late-term abortions.

Here's a newsflash for Miss Michon - and Fatimah Ali, for that matter. Skin color counts for nothing in determining the worth of a human being, now or ever! My race is the human race, people.

Stuart Caesar, Philadelphia

Herb Stark, Massapequa, N.Y.

After watching the Obama ad showing McCain in the 1980s with a disco ball, I was wondering if there was a 1980s photo of Obama snorting cocaine and smoking pot, both of which he admits doing.

Keith Callan, Philadelphia

In his interview on "Candidates Forum on Service," Barack Obama spoke of the "sacred obligation" government has to those who help the country in times of war.

This reminded me of how President Bush initiated tax cuts for the rich even as he sent the country to war on a pack of lies.

If President Bush's spin on the horrors of Sept. 11 aren't grounds for high treason against our country, then perhaps they are merely the most perverted expression of anti-"leadership" imaginable, in the context of an individual being entrusted as commander in chief of our nation.

The idea of staying the course, in the wake of these actions, is both incomprehensible and anti-constitutional.

Mitch Deighan, Philadelphia

Xxxxxx

Remember George Bush?

Those of us who didn't vote for him tried to warn those who were planning to that they should look at the real issues and not believe the nonsense, and not get caught up in the nastiness, that was the core of his campaign. Both times.

Any unbiased person, anyone having no agenda except electing the most qualified man, anyone doing their homework on the most pressing issues facing our nation, could not possibly have thought that Bush would be a better president than Al Gore or John Kerry.

But, alas, people have agendas.

The wealthy want tax breaks. Evangelicals want to keep gay people from having the right to marry. People who misunderstand the meaning of patriotism want to "kill them all and let God sort them out." So they vote for the likes of Bush.

Why worry about the economy, or jobs, or affordable health care. Bush told us that he had a plan for each, and too many of us, disregarding the track record of Republican administrations over the last 60 years, believed him.

Before running for president, George Bush had failed in every position he ever held. As president, he's added to that dubious resume.

Now, along comes John McCain, and that fraud he picked as a running mate. The tone of their campaign, the attack ads, the clever phrases substituting for real knowledge virtually guarantee Bush III should they be elected.

By the time people realized Bush was incompetent, arrogant and ignorant, it was way too late.

Remember the saying: "Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me."

Bob Leonardo, Palmyra, N.J.

Xxxxxx

To Stu columnist Bykofsky,

Seven years ago, 19 whack-jobs killed over 3,000 of us.

For decades, the Soviets, a much greater threat, had thousands of nuclear warheads pointed at us, but we didn't have the level of surveillance that we are subject to now (which Bush did first illegally, then Congress codified this summer).

The Republicans, because of 19 perps, declared a multi-billion-dollar "war on terror" to scare us and keep themselves in power.

Because of 19 jerks (and Exxon Mobil), they invade a completely innocent country and now they don't even need warrants to spy on us. You newspaper guys, when you get information from sources overseas, you'll be simultaneously (and warrantlessly) sharing that with eavesdropping spooks. If you're running for office against a Republican, they'll be listening in to your campaign strategy. And with all these memorials and the moment of silence that you want, these emotional soap operas makes us look weak, a more appetizing target to terrorists.

Phil Gramm, though he didn't mean it in this context, is right - we are a nation of whiners.

Hopefully, the ACLU, et al, will overturn FISA on 4th amendment grounds.

And if more Americans die (which is doubtful) as result of less government intrusion, then so be it - that's the cost of freedom. We payed that price in 1776.

Bill Paci, Philadelphia
