195 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


CRONY CAPITALISM;
THE DEMOCRATSARE GOOD ATTHE CRONY PART


BYLINE: Jack Kelly


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 717 words


Lending money to people who probably won't pay it back isn't good business.

If you wrap crummy loans in a clever package, they're still crummy loans.

Your typical Wal-Mart shopper understands this. But the Masters of the Universe on Wall Street and in Washington evidently didn't.

There are a lot of people to blame for the subprime mortgage crisis.

The Federal Reserve Board under Chairman Alan Greenspan (1987-2006) pursued what seems in hindsight clearly to have been way too loose a monetary policy. Banks were awash with money to lend and got careless in how they lent it.

Ostensibly to aid the poor and working class, the Clinton administration and Congress encouraged lenders to give mortgages to bad credit risks. The combination of easy money and the expansion of the number of borrowers unable to repay their loans sent housing prices through the roof, creating the bubble whose bursting has led to this crisis.

Congress in 1999 repealed the law that established a bright line between commercial and investment banks. This meant bad investments by banks could jeopardize depositors.

Wall Street created "derivatives" which multiplied profits in good times, but which also multiplied risk if there were defaults.

Most important was corruption and mismanagement at the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac), which together controlled 90 percent of the secondary mortgage market.

Once your bank has lent you money to buy a house, it can't lend the money again until you pay it back. But if your bank sells your mortgage, it can make another loan right away. Without the secondary market, most of the funds for home mortgages would dry up.

Fannie and Freddie went broke because they bought billions of dollars worth of subprime mortgages, on which borrowers defaulted when the housing bubble popped. Fannie bought most of its bad mortgages from Countrywide Financial, whose CEO, Angelo Mozilo, gave sweetheart loans to senior executives of Fannie Mae.

Fannie and Freddie cooked their books so senior executives would be paid millions of dollars in bonuses to which they were not entitled. Inadequate regulation kept the book-cooking from being discovered until the crisis had become a catastrophe.

President Bush proposed regulatory reforms in 2003, but Congress took no action. In 2005, John McCain and three other GOP senators proposed a strong reform bill. It died when Democrats threatened a filibuster.

Democrats opposed reform in part because they feared it would mean fewer loans to poor people.

"Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are not facing any kind of financial crisis," Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass, told The New York Times when the Bush bill was introduced. "The more pressure there is on these companies, the less we will see in terms of affordable housing."

Democrats and some Republicans opposed reform in part because Fannie and Freddie were very good at greasing palms. Fannie has spent $170 million on lobbying since 1998 and $19.3 million on political contributions since 1990.

The principal recipient of Fannie Mae's largesse was Sen. Chris Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. No. 2 was Barack Obama.

Mr. Dodd was also the second largest recipient in the Senate of contributions from Countrywide's political action committee and its employees, and the recipient of a home loan from Countrywide at well below market rates. The No. 1 senator on Countrywide's list? Barack Obama.

Fannie Mae CEO Franklin Raines was forced to resign in December 2004 because of "accounting irregularities." The Washington Post reported July 16 that the Obama campaign has called Mr. Raines "seeking his advice on mortgage and housing policy matters."

Mr. Obama appointed Mr. Raines' predecessor, James Johnson, as head of his vice presidential search committee until he also was implicated in "accounting irregularities," and it was revealed he'd received cut-rate loans from Countrywide.

Chicago billionaire Penny Pritzker, head of Mr. Obama's finance committee, chaired the now-defunct Superior bank when it began to cook the books to conceal losses from subprime mortgages. The holding company her family owned collected $200 million in dividends on phony profits.

The trouble with crony capitalism isn't capitalism. It's the cronies.


LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Jack Kelly is a columnist for the Post-Gazette (jkelly@post-gazette.com, 412 263-1476).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



196 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


PRESIDENT SPURNED BY GOP CANDIDATES


BYLINE: CATHERINE DODGE AND HOLLY ROSENKRANTZ, BLOOMBERG NEWS


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-11


LENGTH: 670 words


There is an invisible man in the 2008 election: the president of the United States.

Republican candidates have all but shunned him, save those who need him to help raise money. And to the extent any president can keep a low profile, George W. Bush is doing it.

Saddled with one of the lowest approval ratings in polling history, the president is still in demand to shake the party money tree, though almost all of that is done out of the public eye.

"Sadly, a highly visible presence by the president will hurt the party and hurt John McCain," Mr. Bush's former spokesman Ari Fleischer said.

Republican candidates in close races compete for prominent politicians. Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee stumped with North Carolina Sen. Elizabeth Dole, and former Speaker Newt Gingrich campaigned with Ohio Rep. Steve Chabot. Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney is booked for events every week through Election Day, while Mr. Bush's public political calendar has mostly been empty.

"The country is looking for change, and he's not the most popular president in recent times," said David Carney, political director for Bush's father, President George H. W. Bush.

In 2000, Vice President Al Gore generally kept his distance from President Bill Clinton while seeking to succeed him. The two-term incumbent was still in demand with other Democrats, holding 202 fundraisers during his last year in office and campaigning for House candidates in states such as New York, Missouri, and Arkansas, Mrs. Clinton's former spokesman Jake Siewert said.

"Clinton spent an enormous amount of time on the campaign trail," Mr. Siewert said. "There was a fair amount of demand for him to do public events."

Mr. McCain didn't utter Bush's name during his Sept. 4 speech accepting the Republican nomination. Pairing the words "George" and "Bush" is seemingly so politically dangerous that the Arizona senator even referred to the elder Bush only as "the 41st president."

Mr. McCain, 72, isn't the only Republican politician keeping his distance. Of 11 governor's races this year, the president has campaigned just with the North Carolina Republican nominee, Charlotte Mayor Pat McCrory, and he has appeared with only a handful of hopefuls for 435 U.S. House seats.

For candidates this year, being photographed with Mr. Bush gives ammunition to opponents seeking to shackle Republicans to the White House.

"They simply don't want to be seen with him," said Tad Devine, a strategist in presidential campaigns for Mr. Gore and Sen. John F. Kerry.

Democratic presidential nominee Sen. Barack Obama released a television commercial earlier this month that, in 30 seconds, managed to show five different pictures of Mr. McCain with Mr. Bush.

White House political director Barry Jackson wouldn't provide details on Bush's political schedule leading up to the Nov. 4 election. Specifics about Mr. Bush's appearances aren't released until several days before an event, he said.

There are lots of places he's not likely to go, like the Hampton Roads region in southeast Virginia. "We haven't even discussed it," said Corry Bliss, campaign manager for Virginia U.S. Rep. Thelma Drake, when asked about a Bush visit. "This campaign is about next year and the future."

Likewise, there's nothing in the works with Sen. Roger Wicker of Mississippi. "Sen. Wicker is running his own race," campaign spokesman Ryan Annison said.

The president, who toured the Beijing Olympics last month, spent more time in front of cameras with the U.S. women's beach volleyball team than he has lately with the Republican nominee.

Mr. McCain accepted Mr. Bush's endorsement in the White House Rose Garden on March 5, the day after sewing up the nomination. "If he wants my pretty face standing by his side at one of these rallies, I'd be glad to show up," Mr. Bush said.

More than six months later, Mr. McCain hasn't taken up the offer. Their only other joint appearance was on May 27, for less than a minute, when they shook hands as Mr. Bush boarded Air Force One after a Phoenix fundraiser.


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



197 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


BYLINE: Compiled by Greg Victor.


SECTION: EDITORIAL; CUTTING EDGE: NEW IDEAS, SHARP OPINIONS; Pg. G-4


LENGTH: 668 words


OBAMA'S MEDIA POLICE

On the Weekly Standard blog, Jonathan Last blasts the Obama campaign for using its database of supporters to inundate media outlets with calls and e-mails whenever it see or hears something it doesn't like. Citing a Chicago radio producer who said it was difficult to run his talk show in the face of "constant, constant phone calls" and e-mails, Mr. Last likened the tactic to a denial-of-service attack intended to render useless an Internet service or Web site. He notes that such cyber assaults, while legal in the United States, are outlawed in Britain.

(weeklystandard.com)

HARDWIRED CONSERVATIVES

Jonathan Haidt at Edge says science now suggests that "conservatism is a partially heritable personality trait that predisposes some people to be cognitively inflexible, fond of hierarchy and inordinately afraid of uncertainty, change and death. People vote Republican because Republicans offer 'moral clarity' -- a simple vision of good and evil that activates deep-seated fears in much of the electorate. Democrats, in contrast, appeal to reason with their long-winded explorations of policy options for a complex world."

(edge.org)

PALIN VS. MCCAIN?

Ella Hushagen of Stand Up for Health Care quotes and then comments on part of Sarah Palin's speech at the GOP convention:

To the families of special-needs children all across this country, I have a message: For years, you sought to make America a more welcoming place for your sons and daughters. I pledge to you that if we are elected, you will have a friend and advocate in the White House.

"This is a momentous oath -- and one that means Gov. Palin cannot in good faith support the health-care plan of her running mate ... Why not? Unfortunately Sen. McCain's plan would allow most insurance companies in the individual market to continue their current practices of denying coverage, charging far higher premiums and excluding crucial medical services based on peoples' pre-existing conditions."

(standupforhealthcare.org)

POOR PITTSBURGH

Harold Miller at Pittsburgh's Future helps explains why a recently released Census Bureau report found Pittsburgh to be one of the poorest large cities in the country, with a median household income in 2007 of $32,263, the fourth lowest among central cities in the top 40 regions. Pittsburgh, he points out, has a far higher proportion of college students and households headed by seniors than most other cities, and both juniors and seniors tend to make less money. Still, he points out, Pittsburgh wages and salaries do lag, even taking into account the relatively low cost of living here.

(pittsburghfuture.blogspot.com)

EXPLOITING RACISM?

Hotair notes Rush Limbaugh's Wall Street Journal op-ed blasting Barack Obama for a Spanish-language ad that suggests John McCain shares Mr. Limbaugh's hardline views on immigration (he doesn't):

"What kind of potential president would let his campaign knowingly extract two incomplete, out-of-context lines from two radio parodies and build a framework of hate around them in order to exploit racial tensions? The segregationists of the 1950s and 1960s were famous for such vile fear-mongering."

(Hotair.com)

CREATIVE COMMUTING

The Angry Drunk Bureaucrat provides a long list of ways to get to work if Port Authority workers go on strike. Aside from biking, walking and driving, they include:

"Helicopter/airplane -- Should this be an option for you, you probably have more money than sense. I would be perfectly happy to relieve you of this burden.

"Carpooling -- All the charms of a taxi combined with all the joys of being stuck at work with people you don't like.

"Cannon -- I haven't tried this one out yet, but I'm pretty sure with the right wind conditions and with the appropriate caliber gun, anyone can hit the Steel Building. The pain ... is the connecting cannon if your destination is not Downtown. Bring your own helmet.

"Catapult -- See Cannon

"Hanglider -- Silly, and possible target for commuters traveling by cannon."

(angrydrunkbureaucrat.blogspot.com)


LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Please send contributions to opinion@post-gazette.com


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



198 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


ELECTION BATTLE UNUSUAL IN NORTH CAROLINA


BYLINE: LIZ SIDOTI AND MIKE BAKER, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-11


LENGTH: 630 words


DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C.


All of a sudden, North Carolina matters.

It hasn't for decades in presidential elections.

Then Democrat Barack Obama made an aggressive play for this traditionally GOP state and polls showed the race tightening. That forced Republican John McCain to defend his turf or risk ceding the Southern state -- and its 15 electoral votes -- to Democrats for the first time in 32 years.

Now, just seven weeks before the election, North Carolina has become a general-election battleground, one of 13 states where both candidates are competing with television commercials and campaign staff on the ground.

"They clearly see the threat," Obama campaign manager David Plouffe said after Mr. McCain's campaign intensified its efforts here. "They can profess that they're not concerned. But their spending and their actions belie" that.

Steve Schmidt, Mr. McCain's chief strategist, insists the campaign is unconcerned: "It's just one more state where the Obama campaign has allowed its hubris to dictate spending decisions. John McCain will win North Carolina and soon you will see the Obama camp withdraw from North Carolina like you have seen them withdraw from other states."

Public polling shows a competitive race, though private surveys for both Republicans and Democrats give Mr. McCain an edge of anywhere from 3 to 8 percentage points.

A Time/CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll released Wednesday showed the race virtually tied at 48 percent for Mr. McCain, 47 percent for Mr. Obama.

The challenge for Mr. Obama may have increased after Mr. McCain selected Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin as his running mate, a choice that has energized conservatives. At a recent Republican gathering in Cary for veterans, the mere mention of Ms. Palin's name drew thunderous applause while Mr. McCain's name elicited a tepid response.

"I'm not that thrilled about McCain," said James Arscott, 66, a National Guard veteran and a Republican. "That is, I wasn't thrilled about McCain until Sarah Palin came about."

Even Democratic loyalists acknowledge that it is difficult to imagine North Carolina voting for Mr. Obama, who would be the country's first black president.

"I would be stunned," said Tim Rohde, 51, a Democrat from Raleigh. "But it would be amazing."

It takes 270 electoral votes to claim the White House. Typically, candidates compete for them in upward of two dozen states early in a general election only to see those that historically aren't swing states drop out of contention by the fall.

The opposite has occurred with North Carolina. Look no further than the state's population spurt -- and its origins in the more liberal Northeast -- to understand why Mr. Obama thinks he has a shot this year, and why Mr. McCain isn't taking it for granted.

White-collar workers have poured into Charlotte's financial hub in the south, while recent college graduates and their young families have been drawn to plentiful jobs and quality education in the academic Research Triangle encompassing Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill. Retirees concerned about health care and the environment have settled on both sides of the state, from the eastern coastline to the western mountains.

Voter registration rolls illustrate the shifting tide.

State Board of Elections records show that Democratic registrations have risen 7 percent since the start of 2008, while Republican registrations grew about 1 percent. There are now about 40 percent more Democrats than Republicans in North Carolina, although members of both state parties tend to be more conservative than their national counterparts. Registrations among blacks, a pivotal part of the Democratic base, are up almost 10 percent while white registrations are up 4 percent.

The number of registrations for voters who don't claim a political party jumped 11 percent this year.


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



199 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
TWO STAR EDITION


GOVERNOR FORMING 'TRUTH SQUAD'


BYLINE: Joe Fahy, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: STATE; Pg. B-3


LENGTH: 344 words


Gov. Ed Rendell said he plans to announce a "truth squad" initiative tomorrow to counter "lies and distortions" by the campaign of Arizona Sen. John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee.

At a news conference yesterday morning in Pittsburgh with Mayor Luke Ravenstahl and former Iowa Gov. Tom Vilsack, Mr. Rendell said that television ads and statements by the campaign have inaccurately suggested that Mr. McCain's Democratic opponent, Illinois Sen. Barack Obama, would raise taxes on most Americans.

The vast majority, in fact, would receive bigger tax breaks under Mr. Obama's tax plan, he said, outlining various groups of lower- and middle-income people, ranging from a single parent with young children to couples and elderly widows, that he said would do better.

Spokespeople for the McCain campaign did not return calls and e-mails yesterday.

Mr. Rendell and others have accused the McCain campaign before of making false statements about Mr. Obama's tax plan. Last week, for example, FactCheck.org said the McCain campaign "has released yet another ad that makes false claims."

"As we keep saying," the Web site noted, "Obama says he'll raise income taxes and capital gains taxes only for couples earning more than $250,000 per year or singles making over $200,000."

Less clear is how Mr. Obama, if elected, would accomplish those goals, particularly facing budget deficits and a struggling economy, said G. Terry Madonna, a political science professor and pollster from Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster.

The news conference was held at Grandview Park, Mount Washington, where the Obama campaign kicked off "Steps for Change," a local effort to register new voters.

Polls show the race between Mr. McCain and Mr. Obama has narrowed in Pennsylvania, considered a battleground state.

Speaking to a small group of Obama canvassers at the news conference, Mr. Ravenstahl and Mr. Vilsack, a Pittsburgh native, urged them to press on.

"We need to continue to do whatever we can" before the Nov. 4 election, the mayor said. "You all will make the difference."


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Joe Fahy can be reached at jfahy@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1722.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



200 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday
FOUR STAR EDITION


RENDELL FORMING 'TRUTH SQUAD' TO DEFEND OBAMA


BYLINE: JOE FAHY, PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-11


LENGTH: 514 words


Gov. Ed Rendell said he plans to announce a "truth squad" initiative tomorrow to counter "lies and distortions" by the campaign of Arizona Sen. John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee.

At a news conference yesterday morning in Pittsburgh with Mayor Luke Ravenstahl and former Iowa Gov. Tom Vilsack, Mr. Rendell said that television ads and statements by the campaign have inaccurately suggested that Mr. McCain's Democratic opponent, Illinois Sen. Barack Obama, would raise taxes on most Americans.

The vast majority, in fact, would receive bigger tax breaks under Mr. Obama's tax plan, he said, outlining various groups of lower- and middle-income people, ranging from a single parent with young children to couples and elderly widows, that he said would do better.

Paul Lindsay, a McCain campaign spokesman, said that at a time of increased economic hardship, Pennsylvania families deserve to know about Mr. Obama's record, including that he has voted for higher taxes "nearly 100 times" in the Senate and "plans to tax coal and natural gas that are an engine for job growth in the state." In February, Mr. Obama did tell a San Antonio newspaper, "What we ought to tax is dirty energy, like coal and, to a lesser extent, natural gas." But the remark was made after he was asked whether taxes should be levied on renewable energy sources and "was not a general call for increasing taxes on coal or natural gas," according to FactCheck.org. Mr. Obama "certainly does not have any such proposal as part of his public platform," the Web site noted.

Mr. Rendell and others have accused the McCain campaign before of making false statements about Mr. Obama's tax plan. Last week, for example, FactCheck.org said the McCain campaign "has released yet another ad that makes false claims."

"As we keep saying," the Web site noted, "Obama says he'll raise income taxes and capital gains taxes only for couples earning more than $250,000 per year or singles making over $200,000."

Less clear is how Mr. Obama, if elected, would accomplish those goals, particularly facing budget deficits and a struggling economy, said G. Terry Madonna, a political science professor and pollster from Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster.

Mr. Rendell was in town yesterday for political meetings and appearances, but no official business, said his spokesman, Chuck Ardo.

The news conference was held at Grandview Park, Mount Washington, where the Obama campaign kicked off "Steps for Change," a local effort to register new voters. While those efforts have been ongoing, "Steps for Change" acknowledged Pittsburgh's status as the U.S. city with the most public stairways -- 712, with a total of 44,645 steps.

Polls show the race between Mr. McCain and Mr. Obama has narrowed in Pennsylvania, considered a battleground state.

Speaking to a small group of Obama canvassers at the news conference, Mr. Ravenstahl and Mr. Vilsack, a Pittsburgh native, urged them to press on.

"We need to continue to do whatever we can" before the Nov. 4 election, Mr. Ravenstahl told the group. "You all will make the difference."


LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Joe Fahy can be reached at jfahy@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1722


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



201 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday


Without Referees, The Game's Rigged


BYLINE: Gil Smart; Smart Remarks


SECTION: P; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 603 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


So now you own an insurance company.

Don't worry, it's not like you, personally, will be making any decisions. Rather, your government, in your name - and with your money! - assumed a 79.9 percent stake in American Insurance Group last week, to keep the massive institution from failing and causing even more economic turbulence here and around the globe.

"AIG's bailout brings to about $900 billion the total of U.S. rescue efforts to stabilize the financial system and housing market," wrote the Associated Press. "Authorities may get much of that sum back provided asset prices don't continue to slide."

And if they do?

Well. Just don't think about that.

While the rationale for the AIG bailout was understandable, the upshot was a further turn toward what economist Nouriel Roubini has called the "United Socialist State Republic of America." This was, wrote Roubini, the "first pure case of a fully private company, actually the largest insurance company in the world, being nationalized."

And so after several weeks of election-year trivialities, both presidential candidates were forced to step up. Barack Obama's initial response was tepid; the reality is that his party bears some of the blame for the meltdown on Wall Street. Democrats have been almost as bullish about deregulation as the GOP. And Obama has actually taken more in campaign contributions from the financial sector than John McCain.

Still, Obama has long spoken of a "21st century regulatory framework." And Wednesday he released a new ad, a full two minutes long, detailing his plans to deal with the economy. Much of it was boilerplate, though I was struck by his assertion that we need to "bring a responsible end to this war in Iraq so we stop spending billions each month rebuilding their country when we should be rebuilding ours."

McCain's response was angrier, but ultimately less credible. He initially came out against the AIG bailout - a conservative position - but then backed off. More startling was his fiery condemnation of Wall Street. He called the crisis "the result of unchecked corporate greed," and insisted that "government must protect the public from investment schemes too complex for people to understand or regulate."

Greed is bad? Government needs to protect the people from capitalist excesses? Since when do Republicans believe any of this?

McCain has been a champion of deregulation, though to a lesser extent than other Republicans. His economic adviser, Phil Gramm, was an architect of the 1999 Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which removed "the Depression-era walls between banking, investment and insurance companies," according to an article in last week's Washington Post.

"That bill allowed AIG to participate in the gold rush of a rapidly expanding global banking and investment market,'' reported the Post. "But the legislation also helped pave the way for companies such as AIG and Lehman Brothers to become behemoths laden with bad loans and investments."

Deregulation, in other words, led to excess. Who could have guessed?

So now McCain, even his party, are forced to acknowledge that, as one online commenter noted last week, markets without regulation work about as well as a football game without referees. But can they be trusted to tighten the strings they have been so committed to loosening? Is McCain selling out a core principle for the sake of political expediency? Does he actually understand the need for a streamlined, 21st-century regulatory framework?

Do the Democrats?

And perhaps most importantly - do you?

Gil Smart is associate editor of the Sunday News. E-mail him at gsmart@lnpnews.com, or phone 291-8817.


LOAD-DATE: September 22, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Gil Smart Smart Remarks


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



202 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 21, 2008 Sunday


Without Referees, The Game's Rigged


BYLINE: Gil Smart; Smart Remarks


SECTION: P; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 603 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


So now you own an insurance company.

Don't worry, it's not like you, personally, will be making any decisions. Rather, your government, in your name - and with your money! - assumed a 79.9 percent stake in American Insurance Group last week, to keep the massive institution from failing and causing even more economic turbulence here and around the globe.

"AIG's bailout brings to about $900 billion the total of U.S. rescue efforts to stabilize the financial system and housing market," wrote the Associated Press. "Authorities may get much of that sum back provided asset prices don't continue to slide."

And if they do?

Well. Just don't think about that.

While the rationale for the AIG bailout was understandable, the upshot was a further turn toward what economist Nouriel Roubini has called the "United Socialist State Republic of America." This was, wrote Roubini, the "first pure case of a fully private company, actually the largest insurance company in the world, being nationalized."

And so after several weeks of election-year trivialities, both presidential candidates were forced to step up. Barack Obama's initial response was tepid; the reality is that his party bears some of the blame for the meltdown on Wall Street. Democrats have been almost as bullish about deregulation as the GOP. And Obama has actually taken more in campaign contributions from the financial sector than John McCain.

Still, Obama has long spoken of a "21st century regulatory framework." And Wednesday he released a new ad, a full two minutes long, detailing his plans to deal with the economy. Much of it was boilerplate, though I was struck by his assertion that we need to "bring a responsible end to this war in Iraq so we stop spending billions each month rebuilding their country when we should be rebuilding ours."

McCain's response was angrier, but ultimately less credible. He initially came out against the AIG bailout - a conservative position - but then backed off. More startling was his fiery condemnation of Wall Street. He called the crisis "the result of unchecked corporate greed," and insisted that "government must protect the public from investment schemes too complex for people to understand or regulate."

Greed is bad? Government needs to protect the people from capitalist excesses? Since when do Republicans believe any of this?

McCain has been a champion of deregulation, though to a lesser extent than other Republicans. His economic adviser, Phil Gramm, was an architect of the 1999 Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which removed "the Depression-era walls between banking, investment and insurance companies," according to an article in last week's Washington Post.

"That bill allowed AIG to participate in the gold rush of a rapidly expanding global banking and investment market,'' reported the Post. "But the legislation also helped pave the way for companies such as AIG and Lehman Brothers to become behemoths laden with bad loans and investments."

Deregulation, in other words, led to excess. Who could have guessed?

So now McCain, even his party, are forced to acknowledge that, as one online commenter noted last week, markets without regulation work about as well as a football game without referees. But can they be trusted to tighten the strings they have been so committed to loosening? Is McCain selling out a core principle for the sake of political expediency? Does he actually understand the need for a streamlined, 21st-century regulatory framework?

Do the Democrats?

And perhaps most importantly - do you?

Gil Smart is associate editor of the Sunday News. E-mail him at gsmart@lnpnews.com, or phone 291-8817.

203 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 19, 2008 Friday


Palin Isn't Prepared Emily Krugereden Township


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 235 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


McCain's choice of Palin bemuses me, since earlier this summer on CNBC, she asked, "What exactly is it that the vice president does?"

In his recent letter, Christopher Brooks wrote, "Having been a mayor and a governor (commander-in-chief of the National Guard of a state with a Russian border), she has more executive experience than Obama, who has never even run a Dairy Queen." His comparison of the two is laughable.

After graduating with honors from Harvard Law School, Obama taught constitutional law for 11 years and has served in the Illinois and U.S. senates for a total of 13 years. His foreign relations work spans the subjects of nuclear disarmament, genocide and global poverty.

Palin was mayor of Wasilla, a town smaller than Lititz, for six years. Lancaster's Mayor Gray leads a population nearly nine times this size.

I don't think any of Pennsylvania's small-town mayors would have the hubris to claim they are prepared to be president.

Palin has been governor of Alaska, whose population is smaller than Lancaster and Berks counties combined, for 20 months.

Every governor is commander-in- chief of the state's National Guard - none has the power of national deployment. This ritual role denotes leadership experience no more than Alaska's proximity to the Russian wilderness bestows foreign-policy experience.

McCain failed to choose a VP with the experience to lead our country, should the need arise.


LOAD-DATE: September 20, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



204 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 19, 2008 Friday


Palin Isn't Prepared Emily Krugereden Township


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 235 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


McCain's choice of Palin bemuses me, since earlier this summer on CNBC, she asked, "What exactly is it that the vice president does?"

In his recent letter, Christopher Brooks wrote, "Having been a mayor and a governor (commander-in-chief of the National Guard of a state with a Russian border), she has more executive experience than Obama, who has never even run a Dairy Queen." His comparison of the two is laughable.

After graduating with honors from Harvard Law School, Obama taught constitutional law for 11 years and has served in the Illinois and U.S. senates for a total of 13 years. His foreign relations work spans the subjects of nuclear disarmament, genocide and global poverty.

Palin was mayor of Wasilla, a town smaller than Lititz, for six years. Lancaster's Mayor Gray leads a population nearly nine times this size.

I don't think any of Pennsylvania's small-town mayors would have the hubris to claim they are prepared to be president.

Palin has been governor of Alaska, whose population is smaller than Lancaster and Berks counties combined, for 20 months.

Every governor is commander-in- chief of the state's National Guard - none has the power of national deployment. This ritual role denotes leadership experience no more than Alaska's proximity to the Russian wilderness bestows foreign-policy experience.

McCain failed to choose a VP with the experience to lead our country, should the need arise.

205 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


September 19, 2008 Friday
FINAL Edition


Christine M. Flowers: An Obama-nation on immigration


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; P-com Opinion; Pg. 15


LENGTH: 686 words


HE'S AT it again.

First, Barack Obama insulted rural Pennsylvanians, among others, by calling them bitter, clinging to their guns and religion. He said it at a private fund-raiser in San Francisco wine and cheese country, where the sky is as blue as the voters, and apparently thought the rubes would remain blissfully ignorant of his disdain.

But the guy is big on bilingualism. And now he's trying the same thing again - this time in Spanish.

The Obama campaign has just come out with new TV and radio ads trying to link John McCain with racism. And he's given this smear a "muy caliente" multicultural twist. The TV ad features derogatory comments about Latinos presumably made by Rush Limbaugh on his radio show. Limbaugh, of course, is unhappy. He says that his comments were taken out of context. (In an election year, imagine that!)

But I don't care about Limbaugh. For one thing, he and I are borders apart on immigration reform. For another, he's perfectly capable of defending himself against the junior senator of Illinois and his crew.

What I do care about is the false impression Obama is trying to create by encouraging Latinos to believe that John McCain and George Bush are not only racist but anti-immigrant as well.

Flashing pictures of the GOP candidate and the president in the same frame, a disembodied voice implies that "they" derailed immigration reform.

It goes on: "John McCain and his Republican friends have two faces. One that lies just to get our vote and another, even worse, that continues the failed policies of George Bush that put special interests ahead of working families."

But these are the facts, folks:

For the 12 years that I've been practicing immigration law, there have been only two Republicans who actually worked in a major public way toward getting a reasonable solution to the immigration problem.

Both of them are pictured in that dishonest commercial. At great political risk, both men - McCain in particular - tried to work with their ideological opponents to create pragmatic and effective legislation that would reduce the size of the undocumented population in this country.

Bush had his doomed guest- worker program. McCain entered into a shotgun marriage with Ted Kennedy and proposed workable comprehensive immigration legislation that was distorted by a label that made compromise impossible: "Amnesty."

Neither Bush nor McCain were successful in their efforts because of congressional gridlock brought on by fierce public opposition. Ironically, this was one of the few times that rank-and-file Democrats and Republicans agreed on something: Secure that border first.

That battle will continue well beyond this election cycle. And I continue to hope that the misleading labels are erased, and we can finally talk some sense about immigration.

But the time is obviously not now, and the person to do it is definitely not Obama.

What the Democratic nominee is trying to do is appeal to a demographic he desperately needs in November.

The senator from Illinois is trying to convince Latino voters that he's on their side and that the other guy is aiming to deport their families. This is what his Spanish-speaking surrogate says on the radio: "Don't forget that John McCain abandoned us rather than confront the leaders of the Republican Party."

Nice way to twist the truth.

MCCAIN HASN'T "abandoned" immigrants.

What he has done is take a step backward and indicate a desire to find some common ground where immigration reform will not be stymied by the same gridlock that doomed his original proposal.

But Obama seems to think if he just keeps beating that drum long enough, voters will fall in line. They won't need to know if the lyrics are true - they'll just fall for the seductive rhythms.

In pandering to Latinos who voted overwhelmingly for Hillary Clinton during the primaries, Obama has shown that, contrary to his campaign's accusations, he's the one playing the race card in this election. Only this time it's brown, not black.

Que verguenza. And I'm sure Obama knows what that means: "That's shameful!" *

Christine M. Flowers is a lawyer.

E-mail cflowers1961@yahoo.com.


LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photograph by: Lissa Atkins


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



206 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 19, 2008 Friday
SOONER EDITION


JERRY AND BILL, MEET JOHN AND SARAH


BYLINE: Tony Norman


SECTION: LIFESTYLE; Pg. A-2


LENGTH: 721 words


Even Don Draper, the fictional advertising executive played by Jon Hamm on "Mad Men," couldn't salvage Microsoft's ad campaign featuring Jerry Seinfeld and Bill Gates.

It was not a pretty sight. The former sitcom star and the world's richest software developer ambled through the mystifying TV spots like Vladimir and Estragon on the lam from "Waiting for Godot." The ads, the first wave of a campaign to rehabilitate Windows, were derided by computer geeks and normal people alike. Microsoft pulled the plug this week (though claiming that was their plan all along).

In the first spot, the two men -- who could easily buy entire ZIP codes with the cash they had in their pockets that day -- fake familiarity with downscale shopping at a discount shoe store. In another, the celebrities, bunking with an ordinary family in a suburban split-level, find themselves commenting on the incongruity of it all:

Gates: "Why are we doing this?"

Seinfeld: "Why, Bill? Because as we discussed, you and I are a little out of it. You're in some kind of moon house hovering over Seattle like the mothership. I've got so many cars, I get stuck in my own traffic. We need to connect with real people."

(The resident grandmother wanders by their bedroom door wailing: "Who took my teeth out of the freezer?")

Seinfeld [pointing to her]: "That's real!"

Gates [nodding]: "Hmmm. I felt that."

If the spots are supposed to be an answer to Apple's "I'm a Mac, I'm a PC" campaign, it was a miserable failure. Bill Gates is no John Hodgman, though Jerry Seinfeld has a lot in common with the smug, black-attired Mac guy in the ads.

For his trouble, Mr. Seinfeld pocketed a cool $10 million for writing the most baffling commercials in a generation. I know a lot of pretentious people, and no one has been able to explain to me what's going on in these spots.

In many ways, the absurdity of two gazillionaires shopping at a discount shoe outlet is reminiscent of the McCain campaign's faux populism of recent weeks.

Sen. John McCain and Gov. Sarah Palin are very much like Bill Gates and Jerry Seinfeld -- except the latter are keenly aware how phony their pose as mall rats looks to others.

Meanwhile, the Republican presidential ticket doesn't care how inauthentic they sound as long as their stump speech helps them "connect with real people."

So John McCain hits the campaign trail every day, sounding increasingly like actor Wallace Shawn doing a really bad Huey Long imitation.

It's clear that being a man of the people doesn't come naturally to Mr. McCain. Even as storied financial institutions began crashing and burning like the Hindenburg all over Wall Street, John McCain stuck to his assessment that the "fundamentals of the economy" were sound.

When the post-convention bounce that tied the two campaigns suddenly evaporated, Mr. McCain abandoned his relentlessly optimistic line about the economy.

Now we're supposed to believe that the "fundamentals" he's been referring to all along is really a metaphor for the humble American worker -- not the market. He assures us he would never say that the "fundamentals" of American capitalism are sound.

As if to prove John McCain's bona fides as the kind of man an unemployed steel worker in Ohio could have a beer with, the campaign rolled out a prominent Hillary supporter who defected to the Republicans -- Lynn Forester de Rothschild.

Lady Rothschild, a member in good standing of the "Let 'em eat cake" wing of the Democratic Party, told an incredulous Campbell Brown on CNN that she couldn't support Barack Obama because he is "elitist."

"So, you have to understand how ridiculous this seems to a lot of people," Ms. Brown said. "You're a Rothschild. You're married to a billionaire. You were a millionaire before you married him. You're a jetsetter. You live between New York and London. And yet, you're calling Barack Obama an elitist. Are you not a member of the elite?"

Lady Rothschild, after noting her middle-class upbringing in New Jersey, insisted that Barack Obama was a divisive figure who promulgated class warfare and thinks he's "grander than the rest of us." She supports Mr. McCain because he's a champion of the middle class and that he and Sarah Palin "are the great Americans."

For a second, I thought I was watching another one of Jerry Seinfeld's maddeningly opaque Microsoft commercials.


LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Tony Norman can be reached at tnorman@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1631.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



207 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


September 19, 2008 Friday


Our community for 09/19/08


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1322 words


HACC-YORK
Free workshops
Harrisburg Area Community College's Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies is offering a series of free workshops next week for anyone thinking about navigating the waters of business ownership.

"These sessions are aimed at giving would-be entrepreneurs valuable information and tips on developing a business plan, getting financing, sales and successful marketing," said Kathy Snavely, HACC business counselor and co-facilitator of the workshops, which will be held Monday-Thursday, Sept. 22-25, at various locations around York County.

In addition to Snavely, who also is the owner of Lightkeeper Consulting in Mount Gretna, facilitators include Barbara Schreiber, chief idea officer of The Idea Zoo in York, and Lisa Steffen, HACC business counselor.

The hour-long sessions include a 45-minute presentation and 15-minute question-and-answer period. To attend any of the free "Start Your Own Business" workshops or for more information about IES, call 1-800-ABC-HACC (800-222-4222), ext. 1311.

Here's the schedule:

---Monday, Sept. 22:

1 p.m. "Low Cost, High Impact Personal Marketing" at the Dover Community Library, 3700-3 Davidsburg Road.

3:30 p.m. "Low Cost, High Impact Personal Marketing" at Kaltreider/Benfer Library, 147 S. Charles St., Red Lion.

---Tuesday, Sept. 23:

2 p.m. "Where Do I Get the Money?" at Martin Library, 159 E. Market St., York.

7 p.m. "USP (unique selling position) is a Do or DIE!" at Guthrie Memorial Library, 2 Library Place, Hanover.

---Wednesday, Sept. 24:

1:30 p.m. "Business Plan Schman" at Ship to Shore Coffee, 17 Old Farm Lane, Shrewsbury.

---Thursday, Sept. 25:

10 a.m. "Sales" at Fulton Bank, 866 N. U.S. Route 15, Dillsburg.
GETTYSBURG
Whitman to speak
Former New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman will speak about women, politics and power Monday at Gettysburg College.

Whitman's talk, "Women, Power, and Politics: The View from Just under the Glass Ceiling," will take place at 7:30 p.m. in the College Union Building Ballroom. A book signing will follow her talk, and the event is open to the public at no charge. Tickets are not required.

Sponsored by Gettysburg Colleges Eisenhower Institute and Womens Studies and Political Science departments, Whitman's talk is part of the Women's Studies Program 2008-2009 Lecture Series. More information is available at717-337-6788.
WEST NILE
New infections
The York County West Nile Virus Program is reporting four new confirmed mosquito samples with West Nile virus in York County for 2008. To date 24 samples in York County have now tested positive. Mosquitoes collected by Penn State Extension and PA DEP staff have tested positive for West Nile virus by the Pennsylvania Department of Health.

Positive tests have come from mosquito traps collected near the intersection of Mayfield Street and Skyview Drive Sept. 4 and at the York City waste water treatment plant on Toronita Street Sept. 6, both in Manchester Township; the 6200 block of Canal Road off Route 30 Sept. 11 in Paradise Township; and near the intersection of Graham Street and Eberts Lane Sept. 14 in Springettsbury Township.

The York County West Nile Virus staff did perform a truck spray operation around this area of Springettsbury Township during the evening hours Sept. 16 to reduce high mosquito populations. Additional surveillance and mosquito trapping in these areas is being performed by Penn State Extension staff.
HURRICANE RELIEF
Collection planned
Bishop Kevin C. Rhoades of the Catholic Diocese of Harrisburg has announced that all parishes and missions of the Diocese of Harrisburg will take up a special collection to assist the victims of the recent hurricanes that hit the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean.

The collection will be taken up in churches on the weekend of Sept. 27-28.

In a letter to pastors the bishop encouraged all, "to reach out in Christian love to all our brothers and sisters in need."

Money collected will be sent to Catholic Charities USA for aid relief efforts in the U.S. and to Catholic Relief Services for aid relief efforts in Latin America and the Caribbean. Those wishing to donate directly can send checks to Hurricane Relief, Diocese of Harrisburg, P.O. Box 3651, 17105.

The Diocese of Harrisburg serves 15 counties in south-central Pennsylvania through 89 parishes and missions. More information is available at www.hbgdiocese.org.
CULTURAL ALLIANCE
7-month process
The Cultural Alliance of York County has begun a seven month planning process to create a Community Cultural Plan for York County. Diane Mataraza, a national expert in the field, is conducting the project.

Mataraza is planning meetings with as many groups and individuals as possible. She has already met with more than 200 people in York and hopes to reach more than a thousand, either in person or with surveys.

"Our plan must be informed by as many people as possible in order for it to be effective," said Mataraza. "We want to hear from you."

A survey will be live the week of Nov. 19 through the beginning of January. It will be available on the Cultural Alliance's Web site www.culturalalliance-york.org, as is other Community Cultural Planning information.

A Steering Committee of 60 people has been assembled. These members are charged with introducing Mataraza to their sector.

The Cultural Alliance is a united arts fundraising organization that has raised nearly $8.5 million in cash and in-kind donations in the past nine campaigns. 2009 marks its 10th anniversary.

For more information, call the Cultural Alliance at 812-9255.
YORK COLLEGE
Talk on citizenship
York College professor and author Gerry Patnode will discuss his books on strategic citizenship and civic engagement as well as the upcoming presidential election at an event beginning at 6:30 p.m. Tuesday event. Activities will begin at 6:30 p.m. in DeMeester Recital Hall in Evelyn and Earle Wolf Hall. The event is open to the public free of charge, and signed copies of Patnode's book on strategic citizenship will be available for purchase.

After his remarks, Patnode will announce the results of a mock election, which was conducted through a web-poll taken by 800 first-year students in Information Literary courses offered by Schmidt Library. Students were asked to vote for one of four candidates: Democrat Barack Obama, Republican John McCain, Independent Ralph Nader or Libertarian Robert Barr.
YORK
Watershed event
The Watershed Alliance of York is hosting the Sixth Annual Watershed Weekend Saturday and Sunday, Sept. 27 and 28. The event is being celebrated at 22 venues before, during and after the last weekend of September.

Participants will meet the people and organizations working to restore and protect local communities, economies and the environment. Venues include hands-on environmental conservation, education and stewardship activities in York County, Lower Susquehanna River, and Chesapeake Bay Watersheds.

For more information about how you can get involved, including venue descriptions, directions, and maps, visit www.watershedsyork.org. The Watershed Alliance of York (WAY) is a coalition of stakeholders committed to encouraging watershed-based planning, restoration and protection, through locally led initiatives, in York County and beyond.
BRUNNER ISLAND
Area cleanup
The public can help restore the natural beauty of the environment by working with volunteers from PPL's Brunner Island power plant and the Watershed Alliance of York at the annual Watershed Weekend on Saturday, Sept. 27.

This year's cleanup will take place from 9 a.m. to noon at the Hibiscus Natural Area. Volunteers are needed. Participants will help remove debris around the Hibiscus Pond area.

Everyone interested in helping should meet at 9 a.m. at the Conewago Boat Launch Area on Wago Road at the north end of Brunner Island.

Participants should dress for the weather. Trash bags and gloves will be provided. For more information, contact Karen Ament at 717-284-6274 or kament@pplweb.com


LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



208 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


September 19, 2008 Friday


Obama ad about McCain's education votes not quite right


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 853 words


Anew Obama-Biden ad includes misleading claims about McCain and education spending, according to FactCheck.org:

---It says McCain "voted to cut education funding" and lists five votes. But one was a vote for increased education funding, although for fewer dollars than what Democrats may have wanted. And three others were votes against additional funding, not votes for funding cuts.

---The ad says that "McCain's economic plan gives $200 billion more to special interests while taking money away from public schools." Not exactly. McCain has proposed a one-year freeze on discretionary spending in general. A freeze would mean that funds would not keep pace with inflation and population growth, but no dollars would be "taken away." The $200 billion for "special interests" refers to the cost of McCain's proposal to reduce the tax rate for all business corporations, not just a few "special" ones.

Analysis: On Sept. 9, Obama gave a speech on education in Ohio, and his campaign released a new attack ad.

The Obama ad says that McCain "voted to cut education funding" and lists five Senate votes. But only one of the five meets that description, and even then, the vote requires further explanation.

In 1995, McCain voted for a Republican budget resolution for fiscal year 1996 that would have reduced education spending from the previous year. But education was not the only budget item targeted. The resolution was actually one in a series of appropriations bills for departments ranging from Health and Human Services to the Department of Energy, and in each measure, the Newt Gingrich-led Republicans tried to reduce funding from the previous year's level. President Bill Clinton refused to sign any of the measures, and the government was shut down for a time.

Besides that vote to actually cut funding, the ad lists three votes against increased funding for the Department of Education. In the past, we've criticized Republicans for falsely attacking Obama on voting for tax increases when he actually voted against tax cuts. Obama's ad applies the same faulty logic. Voting against an increase is notably different from voting for a funding cut.

Those three votes were:

---A vote McCain cast against an amendment to the 2006 budget resolution to increase discretionary education funding by $500 million. It passed anyway, and McCain voted for the final bill.

---A vote against an amendment to the 2001 budget resolution that would have repealed tax cuts worth $250 billion in order to increase education funding. It passed anyway, and, again McCain voted for the final bill.

---A vote against an amendment in 2001 to add $250 million to Title I funding for struggling schools. The measure failed.

---Finally, the Obama campaign points to McCain's vote in 2000 for the next year's education appropriations bill, saying in their ad backup that it "underfunded" the department. But that legislation, which was signed into law by President Clinton, was a spending increase from the previous year.

Special interests: The ad also says, "John McCain's economic plan gives $200 billion more to special interests while taking money away from public schools." But that's misleading.

To start, McCain's plan doesn't include any specific cuts to education programs and funding. Rather, he has proposed an across-the-board "freeze [of] non-defense, non-veterans discretionary spending for a year." So education grants, as well as all sorts of other government programs like farm subsidies and NASA projects, would not receive their annual funding increase for one year. Some would argue that a freeze is actually a cut when you factor in the effect of inflation. And others would go further and say it's a cut if the money had been projected by an earlier budget.

Indeed, the Obama campaign provided us with an analysis done by the Tennessee affiliate of the National Education Association that demonstrated the difference in funding between a freeze and the anticipated increase from the previous year's budget. To the NEA Tennessee branch, a freeze is a cut. But even if one agrees with that, McCain's proposal to freeze the entire discretionary budget is different from a proposal to specifically "take money away from public schools," as the ad says. No dollars are being "taken away."

The "$200 billion to special interests" line is actually a new version of an old attack. It refers to the total cost, over five years, of McCain's proposal to lower the corporate tax rate. The Tax Policy Center's analysis of McCain's plan estimates a $200 billion loss of revenue over the next five years. We've criticized the Obama campaign previously for unfairly implying that McCain's plan would give tax breaks targeted to "oil companies." In this case, the campaign calls a change in taxes on all businesses a giveaway to "special interests." But the corporate tax rate is paid by any incorporated entity, a group that includes restaurant owners, garage mechanics and other small businesses that we suspect few would call a "special interest."

FactCheck.org is a project of the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Penn sylvania.


LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



209 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 18, 2008 Thursday


Obama Ad Spotlights Economy;
Points To State College Factory Closing; Rendell Weighs In


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: B; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 459 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Democratic presidential nominee Sen. Barack Obama released a national television ad Tuesday highlighting a Pennsylvania factory that closed four years ago and blaming tax policies embraced by his opponent, Republican Sen. John McCain, for the job losses.

The factory - Corning Inc.'s former State College plant, which manufactured glass television tubes - shut its doors in 2004, leaving 1,000 people without jobs. The workers were then hired to disassemble the plant and ship the equipment to China, according to the ad.

"Washington sold them out with the help of people like John McCain," the narrator says, referencing McCain's support for legislation that Democrats say leads to companies shipping jobs overseas.

The McCain campaign fired back.

"John McCain sees job losses as a crisis that demands leadership, but it's clear that Barack Obama sees them as an opportunity to launch political distortions," said Paul Lindsay, an Ohio-Pennsylvania spokesman for McCain.

The Republican National Committee also released a statement.

"In lieu of accomplishments or any real record of reform, Barack Obama is choosing gutter politics to attack John McCain," GOP spokesman Blair Latoff said. "Pennsylvanians have already seen Barack Obama's thin record and false attacks, and just as they did this spring, they're eager to tell him 'Thanks but no thanks.' "

The Obama camp appears to be stepping up its attacks on McCain's record with the economy as the nation reacts to the recent troubles of several financial giants, including Merrill Lynch.

Polls have consistently shown the economy is the top concern among registered voters in Pennsylvania and that a majority of those who worry about the economy are more likely to vote for Obama.

Nonetheless, McCain and Obama are in a statistical tie in recent Pennsylvania surveys.

During a conference call with reporters Wednesday, Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell launched several sharply worded criticisms of McCain.

Rendell cited votes McCain cast in the Senate - three since 1995 - supporting tax breaks for companies that "ship jobs overseas."

"McCain continues to support tax breaks that are at the heart of what's wrong with the American economy," Rendell said.

The McCain campaign also released a television ad Tuesday after the collapse of investment firm Lehman Brothers, the emergency buyout of investment firm Merrill Lynch and the federal bailout of insurance giant AIG.

"You, the American workers, are the best in the world," McCain says into the camera. "But your economic security has been put at risk by the greed of Wall Street. That's unacceptable. My opponent's only solutions are talk and taxes. I'll reform Wall Street and fix Washington. I've taken on tougher guys than this before."

E-mail: dpidgeon@lnpnews.com


LOAD-DATE: September 18, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



210 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 18, 2008 Thursday


Obama Ad Spotlights Economy;
Points To State College Factory Closing; Rendell Weighs In


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: B; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 459 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Democratic presidential nominee Sen. Barack Obama released a national television ad Tuesday highlighting a Pennsylvania factory that closed four years ago and blaming tax policies embraced by his opponent, Republican Sen. John McCain, for the job losses.

The factory - Corning Inc.'s former State College plant, which manufactured glass television tubes - shut its doors in 2004, leaving 1,000 people without jobs. The workers were then hired to disassemble the plant and ship the equipment to China, according to the ad.

"Washington sold them out with the help of people like John McCain," the narrator says, referencing McCain's support for legislation that Democrats say leads to companies shipping jobs overseas.

The McCain campaign fired back.

"John McCain sees job losses as a crisis that demands leadership, but it's clear that Barack Obama sees them as an opportunity to launch political distortions," said Paul Lindsay, an Ohio-Pennsylvania spokesman for McCain.

The Republican National Committee also released a statement.

"In lieu of accomplishments or any real record of reform, Barack Obama is choosing gutter politics to attack John McCain," GOP spokesman Blair Latoff said. "Pennsylvanians have already seen Barack Obama's thin record and false attacks, and just as they did this spring, they're eager to tell him 'Thanks but no thanks.' "

The Obama camp appears to be stepping up its attacks on McCain's record with the economy as the nation reacts to the recent troubles of several financial giants, including Merrill Lynch.

Polls have consistently shown the economy is the top concern among registered voters in Pennsylvania and that a majority of those who worry about the economy are more likely to vote for Obama.

Nonetheless, McCain and Obama are in a statistical tie in recent Pennsylvania surveys.

During a conference call with reporters Wednesday, Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell launched several sharply worded criticisms of McCain.

Rendell cited votes McCain cast in the Senate - three since 1995 - supporting tax breaks for companies that "ship jobs overseas."

"McCain continues to support tax breaks that are at the heart of what's wrong with the American economy," Rendell said.

The McCain campaign also released a television ad Tuesday after the collapse of investment firm Lehman Brothers, the emergency buyout of investment firm Merrill Lynch and the federal bailout of insurance giant AIG.

"You, the American workers, are the best in the world," McCain says into the camera. "But your economic security has been put at risk by the greed of Wall Street. That's unacceptable. My opponent's only solutions are talk and taxes. I'll reform Wall Street and fix Washington. I've taken on tougher guys than this before."

211 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 18, 2008 Thursday
SOONER EDITION


MCCAIN REVERSES STANCE, ENDORSES BAILOUT OF AIG;
BOTH PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES WANT INSURER'S POLICYHOLDERS PROTECTED


BYLINE: NOAM N. LEVEY AND JOHANNA NEUMAN, LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-6


LENGTH: 808 words


DATELINE: LAKE ORION, Mich.


A day after he dismissed a federal bailout for American International Group Inc., Republican presidential nominee John McCain yesterday announced that circumstances had forced him to shift his position, and that he supported the proposed $85 billion rescue of the insurance giant.

The Arizona senator, who in recent days has slammed what he called Wall Street greed and corruption for causing the latest stock market downward spiral, said he had to change his position on AIG to protect millions of Americans who could be hurt if the company were forced to seek bankruptcy protection.

"The government was forced to commit $85 billion," Mr. McCain said in a statement. "These actions stem from failed regulation, reckless management and a casino culture on Wall Street that has crippled one of the most important companies in America.

"The focus of any such action should be to protect the millions of Americans who hold insurance policies, retirement plans and other accounts with AIG," he said. "We must not bail out the management and speculators who created this mess."

In a campaign stop in Elko, Nev., Mr. McCain's Democratic rival, Barack Obama, also insisted that any federal action must not bail out AIG shareholders and management. He also said the week's economic news was troubling, but insisted that most people already knew the economy was in difficulty. Then the Illinois senator attacked Mr. McCain, emphasizing themes that Democrats have consistently put forward.

"It's been an interesting week for John McCain. It's been really interesting to watch him respond to this economic news," Mr. Obama said. "His first reaction to this crisis on Monday was to stand up and repeat the line he's said over and over and over again throughout this campaign -- quote -- 'the fundamentals of our economy are strong.'

"Now, his campaign must've realized that probably wasn't a smart thing to say on the day of a financial meltdown, so they sent him back out a few hours later to clean up his remarks.

"But it sounds like he got a little carried away because yesterday John McCain actually said that if he's president, he'll take on the -- quote -- 'old boys network' in Washington. I am not making this up.

"This is someone who's been in Congress for 26 years, who put seven of the most powerful Washington lobbyists in charge of his campaign, and now he tells us that he's the one who will take on the old boy network," the Democrat said. "The old boy network? In the McCain campaign, that's called a staff meeting."

All week, the economy has reasserted itself as the top campaign issue. The growing federal role in trying to save the financial sector during a fiercely fought presidential election has both candidates calling for regulatory reform to prevent more capital markets mayhem.

Both have upped their populist rhetoric, insisting to voters that their rival lacks the leadership to make substantial changes. But the financial tailspin represents a special problem for Mr. McCain and Republicans, who generally favor open, unregulated markets and generally oppose federal loan guarantees and bailouts.

During a spate of morning television interviews Tuesday, the Arizona senator opposed the idea of an AIG bailout. "We cannot have the taxpayers bail out AIG or anybody else," he said on NBC's "Today" show.

But the McCain campaign was forced to reconsider, said senior advisor Matt McDonald, who yesterday toured a General Motors auto plant in Michigan with the senator. "He doesn't like what happened, but his priority is working Americans who could be impacted," the advisor said of Mr. McCain. "They're the ones who have to be protected."

Mr. McCain visited the GM plant in Lake Orion, where 4,200 people and 600 robots produce Chevrolet Malibus and the Pontiac G6. "We're not going to leave the workers here in Michigan hung out to dry while we give billions in taxpayers' dollars to Wall Street," Mr. McCain insisted. "We're going to take care of the workers, the workers. They are the ones who deserve our help. It's time to get our auto industry back on its feet."

Campaigning in Cleveland, Mr. McCain's running mate, Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, expressed disappointment that the federal government needed to inject tax money into yet another financial institution.

Meanwhile, the Obama campaign released a two-minute ad on the economy. In the ad, Mr. Obama talks about his ideas for reforming the economy.

He calls for a $1,000 tax break to the middle class, "instead of showering more on oil companies and corporations that outsource our jobs." He pledges "real regulation that protects your investments and pensions," energy independence, an end to the war in Iraq and a crackdown on lobbyists "once and for all, so their backroom deal-making no longer drowns out the voices of the middle class and undermines our common interests as Americans."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

212 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 18, 2008 Thursday
SOONER EDITION


DEMOCRATS PUSHING PAY EQUITY TO SECURE VOTES AMONG WOMEN


BYLINE: MACKENZIE CARPENTER, PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-6


LENGTH: 1037 words


Donna Cole is a small businesswoman, owner of a diner in Shaler and a passionate Hillary Rodham Clinton supporter who, she likes to say, "broke through the glass ceiling all by myself."

But bring up the issue of pay equity, and suddenly the 51-year-old owner of the Cole Cafe -- who is still undecided about who she will vote for in November -- looks like a stumped contestant on "Jeopardy."

"I'm not familiar with that term," she said politely during an interview, before wheeling around and asking eight women -- waitresses and customers: "Have you girls ever heard of something called pay equity?" In unison, the women shook their heads.

Of course, framed differently -- equal pay for women and men doing equal work -- pay equity suddenly becomes an issue most women understand, and Sen. Barack Obama's Democratic presidential campaign is hoping it may also sway votes.

This week, pay equity is being showcased as a centerpiece issue in the campaign's much-ballyhooed "Women for the Change We Need Week of Action."

On Tuesday, the campaign aired an ad about the issue in key battleground states, including Pennsylvania, along with a radio spot and an Internet ad on sites frequented by women.

Last night, Delaware Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, and Mrs. Clinton, the New York senator, talked about pay equity in an online video chat. Meanwhile, Michelle Obama and Jill Biden stumped on the campaign trail with Lilly Ledbetter, the plaintiff in a lawsuit that ended when the U.S. Supreme Court issued a ruling last year making it more difficult for women to sue for pay discrimination.

Most of all, Mr. Obama and his surrogates have been lambasting Sen. John McCain for his opposition to a Senate bill that would have reversed the high court's decision.

But does the issue of pay equity have traction with the one group of voters who matter most -- undecided women?

Certainly, among unmarried female voters, the answer is yes, according to Anna Greenberg of Greenberg Quinlan Rosner, a Washington, D.C., polling and research firm.

"Pay equity has tested very well with unmarried women," who live from paycheck to paycheck, said Ms. Greenberg. "Of course you have to explain it simply, as equal pay for equal work, and it has to be framed as part of a larger attack on John McCain's economic policies and how they negatively impact women."

Mr. McCain has said the Senate bill, which extends the statute of limitations on when suits can be filed, would lead to more unnecessary lawsuits clogging the legal system.

His campaign also struck back with a news release this week claiming that Mr. Obama's female Senate staffers held fewer senior positions than men did and, as a result, were paid on average $9,000 a year less than men on the staff. In Mr. McCain's office, more women held senior positions and, on average, were paid $2,000 more than men, the campaign said.

"How do these candidates actually behave when it comes to equal pay for equal work?" asked Carly Fiorina, former CEO of Hewlett-Packard, in an interview Tuesday -- shortly before she was temporarily benched by the McCain campaign for saying that none of the candidates were ready to run a major corporation.

Allison Price, a spokeswoman for the Obama campaign, called the McCain salvo "dishonest" and noted that it "doesn't change the fact that even in 2008, John McCain still opposes requiring that women be paid the same as men who do the same jobs."

Ms. Fiorina noted that Mr. McCain has a strong record supporting women's equality. He supported the U.S. Glass Ceiling Commission, a 1990s-era federal panel that studied the barriers to female advancement within corporate hierarchies, and fought to eliminate a 43-year ban against women flying combat missions, she said.

She also cited economists who have noted that factors such as schooling, work experience and a preference for part-time work when caring for young children contribute to the pay gap -- not discrimination.

"If most women work in secretarial jobs and men in managerial [positions], women are going to be paid less than men," she said.

It isn't quite that simple, contended Chris Briem, an economist at the University of Pittsburgh's Center for Social and Urban Research.

"Is there still occupational segregation in the workplace? It's better than it's been in the past, but if you look at income strata at the very low end, it's very much women-dominated, and you have to question what's causing that," he said.

"Clearly, women moving in and out of the labor force will see an impact on their future earnings, but is that the only explanation for this disparity? I don't think so."

Still, the existing law's six-month statute of limitations is ample time for a female employee to seek legal redress for paycheck discrimination, Ms. Fiorina said.

That's ridiculous, countered Arizona Gov. Janet Napolitano, noting that Ms. Ledbetter didn't discover that she'd been underpaid in comparison to her male colleagues until six months before she retired -- and 19 years after the discrimination began.

"Most women don't find out about this right away," she told a group of Obama volunteers gathered Sunday at Chatham University. "Most employers don't post salaries, or send out e-mails, so how is it reasonable to expect they will find out within six months? We want to make sure that the statute of limitations in this law isn't used to close the courthouse door."

It was this line that got the biggest round of applause from Obama supporters during Ms. Napolitano's appearance -- but it's not clear if that will translate into votes on that issue alone.

"Oh, wow," said Barbara Pecoraro, a 40-year-old sales representative from Dormont. "The problem with that whole equal pay thing is that there are a lot variables. You can mask a lot of things a lot of different kind of ways. It really is a subjective thing."

Ms. Pecoraro says she will vote for Mr. Obama, but Ms. Cole still wasn't sure.

"I don't know if equal pay would be the determining factor," Ms. Cole said. "I was loyal to Hillary, but now I'm still not sure who I'm going to vote for. A candidate's position on something like this would give me reason to pause and think, but it still wouldn't push me over the edge."


LOAD-DATE: September 18, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Mackenzie Carpenter can be reached at mcarpenter@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1949.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
