244 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Appalled By Mccain Commercials


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 212 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


TO THE EDITOR:

I am writing as a lifelong Republican and Vietnam veteran. I have followed both campaigns and their policies and have been utterly appalled at the outright lies of the McCain ads. Even the Washington Post (Aug. 31) on its editorial page titled one piece: "Mr. McCain's ads on taxes are just plain false."

The candidates have widely differing views on taxes as one would expect. But here are the facts. They quote the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center in pointing out the following: Obama, tax breaks for the bottom fifth, $567 per year; McCain, $21. For the middle fifth, Obama $1,118; McCain, $325.

While McCain firmly stands behind the present tax breaks for oil companies, Obama does not in light of their mind-boggling profits and proposes distributing the savings to taxpayers. McCain firmly stands for present tax breaks for corporations and the wealthiest Americans; Obama proposes to eliminate them for the companies who ship jobs overseas and increasing taxes only on the wealthiest of Americans.

I find it pathetic that John McCain, a man formerly known for integrity and honesty, would support such outright lies. He must assume Americans are uninformed idiots for whom the Big Lie is sufficient. Is this the man we want for president?

Paul H. Wragg, Denver


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



245 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Rendell Says Gop 'Lies';
Presidential Candidates' Camps Clash Over Tax Plans


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 593 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Gov. Ed Rendell Monday summed up John McCain's campaign and the Republican National Convention last week with three words: "The Big Lie."

Making his first remarks here since the GOP convention, Rendell convened a news conference Monday afternoon on the grass-and-concrete patio in front of Franklin & Marshall College's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center, 24 hours before McCain and his running mate, Sarah Palin, were scheduled to appear for a rally.

Rendell, laughing during a lighthearted moment, called on the McCain campaign to suspend by Wednesday all ads he says are mischaracterizing Democratic presidential nominee Barack Obama by indicating he plans to raise taxes on all Americans.

"What is going on is a deliberate campaign: I call it 'The Big Lie,' " Rendell said. "Speaker after speaker after speaker created the impression in the American people's minds that Barack Obama was going to raise their taxes. Television ad after television ad, you can't hear a television ad without hearing Barack Obama's going to raise taxes."

Republicans immediately shot back Monday evening.

"I don't hear many things he doesn't want to raise taxes on," said state Republican Party spokesman Michael Barley.

Rendell - surrounded by Lancaster city officials, including Mayor Rick Gray, local Obama supporters and former U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford - focused his attack on what he said are "lies" perpetuated by Republicans, including McCain and Palin, about Obama's tax plans.

He even penned a letter that Abe Amoros, political and communications director for the state Democratic Party, will try to hand-deliver to McCain during the F&M event. The letter outlines Obama's and McCain's tax plans, then says: "I hope that you will stop misleading the American public about Barack Obama's tax plan."

According to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center in Washington, D.C., people earning $66,354 or less (about 60 percent of income earners) will see tax reductions if either of the candidates' plans are adopted, but the reductions are between three and 19 times deeper in Obama's proposals than McCain's.

Those making between $37,596 and $66,354 would receive a $1,042 tax cut under Obama's plan or a $319 cut in McCain's plan. The margins grow wider the lower the annual income.

Rendell also pointed to Obama's plans to eliminate federal income taxes for working seniors earning $50,000 or less and proposed tax cuts on mortgage rates and college tuition.

Obama, though, would raise taxes on capital gains, income and dividends if a person or business is making more than $250,000 from those sources of income, but the rates would be the same as those during the 1990s, according to Rendell.

"He's raising taxes on the very wealthy, and he's cutting taxes for the middle class," Rendell said.

McCain's tax plan calls for tax cuts in all income brackets. The deepest cuts would go to the top earners - those making $160,973 and more - who would see at least a 3 percent reduction in income taxes.

While Rendell accused McCain of pandering to wealthy earners and rich corporations, Barley said that's a tired argument frequently used by Democrats.

"The rich people pay a larger amount of taxes," Barley said. "The wealthier people are also the people who help to provide jobs. They help the economy. They are typically the ones who do a lot of purchasing. I understand that's a favorite argument of Democrats, but you have to look and say that John McCain, at the end of the day, is going to leave more in your paycheck than Barack Obama. There's no doubt about it."

E-mail: dpidgeon@lnpnews.com


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Gov. Ed Rendell Discusses Republican Presidential Candidate Sen. John Mccain During A News Conference Monday Outside F&M's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center, Where Mccain Is Scheduled To Speak Today. Suzette Wenger
Gov. Ed Rendell Campaigns For Sen. Barack Obama Monday Afternoon At Franklin & Marshall College. Listening, From Left, Are Lancaster City Mayor Rick Gray, Former U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford And City Councilman Jose Urdaneta, Who Is Running For State Senate. Suzette Wenger


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



246 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Appalled By Mccain Commercials


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 212 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


TO THE EDITOR:

I am writing as a lifelong Republican and Vietnam veteran. I have followed both campaigns and their policies and have been utterly appalled at the outright lies of the McCain ads. Even the Washington Post (Aug. 31) on its editorial page titled one piece: "Mr. McCain's ads on taxes are just plain false."

The candidates have widely differing views on taxes as one would expect. But here are the facts. They quote the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center in pointing out the following: Obama, tax breaks for the bottom fifth, $567 per year; McCain, $21. For the middle fifth, Obama $1,118; McCain, $325.

While McCain firmly stands behind the present tax breaks for oil companies, Obama does not in light of their mind-boggling profits and proposes distributing the savings to taxpayers. McCain firmly stands for present tax breaks for corporations and the wealthiest Americans; Obama proposes to eliminate them for the companies who ship jobs overseas and increasing taxes only on the wealthiest of Americans.

I find it pathetic that John McCain, a man formerly known for integrity and honesty, would support such outright lies. He must assume Americans are uninformed idiots for whom the Big Lie is sufficient. Is this the man we want for president?

Paul H. Wragg, Denver


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



247 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Rendell Says Gop 'Lies';
Presidential Candidates' Camps Clash Over Tax Plans


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 593 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Gov. Ed Rendell Monday summed up John McCain's campaign and the Republican National Convention last week with three words: "The Big Lie."

Making his first remarks here since the GOP convention, Rendell convened a news conference Monday afternoon on the grass-and-concrete patio in front of Franklin & Marshall College's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center, 24 hours before McCain and his running mate, Sarah Palin, were scheduled to appear for a rally.

Rendell, laughing during a lighthearted moment, called on the McCain campaign to suspend by Wednesday all ads he says are mischaracterizing Democratic presidential nominee Barack Obama by indicating he plans to raise taxes on all Americans.

"What is going on is a deliberate campaign: I call it 'The Big Lie,' " Rendell said. "Speaker after speaker after speaker created the impression in the American people's minds that Barack Obama was going to raise their taxes. Television ad after television ad, you can't hear a television ad without hearing Barack Obama's going to raise taxes."

Republicans immediately shot back Monday evening.

"I don't hear many things he doesn't want to raise taxes on," said state Republican Party spokesman Michael Barley.

Rendell - surrounded by Lancaster city officials, including Mayor Rick Gray, local Obama supporters and former U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford - focused his attack on what he said are "lies" perpetuated by Republicans, including McCain and Palin, about Obama's tax plans.

He even penned a letter that Abe Amoros, political and communications director for the state Democratic Party, will try to hand-deliver to McCain during the F&M event. The letter outlines Obama's and McCain's tax plans, then says: "I hope that you will stop misleading the American public about Barack Obama's tax plan."

According to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center in Washington, D.C., people earning $66,354 or less (about 60 percent of income earners) will see tax reductions if either of the candidates' plans are adopted, but the reductions are between three and 19 times deeper in Obama's proposals than McCain's.

Those making between $37,596 and $66,354 would receive a $1,042 tax cut under Obama's plan or a $319 cut in McCain's plan. The margins grow wider the lower the annual income.

Rendell also pointed to Obama's plans to eliminate federal income taxes for working seniors earning $50,000 or less and proposed tax cuts on mortgage rates and college tuition.

Obama, though, would raise taxes on capital gains, income and dividends if a person or business is making more than $250,000 from those sources of income, but the rates would be the same as those during the 1990s, according to Rendell.

"He's raising taxes on the very wealthy, and he's cutting taxes for the middle class," Rendell said.

McCain's tax plan calls for tax cuts in all income brackets. The deepest cuts would go to the top earners - those making $160,973 and more - who would see at least a 3 percent reduction in income taxes.

While Rendell accused McCain of pandering to wealthy earners and rich corporations, Barley said that's a tired argument frequently used by Democrats.

"The rich people pay a larger amount of taxes," Barley said. "The wealthier people are also the people who help to provide jobs. They help the economy. They are typically the ones who do a lot of purchasing. I understand that's a favorite argument of Democrats, but you have to look and say that John McCain, at the end of the day, is going to leave more in your paycheck than Barack Obama. There's no doubt about it."

E-mail: dpidgeon@lnpnews.com


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Gov. Ed Rendell Discusses Republican Presidential Candidate Sen. John Mccain During A News Conference Monday Outside F&M's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center, Where Mccain Is Scheduled To Speak Today. Suzette Wenger
Gov. Ed Rendell Campaigns For Sen. Barack Obama Monday Afternoon At Franklin & Marshall College. Listening, From Left, Are Lancaster City Mayor Rick Gray, Former U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford And City Councilman Jose Urdaneta, Who Is Running For State Senate. Suzette Wenger


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



248 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Ready To Rally;
Mccain, Palin Headed Here To Talk Up Reform And Talk Down Obama.


BYLINE: Tom Murse


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 871 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Republicans John McCain and Sarah Palin, on their way to Lancaster for an afternoon rally today, will portray themselves here as reformers who will "drain the Washington swamp" and fight special interests, aides and recent appearances suggest.

The GOP presidential nominee will renew his emphasis on his reputation as a maverick and call for more offshore drilling and support for nuclear power.

Arriving here just five days after winning his party's nomination, McCain is expected to criticize Democratic opponent Barack Obama's position on the surge strategy in Iraq - another staple of his stump speech.

Running mate Palin, meantime, has launched a new line of attack on Obama and his use of congressional earmarks, money for projects that lawmakers try to get for their home districts and constituents - a theme she is likely to repeat here.

"Just the other day our opponent brought up earmarks - and frankly I was surprised that he would even raise the subject at all," Palin said at a rally Monday in Missouri. "I thought he wouldn't want to go there."

Local Republicans expect a capacity crowd - 6,500 to 7,000 supporters - to greet McCain and Palin in their first post-convention visit to Pennsylvania and Lancaster County.

The U.S. senator from Arizona and his surprise pick for vice president, the governor of Alaska, were to speak at a 3:30 p.m. rally at Franklin & Marshall College's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center.

"The excitement surrounding this visit is proof of the enthusiasm for the McCain-Palin ticket among voters in Central Pennsylvania," said McCain spokesman Paul Lindsay.

"These are two mavericks who have a record of reform that they will bring to Washington in order to get our economy moving again and put government on the side of the people."

McCain and Palin were expected to fly into Lancaster Airport at 1:30 p.m. aboard the presidential nominee's campaign plane, "Straight Talk Air." They were speaking before some 5,000 supporters at a rally in Lebanon, Ohio, late this morning.

"What we're going to do, what we have to do is take our message of reform - because Washington desperately needs reform - all across this nation to everyone in every party or no party at all," Palin said.

"We are committed to that reform. That's what John McCain, that's what I am all about. It's going to be small-town America getting us to where we need to get that reform," Palin said. "It's with your help and with your vote we're going to Washington, and we're going to shake things up."

"John McCain doesn't walk with the Washington herd," she said.

Palin also talked at length about spending cuts she made as Alaska's governor, and how she took on the state's "good-old-boys network." She also repeated her criticism of Obama for trying to win congressional earmarks.

"So as we reformed the abuses of earmarks in our state, our opponent was requesting nearly $1 billion in earmarks," she said.

Obama hasn't asked for any earmarks this year. Last year, he asked for $311 million worth, about $25 for every Illinois resident. Alaska asked this year for earmarks totaling $198 million, about $295 for every Alaska citizen.

Palin has cut back on pork project requests. But, under her administration, Alaska is still by far the largest per-capita consumer of federal pet-project spending, according to news reports. The governor did reject plans to build the notorious "Bridge to Nowhere" after Congress had cut off its financing.

Palin said in Ohio that "I told Congress thanks but no thanks for that Bridge to Nowhere in Alaska."

McCain, speaking after Palin this morning, said, "I can't wait to introduce her to Washington, D.C., and the big spenders ... she'll take 'em on like she did in Alaska.

"Change is coming, and real change is coming to Washington, D.C.," McCain said. "You've got a team of mavericks."

As McCain and Palin make their way to the college, a group of community organizers from across the state was expected to gather outside the field house and criticize the GOP's attempts to minimize their work.

The group, led by former Green Party gubernatorial candidate Michael Morrill, will try to deliver a petition to the Republicans calling on them to "stop their attacks on their chosen career," according to a statement, and asking for an apology for "the demeaning attacks on the important work that we do to strengthen our communities and our great nation."

Several Republicans, speaking at the party's convention last week, ridiculed Barack Obama's work as a community organizer in Chicago two decades ago.

Democratic state Rep. Mike Sturla, of Lancaster, and other local Democrats held their own news conference late this morning to criticize the GOP ticket, just as Gov. Ed Rendell, city Mayor Rick Gray and U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford did here on Monday afternoon.

Rendell focused his attack on what he said are "lies" perpetuated by Republicans, including McCain and Palin, about Obama's tax plans.

"Speaker after speaker after speaker (at the Republican National Convention) created the impression in the American people's minds that Barack Obama was going to raise their taxes. Television ad after television ad, you can't hear a television ad without hearing Barack Obama's going to raise taxes," Rendell said.


LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Lancaster Newspapers Democratic Gov. Ed Rendell Speaks At A News Conference At Franklin & Marshall College On Monday. Suzette Wenger
Workers Prepare For The 6,500 People Who Will Flood Franklin & Marshall College For John Mccain's And Sarah Palin's Rally Today. Marty Heisey
The Republican Nominees Sarah Palin And John Mccain Speak At A Recent Campaign Rally.
Live Blog Of Mccain Visit Staff Writer Tom Murse Will Provide Up-To-The-Minute Coverage From Sen. John Mccain's Stop At F&M On His Blog, "Capitol Punmanship." Blogs.Lancasteronline.Com TODAY


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



249 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday


Ready To Rally;
Mccain, Palin Headed Here To Talk Up Reform And Talk Down Obama.


BYLINE: Tom Murse


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 871 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Republicans John McCain and Sarah Palin, on their way to Lancaster for an afternoon rally today, will portray themselves here as reformers who will "drain the Washington swamp" and fight special interests, aides and recent appearances suggest.

The GOP presidential nominee will renew his emphasis on his reputation as a maverick and call for more offshore drilling and support for nuclear power.

Arriving here just five days after winning his party's nomination, McCain is expected to criticize Democratic opponent Barack Obama's position on the surge strategy in Iraq - another staple of his stump speech.

Running mate Palin, meantime, has launched a new line of attack on Obama and his use of congressional earmarks, money for projects that lawmakers try to get for their home districts and constituents - a theme she is likely to repeat here.

"Just the other day our opponent brought up earmarks - and frankly I was surprised that he would even raise the subject at all," Palin said at a rally Monday in Missouri. "I thought he wouldn't want to go there."

Local Republicans expect a capacity crowd - 6,500 to 7,000 supporters - to greet McCain and Palin in their first post-convention visit to Pennsylvania and Lancaster County.

The U.S. senator from Arizona and his surprise pick for vice president, the governor of Alaska, were to speak at a 3:30 p.m. rally at Franklin & Marshall College's Alumni Sports & Fitness Center.

"The excitement surrounding this visit is proof of the enthusiasm for the McCain-Palin ticket among voters in Central Pennsylvania," said McCain spokesman Paul Lindsay.

"These are two mavericks who have a record of reform that they will bring to Washington in order to get our economy moving again and put government on the side of the people."

McCain and Palin were expected to fly into Lancaster Airport at 1:30 p.m. aboard the presidential nominee's campaign plane, "Straight Talk Air." They were speaking before some 5,000 supporters at a rally in Lebanon, Ohio, late this morning.

"What we're going to do, what we have to do is take our message of reform - because Washington desperately needs reform - all across this nation to everyone in every party or no party at all," Palin said.

"We are committed to that reform. That's what John McCain, that's what I am all about. It's going to be small-town America getting us to where we need to get that reform," Palin said. "It's with your help and with your vote we're going to Washington, and we're going to shake things up."

"John McCain doesn't walk with the Washington herd," she said.

Palin also talked at length about spending cuts she made as Alaska's governor, and how she took on the state's "good-old-boys network." She also repeated her criticism of Obama for trying to win congressional earmarks.

"So as we reformed the abuses of earmarks in our state, our opponent was requesting nearly $1 billion in earmarks," she said.

Obama hasn't asked for any earmarks this year. Last year, he asked for $311 million worth, about $25 for every Illinois resident. Alaska asked this year for earmarks totaling $198 million, about $295 for every Alaska citizen.

Palin has cut back on pork project requests. But, under her administration, Alaska is still by far the largest per-capita consumer of federal pet-project spending, according to news reports. The governor did reject plans to build the notorious "Bridge to Nowhere" after Congress had cut off its financing.

Palin said in Ohio that "I told Congress thanks but no thanks for that Bridge to Nowhere in Alaska."

McCain, speaking after Palin this morning, said, "I can't wait to introduce her to Washington, D.C., and the big spenders ... she'll take 'em on like she did in Alaska.

"Change is coming, and real change is coming to Washington, D.C.," McCain said. "You've got a team of mavericks."

As McCain and Palin make their way to the college, a group of community organizers from across the state was expected to gather outside the field house and criticize the GOP's attempts to minimize their work.

The group, led by former Green Party gubernatorial candidate Michael Morrill, will try to deliver a petition to the Republicans calling on them to "stop their attacks on their chosen career," according to a statement, and asking for an apology for "the demeaning attacks on the important work that we do to strengthen our communities and our great nation."

Several Republicans, speaking at the party's convention last week, ridiculed Barack Obama's work as a community organizer in Chicago two decades ago.

Democratic state Rep. Mike Sturla, of Lancaster, and other local Democrats held their own news conference late this morning to criticize the GOP ticket, just as Gov. Ed Rendell, city Mayor Rick Gray and U.S. Sen. Harris Wofford did here on Monday afternoon.

Rendell focused his attack on what he said are "lies" perpetuated by Republicans, including McCain and Palin, about Obama's tax plans.

"Speaker after speaker after speaker (at the Republican National Convention) created the impression in the American people's minds that Barack Obama was going to raise their taxes. Television ad after television ad, you can't hear a television ad without hearing Barack Obama's going to raise taxes," Rendell said.

250 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


September 9, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Jenice Armstrong: Oprah & Sarah: A new war?


SECTION: FEATURES; DN Yo! Features; Pg. 31


LENGTH: 737 words


SUPPORTERS of Republican vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin should be glad that Oprah Winfrey wants to wait until after the election to have the Alaska governor appear on her show.

Can you imagine Winfrey fixing that wide-eyed gaze of hers on Palin, a supporter of abstinence-only sex education, as she quizzes the veep candidate about her pregnant 17-year-old? Given Winfrey's own troubled sexual history as a teen, the talk-show diva isn't likely to give her much slack.

And what would happen once the book-loving Winfrey starts probing Palin about allegations that the former mayor of Wasilla tried to ban certain books from a public library?

Or if she really wanted to pander to her viewership, she could bring on Sen. Hillary Clinton and let her offer up a counterpoint to Palin's view on the war in Iraq.

No, for Palin, who has been lying low in terms of giving interviews, the smarter thing is to back away slowly . . . no, run . . . from being in the Oprah hot seat. After all, the much-heralded "Oprah Effect" isn't bestowed just by being in proximity to the Queen of All Media. It's all about whether Winfrey actually gives you the thumbs-up. Someone needs to tell that to those trying to stir up trouble.

Amid conservative complaints that the media in general is biased against Palin, a Republican women's group in Florida yesterday announced plans to boycott the top-rated talk show and are encouraging women to cancel their subscriptions to O: The Oprah Magazine. Oprah's show reaches an audience of roughly 8 million viewers per day, the vast majority of whom are women.

"Women in Florida helped build Oprah into the icon she is today," said Linda Ivell, president of Florida Federation of Republican Women, in a statement. "We are deeply disappointed in Ms. Winfrey's decision to sit out the greatest political moment in the history of women since suffrage."

That announcement came after Winfrey's move on Friday to rebut an unsubstantiated report on the Drudge Report about infighting among her employees over whether to invite Palin to appear on the show.

"There has been absolutely no discussion about having Sarah Palin on my show," Winfrey said. "At the beginning of this presidential campaign, when I decided that I was going to take my first public stance in support of a candidate, I made the decision not to use my show as a platform for any of the candidates."

Palin's story of having made her way from the local Parent Teachers Association to the Alaska governor's office is just the kind of inspirational tale Winfrey is famous for spotlighting. Winfrey, who's seen as an American everywoman, has made a career of cheerleading for people, women in particular, to reach for their dreams and to live their best lives.

But for months now, Winfrey has been all about her support for Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Barack Obama - even in the face of negative pushback from viewers upset about her backing a man instead of Clinton. Now, it's Palin that has some of her viewers buzzing. The message board has been flooded with e-mails from those who accuse her of abandoning her fans.

"Oprah was made in part by white women, we are her largest viewing base," one poster wrote. "Oprah do what is right, even if you do not like Sarah, for the sake of your base. . . . all of us women out here, put this woman on your show. I am asking that you do the right thing and give back to us who made you who you are."

Last I checked, Winfrey wasn't hosting "Meet the Press." And it's not as if she's had Obama on since he announced his run for president. Nor has Sen. John McCain been on since the campaign got underway. Yet there are these ugly rumblings, as if Winfrey has somehow wronged Palin by not having her on the show.

"It's become this war between the liberals and Republican, right-wing, no-abortion women, and Oprah is a convenient target," said Barbara Lippert, an Ad Week editor who has written about Palin. "These were women who were just waiting for their moment. They felt they were not represented."

Palin, she said, "has ignited every war between between women. It's like she's invented new wars . . . people have a lot of anger that's been waiting to come out." *

Have you peeped a hot trend that hasn't been reported? E-mail heyjen@phillynews.com and let me know what you know. To discuss this column and to also see what else we're talking about, log onto my blog at http://go.philly.com/hfyje


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

All Rights Reserved



251 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday
SOONER EDITION


MCCAIN, PALIN CRITICIZE EARMARKS;
THE REPUBLICAN TICKET TAKES A SWIPE AT BARACK OBAMA


BYLINE: SARA KUGLER, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-4


LENGTH: 563 words


DATELINE: LEE'S SUMMIT, Mo.


Arizona Sen. John McCain and Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin criticized Illinois Sen. Barack Obama over the amount of money he has requested for his home state, even though Alaska under Ms. Palin's leadership has asked Washington for 10 times more money per citizen for pet projects.

At a rally in swing state Missouri, the Republican presidential nominee and his running mate accused Mr. Obama, Mr. McCain's Democratic rival, of requesting nearly $1 billion in earmarks for his state during his time as a senator.

The new line of attack came after Mr. Obama over the weekend made his first direct criticism of Mr. McCain's vice-presidential choice, citing the topic of Ms. Palin's earmarks, which are special projects that lawmakers try to get for their districts and constituents.

"Just the other day our opponent brought up earmarks -- and, frankly, I was surprised that he would even raise the subject at all," Ms. Palin said. "I thought he wouldn't want to go there."

Mr. Obama hasn't asked for any earmarks this year. Last year, he asked for $311 million worth, or about $25 for every Illinois resident. Alaska asked this year for earmarks totaling $198 million, or about $295 for every Alaska citizen.

Ms. Palin has cut back on pork project requests, but under her administration, Alaska is still the largest per-capita consumer of federal pet-project spending by far.

The governor did reject plans to build the notorious "Bridge to Nowhere" after Congress had cut off its financing.

Mr. McCain and Ms. Palin were presented as a maverick team in an ad their campaign released yesterday that played up their reputation for taking on entrenched interests. The ad credits Ms. Palin with stopping the bridge, without mentioning that she once appeared to support it.

President Bush, who came to Washington as a former Texas governor without national legislative experience, called the Alaska governor "an inspired pick" by Mr. McCain. "She's had executive experience, and that's what it takes to be a capable person here in Washington, D.C., in the executive branch," he said in a Fox News interview to be shown today.

In Rome, Vice President Dick Cheney also sought to deflect Democratic criticism that Ms. Palin, a former small-town mayor with less than two years in the governor's office, lacks the gravity to be vice president. "Each administration is different," he said. "And there's no reason why Sarah Palin can't be a successful vice president in a McCain administration." He said her convention speech was superb.

In attacking Mr. Obama yesterday, Mr. McCain said the Illinois senator's earmark total over the years amounts to "almost a million dollars for every single day he was in the United States Senate."

For his part, Mr. McCain doesn't seek pork projects and vows to do away with them as president.

While speaking to voters in Indiana over the weekend, Mr. Obama ridiculed the idea of Mr. McCain and Ms. Palin presenting themselves as reformers, and suggested that Ms. Palin was distorting her own record on earmarks.

"I know the governor of Alaska has been saying she's change, and that's great," Mr. Obama said Saturday. "She's a skillful politician. But, you know, when you've been taking all these earmarks when it's convenient, and then suddenly you're the champion anti-earmark person, that's not change. Come on! I mean, words mean something; you can't just make stuff up."


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



252 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 9, 2008 Tuesday
SOONER EDITION


OLBERMANN, MATTHEWS OUT AS ANCHORS


BYLINE: David Bauder, Associated Press


SECTION: ARTS & ENTERTAINMENT; TV NOTES; Pg. C-3


LENGTH: 773 words


MSNBC said Sunday it is replacing Keith Olbermann and Chris Matthews as co-anchors of political night coverage with David Gregory, and will use the two newsmen as commentators.

The change reflects tensions between the freewheeling, opinionated MSNBC and the impartial newsgatherers at NBC News. Throughout the primaries and summer, MSNBC argued that Olbermann and Matthews could serve as dispassionate anchors on political news nights and that viewers would accept them in that role, but things fell apart during the conventions.

Gregory, the veteran Washington hand, will anchor MSNBC's coverage of the presidential and vice presidential debates and election night, said Jeremy Gaines, network spokesman. The change was first reported by The New York Times.

The tipping point appears to have come during the Republican convention when Olbermann, after the network aired a Sept. 11-themed video prepared by the Republicans, said that MSNBC should not have shown it.

MSNBC executives, who had publicly defended their anchors' roles while privately monitoring it throughout the political season, made the change over the weekend after discussions with Olbermann. Despite the controversy around him, Olbermann has been a hero with left-leaning viewers and keyed MSNBC's growth among coveted young viewers.

During her acceptance speech last week, Republican vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin talked about the "Washington elite" not accepting her qualifications for the job. Some delegates on the convention floor began chanting, "N-B-C, N-B-C."

Olbermann began to have difficulty keeping his opinions in check, or simply stopped trying.

He sarcastically dismissed GOP pundit Pat Buchanan on the air after Buchanan said the GOP had been enlivened by the entrance of a conservative Republican. Perhaps most embarrassing, Joe Scarborough was discussing positive developments in John McCain's campaign at one point when Olbermann was heard on an offstage microphone saying: "Jesus, Joe, why don't you get a shovel?"

Scarborough, a former Republican congressman and host of MSNBC's "Morning Joe," got in another nasty on-air exchange with MSNBC reporter David Shuster, and Matthews snapped at Olbermann on-air when it appeared Olbermann was criticizing him for talking too much.

All the drama made MSNBC a punch line when top NBC anchor Brian Williams appeared on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show" last week. "Is there no control?" Stewart asked him. "Is it 'Lord of the Flies?' "

A sheepish Williams said that every family has a dynamic of its own.

"But does MSNBC have to be the Lohans?" Stewart said.

RATINGS UPDATE

As a television draw, John McCain was every bit the equal of Barack Obama.

The GOP presidential candidate attracted roughly the same number of viewers to his convention acceptance speech Thursday as Obama did before the Democrats last week, according to Nielsen Media Research. Last week's ratings, with an average of 34.5 million viewers watching the GOP convention over three days, proved people are becoming more interested in what the Republicans have to say. The Democrats had an average audience of 30.2 million over four days, Nielsen said.

Nielsen said that 38.9 million people watched McCain accept the GOP nomination Thursday on either ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, Fox News Channel or MSNBC. PBS, which has a more imprecise estimate based on samples in a few big cities, said 3.5 million watched on its network.

Last week, Obama's speech in Denver was seen by 38.4 million on 10 different commercial networks, and an additional 4 million on PBS.

Add it up, and that's McCain, 42.4 million, to Obama, 42.4 million.

No one can really tell who truly had the biggest audience, because C-SPAN also showed the speeches, and Nielsen doesn't measure the cable channel's viewers. But if the presidential vote is this close on Nov. 4, it will be a long night.

McCain may have caught a break Thursday when the opening NFL game between the New York Giants and Washington Redskins finished a couple of minutes before the Republican took the stage, Wallace said.

More men (17.9 million) watched McCain speak than watched Obama (16.2 million), Nielsen said. The numbers put to rest the thought that politics has been a turnoff and death for ratings, which has long been gospel at the TV networks, Rosenstiel said.

That has particularly applied to convention coverage, which broadcast networks have backed away from over the years because executives saw them as stage-managed events. ABC, CBS and NBC each added an hour this year to convention coverage, but it didn't halt one trend: Viewers are just as likely to watch the conventions on cable news networks.


LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



253 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 8, 2008 Monday


Regional Police;
Why 'Ombudsman' Is Needed Here Crucial Marietta Vote Whose White House?


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 840 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Most of the time, you hear remarks about our law enforcement that are nasty.

But on the evening of Aug. 28, when Regional Police searched a very questionable house in Marietta, the officers were very thorough in their investigation, plus they allowed three small children and one handicapped child to leave with their grandmother before they cuffed the mother.

This shows compassion.

Marietta has an excellent police force. We thank you for protecting our small but quiet town.

Joan Parsons,Marietta

This letter is in response to your editorial of Friday, Aug. 29, on the subject of the proposed "entrepreneurship ombudsman." I'd like to thank you for bringing this important action to the public's attention, because I'm all for it.

There's a budding technology-based community growing in our midst. There are at least nine such companies at the Burle Industrial Park and perhaps an equal number in downtown Lancaster.

The companies at Burle tend to be "hardware" companies; those downtown tend to be "software" companies. All told, these companies have around 100 employees. Several are growing and actively hiring.

We need to build a structure to encourage the formation of new companies of this type, since they represent new opportunities that will help to continue the county's growth.

Yes, Lancaster has a variety of government and private services available to entrepreneurs. The ombudsman's job is to connect them.

Why is this needed? Very few entrepreneurs start a company with all the necessary skills and experience.

In the technology field, nearly 100 percent of start-up companies bring strong technology knowledge to the party. That's something that can usually be counted upon.

However, most of the entrepreneurs come from large companies, where the other functions, including sales and marketing and legal affairs, are not within their experience base.

They don't know where or how to find the help they need. They need help finding reliable advice and mentoring. That's where the "entrepreneurship ombudsman" comes in.

As you point out, Lancaster County is well endowed with people and organizations that can help. (I'd like to point out that the Lancaster Library, the Lancaster Angel Network and our area venture capital people should be included in your list.)

The problem, which is well recognized within the entrepreneurial community, and at the state level as well, is that Lancaster County has no designated place to go for the information. It's available, small piece by small piece, from many sources and at many locations.

The proposed ombudsman is not a substitute for, and will not be allowed to become, a competitor for any of the organizations you mention in your editorial. The intent is to avoid competition and duplication entirely, while pointing the entrepreneur in the right direction so he can get the needed answers quickly, skillfully and at no or minimum cost - from the existing sources.

G. Yale Eastman, East Lampeter Township

All Marietta residents should attend the borough council meeting on Tuesday at 7 p.m., when council members are expected to vote on the proposed borough-levee system. The council chambers are at 113 E. Market St.

About 100 people saw a presentation on this two-mile-long "Marietta Smaller Levee System," given by engineers from the state Department of Environmental Protection in July. The public has had two months for input.

Now there are concerns that council will vote no on the levee.

One excuse is that Marietta residents can't afford the small bond required to maintain the system, even though the levee would be constructed and paid with state and federal funds.

Another excuse is that the Harrisburg engineers have canceled the project, regardless whether Marietta Borough citizens want it or not.

The cost of a bond issue would be more than offset by the savings on the present high cost of flood insurance, with a properly designed levee system, and Marietta residents' lives and properties would be much safer.

Global warming and climate change are serious issues.

At a special meeting in Geneva, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change discussed a July report on the relation of global warming and water levels. The report can be found at www.ipcc.ch.

A nationally recognized insurance company is sending letters to home owners throughout Lancaster County about flood insurance, even though they may not be near any rivers or creeks.

It includes this statement: "Many people assume that their homeowner's or other personal property insurance policy would cover these types of losses when, in fact, a homeowners or other personal-property policy does not cover damage caused by flooding."

Jesse Charles Wagner II, Marietta

In Obama's early commercials, he kept calling the White House his house. Now he has one on the seven houses that McCain supposedly has.

My question is, how does one go about searching the deed to the White House and see who really owns it?

If Obama does, how much does he make renting out all the offices that are in the White House?

Biddie J. Helton, Mountville


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



254 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


September 8, 2008 Monday


Regional Police;
Why 'Ombudsman' Is Needed Here Crucial Marietta Vote Whose White House?


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: A; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 840 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Most of the time, you hear remarks about our law enforcement that are nasty.

But on the evening of Aug. 28, when Regional Police searched a very questionable house in Marietta, the officers were very thorough in their investigation, plus they allowed three small children and one handicapped child to leave with their grandmother before they cuffed the mother.

This shows compassion.

Marietta has an excellent police force. We thank you for protecting our small but quiet town.

Joan Parsons,Marietta

This letter is in response to your editorial of Friday, Aug. 29, on the subject of the proposed "entrepreneurship ombudsman." I'd like to thank you for bringing this important action to the public's attention, because I'm all for it.

There's a budding technology-based community growing in our midst. There are at least nine such companies at the Burle Industrial Park and perhaps an equal number in downtown Lancaster.

The companies at Burle tend to be "hardware" companies; those downtown tend to be "software" companies. All told, these companies have around 100 employees. Several are growing and actively hiring.

We need to build a structure to encourage the formation of new companies of this type, since they represent new opportunities that will help to continue the county's growth.

Yes, Lancaster has a variety of government and private services available to entrepreneurs. The ombudsman's job is to connect them.

Why is this needed? Very few entrepreneurs start a company with all the necessary skills and experience.

In the technology field, nearly 100 percent of start-up companies bring strong technology knowledge to the party. That's something that can usually be counted upon.

However, most of the entrepreneurs come from large companies, where the other functions, including sales and marketing and legal affairs, are not within their experience base.

They don't know where or how to find the help they need. They need help finding reliable advice and mentoring. That's where the "entrepreneurship ombudsman" comes in.

As you point out, Lancaster County is well endowed with people and organizations that can help. (I'd like to point out that the Lancaster Library, the Lancaster Angel Network and our area venture capital people should be included in your list.)

The problem, which is well recognized within the entrepreneurial community, and at the state level as well, is that Lancaster County has no designated place to go for the information. It's available, small piece by small piece, from many sources and at many locations.

The proposed ombudsman is not a substitute for, and will not be allowed to become, a competitor for any of the organizations you mention in your editorial. The intent is to avoid competition and duplication entirely, while pointing the entrepreneur in the right direction so he can get the needed answers quickly, skillfully and at no or minimum cost - from the existing sources.

G. Yale Eastman, East Lampeter Township

All Marietta residents should attend the borough council meeting on Tuesday at 7 p.m., when council members are expected to vote on the proposed borough-levee system. The council chambers are at 113 E. Market St.

About 100 people saw a presentation on this two-mile-long "Marietta Smaller Levee System," given by engineers from the state Department of Environmental Protection in July. The public has had two months for input.

Now there are concerns that council will vote no on the levee.

One excuse is that Marietta residents can't afford the small bond required to maintain the system, even though the levee would be constructed and paid with state and federal funds.

Another excuse is that the Harrisburg engineers have canceled the project, regardless whether Marietta Borough citizens want it or not.

The cost of a bond issue would be more than offset by the savings on the present high cost of flood insurance, with a properly designed levee system, and Marietta residents' lives and properties would be much safer.

Global warming and climate change are serious issues.

At a special meeting in Geneva, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change discussed a July report on the relation of global warming and water levels. The report can be found at www.ipcc.ch.

A nationally recognized insurance company is sending letters to home owners throughout Lancaster County about flood insurance, even though they may not be near any rivers or creeks.

It includes this statement: "Many people assume that their homeowner's or other personal property insurance policy would cover these types of losses when, in fact, a homeowners or other personal-property policy does not cover damage caused by flooding."

Jesse Charles Wagner II, Marietta

In Obama's early commercials, he kept calling the White House his house. Now he has one on the seven houses that McCain supposedly has.

My question is, how does one go about searching the deed to the White House and see who really owns it?

If Obama does, how much does he make renting out all the offices that are in the White House?

Biddie J. Helton, Mountville


LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



255 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


September 8, 2008 Monday
CITY-D Edition


A light on varied voices of women;
Campaign dispels notion of a political monolith.


BYLINE: By Carolyn Davis; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News for PC Home Page; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1048 words


The United States won't be electing a Madame President this year. But if there's one thing this campaign season has made especially vivid, it's this:

American women don't speak with a single political voice, not even to each other.

Suddenly, any monolithic notion of the "woman voter" has been cracked wide open.

"It's a huge thing," says former Rep. Pat Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who ran for president in 1988. "People keep thinking they are of one ilk, but they really all have been very diverse."

In many quarters, the political discussion among women has now moved beyond old labels and lingo. "Even women who profess not to be feminists and part of the movement also feel it's time for women to have their say and be on the center stage. That's a huge gain," Schroeder says.

Connecticut Gov. M. Jodi Rell, a Republican, says women are getting to see both sides in this election. "They get the femininity, and they get the hard and challenging, capable women."

These days, a lot of Republican women are ecstatic over Sen. John McCain's choice of Sarah Palin, a deeply conservative mother of five, as his running mate. Some critics say Palin's position on abortion, for example - she opposes it even in cases of rape or incest - is extreme, though these beliefs appeal to many GOP faithful.

She is the supremely confident first-term governor of Alaska and former co-owner of a commercial fishing operation. Michelle Obama, wife of Sen. Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential nominee, is an accomplished Chicago hospital administrator with a bachelor's from Princeton and a law degree from Harvard.

McCain's wife, Cindy, is a global humanitarian whose family's beer-distribution business made her a multimillionaire. Jill Biden, a community college professor and wife of Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic vice presidential candidate, has a doctorate in education and two master's degrees.

Each woman is successful in her own right - and, in McCain's case, wealthier than her spouse.

Early on in the Democratic primary season, some of Michelle Obama's remarks on the campaign trail highlighted differences between African American and white women as they split their support between her husband and Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton.

"I think the campaign has exposed a divide between black and white women and feminists," says Shirley Staples Carter, a University of South Carolina professor who focuses on multicultural communications.

"I think people in general have a problem with Michelle Obama because of the perception she's outspoken and very well-educated," says Carter. "It's curious to me that those attributes that we celebrate in Sen. Clinton aren't also celebrated in Michelle Obama and black women in general. When we are strong and confident, we're seen as aggressive and menacing."

Research has shown that white feminists are most concerned with "elevating the cause of women per se," she adds, "whereas with African American women, it's not just about our liberation, but also the liberation of African American males."

Traditional feminists "don't know what to do about black women," says Anita L. Allen, a University of Pennsylvania law professor specializing in race and race relations. "My concern is that feminists might not notice that some of the things said about Michelle Obama are sexist and racist."

Last week, one big debate was whether it was appropriate for Palin to have her baby son, Trig, who has Down syndrome, on stage Wednesday night at the Republican National Convention.

Conservative women have defended Palin, blaming reporters for questions about whether her candidacy renders her a neglectful mother.

Christie Whitman, former Republican governor of New Jersey, says it's clear women are held to a different standard than men when children are involved. Joe Biden wasn't grilled about raising his sons after the car accident that killed his first wife and daughter, Whitman says.

"Clearly, that's still there," she says. "It's still relevant there's a double standard.

"I've always found women are harder on other women than they are on their male counterparts," Whitman says. "I've never bought into the theory that they brought Palin onto the ticket to get the disaffected Hillary Clinton voters."

Though Palin has electrified the GOP base, and represents this election year's only remaining chance for women to break through the executive-branch glass ceiling - despite the 18 million cracks Clinton likes to say she and supporters inflicted upon it - not all women are rallying around her.

"There's always satisfaction when a woman goes where no woman has gone before," says Kim Gandy, president of the liberal National Organization for Women. "But it would unfortunately be bad for the country. It would be a hollow satisfaction. . . . Her policies would injure more women than her example would benefit."

Wendy Wright, president of the conservative, biblical-based Concerned Women for America, sees Palin as the same kind of trailblazer Democrats see in Clinton.

"Sarah Palin has really moved the bar. She has expanded the universe," Wright says. "It's very bad to see the old guard in the feminist movement being so critical of Sarah Palin."

Star Parker, president of the conservative Coalition on Urban Renewal and Education, says she feels zero kinship toward Michelle Obama, even though both are African American.

"The women's movement or politics is similar to race politics. Unless it's liberal, it's not legitimate," Parker says mockingly. "But the uniqueness of womanhood and diversity of thought has always been there. . . . Now we see through Gov. Palin that the diversity is there. Now we can get to discussions important to all of us. Not just equal pay."

No matter the party or perspective, this could turn out to be the biggest political year for women since 1992, when 24 were newly elected to the U.S. House of Representatives and four to the Senate, says Robert P. Watson, director of American studies at Florida's Lynn University.

Should Palin become vice president, "it sends a very powerful image," Watson says. "I don't think we can begin to imagine how utterly empowering that would be for a generation of young women today."

Contact staff writer Carolyn Davis at 215-854-4214 or cdavis@phillynews.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

256 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


September 8, 2008 Monday
FINAL Edition


Stu Bykofsky: Everything I, the typical American, ever needed to know I learned from Rush and Jon


SECTION: LOCAL; P-com Biggie News Update; Pg. 08


LENGTH: 595 words


WITH THE conventions in our rear-view mirror (objects are smaller than they appear), the presidential campaigns shift into high gear.

Barack Obama hires two staffers to clarify what he meant in his last remarks and John McCain hands Sarah Palin an over-and-under shotgun to guard his Straight Talk Express, now parked on the Mexico/Arizona border for immigrants to use as a comfort stop.

The candidates are ready for us, but are we ready for them? Over the last four decades, only 54 percent of eligible Americans bothered to vote for president. Appeals to party, patriotism and virtue worked as well as Jell-O handcuffs.

This year, it might be different. Obama appeals to callow, never-before voters, while McCain delights hardened-artery, Social Security seniors.

But listen to the Typical American:

"Most elections, I don't vote.

"When I do, it's because I've been goosed by TV commercials, where I get my political opinions.

"The BEST information I get from blogs and anonymous e-mails. That's how I know the North Vietnamese gave John McCain prostitutes when he was a POW. He didn't take early release because he was having too many seaweed wraps and too much sex.

"From e-mails I learned Barack HUSSEIN Obama is a secret Muslim, trained in a madrassa when he lived in Microsoftnesia, or someplace like that. I don't know what a madrassa is, but it sounds scary.

"MoveOn.org says McCain would keep U.S. troops fighting in Iran or Iraq (I forget which) for 100 years. That will make them the oldest soldiers in the world. They'd be riding Rascal scooters instead of Humvees.

"When I do bother to vote, I don't know the issues, just one or two that grab my gut. I get my political news from Rush Limbaugh and Jon Stewart. They're super-smart and they care about me.

"When I actually step into a voting booth - Wow! They're electronic now; hope I push the right button, not like some Florida Jews. When I don't know the candidates, I vote for those with my ethnic background.

"Bond Issues and Questions, I ignore. They don't affect me. Do they?

"The only one Rush talks about is gay marriage, which attacks the institution of marriage, he says. Who knows better than a man with three failed marriages? Stewart likes gay marriage. Because he's gay! At least he looks gay. But it's OK. You can be as gay as a pink squirrel if

you're funny.

"I rarely watch election shows on cable TV, where they have political consultants from past campaigns talk about current candidates. Cable gets them because even a maggot has more dignity.

"Will James Carville ever say anything nasty about a Democrat (unless it's a Democrat running against Hillary or Bill)? Bob Shrum has been losing elections for Democrats since George McGovern in '72. Conservative Cal Thomas looks like a mortician's practice mannequin. Sean Hannity calls Karl Rove 'the Architect.' Rove got Bush elected, but wrecked the Republican Party. You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs.

"Pat Buchanan, is he a Republican? Is he an earthling? Instead of an American flag, he wears an Iron Cross on his lapel. Dick Morris is a gas. He hates Hillary, even though he used to strategize for Bill. Then he got caught with a hooker. Dick, I mean. Bill got caught with an intern. And a hillbilly. And a lounge singer. And Barbra Streisand, the blogs say. And if it's on the Internet, you know it's true. Like Palin's infant is really her grandson."

The race is on. Don't read "old media" newspapers. Tune to Rush and Jon for truthiness.

E-mail stubyko@phillynews.com or call 215-854-5977. For recent columns:

http://go.philly.com/byko.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

257 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


September 7, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


GOP back on cultural battleground;
Convention speakers cited Obama, other Democrats and the news media as threats to American values.


BYLINE: By Thomas Fitzgerald; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; Inq World & Nation; Pg. A16


LENGTH: 845 words


ST. PAUL, Minn. - Republicans declared a renewal of hostilities in the culture wars during their national convention last week, with speakers stoking the conservative base to build enthusiasm for presidential nominee John McCain.

Former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, for instance, sneered he was "sorry" that a small Alaska town was not "flashy enough or cosmopolitan enough" for Democratic nominee Barack Obama. We are lucky, Giuliani said, that real Americans from small towns pick the president, instead of "Hollywood celebrities."

Mitt Romney, a former Republican governor of Massachusetts with two Ivy League graduate degrees, decried the "Eastern elites" who control the media.

The St. Paul gathering was kinder and gentler than the famously bellicose 1992 GOP convention in Houston, remembered for Patrick Buchanan's summons to "cultural war."

But coming from the podium in Minnesota was an unmistakable us-vs.-them theme, with speakers citing Obama, the Democrats and the news media as the forces threatening the values of an idealized small-town America.

The right rallied around Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, the former mayor of tiny Wasilla, who was chosen as McCain's running mate and came under immediate fire in the media. The pick also brought the abortion issue to the fore. A Christian conservative, Palin has become a hero to many evangelicals because she had a baby with Down syndrome four months ago, choosing not to have an abortion although in-utero testing had confirmed the condition. Gun owners love her because she is a hunter and outdoorswoman.

McCain, though he has a strong voting record against abortion rights, seldom likes to talk about social issues or his religious faith, and he has urged the GOP to tone down the abortion talk in the past.

The new post-Palin nod to the right also contrasted with the 2000 and 2004 Republican conventions, when social issues were rarely mentioned.

"Now the conservatives . . . evangelicals, they have got somebody to go out and work for, to root for, to help," Buchanan said Wednesday on MSNBC. "I think you've really got almost an even race in terms of enthusiasm, energy and fire."

After Palin was named, the Obama campaign began running an ad in several states blasting McCain as an enemy of abortion rights. It has also deployed prominent Democratic women on the campaign trail and in TV studios in recent days to counter the GOP's new star.

"What I think John McCain has done very clearly is to definitely change to embrace the very radical wing of his party on social issues," Kansas Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, a Democrat, said Friday on CNN. "A lot of Republicans and moderates I know here . . . find it very troubling."

Former Tennessee Sen. Fred Thompson drew an ovation at the convention when he took a shot at Obama's support of abortion rights.

He said McCain would be a president who "doesn't think that the protection of the unborn or a newly born baby is 'above his pay grade.' " It was a reference to Obama's answer to a question about when life begins during a forum last month at the Saddleback evangelical church.

An Obama presidency, Thompson continued, would mean a Supreme Court "lost to liberalism for the next generation."

It makes strategic sense for the Republicans to energize social conservatives because the party is facing a hostile political environment.

The GOP remains tied in the public mind to a president with a near-record-low approval rating; an optional and unpopular war in Iraq, albeit a conflict that has shown recent signs of progress; and economic anxieties.

Disdain for perceived elitism has a long history in populist movements in both parties.

For the Republicans, it has been an effective wedge in modern elections. President George H.W. Bush's common-man fondness for pork rinds, horseshoes and powerboats, for instance, was hyped as a contrast with the buttoned-down technocrat Michael Dukakis in 1988. Four years ago, the GOP mocked Democrat John F. Kerry's windsurfing, his $5,000 Italian bicycle, and his sometimes-ponderous manner.

New York Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton showed the effectiveness of the argument against Obama in the late Democratic primaries, rolling up big margins among working-class voters without college educations while portraying him as pedantic and out of touch with real life.

Republicans worked the elitism angle heavily at the convention, with more than a few mentions of Obama's off-the-cuff comments at a San Francisco fund-raiser that he believed small-town Pennsylvanians "cling to guns or religion" because of their economic anxiety.

It was no accident that the rollout of Palin focused on her ability to hunt and field-dress an elk, her fondness for mooseburgers, and her husband's success in snowmobile racing.

"I had the privilege of living most of my life in a small town," Palin said. "I might add that in small towns . . . we tend to prefer candidates who don't talk about us one way in Scranton and another way in San Francisco."

Contact staff writer Thomas Fitzgerald at 215-854-2718 or tfitzgerald@phillynews.com.


LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
