PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



271 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


September 3, 2008 Wednesday
FINAL Edition


N.E. Phila.: Key to McCain Pa. victory?


BYLINE: By CATHERINE LUCEY; luceyc@phillynews.com 215-854-4172


SECTION: LOCAL; P-com News; Pg. 06


LENGTH: 851 words


IF JOHN MCCAIN hopes to win the key state of Pennsylvania, conventional wisdom holds, he'll have to find his votes outside Philadelphia, which is teeming with devoted African-American supporters of Barack Obama.

But those offering that wisdom should make a trip to Mayfair.

It's a white working-class neighborhood of attached brick houses and modest commercial strips in Northeast Philadelphia, where Republicans aren't an endangered species, Democrats can swing any which way and Obama has his work cut out for him.

No Republican expects McCain to win Philadelphia, but if he and running mate Sarah Palin can hold Obama's margin in the city to 350,000 votes or less, GOP insiders think that they could win the state and its 21 electoral votes.

That's why Republicans are looking carefully at Mayfair and the rest of the Northeast.

"I'm pulling out all my guns in Philly to make sure John McCain can win Pennsylvania," said Rob Gleason, state GOP chairman.

McCain's campaign has set up its city headquarters in Mayfair, at Frankford and Cottman avenues. And McCain made a Northeast stop yesterday, serving coffee and doughnuts to firefighters at a fire station in Fox Chase.

Four years ago, Sen. John Kerry beat President Bush in every ward in the Northeast. In the 55th Ward, which covers Mayfair, his margin was 15 points. But this year's presidential matchup is different, and Republicans are encouraged by what they saw in the April Democratic primary.

Democrats in the Northeast overwhelmingly backed Sen. Hillary Clinton. Clinton was cheered by an adoring crowd of 1,500 at a rally held outside the Mayfair Diner, and she went on to crush Obama in the Northeast, winning the 55th Ward with 75 percent of the vote. So far, her voters have not all converted to Obama.

When you add skeptical Democrats to the 72,000 registered Republicans in the Northeast, you've got a real shot for McCain to shrink Obama's margin in the city Obama needs to win big.

"I already made my mind up and I'm a Democrat - McCain," said Diana Linke, 49, of Mayfair, who supported Clinton. "I don't believe Barack Obama has the experience."

Democrats have said that Obama needs to win Philly by more than 400,000 to win Pennsylvania.

Kerry secured a 412,000-vote margin in Philadelphia in 2004 and went on to win the state. But McCain's Northeast support could impact that margin.

"I think McCain will do well up there," said political analyst Larry Ceisler. "The problem in some of these places, Obama's message is change, and people in these places don't want a change."

The Republicans struggled in the Northeast four years ago because President Bush was widely disliked. But McCain is favorably viewed as an experienced, independent senator. And, just as in other blue-collar areas, these working-class voters who are worried about gas prices, health-care costs and jobs haven't warmed to Obama.

"I'm voting for McCain because Obama is all b.s.," said Democrat George Scaricamazza, 67, of Somerton, who voted for Clinton in the primary. "He's not qualified for nothing."

Obama's Pennsylvania spokesman, Sean Smith, said that the campaign must educate voters in Northeast Philadelphia about Obama.

"We need to tell his story and let voters know that Senator Obama's early life was a lot more like their own than they may realize," Smith said.

The Obama campaign also needs to talk with Northeast voters about economic issues, Smith said.

"The Democrats who voted for Senator Clinton were doing so because of the economy and because of health care," said Smith. "We believe they will vote for Senator Obama on those issues because he is so much better than John McCain."

The selection of Scranton-born Sen. Joe Biden, a Catholic with blue-collar roots, may help Obama in this part of the city.

"I'm going to vote for Obama and Biden," said Emily Deane, 52, of Crescentville, who supported Clinton in the primary. "Biden has experience; he's been in the Senate for 30 years. Biden made up my mind."

But McCain's running mate, Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, a self-described "hockey mom" with five kids, could also appeal to Northeast voters.

"I think she's going to be a great addition to the ticket," said Gleason. "I think she's a woman who understands a lot of the issues of being a working mom."

Another element of both sides' strategic thinking is the Northeast's, (and the city's) history of racial identification in voting. In 2003, the 55th Ward voted for white Republican Sam Katz over Mayor John Street, who is black, by an almost 9-to-1 ratio.

The Northeast also voted for white candidates Tom Knox and Bob Brady in the 2007 mayoral primary, though African-American candidates got a larger share of the Northeast's vote than in previous mayoral contests.

"I think, obviously, race plays a part of this," said Gleason. "But in America, you can vote for somebody on how they part their hair."

Annette Blumenthal, 47, of Pennypack, said she would support McCain over Obama, in part because of race.

"He's a smart guy, he's looks very educated, he has a beautiful wife," she said of Obama. "I just think the world's not ready for a black president." *


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photograph by: Feed Loader


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



272 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


September 2, 2008 Tuesday
CITY-D Edition


Coverage of Gustav tops politics on Day 1


BYLINE: By John Timpane; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News Nation-World; Pg. A06


LENGTH: 461 words


Coverage of the first day of the 2008 Republican National Convention was more meteorology than politics. Gustav/GOP gave the 24/7 news channels a chance to show what TV can do, and the result was both breathtaking and mind-numbing.

Swirling red, blue, yellow and red, Gustav's TV image edged farther and farther northwest throughout the day, and MSNBC, CNN and Fox News made sure that image was usually either center-stage or tucked in the lower right-hand corner of the screen, even during commercials. 

So what if the Republican Party decided Sunday to "scale down" the first day of the convention into a sort of hurricane-relief telethon? There was a hurricane (one disappointed reporter called it "not the mother of all storms after all") to overcover.

CNN's John King, on the convention floor at the Xcel Convention Center in St. Paul, Minn., conjured with the Magic Wall (a digital map that shifts, zooms in, and focuses according to touches and hand signals) to point out bulging levees and endangered neighborhoods.

Then, with a sweep of King's hand, we slid over to Baton Rouge for a zoom-in. It was fresh, on the fly, a fine diversion from the listless milling of the convention.

There was comedy: Fox News' Geraldo Rivera, complete with cameramen, ran right up to the slopping lip of the Industrial Canal in the Upper Ninth Ward of New Orleans.

The high point came during CNN's The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer, when seven live video images ran on one screen: talking heads Blitzer and King, and live shots from five storm-torn locations from Alabama to Mississippi, plus a quotation headline from New Orleans Mayor Ray Nagin ("We're not out of the woods yet") and the ubiquitous crawler, with international news.

An incredible amount of instantly available info.

The best coverage of politics had the least commentary. C-Span showed a Barack Obama speech at Detroit's Hart Plaza in which he deftly twinned praise for the union movement with a silent prayer for storm victims.

C-Span also followed the equally deft President Bush as he visited emergency-response centers in Texas. While not flashy, C-Span's commentless mic-and-camera approach is dramatic: We see the politician's art, his charisma and how people respond. You can learn more from an unmediated C-Span camera than from two hours of punditry.

A shudder may have gone through convention planners when, toward evening's end, MSNBC weatherperson Bill Kairns said Hurricane Hanna might make landfall anywhere from North Carolina to central Florida on Thursday - just about when John McCain is scheduled "to make the biggest speech of his life." And behind Hanna, a storm named Ike is building up. The gods must be crazy.

Contact staff writer John Timpane at 215-854-4406 or jt@phillynews.com.


LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



273 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


September 2, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Paul Hagen: Kendrick vs. Mets? Just skip it


SECTION: SPORTS; DN Columnists; Pg. 65


LENGTH: 797 words


WASHINGTON - Soon the airwaves will be flooded with commercials, hammering home a message to every American man, woman, child and pet goldfish. No, nothing about Obama or McCain. Major League Baseball would like to remind every living soul that "There's Only One October" and has assembled a list of personalities ranging from Jeff Foxworthy to the animated Stewie from "Family Guy" to join the ubiquitous Rick Gonzalez in getting the word out.

Thing is, there's not even a disclaimer in the fine print pointing out that there's also only one September. And that for contending teams that don't take care of business now, there won't be any October at all. At least, not one that MLB and its broadcast partners are going to give a hoot about televising.

The Phillies fall into that more specific focus group. And on the first day of this make-or-break month, Kyle Kendrick's latest meltdown yesterday set off a four-alarm ripple of concern after a dismal, 7-4 loss to last-place Washington at Nationals Park.

The narrow question being casually tossed around before the game was whether Kendrick should be skipped the next time around the rotation to allow Cole Hamels to pitch next Sunday night against the Mets at Shea Stadium.

The real issue now, though, is whether a team that is two games behind New York with just 24 left to play can afford to continue reserving a spot in the rotation for Kendrick at all.

It's hard to see how.

The rules are different in September. Phillies manager Charlie Manager demonstrated his belief in that principal a year ago when he went to the whip with closer Brett Myers and setup relievers J.C. Romero and Tom Gordon while basically putting the rest of the bullpen on hiatus. And it paid off with a hot streak that allowed the Phillies to slip past the Mets on the final day of the season, making it to the one-and-only October for the first time in 14 years.

There's only one March, April, May, June, July and August, too. In those months, though, there's still time to experiment, to allow players to ride out slumps or try to find themselves.

Look, Kendrick was a great story last year when he came out of Double A Reading in June and won 10 games. Without his contributions, the Phillies probably wouldn't have made the playoffs.

But the ugly reality is that, in his last five starts, he is 1-3 with a 9.14 earned run average. He has allowed 48 batters to reach on hits or walks in 21 2/3 innings. He has walked 14 while striking out just seven. Most damning, he needed 84 pitches to get through just four innings yesterday. And that was the third-longest outing in this span.

"Lately, he's having a hard time with his command," Manuel said. "Poise used to be the big thing we talked about with him. He'd just get the ball and throw it. Now he takes a lot of time. He aims the ball. He used to, what I call, throw through the [catcher's] mitt."

Kendrick has no explanation for his troubles.

"I feel good," he said. "That's what's frustrating about it. I feel good. My arm does. I feel good and strong. I don't know what I'm going through at this point."

Based on the success he's had to this point of his career, Kendrick absolutely deserves the opportunity to figure this out.

Just not now, not in September, where the shadows are lengthening across their season just as they did across the Nationals Park field late yesterday afternoon.

Manuel, who has been a staunch Kendrick supporter, said no decision has been made. Pitching coach Rich Dubee said the team isn't going to do "anything rash." Manuel wondered out loud who might replace Kendrick in the rotation.

Funny thing is, he may have dropped a hint earlier. He had 10 pitchers in the bullpen to choose from to pitch the bottom of the fifth and he chose lefty J.A. Happ who is now, in theory at least, in sync with Kendrick's schedule.

Asked if Happ is a possibility, Manuel didn't blink. "He's down there, isn't he? He's a starter," the manager said. "We'll just have to wait and see how things go. We're in the last month and we've got to win every game we can."

Later, asked how much weight the shortness of the remaining schedule and the resultant increase in the importance of every game would be given in whatever decision was made, Manuel was blunt again.

"A whole lot," he said. "That's the big question. It's something we've definitely got to discuss."

There's only one October, sources have confirmed. But for teams that don't do what they need to do in September, it's a pretty empty month.

After all, Chase Utley walking the dog or Brett Myers playing golf or Ryan Howard working out or Jimmy Rollins buying clothes or Brad Lidge playing pingpong or video games isn't exactly must-see TV. Not when there are eight other teams vying for the World Series. *

Send e-mail to hagenp@phillynews.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 2, 2008 Tuesday
SOONER EDITION


HONEST BROKER


BYLINE: DONALD CONWAY Munhall


SECTION: EDITORIAL; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Pg. A-14


LENGTH: 155 words


John McCain has repeatedly made it clear that his wife has her own finances; she files a separate tax return so he has no need to track what is owned only in her name. As such, it is reasonable to assume he cannot quote off-the-cuff the number of investment properties she owns.

When asked how many houses he plus his wife own between them, John McCain appropriately answered he did not know and the answer would have to be researched.

Barack Obama, in his attack ad, states that John McCain's response showed Mr. McCain could not identify the number of homes owned by him. Since the question Mr. McCain responded to included properties owned by Mrs. McCain only, turning the quote into an inability of John McCain to keep track of homes under his own name is a false statement.

Mr. Obama's intentional misquote is therefore an outright lie about what Mr. McCain said. This lie not only has Mr. Obama's approval, it also has his voice.


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



275 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


September 2, 2008 Tuesday


Obama's acceptance gala -- over the top, slightly?


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 801 words


The star of the Democratic National Convention wasn't Michelle Obama, Hillary Clinton, Hillary's husband -- certainly not Joe Biden or even Barack Obama.

The single-most riveting presence at the Democratic gathering -- possibly the entire Democratic political season -- was that kooky-bizarro set with the faux-marble columns straddling the 50-yard line of Invesco Field in Denver.

In this veritable neo-Graeco-Roman-Graceland temple, the Anointed One became the Nominated One.

Or so I assume.

Confession: I wrote on the morning of Obama's evening acceptance speech, confident that nothing could speak more volumes to the American people than the sight of this grandiose venue deliberately crafted for the address.

Besides, even as Obama's media squeezes pounded out the anticipatory PR hearts and flowers -- The Washington Post breathlessly revealed that Obama was earlier "crafting a first draft by hand on yellow paper" -- the bookies already reducing the speech to a probable set of cliches.

Not only was it a sure thing that the nominee would use the phrase "I accept," but bookmaker Paddy Power also gave 12-to-1 odds that he would use the phrases "I'd like to thank my wife," "as I stand here today," "fundamental belief" and "defining moment."

Zzzzz... Sorry. Whatever is remembered about what Obama said, the essential point is this: He decided to say it at a plywood Parthenon by klieg light. At least, I hope he did.

I hope he stood firm against the early guffaws elicited by those first fuzzy photos to appear during convention week depicting the temple columns rising amid 76,000 seats and 450 spotlights in Mile High Stadium, a sight that increasingly looked less Leni Riefenstahl and more "This Is Spinal Tap."

After all, the Obama campaign hasn't been immune to similar criticism. According to the London Telegraph, John McCain's commercial depiction of Obama as a vapid "celebrity" after his last rally for the masses in Berlin effectively sent all manner of vapid celebrities into hiding during the convention.

This was because, the paper reported, convention planners had ruled against pop stars making cameo convention appearances -- an indication of "how Republican rival Sen. John McCain's effort to turn Mr. Obama's fame into a weakness has rattled the Democratic campaign."

Can't wait what to see what effect Vladimir Putin has on it. But I digress.

The fact is, your Ben Afflecks, your Josh Brolins, your Annette Bennings came to Denver, but "mostly kept a careful distance from the main arena and Michelle Obama" because they feared "their presence could be detrimental."

The paper continued: "Oscar-winner George Clooney, an avowed Obama supporter, even took the unusual step of issuing a statement to deny he was in regular contact with Obama.

"I have never texted or e-mailed Sen. Obama," the Telegraph quoted Mr. Clooney as saying. Must have been a slow news day.

Of course, celebrity sensitivity and Temple Obama could be connected. Maybe in its efforts to ditch the celebrity image, the Obama campaign thought up the idea for Obama to strike a super-statesmanlike pose on a super-serious set -- Ancient Greece or Rome or whatever. Who are you calling a vapid celebrity now?

But this has left Obama with another problem: Having chosen to accept the nomination for president of the United States in a setting more suited to a Roman emperor if not the oracle at Delphi, what will his fellow citizens -- still not subjects, after all -- think?

Frankly, what the tank ride did for Michael Dukakis, the plywood Parthenon just might do for Obama.

Then again, this entire event, seemingly a miscalculation of epic proportions, could have been an example of perfect political acumen.

For example, before becoming transfixed by Temple Obama, I was reading up on Obama's relationship with ex-Weather Underground member and unrepentant Capitol- and Pentagon-bomber William Ayers -- news of which the Obama campaign has been eager to downplay if not squelch entirely.

I was also trying to unravel the ties between Obama, Obama's unsavory fundraiser Antoin "Tony" Rezko, and Rezko's unsavory money source Iraqi-British billionaire Nadhmi Auchi. (This is another story journalists are being pressured not to cover, as Andrew Walden at Accuracy in Media has shockingly and extensively documented, in this case by Auchi's legal eagles.)

And who knew Obama's veep nominee Joe Biden had Rezko connections through a longtime associate named Joseph Cari Jr., who admitted involvement in a Rezko kickback scheme? And on it goes.

But then, suddenly, Temple Obama went up, and with it, like incense in the fire, all patience for hard news.

Maybe this comes under the age-old Roman heading of bread and circuses. Eureka! All Hail Barackus Husseinus Obamaius.

E-mail Washington Times columnist Diana West at dianawest@verizon.net


LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

276 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


September 1, 2008 Monday
SOONER EDITION


THIS CHICK FLICK STARS AN UNDERQUALIFIED CANDIDATE IN GO-GO BOOTS


BYLINE: Maureen Dowd


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A-13


LENGTH: 806 words


The guilty pleasure I miss most when I'm out slogging on the campaign trail is the chance to sprawl on the chaise and watch a vacuously spunky and generically sassy chick flick.

So imagine my delight, my absolute astonishment, when the hokey chick flick came out on the trail, a Cinderella story so preposterous it's hard to believe it's not premiering on Lifetime. Instead of going home and watching "Miss Congeniality" with Sandra Bullock, I get to stay here and watch "Miss Congeniality" with Sarah Palin.

Sheer heaven.

It's easy to see where this movie is going. It begins, of course, with a cute, cool unknown from Alaska who has never even been on "Meet the Press" triumphing over a cute, cool unknowable from Hawaii who has been on "Meet the Press" a lot.

Americans, suspicious that the Obamas have benefited from affirmative action without being properly grateful, and skeptical that Michelle really likes "The Brady Bunch" and "The Dick Van Dyke Show," reject the 47-year-old black contender as too uppity and untested.

Instead, they embrace 72-year-old John McCain and 44-year-old Sarah Palin, whose average age is 58, a mere two years older than the average age of the Obama-Biden ticket. Enthusiastic Republicans don't see the choice of Palin as affirmative action, despite her thin resume and gaping absence of foreign policy knowledge, because they expect Republicans to put an underqualified "babe," as Rush Limbaugh calls her, on the ticket. They have a tradition of nominating fun, bantamweight cheerleaders, like the previous Miss Congeniality types Dan Quayle and W., and then letting them learn on the job. So they crash into the globe a few times while they're learning to drive, what's the big deal?

Obama may have been president of The Harvard Law Review, but Palin graduated from the University of Idaho with a minor in poli-sci and worked briefly as a TV sports reporter. And she was tougher on the basketball court than the ethereal Obama, earning the nickname "Sarah Barracuda."

The legacy of Geraldine Ferraro was supposed to be that no one would ever go on a blind date with history again. But that crazy maverick and gambler McCain does it, and conservatives and evangelicals rally around him in admiration of his refreshingly cynical choice of Sarah, an evangelical Protestant and anti-abortion crusader who became a hero when she decided to have her baby, who has Down syndrome, and when she urged schools to debate creationism as well as that stuffy old evolution thing.

Palinistas, as they are called, love Sarah's spunky, relentlessly quirky "Northern Exposure" story from being a Miss Alaska runner-up, and winning Miss Congeniality, to being mayor and hockey mom in Wasilla, a rural Alaskan town of 6,715, to being governor for two years to being the first woman ever to run on a national Republican ticket. (Why do men only pick women as running mates when they need a Hail Mary pass? It's a little insulting.)

Sarah is a zealot, but she's a fun zealot. She has a beehive and sexy shoes, and the day she's named she goes shopping with McCain in Ohio for a cheerleader outfit for her daughter.

As she once told Vogue, she's learned the hard way to deal with press comments about her looks. "I wish they'd stick with the issues instead of discussing my black go-go boots," she said. "A reporter once asked me about it during the campaign, and I assured him I was trying to be as frumpy as I could by wearing my hair on top of my head and these schoolmarm glasses."

This chick flick, naturally, features a wild stroke of fate, when the two-year governor of an oversized igloo becomes commander in chief after the president-elect chokes on a pretzel on day one.

The movie ends with the former beauty queen shaking out her pinned-up hair, taking off her glasses, slipping on ruby red peep-toe platform heels that reveal a pink French-style pedicure, and facing down Vladimir Putin in an island in the Bering Strait. Putting away her breast pump, she points her rifle and informs him frostily that she has some expertise in Russia because it's close to Alaska. "Back off, Commie dude," she says. "I'm a much better shot than Cheney."

Then she takes off in her seaplane and lands on the White House lawn, near the new ice fishing hole and hockey rink. The "First Dude," as she calls the hunky Eskimo in the East Wing, waits on his snowmobile with the kids -- Track (named after high school track meets), Bristol (after Bristol Bay where they did commercial fishing), Willow (after a community in Alaska), Piper (just a cool name) and Trig (Norse for "strength").

"The PTA is great preparation for dealing with the KGB," President Palin murmurs to Todd, as they kiss in the final scene while she changes Trig's diaper. "Now that Georgia's safe, how 'bout I cook you up some caribou hot dogs and moose stew for dinner, babe?"


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Maureen Dowd is a syndicated columnist for The New York Times.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Palin: in a preposterous role


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



277 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


MCCAIN'S MASTERSTROKE;
IF I WERE JOE BIDEN, I'D BE WORRIED ABOUT SARAH PALIN


BYLINE: Jack Kelly


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 750 words


I wrote a column back in June in which I said Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin would be the ideal running mate for Sen. John McCain. But I never thought he'd pick her.

I underestimated him. And Democrats will underestimate "Sarah Barracuda" at their peril.

At 44, Sarah Louise Heath Palin is the youngest governor in Alaska's relatively brief history as a state. She's also the nation's most popular governor, with an approval rating in the 80s.

Ms. Palin is popular in part because of her personal qualities. She earned the "Sarah Barracuda" nickname as the point guard on her Wasilla high school basketball team, which she led to the state championship in 1982. Two years later, when she won the Miss Wasilla beauty pageant (and went on to be the first runner up in the Miss Alaska contest) she was also named Miss Congeniality. Fire and nice.

But it's mostly because she's been a crackerjack governor, a strong fiscal conservative and a ferocious fighter of corruption, especially in her own party.

Ms. Palin touches other conservative bases, some of which Mr. McCain has been accused of missing. A regular churchgoer, she's staunchly pro-life. Her eldest son is a soldier. She's a lifetime member of the National Rifle Association who hunts, fishes and runs marathons.

Her wholesome family and modest lifestyle contrast with the wealth Mr. McCain married into, and will make it harder for Democrats to portray the GOP ticket as out of touch with the concerns of ordinary Americans. And it doesn't hurt that Ms. Palin's husband, Todd, a Native American, is a commercial fisherman and an oilfield worker.

Ms. Palin is an expert on energy policy, which figures to be the top domestic issue in this election. (She was ethics commissioner of the Alaska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission before resigning in protest over what she alleged were the lack of ethics by fellow Republicans.) Her presence on the ticket raises hopes that Mr. McCain will soften his opposition to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Preserve.

Kimberley Strassel of the Wall Street Journal has said that Mr. McCain should run -- a la Harry Truman -- against a corrupt, do-nothing Congress this fall. If he chooses to do so, Ms. Palin is the ideal partner. She took on a corrupt GOP establishment in Alaska and pushed a landmark ethics reform bill through the state legislature. She's as much a maverick as Mr. McCain, though one who elates, rather than irritates, conservatives.

"If McCain has in fact chosen Gov. Palin, then count me in with both feet," said radio talk show host Mark Levin, a frequent and often savage critic of Mr. McCain. "Palin is by all accounts a principled conservative and government reformer who can contribute mightily to the decision-making that occurs in the White House."

If elected, Ms. Palin would be the first female vice president in history. This prospect may appeal to some disgruntled Hillary Clinton supporters. On the other hand, pro-abortion women might be put off by her pro-life views.

There is no such thing as the perfect candidate. The knock on Sarah Palin would be her relative inexperience. She's been governor for only 18 months, and before that, the mayor of Wasilla, a small suburb of Anchorage.

But it will be difficult for Democrats to attack Ms. Palin on this without calling attention to Barack Obama's lack of experience. Ms. Palin is the undercard, not the top of the ticket. And her 18 months as governor (not to mention her two terms as mayor) is 18 months more executive experience than Sens. Barack Obama and Joe Biden have combined.

Whether this is a brilliant choice or a bad risk will depend on how Ms. Palin performs on the campaign trail. But if I were Joe Biden, I'd be worried. A former journalist, Sarah Palin is careful about what she says and says it well, qualities for which Mr. Biden is not reknowned. Mr. Obama picked Mr. Biden in part because of his reputed skill as a hatchet man. But if Mr. Biden comes on too hard in the vice presidential debate, he'll look like a bully. And Alaska is littered with the bodies of those who tried to bully Sarah Palin and failed.

What's not in doubt is that Mr. McCain's rollout of his running mate was brilliant. The secret was kept until the last minute, which is remarkable in politics. Speculation about who it would be dominated the morning talk shows Friday, pushing aside discussion of Mr. Obama's acceptance speech.

Mr. McCain has shown political skills few of us thought he had. I think he's about to take the new kid to school.


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Jack Kelly is a columnist for the Post-Gazette (jkelly@post-gazette.com, 412 263-1476).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



278 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


OBAMA FIGHTS SWIFT-BOAT STYLE ATTACKS;
COUNTERATTACK INCLUDES LEGAL ACTION, BOYCOTTS, RESPONSE ADS


BYLINE: Jonathan Weisman, The Washington Post


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-9


LENGTH: 741 words


DATELINE: DENVER


Illinois Sen. Barack Obama's campaign and its allies, mindful of the lessons of the Swift boat attacks of 2004, have begun an aggressive, multi-pronged attack on an advertisement running in swing states that seeks to link the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee to former domestic terrorist William Ayers.

With threats of legal action, boycotts and a response ad launched quietly to avoid publicity, the Obama campaign has put conservative donors and television stations on notice that 2008 will not be 2004, when Massachusetts Sen. John F. Kerry, the Democratic nominee, waited weeks to respond to attacks on his Vietnam War record and ultimately did so ineffectively.

Christian Pinkston, a spokesman for the American Issues Project, which is airing the anti-Obama ad, called the response intimidation and harassment.

Obama campaign lawyer Robert Bauer replied: "If someone rides up to a convenience store with a sawed-off shotgun and a prior record, I'm not intimidating anybody by calling the cops. ... If this [Republican] campaign is going to be run in McCarthyite fashion by lawbreakers in an illegal way, they are going to pay a price."

Mr. Ayers was a member of the Weather Underground, a radical organization that claimed responsibility for a dozen bombings between 1970 and 1974. He is now a professor at the University of Illinois at Chicago and an expert on public school reform.

The ad, financed with a $2.9 million donation from Texas billionaire Harold Simmons, a bundler for Republican Arizona Sen. John McCain, says Mr. Obama has defended Mr. Ayers as "respectable" and "mainstream," and that he launched his political career from Mr. Ayers' home. The Obama campaign says the assertions are demonstrably false.

"Why would Barack Obama be friends with somebody who bombed the Capitol and is proud of it?" intones a voice on the ad, which is running in conservative stretches of Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia. "Do you know enough to elect Barack Obama?"

The ad is no video stunt, said Evan Tracey of the Campaign Media Analysis Group, which tracks political advertising. It began running 10 days ago, and as of Tuesday, $360,000 had been spent on 264 showings, 52 of them in the Grand Rapids, Mich., media market, just under 40 around Cincinnati, 18 in Norfolk, and half a dozen around Pittsburgh, a corner of Pennsylvania that New York Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton dominated in the spring Democratic primary battle.

"Certainly, it connects with base voters," Mr. Tracey said. "If you can't get excited about voting for McCain, these are the kinds of ads that get them excited about voting against Obama."

The television spot has left Mr. Obama with the same dilemma that Mr. Kerry faced four years ago: Respond and risk pushing the issue onto the political talk shows and front pages of newspapers, or ignore it and hope that the attack will not sink in. Mr. Kerry, convinced that few would believe that a decorated Vietnam combat veteran would fabricate his war record, chose to ignore the group Swift Boat Veterans for Truth. When he finally responded, his national advertisement stoked the issue all over again.

Obama campaign officials are taking a different tack. They are running an ad to counter the Ayers spot in the same media markets, but they began with no national media announcement or news conference. The ad itself blames Mr. McCain for the independent Ayers campaign, accusing him of "talking about the '60s" and crimes that Mr. Ayers committed when Mr. Obama was 8 years old, instead of war spending, economic crisis and tax breaks for companies that send jobs overseas.

Mr. Simmons, who helped finance the 2004 Swift boat campaign, has raised $50,000 to $100,000 for Mr. McCain's bid, according to the campaign's Web site.

The counter ad is only part of the Obama team's response. Mr. Bauer has written legal letters to television stations, asserting that the Ayers ad is illegal and false, and that its airing is subject to a Federal Election Commission penalty. Mr. Obama did not call Mr. Ayers "respectable" and "mainstream," Mr. Bauer said. Those words were used by a journalist in an article that was posted along with many others on the Obama campaign Web site.

McCain campaign spokesman Brian Rogers called it "100 percent misleading" to blame the Republican for an ad he had nothing to do with.

He said the campaign has had no discussions with Mr. Simmons about the ad, the issue or the organization.


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: THE ROAD TO THE WHITE


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



279 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


BYLINE: Compiled by Bill Toland


SECTION: EDITORIAL; CUTTING EDGE; Pg. G-4


LENGTH: 716 words


We had a dream

America made history last week, folks. A black man has been nominated by one of the two major parties to run for the presidency of these United States. Gromer Jeffers Jr. of The Dallas Morning News writes:

"For a nation where the torrents of race have tainted history and threaten the future, Mr. Obama's historic nomination makes him the great hope of his party and a barometer of just how much the racial divide has narrowed. Mr. Obama's nomination could deal a death blow to racial politics and the intolerance it often creates. Or racism could resurge with obvious and subtle attempts to stop a black man from winning the White House. So for the next two months -- and the next four years, if Mr. Obama wins -- the nation is in uncharted territory." (dallasnews.com)

Poor Pittsburgh

Last week the U.S. Census told us that Pittsburgh is one of the 10 poorest American cities, based on median household income. The Allegheny Institute blames a Democratic stranglehold on city politics:

"For decades, Pittsburgh has been a city ruled by one party and controlled in large part by the labor unions. These politicians have enacted policies that have shackled economic growth and development and pushed businesses and people across its borders. [Their] idea of economic growth has been to subsidize favored projects like retail stores (Lazarus and Lord & Taylor's), large-scale urban development (Marketplace at Fifth and Forbes), and professional sports teams. Joining Pittsburgh at the bottom of the list are the rust belt cities of Detroit, Cleveland, and Buffalo. ... All these cities share the problem of one-party rule and union-dominated policy making." (alleghenyinstitute.org/blog)

Complicit or incompetent?

The world-famous Burgh Report asks this very question of Pittsburgh Mayor Luke Ravenstahl, now that URA chief Pat Ford has resigned and in so doing accused the young mayor is promoting a "culture of deception and corruption":

"Pat Ford's attorney stated to the PG that the corruption was evidenced by 'the way contracts are supposed to be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, and the way contributions have been made to the mayor.' ... The URA contract for construction management went to McTish, Kunkel & Associates. Firm President Matthew McTish gave Mr. Ravenstahl's campaign a $10,000 contribution in December 2006. [Is] Ford some rogue, cavalier individual? Is Luke Ravenstahl just some doddering old 20-something asleep at the wheel as the city is sold dahna river? [I'm] saying the sharp money is on complicit." (burghreport.blogspot.com)

Donde esta Pedro?

The local sports blogosphere and Bucs fans everywhere had a minor coronary over the Scott Boras / Pedro Alvarez affair: "What's all this business about a missed deadline? About a null and void contract? Why can't I feel my left arm? GAACK." With Scott Boras, super-agent to the superstars, it's almost always about money, writes Patrick Lackey in his blog "Where Have You Gone, Andy Van Slyke?":

"There's no way Boras is pushing this issue if he doesn't have a leg to stand on. What I'm guessing that Boras wants is for the Pirates to renegotiate with Alvarez for any amount of money at all, to avoid the prospect of having the contract voided by a judge or arbitrator. Even if it's only for $200,000, a precedent will be set for renegotiation after the signing deadline, and the deadline itself is rendered relatively useless. That's still what I think this is about, and I don't think Boras would be doing it without some kind of real plan of attack." (whygavs.com)

Don't you know how I hate losing to the Pirates?

With ObamaFest now in the books, Don Surber of the Charleston Daily Mail looks ahead to Sen. John McCain's nomination, and looks back on his resurrection:

"McCain's is one of the biggest comebacks in American political history. He ran out of money last August, had to fire most of his campaign staff and fly commercial. He carried his own baggage. He was down to his last endorsement: Wilford Brimley. On her blog, McCain's daughter, Meghan, recalled how Brimley called in his support and the small group of campaigners left on the McCain staff cheered. Brimley rallied them. With Wilford Brimley on board, all things are possible." (blogs.dailymail.com/donsurber)

Wilford Brimley, Secretary of State?


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: NEW IDEAS SHARP OPINIONS/ Compiled by Bill Toland (btoland@post-gazette.com).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



280 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday
TWO STAR EDITION


NOT A NATURAL SPOT FOR REPUBLICANS


BYLINE: Dennis B. Roddy Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-8


LENGTH: 495 words


DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Minn.


Try as you will, finding Republicans in this town is a veritable snipe hunt. This is not their natural habitat. One of the airport terminals is named for Hubert Humphrey. When a vendor popped into Mickey's, a gritty, dining-car-shaped joint at the corner of 7th and St. Peter, he attempted to hawk some "On Board With McCain" placards.

"I want one that says Obama," replied the waitress.

Business, at least for this guy, will have to wait until tomorrow, when the town is aswarm with conservatives in funny hats.

Visitors from Planet GOP will be deep in the belly of the beast, and the beast looks very much like a donkey.

"I mean, they've gotta have it someplace. I don't know exactly why they picked here," said Josh Johnson, who was strolling a courtyard of sidewalk cafes.

His companion, Mary Schmidt, mentioned that protesters -- she's not entirely sure what they're protesting -- are renting out apartments near her downtown flat for $2,000 each.

"I don't know if I'll protest. I'll probably go check it out. My brother's coming to protest," she said.

At the Coney Island Cafe along St. Peter Street, Mary Arvanitis explained to visitors that her family has owned the business since 1923 and the building dated to 1858, the year of Minnesota's statehood. They advertise the coldest beer in town. Bartender Kurt Hinrichsen estimates it at 37 degrees.

"It's great for our city. We're proud to have them here in the spirit of this election. We're ready. It's a time for everyone to join in and welcome people," said Ms. Arvanitis.

The bar had been closed for 14 years; the owners reopened two days ago to see if the GOP will drink them back to prosperity. On the night they opened Sen. Barack Obama's acceptance speech in Denver was on the bar TV.

Does that mean she'll be voting for the Republicans? She summoned Mr. Hinrichshen, the bartender, and passed the question on to him. He passed it back.

Erin Meister, a 19-year-old college student picked it up, and promptly turned it on its side. "It's definitely spicing up downtown," she said of the Republican invasion.

"It's great for local businesses," chimed in her friend, Annie Heideman, also 19.

Pressed to answer -- and people in this laid-back slice of the Midwest hate to be pressed -- they conceded that the Land of Hubert Humphrey isn't likely to become the adoptive parent of John McCain.

"It is a liberal area," Ms. Meister said. "I don't think people are easily swayed here. I'm not sure it's going to swing their vote."

Would either of them consider voting for the visiting team? A long pause ensued and the room chilled like the beer at Coney Island.

"Clearly," said Miss Heideman, "we don't care to answer that question."

Generally, said Miss Heideman, they try not to think about labels.

Nobody offhand had a precise label for people from St. Paul, save Keith Schmitz, the short-order cook at Mickey's Diner a few blocks from the Xcel Center, where the GOP will convene. "In the wintertime we're called Eskimos," he said.


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE/ Dennis Roddy can be reached at droddy@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1965.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Matthew Hinton/Agence France Presse/Getty Images: People in wheelchairs wait to be loaded onto charter buses at New Orleans Union Passenger Terminal yesterday as voluntary evacuations of Orleans Parish began ahead of a projected landfall of Hurricane Gustav.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



281 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday


Back House Bill 2525 Discovers Puppy Mill In A Pig's Life Barbaric Photo We Are Not Worthy Teacher Offended The Best Medical Care The Race On Race Avenue Obama's 'Choice' Register To Vote Wasted Process Vote Third-Party Similarities With 1896 The Real Issues The Age Card Taking A Back Seat School After Labor Day School Projects More Symptoms


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: P; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 3068 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


TREATMENT OF ANIMALS

July 24, state dog wardens conducted routine inspections of two licensed kennels in Berks County and found dogs suffering from fleas and fly sores so severe that they required immediate medical attention. Rather than arrange for veterinary care, the kennel owners shot every dog in their kennels. Eighty innocent dogs died that day.

In the wake of this senseless tragedy, we are more determined than ever to put a stop to such cruel practices.

The Humane League of Lancaster County is ground zero for dealing with the area's infamous puppy mills. It is our staff and volunteers who spend hours providing puppy mill survivors with the first physical contact they may have ever had and introducing these pathetic creatures to comfort and love, which they have never before known. We have hundreds of success stories, yet know there are thousands waiting to be rescued.

We urge you to contact your local legislator in support of House Bill 2525, which will make it illegal for anyone but a licensed veterinarian to euthanize dogs in commercial breeding kennels and improve the living conditions for those dogs valued only for the puppies they produce. For additional information on getting involved in the fight against puppy mills, contact the Humane League at 393-6551 or visit us online at www.humaneleague.com.

Joan E. Brown

President/CEO

Humane League of Lancaster County

In a recent Internet search for a particular breed of dog, I found a reputable-looking Web site advertising an American Kennel Club-registered kennel in Ronks. The site was inviting, showing very professional pictures of sweet puppies. I called to make an appointment to see the puppies.

Upon arrival, I found an Amish farm with a long, two-story, white building that, by the sight of cages through the windows and barking dogs, I realized was a puppy mill. When I began moving toward the building to see the puppies,I was told I could not enter; they would bring the puppies to me.

As I engaged the kennel owners, it was obvious they knew very little about this particular breed. They knew nothing about the lineage of the parent dogs, and I was prohibited from seeing them. After reporting the kennel to local authorities and the Department of Agriculture, I was told this kennel was denied its 2008 kennel license and the case was in appeal. It continues to be able to sell puppies during this appeal.

Bringing some solace to the situation is that the dog-law enforcement officers do make visits to the kennel. But in the meantime, there are puppies and dogs in a building that is not air-conditioned, living in cages 24/7.

House Bill 2525 must be passed without reservation so that dog-law enforcement officers can put an end to the "gentle folk" abusing and taking innocent lives. Please share your concern with your local legislators.

Nina L. Brown

Lititz

For a county that so little values the rights of animals, based on the unforgivable atrocities taking place at puppy mills, it did not surprise me to be met with the image of a slaughtered pig's head on the front of the Aug. 24 Lancaster section, with the story on the New Holland barbecue cook-off. That is not to say that I was not utterly repulsed.

For that pig to end up as "adornment," as the caption reads, it most likely endured great suffering in the six or so months of its life leading up to slaughter. Castration without anesthetic is commonplace for newborn male pigs, and it is a standard practice to clip both teeth and tails to reduce biting among the animals. As a result of living on a concrete floor, confined to areas with less than a square foot available for movement, they resort to violence. This is far from their natural, affectionate state.

As research indicates the growing health risks of a meat-based diet and worldwide demand for food and energy increases, it makes sense to investigate the benefits of a vegan diet. It is rewarding to contribute to saving the lives of countless animals, as well as to helping reduce the strain on our natural resources.

Let's celebrate the wealth of local and organic produce available to us in Lancaster County and do our part to ensure a sustainable future.

Tracy Fiedler

Earl Township

The top of the Section B cover last Sunday featured a color photo of the charred and decapitated head of a pig as part of the "Going whole-hog in New Holland" article. I had mixed reactions to the paper's decision to print the photo.

On the one hand, such a disgusting and barbaric photo was in poor taste for a family newspaper. And, the photo's caption didn't help matters: "The head of the pig adorns a Momo BBQ table." Adorns?

On the other hand, printing that grotesque image of the barbecued head of what had been a living, innocent, sentient being certainly put a real face on pork for many readers. That image probably did more to influence readers' attitudes towards eating meat than anything People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals or Farm Sanctuary could have accomplished.

The recent shooting of 80 puppy-mill dogs created justifiable outrage - even without the dogs being barbecued or having their heads "adorn" a table as part of a festive, family-oriented event. But because this was just a pig, and not a potential pet, it's somehow acceptable. Explain that logic to the pig - or a child.

Rick L. Thompson

Lancaster

TEACHER BENEFITS

Thank you for printing the wonderfully uplifting letter from retired teacher Joan Galloway [Aug. 24]. It is immensely reassuring to know there are such valuable people in this world.

Oh, the sacrifices! Having to live a lifestyle that holds up to scrutiny. Keeping a clean record. The personal restrictions. The effort that must have gone into achieving excellent credentials.

There is no comparison to the average flapjack-flipping, ditch-digging worker. We are not even worthy to carry her ego.

Bill Haus, Conestoga

Having taught social studies in both the private and public sectors for over a quarter century, I am offended by your editorial ["Do the math," Aug. 24] that serves to mislead and polarize the community. I raise the following points:

-You neglect to mention that teachers are taxpayers, just like everyone else in the community.

-You compare the "average Lancaster County teacher" salary to the "median household income" in the county. That's comparing apples to oranges. It would be appropriate to compare the salaries of teachers to the salaries of professionals who are required to earn a bachelor's degree and state certification and to continue earning academic credits throughout their careers.

-By calling on teachers to "do the right thing," you imply that they are doing the wrong thing by accepting salaries and benefits obtained during contract negotiations with the elected representatives of their school districts. I wonder how many members of the editorial board of your newspaper are willing to give up their employment benefits so that the price of the newspaper could be reduced to benefit the public.

Elizabeth G. Lewis

Elizabethtown

THANK-YOU NOTES

In August 2007, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. My only real option was the removal of my prostate. I did have two choices to make: the hospital, and the doctor.

Family and friends spoke out - Philadelphia, Cleveland, Baltimore, that's where you need to go. After looking into everything and knowing I had the means to go anywhere, I chose Lancaster General Hospital.

My decision resulted in a full recovery. The LGH staff was absolutely terrific. Urological Associates of Lancaster Drs. Paul Sieber and Chris Theodoran are among the best in the country.

This July, I was again diagnosed with cancer. This time renal cell carcinoma (a nasty kidney cancer). Again, I chose Lancaster General Hospital. From beginning to end, the LGH staff, Urological Associates of Lancaster and Dr. [Michael} Rommel were outstanding, and I am a grateful and humble cancer survivor for a second time.

You can go wherever you want. But why would you go elsewhere, when the best care and doctors are right here?

R.E. Lichty, Elizabethtown

nThe West End Cycling Club put on a great bike race Aug. 23, thanks to volunteers and sponsors, as well as the city police and public works departments. More than 120 cyclists from ages 4 to 70 participated.

Last year the city traffic commission approved a Franklin & Marshall College/Public Works Department proposal to construct 10 bulb-outs (curb extensions) and three traffic humps on Race Avenue. Had this plan been carried out, the bike race could not have been held on Race Avenue. Organizers of Saturday's race hope Race Avenue will remain as it is so future bike races can be held here.

Kathy Kunkel, Lancaster

Jerry Greiner, Lancaster

POLITICS

A reader [Aug. 24] claims that because John McCain is pro-life, he will want to invoke the death penalty for women having abortions. This ridiculous statement is typical of the hysteria that abortion advocates attempt to use as they rationalize the horrendous procedures that have been used to terminate the lives of more than 40 million preborn humans.

No one in the pro-life movement advocates penalties for women who are themselves victims of the culture of death that permeates our society. They need compassion and understanding and efforts to alleviate the circumstances that led to such a life-changing decision.

If abortion were no longer legal, the so-called doctors who perform these procedures, usually bottom-feeders who can't make a living preserving life, should have penalties imposed on them such as loss of license, fines and even jail time.

While McCain knows what human life is, Obama can't figure out when a baby, much less a fetus, has human rights. This is not surprising, since in addition to being the most aggressive proponent in the U.S. Senate for abortion at every stage of development, including the barbaric, medically useless procedure known as partial-birth abortion, he is opposed to the "Born Alive" bill that would demand lifesaving treatment for infants who survive attempts to destroy them in the womb. Is supporting such horror as being left to die alone in a cold broom closet the kind of "change" America really wants?

N. Anthony Mastropietro, MD

Lancaster

"We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union" is the opening clause in the preamble to the Constitution.

We, the people, will choose our leadership in November. Yet barely half of the voting-age population exercises the right to vote.

In our country, the accounts of early patriots, women suffragists and civil rights activists document violence inflicted on them that did not derail the movements to win the franchise. Such recollections remind us that our entitlement is both precious and hard-won.

When my husband was in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the first elections in that new state on the heels of decades of dictatorship and years of war, citizens came to the polls dressed up for this solemn and jubilant inaugural occasion.

Oct. 6, at 5 p.m., is the deadline in the county for voter registration. A voter registration form is available online. Google "Lancaster County Voter Registration" for the Web site. The libraries will assist anyone who lacks access to a computer.

Let us see what we, the people, every voter, can do.

Anne Wallace-DiGarbo

Lititz

The candidates for president were chosen prior to the conventions. What a waste of time and money.

I believe the current primary process is extremely unfair to the majority of the voting public. By the time Pennsylvania held its primary, many candidates had already dropped out of the race.

I think the primary election should be held in the same way the presidential election is held - on the same day all across the nation, in June or July, with all serious contenders on the ballot. The top two vote-getters from each party would go out and campaign. Then at the convention in September, the final candidates would be chosen. The presidential election would be held in November, as it is now.

Jeanette Miller, Akron

The first presidential election with both a Democratic and Republican candidate took place in 1856, between Buchanan and Fremont. The problem is both parties have evolved into "Republicrats" and are running candidates that philosophically are the same.

There is a left-wing senator from Illinois who is running to the mainstream, and a Republican from Arizona who is content with dumping his party's base when necessary. Can all of us believe a genuine change will occur if either Obama or McCain get elected?

What America needs is a third-party candidate. I would recommend to anyone who is concerned with the direction of our country to research Libertarian candidate Bob Barr. He understands the need for a common-sense foreign policy, keeping Uncle Sam out of your wallet (tax reform), respecting privacy, maintaining the Second Amendment, and reforming both Social Security and health care.

If you decide Bob Barr's agenda is common sense, be sure to cast a ballot for him in the general election. If you are content with our government as it is, then I suggest voting for either the Democratic or Republican candidate because each one knows how to play partisan politics and not get anything done for the American people.

Jeremy Weaver

New Holland

A lot has been written about how similar this presidential election is to others, but no one has mentioned the election of 1896.

During the second term of Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, the country fell into a economic slump (much worse than this year's), and Democrats suffered huge setbacks in Congress. They nominated a flamboyant, young, handsome and articulate former congressman from Nebraska named William Jennings Bryan. The Republicans nominated the governor of Ohio and Civil War veteran William McKinley.

Bryan was 36 and McKinley was 53. Bryan was energetic, crisscrossed the country giving spellbinding speeches. McKinley could not match Bryan's eloquence or energy but gave "front-porch" speeches at his home.

McKinley went on to win the popular vote by 51 percent . He also won in 1900, beating Bryan once more. He was assassinated early in his second term.

The rest, as they say, is history, though Bryan ran one last time in 1908 and lost to Taft.

Joel Westerhoff

Ephrata

Many Americans of all political parties have suffered both moral and financial blows under George W. Bush. Still, the Republicans advertise doom and gloom if Sen. Obama is elected.

What's the worst that could happen? What if we had eight years of peace and prosperity, ending with a budget surplus, as we had under Bill Clinton?

The spin doctors are knocking each other out to jump on the candidates for every slip of the tongue, shredding character, and constantly harping on negative perception and flimsy supposition. A better way is to compare the Web sites of each candidate and get their views in their own words.

Political diehards who follow a wide array of news sources and feel strongly about their choice can toss off the silliness. The "undecideds," on the other hand, are not just so many percentage points that will determine the winner. They are real people, and they ought to be helped to make a choice based on truth and important issues, not on innuendo and nit-picking.

Frances Gouveia

Lancaster

Undoubtedly, in the presidential debates and discussions, one of the obvious exploitations will be age versus youth.

The Republican's notorious political spin machine will inveigh McCain's experience versus Obama's lack of experience. It may be recalled that Reagan's second term manifested some declining cognitive performance, although he won by a landslide. His opponent (Mondale, 56) did not belabor the age issue.

The Republicans would be ill-advised to use experience as a club; to wit, we have been blessed with the likes of Cheney, Wolfowitz and others. See what a catastrophe we now have. I will opt for the talented and intellectual individual and his excellent advisers.

Poor loser, "experienced" H. Clinton and husband have exploited racial division as their legacy.

G.B. Bisignano, Lancaster

OTHER SUBJECTS

You need to talk to the genius who relegated Kathleen Parker and Leonard Pitts [Aug. 24] to the last page of the Employment section, of all places. Brilliant, really brilliant.

Richard Lauriello

Manheim Township

Our family would like to thank the Manheim Township School District for waiting until after Labor Day to start classes. Although there may be economic benefits, energy efficiencies, and a positive educational impact associated with a first day of school in September, it's also evident that our family with two elementary school children has certainly enjoyed this final week of summer vacation leading up to the traditional end-of-summer holiday.

Karen and Bill Murdock

Manheim Township

Sept. 4, Columbia Borough School Board will hold a public presentation on the costs of renovations in the district. The board is looking to spend as much as $42 million. With Columbia Borough $5.4 million in debt, in addition to skyrocketing taxes, when will it stop? I trust this board did a feasibility study on what impact it will have on property owners.

The enormity of the cost of this project should not be limited to a decision by the nine-member board. I urge every resident to attend this meeting and voice their concern.

How long can we as taxpayers sustain these soaring taxes before foreclosures and for-sale signs decorate this borough?

Tim Swartz

Columbia

I read the story about Abigail Horn's son Ricky, who has Tourette's Syndrome [Aug. 17]. My husband and I have two sons: Tyler, 14, has had Tourette's since he was 4, and Joshua has facial tics and obsessive-compulsive disorder. We, too, have had a lifelong battle with schools and their lack of knowledge of Tourette's.

I believe some of the blame is with people who publish information about this disability. Every time I read an article, there is always the same description of Tourette's, but there are so many more symptoms that are important to acknowledge. There are mental tics as well: singing a song before performing a task, repeating what someone has just said under the breath, writing and rewriting on top of numbers and letters; the list goes on.

I encourage Abigail and her husband to print out a list of all the tics, available on Web sites, and make copies for teachers, especially substitutes and those teachers who will forever think that your child is faking. We have been through it all. Good luck.

Paula Ross

Leola


LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

Joan E. Brown

President/CEO

Humane League of Lancaster County

Lititz

Earl Township

The top of the Section B cover last Sunday featured a color photo of the charred and decapitated head of a pig as part of the "Going whole-hog in New Holland" article. I had mixed reactions to the paper's decision to print the photo.

On the one hand, such a disgusting and barbaric photo was in poor taste for a family newspaper. And, the photo's caption didn't help matters: "The head of the pig adorns a Momo BBQ table." Adorns?

But because this was just a pig, and not a potential pet, it's somehow acceptable. Explain that logic to the pig - or a child.

TEACHER BENEFITS

Thank you for printing the wonderfully uplifting letter from retired teacher Joan Galloway [Aug. 24]. It is immensely reassuring to know there are such valuable people in this world.

Oh, the sacrifices! Having to live a lifestyle that holds up to scrutiny. Keeping a clean record. The personal restrictions. The effort that must have gone into achieving excellent credentials.
