Having taught social studies in both the private and public sectors for over a quarter century, I am offended by your editorial ["Do the math," Aug. 24] that serves to mislead and polarize the community. I raise the following points:

-You neglect to mention that teachers are taxpayers, just like everyone else in the community.

-You compare the "average Lancaster County teacher" salary to the "median household income" in the county. That's comparing apples to oranges. It would be appropriate to compare the salaries of teachers to the salaries of professionals who are required to earn a bachelor's degree and state certification and to continue earning academic credits throughout their careers.

-By calling on teachers to "do the right thing," you imply that they are doing the wrong thing by accepting salaries and benefits obtained during contract negotiations with the elected representatives of their school districts. I wonder how many members of the editorial board of your newspaper are willing to give up their employment benefits so that the price of the newspaper could be reduced to benefit the public.

Elizabeth G. Lewis

Elizabethtown

THANK-YOU NOTES

In August 2007, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. My only real option was the removal of my prostate. I did have two choices to make: the hospital, and the doctor.

Family and friends spoke out - Philadelphia, Cleveland, Baltimore, that's where you need to go. After looking into everything and knowing I had the means to go anywhere, I chose Lancaster General Hospital.

My decision resulted in a full recovery. The LGH staff was absolutely terrific. Urological Associates of Lancaster Drs. Paul Sieber and Chris Theodoran are among the best in the country.

This July, I was again diagnosed with cancer. This time renal cell carcinoma (a nasty kidney cancer). Again, I chose Lancaster General Hospital. From beginning to end, the LGH staff, Urological Associates of Lancaster and Dr. [Michael} Rommel were outstanding, and I am a grateful and humble cancer survivor for a second time.

You can go wherever you want. But why would you go elsewhere, when the best care and doctors are right here?

R.E. Lichty, Elizabethtown

The West End Cycling Club put on a great bike race Aug. 23, thanks to volunteers and sponsors, as well as the city police and public works departments. More than 120 cyclists from ages 4 to 70 participated.

Last year the city traffic commission approved a Franklin & Marshall College/Public Works Department proposal to construct 10 bulb-outs (curb extensions) and three traffic humps on Race Avenue. Had this plan been carried out, the bike race could not have been held on Race Avenue. Organizers of Saturday's race hope Race Avenue will remain as it is so future bike races can be held here.

Kathy Kunkel, Lancaster

Jerry Greiner, Lancaster

POLITICS

A reader [Aug. 24] claims that because John McCain is pro-life, he will want to invoke the death penalty for women having abortions. This ridiculous statement is typical of the hysteria that abortion advocates attempt to use as they rationalize the horrendous procedures that have been used to terminate the lives of more than 40 million preborn humans.

No one in the pro-life movement advocates penalties for women who are themselves victims of the culture of death that permeates our society. They need compassion and understanding and efforts to alleviate the circumstances that led to such a life-changing decision.

If abortion were no longer legal, the so-called doctors who perform these procedures, usually bottom-feeders who can't make a living preserving life, should have penalties imposed on them such as loss of license, fines and even jail time.

While McCain knows what human life is, Obama can't figure out when a baby, much less a fetus, has human rights. This is not surprising, since in addition to being the most aggressive proponent in the U.S. Senate for abortion at every stage of development, including the barbaric, medically useless procedure known as partial-birth abortion, he is opposed to the "Born Alive" bill that would demand lifesaving treatment for infants who survive attempts to destroy them in the womb. Is supporting such horror as being left to die alone in a cold broom closet the kind of "change" America really wants?

N. Anthony Mastropietro, MD

Lancaster

"We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union" is the opening clause in the preamble to the Constitution.

We, the people, will choose our leadership in November. Yet barely half of the voting-age population exercises the right to vote.

In our country, the accounts of early patriots, women suffragists and civil rights activists document violence inflicted on them that did not derail the movements to win the franchise. Such recollections remind us that our entitlement is both precious and hard-won.

When my husband was in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the first elections in that new state on the heels of decades of dictatorship and years of war, citizens came to the polls dressed up for this solemn and jubilant inaugural occasion.

Oct. 6, at 5 p.m., is the deadline in the county for voter registration. A voter registration form is available online. Google "Lancaster County Voter Registration" for the Web site. The libraries will assist anyone who lacks access to a computer.

Let us see what we, the people, every voter, can do.

Anne Wallace-DiGarbo

Lititz

The candidates for president were chosen prior to the conventions. What a waste of time and money.

I believe the current primary process is extremely unfair to the majority of the voting public. By the time Pennsylvania held its primary, many candidates had already dropped out of the race.

I think the primary election should be held in the same way the presidential election is held - on the same day all across the nation, in June or July, with all serious contenders on the ballot. The top two vote-getters from each party would go out and campaign. Then at the convention in September, the final candidates would be chosen. The presidential election would be held in November, as it is now.

Jeanette Miller, Akron

The first presidential election with both a Democratic and Republican candidate took place in 1856, between Buchanan and Fremont. The problem is both parties have evolved into "Republicrats" and are running candidates that philosophically are the same.

There is a left-wing senator from Illinois who is running to the mainstream, and a Republican from Arizona who is content with dumping his party's base when necessary. Can all of us believe a genuine change will occur if either Obama or McCain get elected?

What America needs is a third-party candidate. I would recommend to anyone who is concerned with the direction of our country to research Libertarian candidate Bob Barr. He understands the need for a common-sense foreign policy, keeping Uncle Sam out of your wallet (tax reform), respecting privacy, maintaining the Second Amendment, and reforming both Social Security and health care.

If you decide Bob Barr's agenda is common sense, be sure to cast a ballot for him in the general election. If you are content with our government as it is, then I suggest voting for either the Democratic or Republican candidate because each one knows how to play partisan politics and not get anything done for the American people.

Jeremy Weaver

New Holland

A lot has been written about how similar this presidential election is to others, but no one has mentioned the election of 1896.

During the second term of Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, the country fell into a economic slump (much worse than this year's), and Democrats suffered huge setbacks in Congress. They nominated a flamboyant, young, handsome and articulate former congressman from Nebraska named William Jennings Bryan. The Republicans nominated the governor of Ohio and Civil War veteran William McKinley.

Bryan was 36 and McKinley was 53. Bryan was energetic, crisscrossed the country giving spellbinding speeches. McKinley could not match Bryan's eloquence or energy but gave "front-porch" speeches at his home.

McKinley went on to win the popular vote by 51 percent . He also won in 1900, beating Bryan once more. He was assassinated early in his second term.

The rest, as they say, is history, though Bryan ran one last time in 1908 and lost to Taft.

Joel Westerhoff

Ephrata

Many Americans of all political parties have suffered both moral and financial blows under George W. Bush. Still, the Republicans advertise doom and gloom if Sen. Obama is elected. What's the worst that could happen? What if we had eight years of peace and prosperity, ending with a budget surplus, as we had under Bill Clinton? The spin doctors are knocking each other out to jump on the candidates for every slip of the tongue, shredding character, and constantly harping on negative perception and flimsy supposition. A better way is to compare the Web sites of each candidate and get their views in their own words. Political diehards who follow a wide array of news sources and feel strongly about their choice can toss off the silliness. The "undecideds," on the other hand, are not just so many percentage points that will determine the winner. They are real people, and they ought to be helped to make a choice based on truth and important issues, not on innuendo and nit-picking.

Frances Gouveia

Lancaster

nUndoubtedly, in the presidential debates and discussions, one of the obvious exploitations will be age versus youth.

The Republican's notorious political spin machine will inveigh McCain's experience versus Obama's lack of experience. It may be recalled that Reagan's second term manifested some declining cognitive performance, although he won by a landslide. His opponent (Mondale, 56) did not belabor the age issue.

The Republicans would be ill-advised to use experience as a club; to wit, we have been blessed with the likes of Cheney, Wolfowitz and others. See what a catastrophe we now have. I will opt for the talented and intellectual individual and his excellent advisers.

Poor loser, "experienced" H. Clinton and husband have exploited racial division as their legacy.

G.B. Bisignano, Lancaster

OTHER SUBJECTS

You need to talk to the genius who relegated Kathleen Parker and Leonard Pitts [Aug. 24] to the last page of the Employment section, of all places. Brilliant, really brilliant.

Richard Lauriello

Manheim Township

Our family would like to thank the Manheim Township School District for waiting until after Labor Day to start classes. Although there may be economic benefits, energy efficiencies, and a positive educational impact associated with a first day of school in September, it's also evident that our family with two elementary school children has certainly enjoyed this final week of summer vacation leading up to the traditional end-of-summer holiday.

Karen and Bill Murdock

Manheim Township

Sept. 4, Columbia Borough School Board will hold a public presentation on the costs of renovations in the district. The board is looking to spend as much as $42 million. With Columbia Borough $5.4 million in debt, in addition to skyrocketing taxes, when will it stop? I trust this board did a feasibility study on what impact it will have on property owners.

The enormity of the cost of this project should not be limited to a decision by the nine-member board. I urge every resident to attend this meeting and voice their concern.

How long can we as taxpayers sustain these soaring taxes before foreclosures and for-sale signs decorate this borough?

Tim Swartz

Columbia

I read the story about Abigail Horn's son Ricky, who has Tourette's Syndrome [Aug. 17]. My husband and I have two sons: Tyler, 14, has had Tourette's since he was 4, and Joshua has facial tics and obsessive-compulsive disorder. We, too, have had a lifelong battle with schools and their lack of knowledge of Tourette's.

I believe some of the blame is with people who publish information about this disability. Every time I read an article, there is always the same description of Tourette's, but there are so many more symptoms that are important to acknowledge. There are mental tics as well: singing a song before performing a task, repeating what someone has just said under the breath, writing and rewriting on top of numbers and letters; the list goes on.

I encourage Abigail and her husband to print out a list of all the tics, available on Web sites, and make copies for teachers, especially substitutes and those teachers who will forever think that your child is faking. We have been through it all. Good luck.

Paula Ross

Leola


LOAD-DATE: September 2, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



283 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 31, 2008 Sunday


Back House Bill 2525 Discovers Puppy Mill In A Pig's Life Barbaric Photo We Are Not Worthy Teacher Offended The Best Medical Care The Race On Race Avenue Obama's 'Choice' Register To Vote Wasted Process Vote Third-Party Similarities With 1896 The Real Issues The Age Card Taking A Back Seat School After Labor Day School Projects More Symptoms


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: P; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 3068 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


TREATMENT OF ANIMALS

July 24, state dog wardens conducted routine inspections of two licensed kennels in Berks County and found dogs suffering from fleas and fly sores so severe that they required immediate medical attention. Rather than arrange for veterinary care, the kennel owners shot every dog in their kennels. Eighty innocent dogs died that day.

In the wake of this senseless tragedy, we are more determined than ever to put a stop to such cruel practices.

The Humane League of Lancaster County is ground zero for dealing with the area's infamous puppy mills. It is our staff and volunteers who spend hours providing puppy mill survivors with the first physical contact they may have ever had and introducing these pathetic creatures to comfort and love, which they have never before known. We have hundreds of success stories, yet know there are thousands waiting to be rescued.

We urge you to contact your local legislator in support of House Bill 2525, which will make it illegal for anyone but a licensed veterinarian to euthanize dogs in commercial breeding kennels and improve the living conditions for those dogs valued only for the puppies they produce. For additional information on getting involved in the fight against puppy mills, contact the Humane League at 393-6551 or visit us online at www.humaneleague.com.

Joan E. Brown

President/CEO

Humane League of Lancaster County

In a recent Internet search for a particular breed of dog, I found a reputable-looking Web site advertising an American Kennel Club-registered kennel in Ronks. The site was inviting, showing very professional pictures of sweet puppies. I called to make an appointment to see the puppies.

Upon arrival, I found an Amish farm with a long, two-story, white building that, by the sight of cages through the windows and barking dogs, I realized was a puppy mill. When I began moving toward the building to see the puppies,I was told I could not enter; they would bring the puppies to me.

As I engaged the kennel owners, it was obvious they knew very little about this particular breed. They knew nothing about the lineage of the parent dogs, and I was prohibited from seeing them. After reporting the kennel to local authorities and the Department of Agriculture, I was told this kennel was denied its 2008 kennel license and the case was in appeal. It continues to be able to sell puppies during this appeal.

Bringing some solace to the situation is that the dog-law enforcement officers do make visits to the kennel. But in the meantime, there are puppies and dogs in a building that is not air-conditioned, living in cages 24/7.

House Bill 2525 must be passed without reservation so that dog-law enforcement officers can put an end to the "gentle folk" abusing and taking innocent lives. Please share your concern with your local legislators.

Nina L. Brown

Lititz

For a county that so little values the rights of animals, based on the unforgivable atrocities taking place at puppy mills, it did not surprise me to be met with the image of a slaughtered pig's head on the front of the Aug. 24 Lancaster section, with the story on the New Holland barbecue cook-off. That is not to say that I was not utterly repulsed.

For that pig to end up as "adornment," as the caption reads, it most likely endured great suffering in the six or so months of its life leading up to slaughter. Castration without anesthetic is commonplace for newborn male pigs, and it is a standard practice to clip both teeth and tails to reduce biting among the animals. As a result of living on a concrete floor, confined to areas with less than a square foot available for movement, they resort to violence. This is far from their natural, affectionate state.

As research indicates the growing health risks of a meat-based diet and worldwide demand for food and energy increases, it makes sense to investigate the benefits of a vegan diet. It is rewarding to contribute to saving the lives of countless animals, as well as to helping reduce the strain on our natural resources.

Let's celebrate the wealth of local and organic produce available to us in Lancaster County and do our part to ensure a sustainable future.

Tracy Fiedler

Earl Township

The top of the Section B cover last Sunday featured a color photo of the charred and decapitated head of a pig as part of the "Going whole-hog in New Holland" article. I had mixed reactions to the paper's decision to print the photo.

On the one hand, such a disgusting and barbaric photo was in poor taste for a family newspaper. And, the photo's caption didn't help matters: "The head of the pig adorns a Momo BBQ table." Adorns?

On the other hand, printing that grotesque image of the barbecued head of what had been a living, innocent, sentient being certainly put a real face on pork for many readers. That image probably did more to influence readers' attitudes towards eating meat than anything People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals or Farm Sanctuary could have accomplished.

The recent shooting of 80 puppy-mill dogs created justifiable outrage - even without the dogs being barbecued or having their heads "adorn" a table as part of a festive, family-oriented event. But because this was just a pig, and not a potential pet, it's somehow acceptable. Explain that logic to the pig - or a child.

Rick L. Thompson

Lancaster

TEACHER BENEFITS

Thank you for printing the wonderfully uplifting letter from retired teacher Joan Galloway [Aug. 24]. It is immensely reassuring to know there are such valuable people in this world.

Oh, the sacrifices! Having to live a lifestyle that holds up to scrutiny. Keeping a clean record. The personal restrictions. The effort that must have gone into achieving excellent credentials.

There is no comparison to the average flapjack-flipping, ditch-digging worker. We are not even worthy to carry her ego.

Bill Haus, Conestoga

Having taught social studies in both the private and public sectors for over a quarter century, I am offended by your editorial ["Do the math," Aug. 24] that serves to mislead and polarize the community. I raise the following points:

-You neglect to mention that teachers are taxpayers, just like everyone else in the community.

-You compare the "average Lancaster County teacher" salary to the "median household income" in the county. That's comparing apples to oranges. It would be appropriate to compare the salaries of teachers to the salaries of professionals who are required to earn a bachelor's degree and state certification and to continue earning academic credits throughout their careers.

-By calling on teachers to "do the right thing," you imply that they are doing the wrong thing by accepting salaries and benefits obtained during contract negotiations with the elected representatives of their school districts. I wonder how many members of the editorial board of your newspaper are willing to give up their employment benefits so that the price of the newspaper could be reduced to benefit the public.

Elizabeth G. Lewis

Elizabethtown

THANK-YOU NOTES

In August 2007, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. My only real option was the removal of my prostate. I did have two choices to make: the hospital, and the doctor.

Family and friends spoke out - Philadelphia, Cleveland, Baltimore, that's where you need to go. After looking into everything and knowing I had the means to go anywhere, I chose Lancaster General Hospital.

My decision resulted in a full recovery. The LGH staff was absolutely terrific. Urological Associates of Lancaster Drs. Paul Sieber and Chris Theodoran are among the best in the country.

This July, I was again diagnosed with cancer. This time renal cell carcinoma (a nasty kidney cancer). Again, I chose Lancaster General Hospital. From beginning to end, the LGH staff, Urological Associates of Lancaster and Dr. [Michael} Rommel were outstanding, and I am a grateful and humble cancer survivor for a second time.

You can go wherever you want. But why would you go elsewhere, when the best care and doctors are right here?

R.E. Lichty, Elizabethtown

nThe West End Cycling Club put on a great bike race Aug. 23, thanks to volunteers and sponsors, as well as the city police and public works departments. More than 120 cyclists from ages 4 to 70 participated.

Last year the city traffic commission approved a Franklin & Marshall College/Public Works Department proposal to construct 10 bulb-outs (curb extensions) and three traffic humps on Race Avenue. Had this plan been carried out, the bike race could not have been held on Race Avenue. Organizers of Saturday's race hope Race Avenue will remain as it is so future bike races can be held here.

Kathy Kunkel, Lancaster

Jerry Greiner, Lancaster

POLITICS

A reader [Aug. 24] claims that because John McCain is pro-life, he will want to invoke the death penalty for women having abortions. This ridiculous statement is typical of the hysteria that abortion advocates attempt to use as they rationalize the horrendous procedures that have been used to terminate the lives of more than 40 million preborn humans.

No one in the pro-life movement advocates penalties for women who are themselves victims of the culture of death that permeates our society. They need compassion and understanding and efforts to alleviate the circumstances that led to such a life-changing decision.

If abortion were no longer legal, the so-called doctors who perform these procedures, usually bottom-feeders who can't make a living preserving life, should have penalties imposed on them such as loss of license, fines and even jail time.

While McCain knows what human life is, Obama can't figure out when a baby, much less a fetus, has human rights. This is not surprising, since in addition to being the most aggressive proponent in the U.S. Senate for abortion at every stage of development, including the barbaric, medically useless procedure known as partial-birth abortion, he is opposed to the "Born Alive" bill that would demand lifesaving treatment for infants who survive attempts to destroy them in the womb. Is supporting such horror as being left to die alone in a cold broom closet the kind of "change" America really wants?

N. Anthony Mastropietro, MD

Lancaster

"We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union" is the opening clause in the preamble to the Constitution.

We, the people, will choose our leadership in November. Yet barely half of the voting-age population exercises the right to vote.

In our country, the accounts of early patriots, women suffragists and civil rights activists document violence inflicted on them that did not derail the movements to win the franchise. Such recollections remind us that our entitlement is both precious and hard-won.

When my husband was in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the first elections in that new state on the heels of decades of dictatorship and years of war, citizens came to the polls dressed up for this solemn and jubilant inaugural occasion.

Oct. 6, at 5 p.m., is the deadline in the county for voter registration. A voter registration form is available online. Google "Lancaster County Voter Registration" for the Web site. The libraries will assist anyone who lacks access to a computer.

Let us see what we, the people, every voter, can do.

Anne Wallace-DiGarbo

Lititz

The candidates for president were chosen prior to the conventions. What a waste of time and money.

I believe the current primary process is extremely unfair to the majority of the voting public. By the time Pennsylvania held its primary, many candidates had already dropped out of the race.

I think the primary election should be held in the same way the presidential election is held - on the same day all across the nation, in June or July, with all serious contenders on the ballot. The top two vote-getters from each party would go out and campaign. Then at the convention in September, the final candidates would be chosen. The presidential election would be held in November, as it is now.

Jeanette Miller, Akron

The first presidential election with both a Democratic and Republican candidate took place in 1856, between Buchanan and Fremont. The problem is both parties have evolved into "Republicrats" and are running candidates that philosophically are the same.

There is a left-wing senator from Illinois who is running to the mainstream, and a Republican from Arizona who is content with dumping his party's base when necessary. Can all of us believe a genuine change will occur if either Obama or McCain get elected?

What America needs is a third-party candidate. I would recommend to anyone who is concerned with the direction of our country to research Libertarian candidate Bob Barr. He understands the need for a common-sense foreign policy, keeping Uncle Sam out of your wallet (tax reform), respecting privacy, maintaining the Second Amendment, and reforming both Social Security and health care.

If you decide Bob Barr's agenda is common sense, be sure to cast a ballot for him in the general election. If you are content with our government as it is, then I suggest voting for either the Democratic or Republican candidate because each one knows how to play partisan politics and not get anything done for the American people.

Jeremy Weaver

New Holland

A lot has been written about how similar this presidential election is to others, but no one has mentioned the election of 1896.

During the second term of Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, the country fell into a economic slump (much worse than this year's), and Democrats suffered huge setbacks in Congress. They nominated a flamboyant, young, handsome and articulate former congressman from Nebraska named William Jennings Bryan. The Republicans nominated the governor of Ohio and Civil War veteran William McKinley.

Bryan was 36 and McKinley was 53. Bryan was energetic, crisscrossed the country giving spellbinding speeches. McKinley could not match Bryan's eloquence or energy but gave "front-porch" speeches at his home.

McKinley went on to win the popular vote by 51 percent . He also won in 1900, beating Bryan once more. He was assassinated early in his second term.

The rest, as they say, is history, though Bryan ran one last time in 1908 and lost to Taft.

Joel Westerhoff

Ephrata

Many Americans of all political parties have suffered both moral and financial blows under George W. Bush. Still, the Republicans advertise doom and gloom if Sen. Obama is elected.

What's the worst that could happen? What if we had eight years of peace and prosperity, ending with a budget surplus, as we had under Bill Clinton?

The spin doctors are knocking each other out to jump on the candidates for every slip of the tongue, shredding character, and constantly harping on negative perception and flimsy supposition. A better way is to compare the Web sites of each candidate and get their views in their own words.

Political diehards who follow a wide array of news sources and feel strongly about their choice can toss off the silliness. The "undecideds," on the other hand, are not just so many percentage points that will determine the winner. They are real people, and they ought to be helped to make a choice based on truth and important issues, not on innuendo and nit-picking.

Frances Gouveia

Lancaster

Undoubtedly, in the presidential debates and discussions, one of the obvious exploitations will be age versus youth.

The Republican's notorious political spin machine will inveigh McCain's experience versus Obama's lack of experience. It may be recalled that Reagan's second term manifested some declining cognitive performance, although he won by a landslide. His opponent (Mondale, 56) did not belabor the age issue.

The Republicans would be ill-advised to use experience as a club; to wit, we have been blessed with the likes of Cheney, Wolfowitz and others. See what a catastrophe we now have. I will opt for the talented and intellectual individual and his excellent advisers.

Poor loser, "experienced" H. Clinton and husband have exploited racial division as their legacy.

G.B. Bisignano, Lancaster

OTHER SUBJECTS

You need to talk to the genius who relegated Kathleen Parker and Leonard Pitts [Aug. 24] to the last page of the Employment section, of all places. Brilliant, really brilliant.

Richard Lauriello

Manheim Township

Our family would like to thank the Manheim Township School District for waiting until after Labor Day to start classes. Although there may be economic benefits, energy efficiencies, and a positive educational impact associated with a first day of school in September, it's also evident that our family with two elementary school children has certainly enjoyed this final week of summer vacation leading up to the traditional end-of-summer holiday.

Karen and Bill Murdock

Manheim Township

Sept. 4, Columbia Borough School Board will hold a public presentation on the costs of renovations in the district. The board is looking to spend as much as $42 million. With Columbia Borough $5.4 million in debt, in addition to skyrocketing taxes, when will it stop? I trust this board did a feasibility study on what impact it will have on property owners.

The enormity of the cost of this project should not be limited to a decision by the nine-member board. I urge every resident to attend this meeting and voice their concern.

How long can we as taxpayers sustain these soaring taxes before foreclosures and for-sale signs decorate this borough?

Tim Swartz

Columbia

I read the story about Abigail Horn's son Ricky, who has Tourette's Syndrome [Aug. 17]. My husband and I have two sons: Tyler, 14, has had Tourette's since he was 4, and Joshua has facial tics and obsessive-compulsive disorder. We, too, have had a lifelong battle with schools and their lack of knowledge of Tourette's.

I believe some of the blame is with people who publish information about this disability. Every time I read an article, there is always the same description of Tourette's, but there are so many more symptoms that are important to acknowledge. There are mental tics as well: singing a song before performing a task, repeating what someone has just said under the breath, writing and rewriting on top of numbers and letters; the list goes on.

I encourage Abigail and her husband to print out a list of all the tics, available on Web sites, and make copies for teachers, especially substitutes and those teachers who will forever think that your child is faking. We have been through it all. Good luck.

Paula Ross

Leola

July 24, state dog wardens conducted routine inspections of two licensed kennels in Berks County and found dogs suffering from fleas and fly sores so severe that they required immediate medical attention. Rather than arrange for veterinary care, the kennel owners shot every dog in their kennels. Eighty innocent dogs died that day.

It is our staff and volunteers who spend hours providing puppy mill survivors with the first physical contact they may have ever had and introducing these pathetic creatures to comfort and love, which they have never before known. We have hundreds of success stories, yet know there are thousands waiting to be rescued.

We urge you to contact your local legislator in support of House Bill 2525, which will make it illegal for anyone but a licensed veterinarian to euthanize dogs in commercial breeding kennels and improve the living conditions for those dogs valued only for the puppies they produce. For additional information on getting involved in the fight against puppy mills, contact the Humane League at 393-6551 or visit us online at www.humaneleague.com.

Joan E. Brown

President/CEO

Humane League of Lancaster County

In a recent Internet search for a particular breed of dog, I found a reputable-looking Web site advertising an American Kennel Club-registered kennel in Ronks. The site was inviting, showing very professional pictures of sweet puppies. I called to make an appointment to see the puppies.

Upon arrival, I found an Amish farm with a long, two-story, white building that, by the sight of cages through the windows and barking dogs, I realized was a puppy mill. When I began moving toward the building to see the puppies,I was told I could not enter; they would bring the puppies to me.

As I engaged the kennel owners, it was obvious they knew very little about this particular breed. They knew nothing about the lineage of the parent dogs, and I was prohibited from seeing them. After reporting the kennel to local authorities and the Department of Agriculture, I was told this kennel was denied its 2008 kennel license and the case was in appeal. It continues to be able to sell puppies during this appeal.

Bringing some solace to the situation is that the dog-law enforcement officers do make visits to the kennel. But in the meantime, there are puppies and dogs in a building that is not air-conditioned, living in cages 24/7.

House Bill 2525 must be passed without reservation so that dog-law enforcement officers can put an end to the "gentle folk" abusing and taking innocent lives. Please share your concern with your local legislators.

Nina L. Brown

Lititz

nFor a county that so little values the rights of animals, based on the unforgivable atrocities taking place at puppy mills, it did not surprise me to be met with the image of a slaughtered pig's head on the front of the Aug. 24 Lancaster section, with the story on the New Holland barbecue cook-off. That is not to say that I was not utterly repulsed.

For that pig to end up as "adornment," as the caption reads, it most likely endured great suffering in the six or so months of its life leading up to slaughter. Castration without anesthetic is commonplace for newborn male pigs, and it is a standard practice to clip both teeth and tails to reduce biting among the animals. As a result of living on a concrete floor, confined to areas with less than a square foot available for movement, they resort to violence. This is far from their natural, affectionate state.

It is rewarding to contribute to saving the lives of countless animals, as well as to helping reduce the strain on our natural resources.

Let's celebrate the wealth of local and organic produce available to us in Lancaster County and do our part to ensure a sustainable future.

Tracy Fiedler

Earl Township

The top of the Section B cover last Sunday featured a color photo of the charred and decapitated head of a pig as part of the "Going whole-hog in New Holland" article. I had mixed reactions to the paper's decision to print the photo.

On the one hand, such a disgusting and barbaric photo was in poor taste for a family newspaper. And, the photo's caption didn't help matters: "The head of the pig adorns a Momo BBQ table." Adorns?

On the other hand, printing that grotesque image of the barbecued head of what had been a living, innocent, sentient being certainly put a real face on pork for many readers. That image probably did more to influence readers' attitudes towards eating meat than anything People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals or Farm Sanctuary could have accomplished.

The recent shooting of 80 puppy-mill dogs created justifiable outrage - even without the dogs being barbecued or having their heads "adorn" a table as part of a festive, family-oriented event. But because this was just a pig, and not a potential pet, it's somehow acceptable. Explain that logic to the pig - or a child.

Rick L. Thompson

Lancaster

TEACHER BENEFITS

Thank you for printing the wonderfully uplifting letter from retired teacher Joan Galloway [Aug. 24]. It is immensely reassuring to know there are such valuable people in this world.

Oh, the sacrifices! Having to live a lifestyle that holds up to scrutiny. Keeping a clean record. The personal restrictions. The effort that must have gone into achieving excellent credentials.

There is no comparison to the average flapjack-flipping, ditch-digging worker. We are not even worthy to carry her ego.

Bill Haus, Conestoga

Having taught social studies in both the private and public sectors for over a quarter century, I am offended by your editorial ["Do the math," Aug. 24] that serves to mislead and polarize the community. I raise the following points:

-You neglect to mention that teachers are taxpayers, just like everyone else in the community.

-You compare the "average Lancaster County teacher" salary to the "median household income" in the county. That's comparing apples to oranges. It would be appropriate to compare the salaries of teachers to the salaries of professionals who are required to earn a bachelor's degree and state certification and to continue earning academic credits throughout their careers.

-By calling on teachers to "do the right thing," you imply that they are doing the wrong thing by accepting salaries and benefits obtained during contract negotiations with the elected representatives of their school districts. I wonder how many members of the editorial board of your newspaper are willing to give up their employment benefits so that the price of the newspaper could be reduced to benefit the public.

Elizabeth G. Lewis

Elizabethtown

THANK-YOU NOTES

In August 2007, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. My only real option was the removal of my prostate. I did have two choices to make: the hospital, and the doctor.

Family and friends spoke out - Philadelphia, Cleveland, Baltimore, that's where you need to go. After looking into everything and knowing I had the means to go anywhere, I chose Lancaster General Hospital.

My decision resulted in a full recovery. The LGH staff was absolutely terrific. Urological Associates of Lancaster Drs. Paul Sieber and Chris Theodoran are among the best in the country.

This July, I was again diagnosed with cancer. This time renal cell carcinoma (a nasty kidney cancer). Again, I chose Lancaster General Hospital. From beginning to end, the LGH staff, Urological Associates of Lancaster and Dr. [Michael} Rommel were outstanding, and I am a grateful and humble cancer survivor for a second time.

You can go wherever you want. But why would you go elsewhere, when the best care and doctors are right here?

R.E. Lichty, Elizabethtown

The West End Cycling Club put on a great bike race Aug. 23, thanks to volunteers and sponsors, as well as the city police and public works departments. More than 120 cyclists from ages 4 to 70 participated.

Last year the city traffic commission approved a Franklin & Marshall College/Public Works Department proposal to construct 10 bulb-outs (curb extensions) and three traffic humps on Race Avenue. Had this plan been carried out, the bike race could not have been held on Race Avenue. Organizers of Saturday's race hope Race Avenue will remain as it is so future bike races can be held here.

Kathy Kunkel, Lancaster

Jerry Greiner, Lancaster

POLITICS

A reader [Aug. 24] claims that because John McCain is pro-life, he will want to invoke the death penalty for women having abortions. This ridiculous statement is typical of the hysteria that abortion advocates attempt to use as they rationalize the horrendous procedures that have been used to terminate the lives of more than 40 million preborn humans.

No one in the pro-life movement advocates penalties for women who are themselves victims of the culture of death that permeates our society. They need compassion and understanding and efforts to alleviate the circumstances that led to such a life-changing decision.

If abortion were no longer legal, the so-called doctors who perform these procedures, usually bottom-feeders who can't make a living preserving life, should have penalties imposed on them such as loss of license, fines and even jail time.

While McCain knows what human life is, Obama can't figure out when a baby, much less a fetus, has human rights. This is not surprising, since in addition to being the most aggressive proponent in the U.S. Senate for abortion at every stage of development, including the barbaric, medically useless procedure known as partial-birth abortion, he is opposed to the "Born Alive" bill that would demand lifesaving treatment for infants who survive attempts to destroy them in the womb. Is supporting such horror as being left to die alone in a cold broom closet the kind of "change" America really wants?

N. Anthony Mastropietro, MD

Lancaster

"We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union" is the opening clause in the preamble to the Constitution.

We, the people, will choose our leadership in November. Yet barely half of the voting-age population exercises the right to vote.

In our country, the accounts of early patriots, women suffragists and civil rights activists document violence inflicted on them that did not derail the movements to win the franchise. Such recollections remind us that our entitlement is both precious and hard-won.

When my husband was in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the first elections in that new state on the heels of decades of dictatorship and years of war, citizens came to the polls dressed up for this solemn and jubilant inaugural occasion.

Oct. 6, at 5 p.m., is the deadline in the county for voter registration. A voter registration form is available online. Google "Lancaster County Voter Registration" for the Web site. The libraries will assist anyone who lacks access to a computer.

Let us see what we, the people, every voter, can do.

Anne Wallace-DiGarbo

Lititz

The candidates for president were chosen prior to the conventions. What a waste of time and money.

I believe the current primary process is extremely unfair to the majority of the voting public. By the time Pennsylvania held its primary, many candidates had already dropped out of the race.

I think the primary election should be held in the same way the presidential election is held - on the same day all across the nation, in June or July, with all serious contenders on the ballot. The top two vote-getters from each party would go out and campaign. Then at the convention in September, the final candidates would be chosen. The presidential election would be held in November, as it is now.

Jeanette Miller, Akron

The first presidential election with both a Democratic and Republican candidate took place in 1856, between Buchanan and Fremont. The problem is both parties have evolved into "Republicrats" and are running candidates that philosophically are the same.

There is a left-wing senator from Illinois who is running to the mainstream, and a Republican from Arizona who is content with dumping his party's base when necessary. Can all of us believe a genuine change will occur if either Obama or McCain get elected?

What America needs is a third-party candidate. I would recommend to anyone who is concerned with the direction of our country to research Libertarian candidate Bob Barr. He understands the need for a common-sense foreign policy, keeping Uncle Sam out of your wallet (tax reform), respecting privacy, maintaining the Second Amendment, and reforming both Social Security and health care.

If you decide Bob Barr's agenda is common sense, be sure to cast a ballot for him in the general election. If you are content with our government as it is, then I suggest voting for either the Democratic or Republican candidate because each one knows how to play partisan politics and not get anything done for the American people.

Jeremy Weaver

New Holland

A lot has been written about how similar this presidential election is to others, but no one has mentioned the election of 1896.

During the second term of Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, the country fell into a economic slump (much worse than this year's), and Democrats suffered huge setbacks in Congress. They nominated a flamboyant, young, handsome and articulate former congressman from Nebraska named William Jennings Bryan. The Republicans nominated the governor of Ohio and Civil War veteran William McKinley.

Bryan was 36 and McKinley was 53. Bryan was energetic, crisscrossed the country giving spellbinding speeches. McKinley could not match Bryan's eloquence or energy but gave "front-porch" speeches at his home.

McKinley went on to win the popular vote by 51 percent . He also won in 1900, beating Bryan once more. He was assassinated early in his second term.

The rest, as they say, is history, though Bryan ran one last time in 1908 and lost to Taft.

Joel Westerhoff

Ephrata

Many Americans of all political parties have suffered both moral and financial blows under George W. Bush. Still, the Republicans advertise doom and gloom if Sen. Obama is elected. What's the worst that could happen? What if we had eight years of peace and prosperity, ending with a budget surplus, as we had under Bill Clinton? The spin doctors are knocking each other out to jump on the candidates for every slip of the tongue, shredding character, and constantly harping on negative perception and flimsy supposition. A better way is to compare the Web sites of each candidate and get their views in their own words. Political diehards who follow a wide array of news sources and feel strongly about their choice can toss off the silliness. The "undecideds," on the other hand, are not just so many percentage points that will determine the winner. They are real people, and they ought to be helped to make a choice based on truth and important issues, not on innuendo and nit-picking.

Frances Gouveia

Lancaster

nUndoubtedly, in the presidential debates and discussions, one of the obvious exploitations will be age versus youth.

The Republican's notorious political spin machine will inveigh McCain's experience versus Obama's lack of experience. It may be recalled that Reagan's second term manifested some declining cognitive performance, although he won by a landslide. His opponent (Mondale, 56) did not belabor the age issue.

The Republicans would be ill-advised to use experience as a club; to wit, we have been blessed with the likes of Cheney, Wolfowitz and others. See what a catastrophe we now have. I will opt for the talented and intellectual individual and his excellent advisers.

Poor loser, "experienced" H. Clinton and husband have exploited racial division as their legacy.

G.B. Bisignano, Lancaster

OTHER SUBJECTS

You need to talk to the genius who relegated Kathleen Parker and Leonard Pitts [Aug. 24] to the last page of the Employment section, of all places. Brilliant, really brilliant.

Richard Lauriello

Manheim Township

Our family would like to thank the Manheim Township School District for waiting until after Labor Day to start classes. Although there may be economic benefits, energy efficiencies, and a positive educational impact associated with a first day of school in September, it's also evident that our family with two elementary school children has certainly enjoyed this final week of summer vacation leading up to the traditional end-of-summer holiday.

Karen and Bill Murdock

Manheim Township

Sept. 4, Columbia Borough School Board will hold a public presentation on the costs of renovations in the district. The board is looking to spend as much as $42 million. With Columbia Borough $5.4 million in debt, in addition to skyrocketing taxes, when will it stop? I trust this board did a feasibility study on what impact it will have on property owners.

The enormity of the cost of this project should not be limited to a decision by the nine-member board. I urge every resident to attend this meeting and voice their concern.

How long can we as taxpayers sustain these soaring taxes before foreclosures and for-sale signs decorate this borough?

Tim Swartz

Columbia

I read the story about Abigail Horn's son Ricky, who has Tourette's Syndrome [Aug. 17]. My husband and I have two sons: Tyler, 14, has had Tourette's since he was 4, and Joshua has facial tics and obsessive-compulsive disorder. We, too, have had a lifelong battle with schools and their lack of knowledge of Tourette's.

I believe some of the blame is with people who publish information about this disability. Every time I read an article, there is always the same description of Tourette's, but there are so many more symptoms that are important to acknowledge. There are mental tics as well: singing a song before performing a task, repeating what someone has just said under the breath, writing and rewriting on top of numbers and letters; the list goes on.

I encourage Abigail and her husband to print out a list of all the tics, available on Web sites, and make copies for teachers, especially substitutes and those teachers who will forever think that your child is faking. We have been through it all. Good luck.

Paula Ross

Leola

285 of 461 DOCUMENTS



York Daily Record (Pennsylvania)


Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News


August 31, 2008 Sunday


OPINION: Time for campaign to focus on the little things


BYLINE: Mike Argento, York Daily Record, Pa.


SECTION: COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 911 words


Aug. 31--NEWS ITEM: On the first night of the Democratic National Convention, after Michelle Obama delivered a speech, she was joined on stage by her daughters, Malia, 10, and Sasha, 7, as her husband joined them via satellite from the Kansas City living room of the Gerardo family. Sasha grabbed the mic and said, "Hi, Gerardo family!"

VOICE-OVER: She's one of the cutest kids you'll ever see.

SASHA (on stage at the convention): Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: She's cuter than a bucket full of puppies. Cuter than a wheelbarrow full of kittens, or a dump truck full of Mylie Cyruses. She's probably one of the cutest kids on the face of the earth right now.

SASHA (again from the convention): Hi, Gerardo family!

VOICE-OVER: She can say hi to her daddy and to the Gerardo family. She loves the Jonas Brothers. And she is so cute she makes your teeth hurt. But is she ready to lead? Does she even know the Gerardo family?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: As American families wonder about how they are going to pay their bills and are struggling to keep up with inflation, Sasha Obama does nothing.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Is she opposed to off-shore drilling? Here is her answer.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Is she opposed to raising taxes?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Does she have a plan to win the war in Iraq?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: This country is facing

numerous problems and her answer is always the same.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Can America afford four years of this?

SASHA: What city are you in, Daddy?

VOICE-OVER: It was after 10 o'clock, and she didn't know where her daddy was.

JOHN McCAIN: I'm John McCain and I approve this message.

VOICE-OVER: Out-of-control gas prices. An uncertain economy. A health care crisis. A wasteful war in Iraq. And what do we get from the John McCain campaign?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: More of the same old political nonsense from some guy who doesn't even know how many houses he owns. He criticizes Sasha Obama, but does he have any ideas of his own?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: And who's John McCain's daddy? George Bush. McCain has supported George Bush's failed policies more than we can ever say in a short TV ad. Are we ready for four more years of George Bush?

SASHA: No, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Like a lot of young people, Sasha believes in hope. She hopes for a better America. And ending tax breaks for big oil companies.

SASHA: I'm Sasha Obama and my daddy approves this message.

VOICE-OVER: Sasha Obama says she believes in hope. But it'll take more than hope and cute kids to get this country back on track.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: She is very cute, but where was she when John McCain was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam? Was she even aware that John McCain was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam? Did she even care?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: She's a little kid who's not ready to lead. She's not the kind of change we can believe in.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: This kid is getting annoying. Does she even care that John McCain was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam? Did you know that John McCain was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam? This snot-nosed little brat stands there looking all cute and everything, not even knowing that John McCain was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam. Little brat.

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

VOICE-OVER: Shut up, already!

McCAIN: I'm John McCain and I approve this message.

VOICE-OVER: John McCain thinks he can call Sasha Obama a snot-nosed little brat? Where does he get off? The guy doesn't even know how many houses he owns.

McCAIN: My friends . . .

VOICE-OVER: And what's with him always referring to us as "my friends"? We're not his friends. When's the last time he called us up and asked how our dog was doing? When's the last time he stopped by the house to borrow money to buy another house? When's the last time he invited you over to one of his seven or eight houses to watch a football game?

McCAIN: My friends . . .

VOICE-OVER: He doesn't know what that means. He doesn't even know how many houses he has. My friends. Please.

OBAMA: I'm Barack Obama and I approve this message.

VOICE-OVER: Recently, the Democrats have attacked John McCain because he doesn't know how many houses he owns.

McCAIN: I'll have my staff get back to you.

VOICE-OVER: He doesn't need to know how many houses he has to be president. He has a staff for that. He's not the kind of elitist person who knows, just off the top of his head, how many houses he owns. He's a regular American, just like all of you. If someone were to ask you how many pairs of socks you own, could you tell them? And he was a prisoner of war for 5 1/2 years in Vietnam.

McCAIN: I'm John McCain and I approve this message.

VOICE-OVER: The same old politics. Only one candidate believes we should get back to discussing the important issues facing America: Is Sasha Obama cute or what?

SASHA: Hi, Daddy!

OBAMA: I'm Barack Obama and I approve this message.

Mike Argento's column appears Mondays and Fridays in Living and Sundays in Viewpoints. Reach him at mike@ydr.com or 771-2046.

To see more of the York Daily Record, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to http://www.ydr.com. Copyright (c) 2008, York Daily Record, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. LOAD-DATE: August 31, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


ACC-NO: 20080831-YO-OPINION-Time-for-campaign-to-focus-on-the-little-things-0831

JOURNAL-CODE: YO

286 of 461 DOCUMENTS



York Daily Record (Pennsylvania)


Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News


August 31, 2008 Sunday


Republicans' turn: The local party chairman says the lack of drama will be an asset.


BYLINE: Tom Joyce, York Daily Record, Pa.


SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS


LENGTH: 785 words


Aug. 31--Ron Smith of Dallastown said he'll probably catch some of the Republican National Convention on TV next week.

He's OK with John McCain, if not exactly enthused. He wishes that McCain had a stronger record against abortion and in favor of gun rights. But he figures that when it comes to national security and the economy, the Arizona senator stands head and shoulders above Barack Obama.

So there's no question Smith will vote for McCain come November. He wouldn't be averse to doing some campaign work for the candidate, either.

"He's not my first selection, but I'm willing to support him," Smith said.

Dr. Craig Smith, a professor of communications studies at California State University, Long Beach, said McCain's going to need voters such as Ron Smith if

he's going to win the general election. With the margin of potential swing voters already narrowed since 2004, they'll need crossover Democrats as well.

In the next few days, Craig Smith said, expect to see the national Republican Party reinforcing Ron Smith's reasoning -- that McCain might not be flashy, but he's by far the more pragmatic

choice.

"They understand that the economy is very important, and they would be wise to talk about it," Craig Smith said.

Craig Smith knows a thing or two about trying to get out a message during a national convention, and the difference that message can make in the subsequent vote. He's a former speechwriter for two presidents: Gerald Ford and George H.W. Bush.

At the start of the Republican National Convention in 1988, Michael Dukakis led George H.W. Bush in the polls by 10 points. By the time the convention was over, the elder Bush led by six points and never fell behind again for the rest of the campaign.

What made the difference, Craig Smith said, is that Dukakis was vague enough to let his Republican opponents define him at their convention.

Since his ascendancy to presidential contender, Obama has struggled with a similar perception of vagueness, Craig Smith said. If McCain and his advisors are smart, they'll play off that and present McCain as the man with nuts-and-bolts solutions to the nation's problems. In effect, they'll use Obama's considerable charisma against him.

Though McCain's campaign ended the week with an ad complimenting Obama, Smith said the campaign took a gamble by running negative ads during the Democratic convention. They now leave themselves vulnerable to the Democrats using a similar tactic in the coming week.

In previous years, both parties have observed a kind of gentleman's agreement in staying clear of each other during their respective conventions. But this year, of course, is far from typical.

The extended primary battle between Obama and Hillary Clinton led to unusually late conventions.

McCain selected first-term Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin as his running mate, making her the first Republican woman on a presidential ticket.

Throw in the scheduling conflict with the Olympics, and you end up with the first back-to-back political conventions since the 1920s, Craig Smith said.

In light of that, neither party can count on the distinctive bump in the polls they'd ordinarily get after their respective conventions. That may be why the race is getting so contentious so early, Craig Smith said.

"It's more of a gloves-off mentality among the two campaigns," Craig Smith said.

A. Carville "Peck" Foster, chairman of the York County Republican Party, compares the effect of the back-to-back conventions with two out-of-synch waves that collide and diminish each other's power.

Still, Foster said the two conventions will be distinct. He acknowledges that the Democratic convention had more inherent drama, with the questions surrounding Obama and Clinton's reconciliation.

But he also said a lack of drama will work to the Republicans' advantage.

"I think in the Republican convention, you'll see a very, very unified convention," Foster said.

tjoyce@ydr.com; 771-2089

THE DELEGATES

Delegates to the Republican National Convention from the 19th congressional district are:

--- Main delegates: Nancy Ostot of Enola, Dick Stewart of New Cumberland, Marilyn Gillispie of Jacobus and Muriel Anne Crabbs of Hanover.

--- Alternate delegates: Suzanne Doller of Carlisle, Jeff Gay of Springettsbury Township, Wendy Shrader of Aspers and Michael McDermott of New Cumberland.

To see more of the York Daily Record, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to http://www.ydr.com. Copyright (c) 2008, York Daily Record, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

ACC-NO: 20080831-YO-Republicans-turn-0831


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: YO



Copyright 2008 York Daily Record



287 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 30, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


STEALING OBAMA'S THUNDER


BYLINE: James O'Toole, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-4


LENGTH: 843 words


DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS


Sen. John S. McCain's daring choice of Gov. Sarah Palin gives him the chance to bolster his appeal to two very different constituencies -- former supporters of Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton and conservative activists with whom he has had a sometimes rocky relationship over the years.

At the same time, the relatively short resume of the new Alaska governor risked undercutting one of the core arguments of his candidacy -- his relentless contention that Sen. Barack Obama lacks the experience to be commander-in-chief.

Whatever the long-term effect of the surprise selection, it was clearly a success by one crucial measure. Mr. McCain's appearance yesterday with the 44-year-old mother of five robbed the Democratic ticket of some of the media afterglow that they might have expected from Mr. Obama's spectacular speech the night before in Denver.

The speech was witnessed by 80,000 people inside Denver's Invesco Field and 40 million nationwide on television, an audience larger than the one that witnessed the Olympics opening ceremony in Beijing.

"It created a buzz for sure, and I don't know that any of the other [potential] picks would have created the same kind of buzz," Brad Coker, managing director of Mason-Dixon Polling & Research, said of Mr. McCain's choice.

The campaign will use Ms. Palin, a governor from a state about as far beyond the Beltway as possible, to reinforce the maverick image that Mr. McCain has long embraced.

But that image has often come at the expense of Mr. McCain's relationship with the movement conservative leaders traditionally influential with the GOP base. Ms. Palin's strong social conservatism and reputation as a fiscal hawk were applauded yesterday by a variety of conservative figures.

"This is great news," said Grover Norquist, whose Washington roundtable has had an outsize influence on conservative polices and talking points.

"She ran in a Republican primary on tax and spending issues ... she's very Reaganesque in that sense," he said.

Ms. Palin herself spotlighted the effort to peel away the support of former Clinton partisans.

"It was rightly noted in Denver this week that Hillary [Rodham Clinton] left 18 million cracks in the highest, hardest glass ceiling in America," she said with Mr. McCain at her side. "But it turns out that the women of America aren't finished yet, and we can shatter that glass ceiling once and for all."

John Brabender, a Republican political consultant, argued that "there's a lot of women who probably look at the Democratic ticket and say 'Why couldn't you pick a woman?' "

Ms. Palin, who gave birth to her fifth child in April, is an ardent opponent of abortion. Her stand on the intensely felt issue figures to be a high hurdle for support for many Democratic feminists, such as the activists who bid a reluctant farewell to Mrs. Clinton's candidacy this week in Denver.

"There's no way," Tom Vilsack, the former Iowa governor and early Clinton supporter, said of the prospect of the New York senator's partisans migrating to the McCain camp. "It's all about the Supreme Court," said his wife, Christie Vilsack, herself a prominent figure in Democratic politics in the battleground state.

Mr. Coker maintained that the Democratic activists at the core of the Clinton campaign were probably beyond the GOP's reach regardless of how disappointed they may be with the fate of the Clinton candidacy.

But he said that the Palin pick could reinforce the GOP ticket's appeal with some other women voters.

"There's a broader body of women 35 to 55 that Obama has had problems with, and she gives McCain more of a chance with those women," the pollster said. "[Mrs. Clinton] got a lot of women in places like Kentucky and West Virginia to vote for her in some of the later primaries; [Ms. Palin] is going to help give him a shot with some of those."

Ms. Palin's rugged Alaskan roots -- she's married to an oil field worker and commercial fisherman who holds a United Steelworkers card -- could serve as a counter to recent Democratic efforts to portray Mr. McCain as an out-of-touch plutocrat.

"How can you go wrong with a mooseburger-eating, ice-fishing governor," Sandra Froman, a former NRA president said in a conference call.

But her relatively short record in government will raise questions about her credentials as a president-in-waiting, particularly as she joins a ticket headed by the 72-year old Mr. McCain.

Her dearth of foreign policy experience will produce an even sharper focus on her performance in the vice presidential debate against Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., whose foreign policy expertise was noted by figures including Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice after his selection by Mr. Obama.

Chuck Rocha, the political director of the United Steelworkers, applauded the fact that Ms. Palin's husband is a USW member, but insisted that fact would have little influence with the union's members.

"McCain is the candidate and he has the record that steelworkers will be voting against," he said.

The GOP team will appear this afternoon at Consol Energy Field outside Washington, Pa.


LOAD-DATE: September 4, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE/ Post-Gazette politics editor James O'Toole can be reached at jotoole@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1562. {SERIES} PHOTO
