Another 23 percent said they support him but might change their minds before the election. Thirty percent say they will vote for Republican John McCain, someone else or no one at all.

But a CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll of registered voters, released Sunday, found that about two-thirds of Clinton supporters are backing Obama. Still, another 27 percent of the registered voters in that survey said they will vote for McCain instead.

The latest Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found that only about 52 percent of Clinton supporters are behind Obama.

The dissension is evident in Denver.

"That is a real problem," said Fletcher McClellan, a professor and chairman of Elizabethtown College's Political Science Department. "If you go back to nomination processes and conventions past, the party that has the more divided convention since the 1960s has lost the election. It's a real concern for Democrats to display their unity and Hillary has got to perform, and I'm sure she will."

"I think tonight's speech will be extremely important," McClellan said. "Since she lost the nomination she's appeared with him, and I think made it clear that she strongly supports his election.

"But this is before a national audience. This is before a convention which will be nearly half filled with her supporters. And I think this will be kind of the exclamation point on the end of her campaign and for stating her support for Obama," McClellan said.

Richard Glenn, the chairman of Millersville University's Government and Political Affairs department, said Clinton must at least appear genuine tonight - for Obama's sake as well as her own.

"If she comes across as appearing as a barrier, I think the party will most certainly pass the Clintons by," said Glenn. "Politically, this is a tough call. If John McCain were to win this fall, Hillary Clinton is a player in 2012. If Barack Obama were to win this fall, she's probably not.

"There are personal ambitions and there are political ambitions. Everything she's said, though, suggests she's going to put the party first," said Glenn.

"The Clintons are pragmatists at heart. Both realize that 2008 has passed them by in terms of the presidential election. If she has any future as a leader in the Democratic Party, she has to say, 'We fought hard. Thank you. But now is the time to support Barack Obama,'" Glenn said.

"If I were a betting man, I would say she'll come through for Barack Obama," he said.


LOAD-DATE: August 27, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



300 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 26, 2008 Tuesday
CITY-D Edition


Democrats start the show


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1020 words


DENVER - The 2008 Democratic National Convention opened last night with an impassioned Michelle Obama talking about the values that shaped her husband and the party paying a moving tribute to its cancer-stricken liberal lion, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy.

Michelle Obama framed the candidate's success story, and her own, as emblematic of the American dream and said he would achieve his goals as president by "reminding us how much we share and how alike we really are."

"You see, Barack doesn't care where you're from, or what your background is," she said. ". . . He knows that thread that connects us - our belief in America's promise, our commitment to our children's future - is strong enough to hold us together as one nation even when we disagree."

When she finished, Barack Obama himself appeared on the giant video screens, live from Kansas City, Mo. - and the younger of their two daughters, Sasha, who had joined Michelle on stage, called out, "Hi, Daddy!"

He said of his wife, "Now you know why I asked her out so many times even though she said no. You want a persistent president."

Behind the scenes, representatives of Obama and Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom he defeated for the nomination, were still working out precisely how to stage the events of the next few days - in which Clinton will play a leading role.

The goal was to minimize hard feelings among her most deeply committed supporters, encourage party unity, and deflect attention from those Clinton backers who have not reconciled themselves to Obama's victory.

There was no sign of that difficulty at the Pepsi Center last night. For the thousands gathered, the emotional highlight of the evening was the appearance of Kennedy, who walked onstage with his wife, Vicki, after a video tribute.

"My fellow Democrats, my fellow Americans, it is so wonderful to be here," Kennedy said, speaking with surprising force for a man who was thought to be too ill to come to Denver. "And nothing, nothing is going to keep me away from this special gathering tonight."

And nothing, said the veteran senator from Massachusetts, would stop him from being in the Senate chamber in January when he hopes to serve under a President Obama, whom he supported enthusiastically during the primaries. The crowd chanted, "Teddy, Teddy."

"For me," Kennedy said, "this is a season of hope."

He ended his seven-minute address by adapting the famous closing lines of his speech from the 1980 Democratic convention, proclaiming of himself and Obama, "The work begins anew, the hope rises again, and the dream lives on."

The video tribute was introduced by his niece Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of John F. Kennedy and one of the managers of Obama's search for a running mate. She described Obama as the first politician she had ever encountered who "inspires me the way people tell me my father inspired them."

Aside from the Kennedy tribute, the opening-night program was directed more at the television audience than the delegates in the hall, to flesh out Obama for those voters only now starting to pay serious attention to the election.

Michelle Obama, introduced by her brother, said that this most unconventional man - born to a white mother and a Kenyan father, raised in Hawaii and Indonesia - embodied an approach to life that all Americans could embrace.

"Barack and I were raised with so many of the same values: that you work hard for what you want in life; that your word is your bond and you do what you say you're going to do; that you treat people with dignity and respect, even if you don't know them, and even if you don't agree with them," she said.

"And Barack and I set out to build lives guided by these values, and pass them on to the next generation."

She also made a point of saluting Clinton for her near-triumph in the primaries, putting "those 18 million cracks in the glass ceiling, so that our daughters - and sons - can dream a little bigger and aim a little higher." The mention of Clinton's name was greeted by a loud roar.

Michelle Obama's speech seemed designed in part to address any lingering doubts about her patriotism that sprung up after she said earlier this year that her husband's political success had made her feel "really proud" of her country for the first time as an adult.

Other speakers yesterday, including a steelworker from the Chicago neighborhood where Obama worked as a community organizer in the 1980s, testified to the candidate's ability to relate to working people, countering the Republicans' portrayal of him as an intellectual elitist.

A prominent slot was given to a Republican, former Iowa Rep. Jim Leach, who said of Obama, whom he now supports, "Seldom has an emerging leader so matched the needs of the moment." Leach added, "Little is more risky than more of the same."

The Democrats also began to draw contrasts between themselves and the Republicans, something they didn't do in the 2004 convention that nominated John Kerry.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rattled off issues facing the country, including the economy, health care, energy, and the war in Iraq, leading the crowd in a recurring chant: "Barack Obama is right and John McCain is wrong!"

Representatives of the Obama and Clinton camps were deep in negotiations yesterday over how to orchestrate the presidential roll call slated for tomorrow night. Tonight, Clinton will be the featured speaker.

In a speech to the Pennsylvania delegates, most of whom were Clintonites, Gov. Rendell said the time for "looking back" had passed.

"Nobody worked harder for Sen. Clinton than I did," Rendell said. ". . . If you care about Hillary, you've got to work for Sen. Obama."

Meanwhile, Obama's campaign released an ad designed to link President Bush, McCain and hard economic times. It features a parody of the song "Wonderful World (Don't Know Much)." Instead of starting, "Don't know much about history," it begins "I'm not up on the economy."

It ends with the image of Bush patting McCain's back and a question: "Do we really want four more years of the same old tune?"

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

301 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 26, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Clout: Gonna party like it's 1968 ... not


SECTION: LOCAL; P-com News; Pg. 08


LENGTH: 1197 words


FOR A SECOND DAY, protesters from the group "Re-create '68" demonstrated against the Democrats' decision to cordon them off in a "demonstration zone."

"We're going to stay here for just a couple of minutes to state our disgust with this abomination, the way the city and Secret Service are tearing the Constitution of the United States to shreds and then we will leave," "Re-create '68" organizer Mark Cohen told the Associated Press yesterday.

Why somebody would want to re-create '68 beats us. If it did happen, it would beat them, too.

In 1968, in what an investigative commission later called "a police riot," hundreds of cops bashed in the heads of anti-Vietnam War and anti-establishment yippies and hippies at the Democratic convention in Chicago.

The Denver group, unlike that in Chicago, is a smorgasbord of causes: anti-war and pro-environment, mixed in with black-flag-waving anarchists.

One of the anarchists said he "opposed all authority."

Hey, been there, done that, got the bloody T-shirt.

Hillary's harridansClout dispatched special correspondent Yanik Ruiz-Ramon to the protest zone yesterday and he found a gaggle of Republicans, of all things.

The GOPers were expressing their support for three Hillary Clinton Democrats who said they were going to vote for presumptive Republican nominee John McCain.

The three women were wearing T-shirts that read "NO-bama."

Even though Clinton herself has urged support for Obama, Hillaryite Robin Carlson said, "I refuse to be emotionally blackmailed to vote for a candidate."

Carlson and her group marched down 16th Street to Union Station, where MSNBC was taping "Hardball with Chris Matthews."

During commercial breaks, Ruiz-Ramon told us, "A tall blond producer was waving her arms trying to get more passion" from the group.

We always thought that TV is just supposed to cover the stuff. Was Matthews waving a black flag off camera?

Kenney: Biden made timeIt was fall 1974. President Gerald Ford had just pardoned Richard Nixon for crimes committed in the Watergate scandal.

A young attorney from Delaware, Joe Biden, was in his first term as a U.S. senator. And 15-year-old Jimmy Kenney had a paper due.

The future city councilman, then a sophomore at St. Joe's Prep, called Biden's office and asked for an interview. Kenney was surprised at how quickly Biden's staff put it together. The young man was instructed to take the train to Washington, D.C., to meet the new senator on the platform.

Together, they rode a northbound train back to Wilmington, with Kenney asking questions and Biden giving answers.

Kenney doesn't recall the grade he got on the paper - "An A or a B-plus, I think." But he does remember the lesson. When a student contacts him for a school project, Kenney makes the time to help out.

"It just always inspired me that a person at that level would make time for me," Kenney said.

Narberth kid makes goodDenver Mayor John Hickenlooper kicked off the convention by welcoming delegates to his city.

This makes us proud 'cause Hickenlooper is a Main Line kid who grew up in Narberth and Wynnewood, and graduated from the Haverford School in 1970.

How did he get to Denver? Practice, practice, practice.

Actually, it was his career as an exploration geologist.

In the late 1980s, however, he switched to a more Philly-style business: He opened a brewpub.

Denver: Different century It was exactly 100 years ago that the Democrats last held their convention in Denver.

Some things haven't changed since 1908: Nominee William Jennings Bryan called the Republicans "the party of privilege."

But other things have changed: Although Bryan was progressive on labor issues and foreign policy, he refused to consider a civil-rights plank in the platform.

In fact, Bryan, fearful of losing votes in the segregationist South, would not even allow the platform to include a denunciation of lynching.

Michelle: Soccer mom?Last February, Clout said Michelle Obama's style reminded us of Jackie Kennedy.

Last night, not so much. No pearls, for one thing. And that teal dress. Talbots?

We checked in with our style expert, Daily News columnist Jenice Armstrong, to find out if we were missing something.

"She talked the soccer-mom talk, but didn't look the soccer-mom part," Armstrong told us.

The dress was indeed "simple and understated," Armstrong said, "but do you think she looks like a soccer mom?"

Well, she looks more like a sophisticated Harvard-trained lawyer to us, but what do we know?

The Democrats' plan was to introduce Michelle as a down-to-earth Everymom. In that department it was her daughters who carried the day.

The interaction between Malia, 10, and Sasha, 7, and their mom after her speech did more to create the image the Dems sought than anything Michelle said.

"Nothing says it more than when she brought those girls out," Armstrong said. "How beautiful."

Now if only their dad could figure out the difference between St. Louis and Kansas City.

Best of the blogsWhen Democratic veep pick Joe Biden gets up there and talks poignantly about the typical American family sitting around the kitchen table late at night worrying how to pay its bills, and then twists the dagger on John McCain's "seven kitchen tables," it's a great line politically, but . . .

An article in the New York Times makes it out to be something of a crock, because of Biden's long record of backing the Delaware-centric credit-card industry, especially the former MBNA Corp., which hired the senator's son Hunter Biden for a lucrative lobbying gig.

In 2005, Biden helped win passage of a conservative, anti-working-class bill that made life a lot harder for that struggling family that he depicted at that kitchen table.

- Will Bunch's Daily News blog Attytood, ( www.attytood.com)

Talk about a full house! The Dems are said to be salivating at the possibility of a John McCain-Mitt Romney ticket, as the two families apparently own 12 houses worth about $35 million.

"As the presidential campaign turns increasingly personal and the new Obama-Biden ticket strikes a decidedly more populist tone, Democrats believe a McCain-Romney ticket would provide a near-perfect frame for their class-conscious message.

"It will be a contest, they'll say, between the son of a single mother and son of a car salesman against the son of an admiral and son of a governor."

- Jonathan Martin blogging at the Politico, ( www.politico.com )

For many in Denver, the only story is whether Obama and Clinton can get along:

"And even those who are not passionately committed to one side or the other are trying to figure out why Obama didn't just go through the motions of vetting Clinton [for the vice presidency]. Tell her that she was high on the list and go through the entire process. It wouldn't have been true, and Clinton probably would have known it wasn't true, but what could she have done? As it turned out, since Obama blew her off, she can now claim that she was disrespected in all this."

- Byron York, blogging for National Review Online (corner. nationalreview.com.) *

Staff writers Gar Joseph, Chris Brennan and Will Bunch compiled this report.Have a news tip? Gossip? Suggestion? Contact Bob Warner at warnerb@phillynews.com, call 215-854-5885, or fax 215-854-5910.

302 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 26, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Deborah Leavy: Bullish on Biden


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; DN Columnists; Pg. 19


LENGTH: 859 words


THERE were things I didn't like about Sen. Joe Biden when I worked with him and his staff on the Senate Judiciary Committee when Biden was the chairman.

I thought he compromised too easily and was too deferential to the committee's Republicans.

But the qualities I didn't much appreciate then may be just what is necessary now if Barack Obama is to reach out and win over the voters he needs to prevail in this election.

The choice of Biden for the second slot on the Democratic ticket has been greeted with much praise, including from several GOP senators. Even Fox News admitted Biden is "solid and serious," and "a real political scrapper who knows how to throw a punch."

Dems in southeastern Pennsylvania are particularly happy because Biden is so popular here, especially in the suburbs considered crucial to a Democratic victory, in Pennsylvania and the nation. Biden has worked hard enough for the region to be called our third senator. Gov. Rendell, who helped Hillary Clinton beat Obama in Pennsylvania, likes Biden and will no doubt work harder for the ticket now that Biden's on it.

In Iowa, Biden was an effective campaigner stymied by lack of money. He connected with people in small-town America, but was crushed by the historic nature of the race. Many were disappointed when he had to drop out.

The kid from Scranton grew up in a family struggling to make ends meet. He can empathize with the white working-class voters who Obama has yet to convince. In his first speech as Obama's choice, Biden said, "Your kitchen table is like mine. You sit there at night . . . after you put the kids to bed, and you talk about . . . how to pay the bills . . . That's not a worry John McCain has . . . He'll have to figure out which of the seven tables to sit at."

That's the kind of red meat Biden can deliver. He'll turn the focus back where it should be, on bread-and-butter issues, rather than on GOP attack ads.

Biden is well-known and respected on the world stage. He's trusted in the Jewish community, which can help win over some who mistrust Obama. And with a son getting ready to ship out to Iraq with his National Guard unit, Biden should have enough credibility to make inroads with military families.

Biden also has a solid record in support of issues of special concern to women and families. Clinton supporters should note that at 65, Biden won't be a vice president busy planning his own administration, leaving the door open for her to run again.

And there's no one better than Biden, who presided over the hearings that led to the rejection of Judge Bork, to make the case that the nomination of Supreme Court justices will determine the future of our country.

THERE'S NO doubt McCain will nominate justices who not only would overturn Roe v. Wade, but fundamentally change our system of checks and balances by denying Congress the power to legislate national health and safety protections like those for the workplace while greatly expanding the powers of the executive, including giving the president the power to ignore laws passed by Congress.

Of course, no candidate, including Biden, is without a downside. He's famously gaffe-prone and bound to slip up, but he also has a laser-sharp wit. He's the guy who flattened then-GOP presidential candidate Rudy Giuliani of New York in a debate by reducing him to "a noun, a verb and 9/11."

I hope Biden will see that his old friend McCain has become a noun, a verb and a POW.

Some wonder how a campaign for change can include someone who's been in Washington for 36 years, even longer than McCain. But Biden has never moved to Washington, and with his nightly commute home on Amtrak, has avoided socializing with lobbyists after hours, when many questionable deals are done.

No, Biden's Washington experience is a plus, not a minus. In Biden, Barack Obama will have a partner who knows the ways of Washington well enough to find the last few votes that may be needed to implement Obama's agenda.

Some Republicans have said that in choosing Biden, Obama is showing how weak his experience is. I agree that his choice says a lot about Obama. But I think it shows that his ego doesn't overwhelm his judgment, and that's good for the country.

Does having a 65-year- old on the ticket blunt the age issue dogging McCain? I don't think so.

The vibrant senator who ran on stage to embrace Obama is a bundle of energy, highlighting the flaws of a sometimes slow and forgetful McCain.

As an Obama opponent in the primary season, Biden had some critical things to say about him, and McCain wasted no time in running an ad to remind us. Yes, Biden has strong opinions. But Obama, unlike President Bush, doesn't intend to surround himself just with people who agree with him. He wants to listen to all arguments, and with Biden, he'll hear them.

There's an awful lot that goes into choosing a vice president. It's an opportunity to see how a candidate makes decisions. I think Obama passed this test with flying colors. O and Joe make a winning ticket. *

Deborah Leavy is a regular contributor to the op-ed page and an associate member of the Daily News editorial board. E-mail her at deborah.opinion@gmail.com.

303 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 26, 2008 Tuesday
FINAL Edition


Michelle Obama puts emphasis on family values in convention speech


BYLINE: By WILL BUNCH; bunchw@phillynews.com 215-854-2957


SECTION: LOCAL; P-com News; Pg. 06


LENGTH: 786 words


AT LEAST BEFORE LAST night, there had never in American history been a memorable political-convention speech delivered by a woman seeking to become first lady.

But then, there's never been an applicant for the job quite like Michelle Obama.

Her husband, in seeking to become America's first African-American president, presents an exotic backstory with his Kenyan father and his upbringing in Hawaii and Indonesia.

But Michelle Obama's tale of rising from humble origins on the South Side of Chicago is a more familiar one - yet one that has generated a surprising amount of controversy.

Last night was finally her rebuttal, a chance to answer all the critics who questioned her patriotism, often based on unfounded rumors, and who pounced when she said during the primaries that she was proud of her country "for the first time in my adult life."

Michelle Obama presented herself to the nation last night as the daughter of working-class parents and as a proud working mom.

"I come here as a mom whose girls are the heart of my heart and the center of my world. They're the first thing I think about when I wake up in the morning, and the last thing I think about when I go to bed at night," she said. "Their future - and all our children's future - is my stake in this election."

Bounding out to the strains of Stevie Wonder's "I Was Made to Love Her" in a teal dress, the candidate's wife larded her speech with references to faith and to patriotism, talking about hope and "why I love this country." She also went out of her way to praise Hillary Clinton in front of hundreds of Clinton delegates, saying her campaign had put "18 million cracks in the glass ceiling."

She had an emotional lead-in - a brief appearance by party patriarch Sen. Ted Kennedy, ailing with terminal brain cancer. The brother of slain president John F. Kennedy told delegates at Denver's Pepsi Center that "nothing is going to keep me away from this special gathering tonight."

The stakes are high for Michelle Obama. Wrote Glenn Thrush on the Web site Politico last night:

"Her tasks are twofold: to introduce herself to the convention as a strong-willed, nonthreatening surrogate who has always been proud of her country - while portraying her Barack as a messy, absentminded, regular dad who likes playing with his daughters when he's not out inspiring the millions. How she is received could determine how much she is used on the road this fall."

And so Michelle Obama, joined after her talk by her husband via a big screen from Kansas City, where he was campaigning, sought to humanize the sometimes aloof candidate.

"He's the same man who drove me and our new baby daughter home from the hospital 10 years ago this summer, inching along at a snail's pace, peering anxiously at us in the rearview mirror, feeling the whole weight of her future in his hands, determined to give her everything he'd struggled so hard for himself, determined to give her what he never had: the affirming embrace of a father's love," she said.

One poll taken earlier this year by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press showed that Michelle Obama had an unfavorable rating of 22 percent, which is unusally high for a potential first lady. The same survey found that Republican John McCain's wife, Cindy, had an unfavorable rating of 16 percent.

And, as has been so often the case in this intensely contested race, which polls now show as a dead heat, the McCain camp was mounting a speedy and aggressive response to the Michelle Obama showcase last night.

Time magazine is reporting that Cindy McCain left yesterday with a mission to assess civilian casualties from the Russian assault on the nation of Georgia, a crisis that her husband has placed on the center stage of his national-security-oriented campaign.

And while GOP officials were fairly careful not to go directly after Michelle Obama on the night of her televised address, there were new signs that pro-McCain operatives were stepping up their attack on Barack Obama's patriotism.

A group calling itself the American Issues Project is reportedly spending about $3 million to run ads in key battleground states, including Pennsylvania, that seek to tie Obama to Bill Ayers, a former member of the 1960s radical group the Weather Underground and now a college professor and an Obama acquaintance from his Chicago neighborhood.

The Obama campaign was on the air with a response ad in a matter of a few hours, and that in turn drew a direct retort from the McCain campaign.

"The fact that Barack Obama chose to launch his political career at the home of an unrepentant terrorist raises more questions about Senator Obama's judgment than any TV ad ever could," said Brian Rogers, a McCain spokesman. *


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

304 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 26, 2008 Tuesday
SOONER EDITION


TORCH IS PASSED AGAIN;
KENNEDY'S STRONG-VOICED TRIBUTE DELIGHTS DELEGATES


BYLINE: JAMES O'TOOLE, PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTION; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 808 words


DATELINE: DENVER


Democrats yesterday opened a week of speeches and celebrations in which they hoped to give voters a red-white-and-blue introduction to the first African-American nominee of a major party in the nation's history.

While offering an only-in-America portrayal of their own candidate, convention architects planned a contrary portrayal of his opponent, Sen. John S. McCain, as an out-of-touch plutocrat wedded to the policies of an unpopular administration.

The evening's headliner was would-be first lady Michelle Obama, but its emotional high point was the appearance of the ailing Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, the liberal icon whose early endorsement gave a crucial boost to the insurgent Obama campaign.

His niece, Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of President John F. Kennedy, introduced a taped tribute to her "Uncle Teddy," who was diagnosed with malignant brain cancer this spring. While focusing on the veteran senator, the piece, and Mr. Kennedy's speech, suggested Mr. Obama as the political heir of his family's political tradition.

"I have never had someone inspire me the way people tell me my father inspired them, but I do now -- Barack Obama," Caroline Kennedy said.

The footage, which included the senator at the helm of a sailboat filled with members of his extended family, was followed by the senator's surprise appearance on stage and a huge outpouring of appreciation from the delegates crammed into the Pepsi Center.

"I have come here tonight to change America," Mr. Kennedy said, his voice strong, but his gait unsteady, "and to elect Barack Obama president of the United States."

Mr. Kennedy spoke in a strong voice in a speech repeatedly interrupted by chants of "Teddy, Teddy."

"For me this is a season of hope," he said. Later echoing the rhetoric of his brother John's inaugural address in 1961, and his own eloquent valedictory to his failed presidential bid in 1980, he said, "The torch will be passed again to a new generation of Americans. ... The work begins anew; the hope rises again, and the dream lives on."

The senator waved to a sea of dancing Kennedy signs in the crowd and worked his way smiling around the convention podium.

The endorsements from Mr. Kennedy and the daughter of the slain president came just before Mr. Obama managed to battle Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton to a draw on February's Super Tuesday, a multi-state primary and caucus competition that many had expected to cement Mrs. Clinton's hold on the nomination.

The warm moments last night were a contrast to the persistent reports and speculation over lingering ill will between Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton, the candidate he so narrowly defeated in the longest primary battle in the party's history. Both camps put on a show of unity with Mrs. Clinton insisting that her support for Mr. Obama was unqualified. But the slow-to-be resolved discussions on how the roll call vote would proceed tomorrow did little to dispel the speculation.

Republicans seized on the opening in a new commercial in which a former Clinton supporter said she planned to vote for Mr. McCain.

In an appearance before her home state delegation, Mrs. Clinton dismissed the report, joking, "I'm Hillary Clinton, and I do not approve that message,"

"There was a lot in that story that was wrong," David Plouffe, the Obama campaign manager said of one report of lingering friction between the senior figures.

While promoting their own candidate, the Obama partisans were relentless in targeting Mr. McCain.

In an early evening speech, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi led he delegates in a call-and-response mockery of the Republican.

"And John McCain was wrong," the crowd thundered again and again to a litany of policy contrasts between the two candidates.

Earlier in the day, Mr. Obama's campaign manager pointed once again to Mr. McCain's offhand definition of $5 million as the threshold point for moving out of the middle class, and his amnesia over the number of houses he owns.

"Last week is going to be a seminal week in the campaign. ... There's a real sense that he is out of touch," he said. "We are going to drive a truck through that this week and the rest of the election."

The star of the four-day gathering remained off stage, campaigning in Iowa as the convention was called to order at 3 p.m. local time, and watching his wife's address in Kansas City later last night. For all the publicity he has attracted during he in the 19 months of his precedent-shattering presidential run, Mr. Obama's advisers maintain that voters still don't know him in depth, They planned to fill in those blanks this week.

On Thursday, in another echo of the Kennedy tradition, Mr. Obama will accept his nomination in a speech before more than 70,000 partisan in nearby INVESCO Field. In 1960, President Kennedy accepted the Democratic standard in a similarly non-traditional speech in the Los Angeles Coliseum.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Post-Gazette politics editor James O'Toole can be reached at jotoole@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1562.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Win McNamee/Getty Images: Michelle Obama, wife of presumptive Democratic nominee Sen. Barack Obama, watches her younger daughter, Sasha, 7, blow a kiss to her father as he appears on a video screen during the opening night of the convention in Denver last night. Mrs. Obama had just finished addressing the delegates.
\ PHOTO: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., waves to delegates as he takes the stage last night. With him is his niece, Caroline Kennedy.
\ PHOTO: Paul J. Richards/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images: Caroline Kennedy, center, is surrounded by her children on the podium in Denver last night.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



305 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 26, 2008 Tuesday


Clinton must try to deliver command performance


BYLINE: David M. Brown and Salena Zito


LENGTH: 788 words


DENVER -- Sen. Hillary Clinton's speech tonight at the Democratic National Convention may go down as one of the most highly anticipated in convention history.

Rarely has a runner-up's message to the delegates been given such a buildup.

Clinton will strive to persuade her die-hard delegates to rally behind Barack Obama, the Illinois senator who bested her in the Democratic primary season leading up to Thursday's nomination. Fewer than half of Clinton's primary supporters say they definitely will vote for Obama in November, according to a USA TODAY/Gallup Poll released Monday.

If she can't deliver a big enough majority of the 18 million people who voted for her -- people for whom she has claimed to be a champion -- Clinton could lose her hard-won stature as a power broker. It could make Obama's quest to defeat Republican John McCain all the more difficult.

Gov. Ed Rendell, one of Clinton's strongest early supporters, said he believes the New York lawmaker will get the job done.

"I guarantee you that you are going to hear a message from Hillary Clinton ... that's going to be loud and clear and unequivocal. If you love Hillary, get out there and work your hearts out for Barack," Rendell told Pennsylvania delegates at a breakfast meeting yesterday.

"That's going to be the theme for us. We've got to leave here as a delegation fired up, united and ready to do what's necessary to take this country back," Rendell said.

In the Gallup Poll taken Thursday through Saturday, 47 percent of Clinton supporters say they are solidly behind Obama, and 23 percent say they support him but might change their minds before the election. Thirty percent say they will vote for McCain, someone else or no one at all.

"They're not focusing on her future. They seem to think if Obama loses, that gives her a chance in 2012," said Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics. The rest of the party "will never forgive her and (former president) Bill (Clinton) if Obama loses."

McCain's campaign released a television ad aimed at chipping away at the Democrats' plan to unify the party behind Obama during the four-day national convention here. The ad features Debra Bartoshevich, a Clinton delegate from Wisconsin, who says she proudly supported Clinton because "she had the experience and judgment to be president." Bartoshevich says in the ad she's supporting McCain because "now he's the one with the experience and judgment" and says "it's OK" for Democrats to vote for the Republican.

The ad comes after McCain released another spot laden with Clinton's quotes criticizing Obama during the primary.

McCain is trying to sway voters like Amber and Gavin Ekstron, a Denver couple who brought their three young children downtown to get a glimpse of a national political convention. The registered Democrats backed Clinton but are unsure about Obama.

"We do like Hillary," said Amber Ekstron, 29, who is in the real estate business. "Now we're a little confused. We're trying to educate ourselves."

Gavin Ekstron, 34, a mortgage lender, said Obama's pick of Sen. Joe Biden of Delaware as a running mate seems a good choice. He's uncertain whether he'll vote for Obama or sit the election out.

"I need to be convinced," he said.

So do some delegates.

"There are some people who are still having a hard time. They put their hearts and souls in the campaign and are disappointed, but I don't see any movement on any of the Clinton officials to fire that up and keep that going," said Michael Crossey of Mt. Lebanon, a former Allegheny County councilman and Clinton delegate.

County Chief Executive Dan Onorato, who endorsed Clinton in the primary, said he expects no ruckus on the convention floor from upset Clinton supporters.

"I think Hillary Clinton has a great and golden opportunity (tonight), and I think she will do it in a great way," Onorato said. "Anything I've seen or heard of her across the country, she's for Barack Obama. I don't know what more she could do to say 'Go vote for him.'

"So far as I'm concerned, we're all Obama supporters," he said.

Onorato said Obama has started shoring up support from the white, blue-collar Democrats who went for Clinton in the primary by picking Biden, a Scranton native, as his running mate.

"Joe Biden was a great pick for Pennsylvania. Obviously, he has roots from Scranton, but he has that image as the blue-collar senator," Onorato said.

Clinton is expected on Wednesday to release the delegates she won in primaries and caucuses and encourage them to support Obama.

Staff writer Mike Wereschagin contributed to this report.

David M. Brown can be reached at dbrown@tribweb.com or 412-380-5614. Salena Zito can be reached at szito@tribweb.com

306 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


August 26, 2008 Tuesday


Ad linking McCain, Ralph Reed fails in accuracy


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 739 words


An Obama campaign ad linking John McCain to former Christian Coalition executive Ralph Reed and the Abramoff lobbying scandal fails to provide an accurate picture.

The ad says that Reed "is now raising money for McCain's campaign." But McCain has said he has not sought, nor does he want Reed's support.

The ad says that McCain, as a Senate committee chairman, "never even called Reed to testify" about Abramoff, which is true. But McCain's public report embarrassed Reed and damaged him politically nonetheless.

Obama's presidential campaign released the ad Aug. 20 in Georgia where Reed lost a bid for state office in 2006 in part because of unfavorable publicity over his Abramoff ties.

The ad says that Reed is "now raising money for McCain's campaign." That is true. The Hill newspaper reported that Reed sent out an e-mail to friends and associates urging them to contribute to McCain's campaign and attend a fundraiser for him.

But there isn't any formal connection between McCain's campaign and Reed's activities. McCain flatly told the Atlanta Journal Constitution that, "I neither seek nor want his support."

Reed appears to have gotten the message. He didn't even appear at the fundraiser he told friends to attend.

The ad calls Reed a "power broker" who was "in the middle" of "one of Washington's biggest scandals," the Jack Abramoff affair. And it says that McCain, as chairman of the Senate Indian Affairs Committee, "never even called Reed to testify" in the Abramoff investigation.

That's all true, but what's not said is that McCain's report caused Reed political embarrassment, making public evidence that contradicted Reed's claim that he hadn't known that his lobbying activities among anti-gambling Christian activists had been paid for by casino-owning Indian tribes who wanted to suppress competition.

McCain's Committee on Indian Affairs held a series of three tribal lobbying hearings in 2005 on Abramoff's lobbying for tribes with gaming interests. The result of those hearings was a damning 373-page report.

Journalists had uncovered Reed's activities as a "stealth lobbyist" for tribal casino interests the year before and had traced $4 million in fees to Reed's company from the Coushatta tribe of Louisiana and the Choctaws of Mississippi.

But Reed denied knowledge that he'd been working for gambling interests.

When McCain's report was issued, however, it contained evidence that Reed was a willing and knowing partner, stirring up anti-gambling Christians to oppose gambling operations that might have competed with the tribes who were Abramoff's clients.

The report described, for example, how Reed reached out to his old college friend Abramoff in 1998 seeking paid lobbying work after leaving the Christian Coalition.

For a $20,000 monthly retainer, Reed promised to stir up anti-gambling sentiment among a network of 3,000 pastors and 90,000 religious conservative households in Alabama. The object: to kill legislation that would have legalized video poker games at dog tracks in Alabama, which would have competed with the Silver Star casino in neighboring Mississippi, owned by Abramoff's client, the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians.

He also worked against a bill to create an Alabama state lottery.

Later on, in 2001, Reed worked to support the efforts of the Texas attorney general to shut down casinos owned by two tribes in that state, while working secretly on behalf of the Coushatta tribe, which owned the Grand Casino across the state line in Louisiana.

Should McCain have been tougher on Reed, as Obama's ad suggests? Perhaps. But we should note that Reed was never the main focus of the federal criminal investigations that were under way at the same time that McCain was holding his Senate hearings.

Both Abramoff and his partner Michael Scanlon were charged and then pleaded guilty to felony conspiracy charges. Reed, on the other hand, was not charged with any criminal wrongdoing.

McCain's investigation focused primarily on how Abramoff and Scanlon fleeced tribes by charging them millions in lobbying fees for lobbying work they never performed. But as the report details, Reed actually performed the lobbying work he was paid to do.

So what could Reed have told the committee if McCain had called him as a witness?

We don't know, and the Obama ad doesn't say.

FactCheck.Org is provided by the An nenberg Public Policy Center of the Uni versity of Pennsylvania. Contact them at editor@factcheck.org

307 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 25, 2008 Monday
CITY-D Edition


Democrats descend on Denver


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 849 words


DENVER - As the Democrats prepared to open their convention tonight, top Republicans were doing all they could to stir any lingering resentment among delegates over Barack Obama's decision not to include Hillary Rodham Clinton on the ticket.

Democrats said that the ploy wouldn't work, that the party would leave its convention energized and united, and that Obama's selection of Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware as his running mate was proving popular throughout party ranks.

John McCain's campaign set the terms of the day's political conversation by unveiling a commercial suggesting that Clinton had been passed over because of her critical remarks about Obama during their long and sometimes bitter fight for the Democratic presidential nomination.

"She won millions of votes but isn't on his ticket," an announcer says. "Why?

"For speaking the truth."

The ad includes clips of Clinton raising questions about the presumptive Democratic nominee and concludes: "The truth hurt, and Obama didn't like it."

On the Sunday talk shows, Republican spokesmen sounded the same theme.

Asked what he thought of Obama's selection of Biden, former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani called it a choice made out of weakness and added: "The story here is more the Obama-not-Clinton ticket."

Said Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, a potential McCain running mate: "If I were a Hillary Clinton supporter this morning, I'd be scratching my head."

Democrats said any effectiveness that the commercial might have would be short-lived.

Gov. Rendell predicted that Clinton's much-anticipated speech tomorrow night "will blow this ad out of the water."

Kansas Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, who was a finalist in the vice-presidential selection process, agreed. "Right now, I don't think there's any question that the Clintons are wholeheartedly behind Barack Obama," she said.

And the Associated Press reported that Clinton was inviting her pledged delegates to a reception Wednesday, before the presidential roll call. There, in a show of support for Obama, she reportedly was planning to release her delegates from their pledges.

Obama's aides said their man spoke to both Hillary Clinton and former President Bill Clinton by telephone late last week.

In seeking the roll call, Hillary Clinton said the event would provide "catharsis" for her most devoted supporters, many of whom are delegates. How all of this plays out will help determine how much of a problem Obama still faces in trying to bring the party together before November.

Polls are all over the lot on the question of what percentage of Clinton's 18 million primary voters are prepared to support Obama in the fall. But the surveys indicate that at least one-third of them, and perhaps more, have yet to commit themselves, and a substantial minority say they will vote for McCain.

Tonight's opening session, which has the theme of "One Nation," will begin to answer the question of how much emphasis the Obama team plans to put this week on fleshing out its candidate and how much on drawing the contrasts between his positions and those of his Republican opponent.

Four years ago, strategists for then-nominee John Kerry were widely criticized after the fact for having refrained from attacking their opponent, President Bush, and focusing almost exclusively on Kerry's biography.

David Axelrod, Obama's chief strategist, suggested that his campaign would not leave itself open to that kind of criticism in 2008. "We're not going to shy away from making the contrast," he said, and telling the story "of what's happened to this country" in the last eight years.

On Night One, though, the emphasis will surely be on the Obama biography. The headline speaker is his wife, Michelle, and she will be preceded by his half-sister and his brother-in-law.

Also on the program is a tribute to Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who is suffering from brain cancer and unable to attend.

Obama's choice for vice president, Biden, continued to be a center of attention yesterday, even though he stayed largely out of public view in Delaware.

McCain offered his own reaction to the choice. In an interview with Katie Couric of CBS News, he called it "a very wise selection" and described Biden, his longtime Senate colleague, as "a good friend and a good man."

In honor of Biden's prospective nomination, convention organizers moved the seats set aside for the Delaware delegation from the rear of the Pepsi Center to a prime location on the floor.

Biden is expected to arrive in Denver today and make several public appearances in the next few days before speaking to the convention Wednesday night.

Yesterday, traffic in the downtown area was occasionally disrupted by about 1,000 peaceful antiwar demonstrators who marched through the city streets.

They waved signs and chanted: "Stop the torture, stop the war. That's what we're fighting for."

Giuliani and Axelrod spoke on ABC's This Week, Rendell and Sebelius on CBS's Face the Nation. Pawlenty was interviewed on CNN's Late Edition.

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel

at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.

308 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 25, 2008 Monday
WEB Edition


Clout: This week, it's one Dem thing after another


SECTION: WEB; DN City & Local; Pg. WEB


LENGTH: 917 words


THEY'RE articulate! They're bright! They're clean! They're good-looking! They're Democrats! And they're in Denver for the quadrennial TV infomercial known as the Democratic National Convention. While you won't be seeing any slogans about bright and clean (except during the Tide commercials), you will be seeing and hearing a lot about change.

The theme of U.S. Sen. Barack Obama's presidential acceptance speech is "change you can believe in." His newly minted running-mate, Delaware Sen. Joe Biden, who is about as inside the Beltway as you can be, "has brought change to Washington," Obama said. The convention will air clips daily of everyday Americans calling for change. Panhandlers outside the Pepsi Center will be asking for change. Change, change, change. Then the Republicans will be in your face next week with their convention. Their theme: "Country First." Yeah! We'll be ready for some LeAnn Rimes after all that loose change talk. But first, here's a look at the week ahead: Tonight: Michelle night! The Dems' subject tonight is "One Nation," but the highlight will be Michelle Obama's speech. Right-wing pundits have portrayed her as a bitter radical. The National Review featured her on the cover under the headline "Mrs. Grievance." Look for her to undermine that image by talking about her daughters and showing a bit of Jackie O style. Tomorrow night: Hillary night!The subject is "Renewing America's Promise," but the mission is for primetime speaker U.S. Sen. Hillary Clinton to protect Obama from a PUMA attack. PUMA is the acronymn for "party unity my ass," a coalition of Clinton supporters who resent her treatment by Obama and the media. Wednesday night: Biden night!The topic is "Securing America's Future," which will give Biden a chance to strut his best issue &mdash; foreign policy &mdash; in his acceptance speech. Also speaking: Bill Clinton. Forecast: Windy. Thursday night: Obama night! Obama, whose "we're one people" keynote speech at the 2004 convention brought down the house, will try to top it with his acceptance speech before 75,000 people at Invesco Mile High Stadium. Adding to the pressure: It will be the 45th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech. Friday: McCain day! Republican presidential nominee-to-be John McCain is expected to knock the Dems off the evening news by announcing his vice-presidential pick. Eddie's big mouthGov. Rendell, who's habit of speaking his mind gets him in more hot water than Michael Phelps, did it again. During a panel discussion on TV coverage yesterday, Rendell complained about the treatment of Hillary Clinton, whom he supported, calling MSNBC "the official network of the Obama campaign," according to Politico.com This won't help calm down the PUMAs. Biden's big mouth A national Democratic consultant who likes Obama's pick of Joe Biden cautions nonetheless against Biden's habit of blunt, sometimes controversial statements. "One thing is certain," this consultant tells us, "three times between now and November, someone in Chicago [Obama's headquarters] will be answering the phone with these three words: "HE SAID WHAT!?" Rendell's trip: He's paying With the flap over Mayor Nutter using tax dollars to pay for his five-person entourage to attend the convention, we wondered how Gov. Rendell was paying. According to spokesman Chuck Ardo, Rendell, like Nutter, is paying his own way with campaign money. Unlike Nutter, however, his campaign fund is also paying for his staffers (two) to attend. But Rendell is always accompanied by a security detail. Who's paying for them? "I can't discuss security," Ardo said. Translation: Taxpayers are paying for security. Best of the blogs So far, Hillary Clinton has been full of praise for Barack Obama's vice presidential pick, Joe Biden, and their service together in the Senate surely helped Clinton and Biden bond. But there may be more here than meets the eye. Many believe that Clinton wants one more grab at the brass ring, and Biden makes that more possible. Now 66, Biden would turn 74 shortly after the 2016 election. So even if Obama can win two terms, the Delawarian would be unlikely to run to succeed him. That means that Clinton could either run against a President McCain in 2012 or for a wide open White House in eight years, when she'll be a mere 68. Or as McCain might say, "a spring chicken." &mdash; Will Bunch's Daily News blog Attytood (www.attytood.com.) Joe Biden, teenagebabe magnet? "Anyhow, I would be lying if I said that young Joe seemed destined for politics, let alone greatness. He had little to distinguish himself from the teenaged crowd that I aspired to be a part of beyond having overcome a bad stutter to become a handsome and loquacious babe magnet who happened to have the nicest parents in the world." &mdash; The blog Kiko's House (kikoshouse.blogspot.com), by former Daily News staffer Shaun Mullen, who knew Biden back when. Not every Democrat was thrilled with Biden's selection. He's alienated many progressives over the years, especially when he voted with the GOP in 2005 on a bankruptcy bill viewed as a sop to big credit-card companies, many of which are based in Delaware. "Biden is a reliable supporter of virtually every prevailing bit of conventional wisdom within the American elite political consensus, which is why his selection has been widely praised by the establishment," blogged Salon.com's Glenn Greenwald. * Staff writers Gar Joseph, Will Bunch and John Baer compiled this report.

309 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 25, 2008 Monday
SOONER EDITION


OBAMA HITS THE TRAIL; MCCAIN HITS VP CHOICE


BYLINE: MICHAEL FINNEGAN AND NICHOLAS RICCARDI, LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 858 words


DATELINE: EAU CLAIRE, Wis.


On the eve of the Democratic National Convention, Sen. Barack Obama yesterday framed the November election as a choice between watching the country "get run into the ground" under another Republican president or "solving the big problems" that America faces.

Mr. Obama also gave a preview of the speech that his wife, Michelle, will give tonight at the Denver gathering.

"You'll have a sense of who she is, and what our values are, and how we're raising our kids," Mr. Obama told a few hundred supporters gathered under towering weeping willows in a lakefront park in western Wisconsin, a quadrennial White House battleground.

"And I think what you'll conclude is: He's sort of like us. He comes from a middle-class background. He went to school on scholarships. He had to pay off student loans. He and his wife had to worry about child care. They had to figure out how to start a college fund for their kids."

Mr. Obama, meanwhile, came under attack from Republicans, who took an unusual swipe at him for bypassing Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton as his running mate and instead selecting Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware.

While Sen. John McCain took a day off from the campaign trail and attended church and a baseball game, his organization released a new TV spot asserting that Mrs. Clinton was overlooked for the No. 2 slot on the Democratic ticket because she judged Mr. Obama harshly during the primary. The ad quotes Mrs. Clinton saying "you never hear the specifics" of Mr. Obama's plans and that his campaign had turned "increasingly negative."

"She won millions of votes but isn't on the ticket," the announcer on the ad says. "Why? For speaking the truth."

Former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who will deliver the keynote address at the Republican National Convention next week, contended yesterday that by not picking Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Obama's "choice was made from weakness, not strength."

"The strong choice would have been Hillary Clinton," Mr. Giuliani said on ABC's "This Week."

"You almost have to go to extraordinary lengths to avoid her as the vice-presidential pick of the Democratic Party."

Mr. Obama's chief strategist, David Axelrod, also on the show, responded that the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee "has a high regard for Sen. Clinton. She's going to be an important voice in this campaign, she's going to be an important voice in moving this country forward in the next administration. He felt that Sen. Biden would be the best fit for him at this time."

A Clinton spokeswoman released a statement responding to the ad by saying, "Hillary Clinton's support of Barack Obama is clear. She has said repeatedly that Barack Obama and she share a commitment to changing the direction of the country, getting us out of Iraq, and expanding access to health care. John McCain doesn't. It's interesting how those remarks didn't make it into his ad."

The Republicans' line of attack appeared to be an attempt to stoke the lingering resentments among Clinton supporters who watched their candidate fall barely short of the votes needed for the presidential nomination. Mrs. Clinton and her husband have prime speaking slots at the convention in Denver, which begins today. Her name will be formally placed in nomination Thursday night, when Obama is expected to be chosen.

Still, polls show that some Clinton supporters are not rallying behind Mr. Obama. In an NBC/Wall Street Journal poll last week, only 52 percent said they planned to vote for Mr. Obama, while 21 percent supported Mr. McCain.

Mr. Obama's surrogates argued yesterday that the Biden selection showed their candidate's strengths.

"What it really shows is Barack Obama has the confidence and the judgment to pick someone who is really experienced and is willing to speak their minds," Caroline Kennedy, daughter of the late President Kennedy and one of the lawyers in charge of vetting Obama's vice-presidential candidates, said on "Meet the Press."

Mr. Biden is to spend the week in Denver, where the party is holding its convention, while Mr. Obama swings through battleground states before arriving in Colorado Thursday.

Just before leaving Eau Claire for Chicago, Mr. Obama talked with reporters on an airport tarmac about his acceptance speech, which he has been working on over the past several nights at a Chicago hotel.

"I am still tooling around with my speech a little bit," he said. "It may not be as good as the other headliners the first three nights, but hopefully it will make clear the choice that the American people are going to face in November."

Mr. Obama also said Mr. Biden would be a "great counselor on international crises that may come up."

But he stuck mostly to the economy on his morning visit to Wisconsin, using sarcasm to portray Mr. McCain as out of touch with working Americans.

He ridiculed McCain for losing track of how many homes he owns and saying that $5 million defines a person as rich. Mr. Obama joked that those making $4 million a year were "scrimping."

"You're having a tough time," he told the laughing crowd in the park. "You're middle class. If you only have 1 million, I don't know what -- you qualify for food stamps."


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

John McCain, center, Olympic gold medalist Misty May-Treanor, right, and Diamondbacks CEO Jeff Moorad hold their hands to their hearts during the national anthem at Arizona Diamondbacks baseball game in Phoenix yesterday.

310 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 25, 2008 Monday


Interfaith service boosts importance of evangelical vote


BYLINE: David M. Brown and Salena Zito


LENGTH: 804 words


DENVER -- On the eve of their national convention, Democrats appeared eager to woo a segment of the electorate more identified with the GOP in recent presidential elections: the God vote.

More than 3,000 delegates, party officials and others participating in the Democratic National Convention assembled Sunday afternoon at the Colorado Convention Center for an interfaith worship service.

The service, including choirs singing hymns and spiritual leaders offering prayers from a variety of faiths -- Christian, Jewish, Islamic, Buddhist and others -- was touted as the first time an interfaith event kicked off the party's convention week.

"It's about time," said delegate Valerie McDonald Roberts, a former Pittsburgh city councilwoman and Allegheny County recorder of deeds, who attended the event.

"It was a great event to kick things off, basically an invocation for the weeklong process of our convention that we are about to participate in," she said. "Look, we are a big-tent party and that was one big tent in there. We had Buddhist and Jews, Catholics and evangelical Christians all talking quite frankly and respectfully about their role within the party."

The convention officially starts today as an estimated 50,000 delegates, visitors, politicians and journalists converge for the first formal session from 3 to 9 p.m. Opening hoopla gives way to business sessions and caucus meetings throughout the day, while nightly sessions allotted for prime-time speeches will build to a climax on Thursday with Sen. Barack Obama's acceptance speech.

Obama, the first black person to be nominated for president by a major party, is scheduled to accept the nomination before a crowd of 75,000 at Invesco at Mile High Stadium.

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, hoping to unite the Democratic Party and cement her future in it, will gather her hard-won primary delegates Wednesday at a reception where she is expected to formally release them to Obama.

Clinton has invited her pledged delegates to a reception at the Colorado Convention Center, not far from the main Democratic National Convention arena.

The high-profile gathering of political regulars who once fought against Obama serves a dual purpose for Clinton: Show fellow Democrats that she can be a team player and display her still formidable political strengths for the future. Many of her supporters want her to run for president again.

Some Clinton delegates still plan to vote for her at the convention, even if she releases them.

"This is much bigger than Hillary," said Pam Durham, a Clinton delegate from Fort Worth, Texas. "I have a responsibility. I do not own my vote. I have to represent the voters who sent me."

Pittsburgh City Council President Doug Shields, a delegate and Obama supporter, said it's appropriate for the party to allow Clinton backers to express themselves.

"Politically, it's a smart move," said Shields of Squirrel Hill. "Democratic primaries are always hard fought. I think it's out of respect, and that's good."

Sen. John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, started a television ad suggesting Obama snubbed Clinton for the vice presidential spot because of her criticism of him during the Democratic primary fight. McCain's campaign hopes to persuade disenchanted Democrats who backed Clinton to vote for him in the Nov. 4 election.

Clinton aides responded that she clearly supports Obama and agrees with him on important issues such as health care and the Iraq war, and doesn't agree with McCain on those issues.

Colorado Gov. Bill Ritter welcomed the crowd at the interfaith service, saying Democrats need to "remind the rest of the country that in our party there is absolutely an intersection of faith and politics."

Democratic strategist Dane Strother said the interfaith service event, called "Faith in Action," sends an important signal.

"We cannot cede the evangelical voter any longer," he said.

Christian conservatives played a significant role in President George W. Bush's victories in 2000 and 2004.

"The Democrats are doing a much more inclusive job this year in reaching out to people of faith," Strother said. "And, we are showing much more respect beginning with the convention having the interfaith service and asking various religious leaders to give invocations at the convention."

Burns Strider, who was dubbed Hillary Clinton's "Faith Guru," said the service inspired him.

"The Democratic Party has allowed something extremely authentic and unusual to happen today: an event absent of sound bites and controlled message. What a breath of fresh air," said Strider, a consultant to politicians, businesses and nonprofits on faith issues.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

David M. Brown can be reached at dbrown@tribweb.com or 412-380-5614. Salena Zito can be reached at szito@tribweb.com


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Tribune Review Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



311 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 25, 2008 Monday


Rendell urges Democrats to unite


BYLINE: David M. Brown and Salena Zito


LENGTH: 458 words


DENVER -- Gov. Ed Rendell today made his strongest pitch for party unity since the hard-fought Democratic primary, telling Pennsylvania delegates to the national convention it's time for Hillary Clinton backers to join Barack Obama's bandwagon.

"If you love Hillary, get out there and work your heart out for Barack," Rendell said during a delegation breakfast at the Marriott Tech Center Hotel.

The governor said the Republican party has targeted Pennsylvania as one of three states that went to the Democrats in 2004 that the GOP hopes to carry for John McCain in November.

"For us to do the job we have to do, everybody has to be on board," Rendell said. "Nobody worked harder for Senator Clinton than I did. ... I think she would make a great president. We worked our hearts out. So did many of you. We carried the state of Pennsylvania -- but that's over. If you want Hillary Clinton to be president -- I think someday she might be, but it's not going to be this year."

"She has told us loud and clear that we can't waste a minute looking back," Rendell said. "We've got to elect Senator Obama. He's a good man. His policies are almost identical to Senator Clinton's. If you care about Hillary, you've got to make sure we do the things she's asked us to do. She has asked us to give our heart and soul and the energy we displayed on her behalf to Senator Obama."

The first Democratic National Convention in Denver in 100 years will get underway at 3 p.m. local time (5 p.m. in Pittsburgh). Giving a Colorado flavor to the opening session, the Navajo Code Talkers Association will present the colors and the Colorado Children's Chorale sing the National Anthem.

An estimated 15,000 journalists will be taking notes as approximately 4,440 delegates, ranging in age from 17 to 91, get down to business at the Pepsi Center leading up to Obama's expected nomination Wednesday night. Obama is scheduled to deliver his acceptance speech Thursday night before a crowd of 75,000 at Invesco Field at Mile High.

The McCain campaign today released a television spot trying to chip away at the Democrats' plan to unify the party behind Obama. The ad features Debra Bartoshevich, identifying herself as a Democrat who proudly supported Clinton because "she had the experience and judgment to be president."

The woman says she's supporting McCain because "now he's the one with the experience and judgment."

Obama holds a town hall meeting with Iowans today in Davenport. He will be introduced by Randy Wehrman, a local resident and Republican who is backing the Illinois senator. Obama will be in Kansas City today, watching Michelle Obama's televised speech in Denver. At his wife speaks, Obama is expected to appear "live" at the convention via satellite.


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Tribune Review Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



312 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 24, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


It's Biden for Obama


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 1250 words


DENVER - Sen. Barack Obama, who has built his campaign on the theme of change, yesterday opted for Washington experience and foreign-policy expertise in making Delaware Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. his choice for vice president.

At a rally at the Old State Capitol in Springfield, Ill., the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee described the 36-year veteran of the Senate as someone "uniquely suited to be my partner as we work to put our country back on track."

Once ratified by the party convention in Denver this week, Biden, 65, a two-time presidential candidate himself, will become the first Delawarean in history to run on a major national party ticket.

"Joe Biden is what so many others pretend to be - a statesman with sound judgment who doesn't have to hide behind bluster to keep America strong," Obama told the crowd at the site where he launched his own candidacy 19 months ago. "Joe won't just make a good vice president - he will make a great one."

When Obama finished the introduction, inadvertently referring to his running mate as the next "president" before correcting himself, Biden jogged the length of the stage and embraced him. In his own remarks, Biden talked of the values the two men shared and bemoaned the state of America under Republican stewardship.

"I say with every fiber in my being: We cannot stand four more years of this," he said.

And he attacked Republican presidential candidate John McCain, his Senate colleague and longtime friend, saying McCain's election would amount to four more years of President Bush.

"These times call for total change in Washington's worldview," said Biden, before turning his focus to McCain more directly. "These times require more than a good soldier. They require a wise leader."

In explaining his choice, Obama cited the character, expertise and accomplishments of a senator who has been in Washington for more than half his life - a fact that McCain and the Republicans sought to turn into a negative by suggesting that Obama, in turning to Biden, was admitting he did not have enough experience to be president.

The McCain campaign put out a television commercial showing footage from a debate in August 2007, in which Biden confirmed that he had said of Obama: "I think he can be ready, but right now I don't believe he is. The presidency is not something that lends itself to on-the-job training." The ad also shows Biden praising McCain, saying he "would be honored to run with or against" the Arizona senator because "the country would be better off."

Prominent Democrats, though, were quick to express their approval.

Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton, who many of her backers hoped would get the call, hailed Biden as "exceptionally strong, experienced leader and devoted public servant" who would be a "purposeful and dynamic" vice president.

Kim Gandy, who chairs NOW's political action committee and favored Clinton, described Biden as "a friend of women and a strong selection." The Rev. Jesse Jackson said that Obama "has struck Olympic gold."

Tom Carper, Biden's fellow Democratic senator from Delaware, said Obama had shown "exemplary judgment" in his choice, adding: "Joe brings experience to Barack's message of change."

Several Republican senators - including Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, who had been mentioned as a possible Obama running mate himself - had kind words for Biden, as did his close friend and frequent Amtrak seatmate, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania.

Specter complimented Obama on the selection, spoke of the contrast in experience between the two men, and added: "If it were a race between Sen. McCain and Sen. Biden, it would be a very different race."

Biden is scheduled to arrive here in time to begin campaigning among the delegates before speaking to the full convention Wednesday night.

Born in Scranton, Biden moved with his family to the Wilmington area when he was 10. After graduating from the University of Delaware and Syracuse University Law School, he got elected to the New Castle County Council at age 27.

Two years later, he won the Senate seat that he has held ever since by upsetting Caleb Boggs, a longtime Republican incumbent. He hasn't had a tough race since.

Before Biden could take office, however, his life was shattered by an automobile accident that killed his wife and his daughter and injured his two young sons. He took the oath of office in his sons' hospital room. In order to spend more time with them, he began commuting to Washington on Amtrak, a practice he never abandoned.

He quickly gained a reputation as one of the Democratic Party's most compelling orators, a reputation that helped thrust him into the battle for his party's presidential nomination in 1988. But his candidacy crashed and burned after the revelation that he had virtually stolen his stump speech from a British politician.

In the Senate, Biden served as chairman and ranking member of the Judiciary Committee in the 1980s and 1990s. He played prominent roles in the successful fight to prevent Robert Bork from taking a seat on the U.S. Supreme Court and in the failed attempt to block the confirmation of Clarence Thomas.

Starting in 1997, Biden shifted his focus to foreign relations - as chairman and ranking member on that committee - and ultimately became his party's leading spokesman on the subject in general and the Iraq war in particular.

While he voted to authorize the war in 2002, he went on to become a staunch critic of the Bush administration's handling of the situation, saying the solution rested in dividing Iraq into three, semiautonomous regions, one each for the Kurds, Shiites and Sunnis. He also opposed the surge strategy, advocated by McCain and adopted by the administration, predicting it would fail.

Biden's presidential candidacy this time around lasted only through the first-in-the-nation Iowa caucus. But he got strong reviews for his debate performances, in which he showed a new ability to control his tendency to talk too much.

Over the years, Biden, whose nomination is expected to be ratified by the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday, has compiled a voting record in the Senate that has been more liberal than conservative.

He is up for reelection to the Senate this year, seeking a seventh term. Delaware law allows him to run for senator and vice president at the same time. Biden did not indicate yesterday whether he would do so, although his Republican opponent in the Senate race, Christine O'Donnell, called on him to step aside.

Eight years ago, Joseph Lieberman ran for both in Connecticut. He won a third term in the Senate even as he failed to win the vice presidency on the Democratic ticket with Al Gore.

Joseph Robinette Biden Jr.

Age: 65; born Nov. 20, 1942, in Scranton, the oldest of four siblings.

Experience: U.S. senator from Delaware since 1973; current chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and past chairman of the Judiciary Committee; New Castle County Council member, 1970-72; presidential candidate, 1988 and 2008.

Education: Bachelor's degree in history and political science, University of Delaware, 1965; law degree, Syracuse University, 1968.

Family: Married Neilia Hunter in 1966; they had three children, Beau, Hunter and Naomi. His wife and 1-year-old Naomi died in a 1972 car crash. Married Jill Jacobs in 1977; they have a daughter, Ashley. Beau Biden is Delaware's attorney general.

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.
