313 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 24, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


Offering reassurance, wooing working class


BYLINE: By Thomas Fitzgerald; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 959 words


A year ago, Democratic Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was tramping around Iowa without a police escort or one of those attendant press mobs bristling with microphones. Running for president in the shadow of two celebrities, he was 20 years past his status as The Next Big Thing in American politics.

Yesterday, TV networks went live when Biden made his first appearance in Springfield, Ill., as Sen. Barack Obama's vice presidential running mate.

Biden, 65, an authority on foreign policy and a longtime Washington insider, shores up the perceived weaknesses of the 47-year-old Obama, who, in his first Senate term, lacks significant foreign-policy or legislative experience.

Obama made the critical strategic decision that he needed to reassure voters in his tightening race with Republican Sen. John McCain, picking a 36-year veteran of the Senate instead of an outside-the-Beltway choice that might have underscored what has been his core appeal, as the "change" candidate of a new generation.

There was another important imperative at work: opening a possible entrée to the working-class white voters who mostly shunned Obama for Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton in the final months of their Democratic primary battle.

Biden comes from a blue-collar background and is a native of the battleground state of Pennsylvania, born in Scranton. His favorite TV show: any Philadelphia Eagles game. Biden also is Roman Catholic, a group that Obama had trouble connecting with during the primaries - though he supports abortion rights, making him acceptable to the party's feminist groups.

In Illinois, Obama called Biden that "scrappy kid from Scranton who beat the odds" and said he would be a "fighter" for the middle class. Clinton also highlighted her Scranton ancestry - her father came from there - and used similar pugilistic language to win big in the Pennsylvania primary.

"I'm here for the cops and the firefighters, the teachers and the line workers . . . folks whose lives are the measure of whether the American dream endures," Biden said.

During his short-lived campaign for the 2008 nomination, Biden dwelled in briefing-book detail on foreign affairs and stressed the need to be careful in withdrawing from Iraq - at a time when most voters in the Iowa caucuses just wanted the troops out as soon as possible. "Telling the truth is more important than making you feel good," Biden said at a corn-boil in eastern Iowa in August 2007, a sentiment he repeated often on the trail.

Inevitably, after Biden spoke in an Iowa home, VFW hall or a community center to a handful of Democrats, somebody would say something like: "He's so qualified, so impressive. Too bad he can't win. Maybe he should be secretary of state."

Now, Biden will be on a kind of diplomatic mission for Obama, though he is an envoy with bite. Biden has gravitas - sometimes he sounds like the prototype of a windy senator - but he also has a mischievous Irish gleam in his eye and loves the fight. He should be able to go after McCain while Obama stays above the fray.

"Joe's out there hugging and kissing people - he just keeps going," John Martilla, Biden's media consultant since 1972, said last year, admiring how his client was working rooms in Iowa despite trailing in the polls.

Biden prizes loyalty. Most of his aides have been with him for decades, and his closest adviser is his sister, Valerie Biden Owens, who managed his first campaign for county council years ago.

Biden's mouth also just keeps going. He's blunt and sardonic.

Many Democrats consider the best sound bite of the campaign so far a shot that Biden took at Republican Rudy Giuliani in a televised debate last October at Drexel University. Every sentence that Giuliani utters has "a subject, a verb and 9/11," Biden said. His rivals burst out laughing. In another debate, the moderator asked Biden if he could exercise enough verbal discipline to be president. His succinct answer: "Yes." At still another debate, with rivals scoring one hit or another, Biden began his answer with, "You know, the American people could care less about what's going on up here."

Yesterday, Biden tweaked McCain for his many houses, saying that before McCain could empathize with families' kitchen-table issues, he'd have to figure out which of seven tables at which to sit.

The downside to his fluency is that Biden also has a long history of verbal gaffes.

For instance, Biden had to apologize just as Obama was kicking off his campaign last year because he said that Obama was "the first mainstream African American [presidential candidate] who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy." Campaigning in New Hampshire, Biden said that in Delaware, "You cannot go to a 7-Eleven or a Dunkin' Donuts unless you have a slight Indian accent."

And Republicans are already using Biden's remark last year that Obama was not qualified to be president in an attack ad - and Pennsylvania GOP chairman Rob Gleason said that the pick "weakens their ticket" by pairing the "consummate Washington insider" with the candidate of change.

But Obama may have been looking at Biden's biography differently. He has overcome tremendous obstacles: the accident that killed his wife and daughter and critically injured his two sons before he was sworn in to the Senate.

His first presidential campaign, in 1988, ended in accusations of plagiarism, and then a brain aneurysm almost killed him. Becoming Obama's running mate represents getting up after you get knocked down, as Biden likes to put it.

"I'm a seasoned guy . . . and I really feel completely at ease," Biden said in an interview last year during a snowstorm in Muscatine, Iowa.

Contact staff writer Thomas Fitzgerald at 215-854-2718 or tfitzgerald@phillynews.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

314 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 24, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


What Obama must do in Denver;
At historic convention, candidate aims to revitalize his campaign and unite the party.


BYLINE: By Larry Eichel; Inquirer Senior Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News Nation-World; Pg. A16


LENGTH: 1063 words


DENVER - One of the most intense two weeks in modern political history begins today as Democrats arrive here to nominate Sen. Barack Obama as their candidate for president.

Not since 1916 have the two major parties met back to back, as they are doing this year; the Republicans will assemble next week in St. Paul, Minn., to bestow their nomination on Sen. John McCain.

And never before have both conventions been held so close to Election Day.

In an age when nominations are won and lost in the primaries, political conventions have become little more than carefully staged, nationally televised infomercials designed to showcase the candidate, stir the faithful, and woo the undecided.

That said, Obama has a lot he'd like to accomplish during four days in Denver starting tomorrow.

His overriding goal is to reinvigorate a campaign that has stalled in the last month - losing some of its sense of being special - and boost a polling lead that has dwindled to almost nothing.

An ideal convention for Obama, who still benefits from a national political landscape that favors the Democrats, would accomplish the following, analysts say:

Cast his unusual life story as a classic American tale of success, built on the familiar elements of merit, hard work and achievement.

Make undecided voters more comfortable with a man who has limited foreign-policy experience and only four years on the national stage, starting with his breakthrough speech at the last convention.

Complete the unification of a party that split almost precisely in half - with a majority of Democratic women on the other side - during his long, tough nomination fight with Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Portray a McCain presidency, despite the Arizonan's reputation as a maverick, as four more years of George W. Bush, particularly when it comes to economics.

Address the concerns among some party leaders that there isn't much that drives Obama beyond vague notions of change and hope, and that he's having trouble making a visceral connection with blue-collar voters.

In his campaign appearances and television commercials, the Illinois senator has begun trying to develop more of a traditional, meat-and-potatoes economic message.

He has sought to depict McCain as a politician out of touch with the woes of struggling families - to which the Arizonan contributed by not knowing how many homes he and his wife own - and himself as a populist who understands their fears and would cut their taxes.

Obama said last week that he wanted voters to look at him and say, "This is somebody who's going to fight for me." A new campaign ad, now airing in Philadelphia, ends with the words: "Barack Obama: The middle class first."

Throughout the convention, the trick for the Obama team will be to avoid unwanted drama without putting the country to sleep.

Any hint of drama is likely to come courtesy of the Clintons, the former president and the current senator, whose relationships with Obama remain a subject of intense interest.

On Wednesday night, in a move intended to heal wounds rather than reopen them, Hillary Clinton's name will be put in nomination. A roll call will then proceed.

How it all plays out - and how the die-hard supporters of the most successful female presidential candidate in history react - will determine the degree to which the event provides the "catharsis" leading to unity that Clinton says she wants.

Another element of uncertainty involves Obama's acceptance speech, set for Thursday night at Invesco Field at Mile High, the football stadium where the NFL's Denver Broncos play.

While the weather could gum up the works, the forecast is for fair skies. More important, delivering the speech before 75,000 screaming fans could feed into the Republican theme, developed after Obama's massive rally in Berlin last month, that the man is more celebrity than leader.

If all goes well, the week should produce a "bounce" in the polls for Obama. But a study by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington think tank, shows that the bounces produced by recent conventions were modest and short.

In 2000, for instance, the last election without an incumbent, Bush got an 8-percentage-point boost from the Republican convention in Philadelphia. But two weeks later, Al Gore got the 8 points back after his gathering in Los Angeles.

What bounces there will be in 2008, with the conventions right on top of each other, remain to be seen. In any event, McCain appears ready to try to steal some of Obama's thunder by naming his running mate as early as Friday, the day after Obama's big speech.

When the Democrats get down to business tomorrow night, the focus will be squarely on Obama himself, even though he won't get to town until midweek. The featured speaker is his wife, Michelle, to be preceded by his half-sister and his brother-in-law.

On Tuesday, Hillary Clinton will occupy the spotlight. Wednesday's program includes former President Bill Clinton and the acceptance speech by the vice presidential nominee, Delaware Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr.

The finale on Thursday will be Obama's acceptance speech, which comes, remarkably, on the anniversary of the "I Have a Dream" speech of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Pennsylvania, which has seen more television commercials thus far than any other state, will get a lot of attention at the convention as well.

The roster of speakers includes Rep. Patrick Murphy of Bucks County, the first Iraq war veteran to be elected to the House; Gov. Rendell, one of Clinton's leading supporters in the nominating fight; and Sen. Bob Casey, an antiabortion politician whose antiabortion father, the former governor, wanted to give a speech about his position at the 1992 convention but was kept off the podium.

Denver has hosted a national political convention only once before, precisely 100 years ago, when the Democrats came to town to nominate William Jennings Bryan for the third time. He lost the election, as he had the previous two.

The Twin Cities have gone even longer without a convention; the Republicans met in Minneapolis in 1892, nominating Benjamin Harrison. Despite being the incumbent, Harrison lost, too.

This time around, one of them is pretty much guaranteed to pick a winner. What happens the next two weeks will help determine which one.

Contact senior writer Larry Eichel at 215-854-2415 or leichel@phillynews.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved



315 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday
TWO STAR EDITION


POLITICS THE STAR OF THE LATEST AD CAMPAIGNS


BYLINE: Teresa F. Lindeman, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-1


LENGTH: 861 words


The election chatter has been picking up.

Pizza Hut ran a national commercial earlier this year showing a college student thinking about not voting; thousands bought American Eagle Outfitters' T-shirts that urge voting; then, those old enough to be a part of the "Dewmocracy" weighed in on the next hot Mountain Dew flavor ... or was it the best combo dinner at Smokey Bones restaurants that they were being asked to vote on?

Even as John McCain and Barack Obama spend millions of dollars on messages meant to reverberate with the American electorate, marketers selling everything from pulled pork to cars are making a bid for relevancy by dropping electoral themes into their ad campaigns.

"The election is going to consume our attention from now until October," predicted Tom Dowling, managing director with marketing firm Burson-Marsteller's Downtown office.

Once the Olympics are over, he's so convinced the nation, its media and its consumers will be tuned into the showdown over the White House that he's been telling his firm's public relations clients to think about how their message might relate to the political scene.

His advice: "If your story doesn't somehow, some way connect to the election, don't even bother."

The political flavoring of the commercial environment is a cyclical thing, as predictable as the battle for the presidency every four years, according to Kathleen Hall Jamieson, professor of communication at the University of Pennsylvania who studies campaign rhetoric.

"When it's clever, it potentially works," she said. "The danger, of course, is it's clever and you forget the product."

Advertisers generally avoid any appearance of taking sides, Dr. Jamieson said. Nobody expects to see a spot asking Republicans to buy Chevy trucks or pushing Volvos to Democrats. "You don't ever want to divide your audience," she said.

Consumers get enough of the serious, sometimes negative, messages from candidates, political action groups and others trying to influence the election.

Instead, marketers often link their product to politics through humor. A recent Smokey Bones promotion put images of cows, chickens, turkeys and pigs -- no donkeys or elephants -- in star-spangled red, white and blue.

The Maytag repairman has been seen fixing a voting machine. Were those hanging chads he discovered?

Meanwhile, the Mr. Opportunity character who pitches Hondas picked up on a phrase made familiar by federal election guidelines: "I approve this message."

Dr. Jamieson joked some opportunities haven't been truly exploited. She recommends trying political themes in spots for mouthwash and aids to indigestion.

"If I were an advertiser, that's what I would do," she said, with a laugh.

Seemingly irresistible are quirky quests for the nation's highest office, and not just for entertainment figures such as comedian Stephen Colbert and celebrity heiress Paris Hilton.

A few days ago, Captain Morgan, a brand character who sells rum for London-based Diageo, announced a run for the presidency using the slogan "putting the party back in politics." Back when Morris the Cat of 9Lives cat food fame worked for the H.J. Heinz Co. (he's now an employee of Del Monte Foods), he took a shot at the White House.

Another popular way to link to politics includes the kind of get-out-the-vote messages that have been produced by brands such as Pizza Hut and KFC. The Rock The Vote organization began voter registration campaigns more than a decade ago and has been associated with MTV, Fox, even Comcast.

A spokeswoman for South Side-based American Eagle said the teen retailer has had a good response to its "Vote" T-shirts and planned to continue offering them online through the election, although they're no longer available in stores.

It's hard to go wrong just urging people to claim their right to weigh in on the nation's future. Patriots, not to mention fans of both radio host Rush Limbaugh and Comedy Central's political satire "The Daily Show," can support that message.

But, since this is politics, observers see nuances even in that theme. Mr. Dowling said advertisers who target a younger demographic might be noticing how many young people are gravitating toward the Obama message and trying to catch that wave.

Depending on where companies place get-out-the-vote ads, such messages have the potential to influence the actual vote, if only in a small way, said Dr. Jamieson.

"It can create a political message," she said. Advertisers typically buy spots on certain TV shows or in certain publications because they know who is paying attention to those media outlets. If the audience skews toward fans of one candidate or the other and the get-out-the-vote campaign increases turnout among those people, it could mean a few extra levers pulled.

A T-shirt promotion announced by KFC in June may accomplish the marketing feat of avoiding an appearance of conflicts while making chicken wings top of mind.

The fast-food chain is selling three $15 shirts: a "right wing" red one, a "left wing" blue one and, for the undecided, a white one that says, "Left wing, right wing: Tastes the same to me." All have a small image of Colonel Harland Sanders tucked into the artwork.


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Teresa F. Lindeman can be reached at tlindeman@post-gazette.com or at 412-263-2018.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



316 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


OBAMA IS HIS OWN WORST ENEMY;
DEMOCRATS KNOW THEIR MAN IS FALTERING


BYLINE: Jack Kelly


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 743 words


Democrats begin their national convention with a queasy feeling in the pits of their stomachs. Barack Obama has plunged in the polls, falling into a statistical tie with John McCain. The election that was supposed to be in the bag isn't.

Democrats blame the plunge on negative ads. They plan to respond in kind. The first few days of their convention will feature nonstop assaults on the presumptive GOP nominee.

The Democrats' strategy is driven by what they think happened to John Kerry in 2004. His plans to run as a war hero came a cropper when 15 of the 23 officers who served with him in Vietnam declared him "Unfit for Command." Democrats believe Sen. Kerry's sluggish response to their charges is what cost him the presidency. Sen. Obama has declared he will not be "swift-boated."

But the Democratic strategy has two serious flaws. The first is the blithe assumption by Democrats that if voters prefer the Republican candidate, it has to be because the Republican played a dirty trick. The thought that voters might prefer the Republican because of perceived shortcomings in the Democrat never crosses their minds.

It should. The Swifties' charges hit home because they were credible and came from a credible source. It is Sen. Obama's inexperience and ego, not the brilliance of Sen. McCain's ad writers, that have made his ads mocking Sen. Obama's celebrity status resonate.

The second is their tendency to confuse rudeness with toughness. Liberal bloggers imagine they're being tough when they use profane language to say nasty things about their opponents.

Whining isn't toughness, either. After Sen. McCain bested their man at Pastor Rick Warren's presidential forum last weekend, Sen. Obama staffers told reporters the old white guy must have cheated. Mr. Obama complained, falsely, to the Veterans of Foreign Wars on Tuesday that Mr. McCain has been questioning his patriotism.

Nor is braggadocio. In North Carolina on Tuesday, Mr. Obama said: "John McCain doesn't know what he's up against."

"All that is missing is the quivering lip and foot-stomping," wrote Jennifer Rubin of Commentary Magazine's blog about Mr. Obama's remarks in North Carolina. "I am too tough! I am not going to lose! Presidential it is not. Panicky and defensive it is." There's more to being tough than talking tough. Unless Sen. Obama resolves rising doubts about his toughness, talking tough just makes him seem wimpier.

Democrats plan to paint Mr. McCain as the reincarnation of George W. Bush. This will be difficult to do, since it is so obviously untrue.

Not that truth has been much of a barrier to a Democratic line of attack. Obama surrogates have been referring to Sen. McCain as "Exxon John" because both he and the giant oil company favor offshore drilling. But Exxon employees have given more money to Mr. Obama ($42,100) than to Mr. McCain ($35,166), and Mr. Obama voted for the 2005 energy bill that gave massive tax breaks to oil companies, while Mr. McCain voted against it because he opposed those tax breaks.

But even if Democrats succeed in tarnishing Mr. McCain, it won't solve their fundamental problem, because this election is mostly about Barack Obama. Who is he? What does he really believe? Does he know enough, is he strong enough to lead?

"McCain's message is pretty clear and essentially twofold," wrote liberal blogger Josh Marshall of Talking Points Memo. "Obama is, in so many words, a frivolous phony, someone who really doesn't have any business running for president. McCain is a strong leader who can defend the country.

"From Obama, honestly, I don't sense a really clear message," Mr. Marshall said. "There are attacks on McCain, some of which are quite good. There are positive, uplifting commercials ... But it's hard for me to come up with a clear-cut Obama message in the way that it's pretty simple for me to do with McCain."

If Mr. Obama wants to stop his slide in the polls, he must recognize he has been chiefly responsible for it. If people think Mr. Obama has a big head and a thin skin, he must act in a way that belies that. He must be more forthcoming about his past. And when he makes a mistake or changes a position, he should acknowledge it.

Mr. Obama has to be clear about where he plans to lead the country and explain why he is qualified to do so. Hopenchange won't cut it anymore. His acceptance speech in Denver will be the most important of his life. What will he say?

Phil McCarten/Getty Images

Paris Hilton with Mom and pooch


LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Jack Kelly is a columnist for the Post-Gazette and The Toledo Blade (jkelly@post-gazette.com, 412-263-1476).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



317 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


SHARP CONTRASTS IN TAX PLANS OF OPPOSING PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES


BYLINE: STEPHEN BRAUN, LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-11


LENGTH: 1120 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The sharpening rhetoric between Sens. John McCain and Barack Obama over their competing plans to overhaul the nation's tax system has underscored one of the most profound differences between them -- how they would target America's wealthiest taxpayers.

Under Mr. McCain, the rich would see their tax burden ease. Under Mr. Obama, their rates would rise dramatically.

For much of the campaign, the two candidates have talked sparingly and obliquely about how they would deal with affluent taxpayers. But a recent volley of acid-edged campaign ads stirred up the tax issue, and a question posed last weekend by Orange County pastor Rick Warren zeroed in on how both men defined "rich."

Mr. Obama said the dividing line was income of $250,000 a year, while Mr. McCain responded somewhat flippantly that it was $5 million. McCain aides said later that the senator was joking, but his remark quickly became a campaign flashpoint.

"I guess if you're making $3 million a year, you're middle-class," Mr. Obama sniped, prompting a McCain aide to fire back: "It's not the job of the government to define who is rich."

Where to draw the line among the nation's wealthiest taxpayers is the central difference between rival tax blueprints that offer starkly differing formulas for reviving a faltering economy.

On Tuesday, new ads from both camps played on the public's rising anxiety about taxes, incomes and the volatile economy. "Three Times," an Obama television ad airing from Virginia to Colorado, savages Mr. McCain for lavishing $200 billion tax "giveaways" on "big corporations." Mr. McCain responded with "Millions," a radio ad that predicts Mr. Obama will "raise taxes on your income, your electric bills, even your life savings."

The two camps immediately issued rebuttals, each claiming its position on taxes was being distorted by the opposition. The Obama campaign contended that the overwhelming majority of Americans would not see a tax increase under his plan, only the wealthiest 5 percent or so. The McCain side retorted that the "$4 billion" in tax breaks for oil companies mentioned in Mr. Obama's ad was misleading because Mr. McCain is proposing an across-the-board tax cut for all corporations and is not favoring the oil industry.

A close look at their proposals shows that the differences fall neatly along the traditional policy gulf that has long divided Republicans and Democrats: liberating the wealthy with tax cuts to stimulate the nation's prosperity versus raising their rates to redistribute the tax burden and pay for crucial government programs.

"The real fault lines are over how to treat people in the highest tax brackets. It gets to the heart of their economic philosophies," said Leonard E. Burman, a senior fellow with the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan Washington-based tax reform group that has questioned the details of both tax plans.

Both candidates have promised to balance their tax relief programs with budget cuts designed to trim soaring deficits. But the Tax Policy Center has warned that both plans -- coupled with the candidates' high-cost healthcare proposals -- would balloon the $9.6 trillion national debt. The center's analysis reported that Mr. McCain's tax proposals would add $5 trillion to the debt over the next 10 years, while Mr. Obama's would add $3.6 trillion.

"Both tax plans take for granted a big peace dividend from ending the war in Iraq," Burman said. "That's a big assumption."

Mr. McCain's plan would cater to wealthy taxpayers and corporations by extending and expanding the Bush tax cuts, slashing corporate taxes and weakening the estate tax, but it would also aid taxpayers across the board by making the full Bush cuts permanent.

A deficit hawk and formerly a critic of the massive tax cuts launched in 2001 by the Bush administration, Mr. McCain now embraces the tax policies of supply-side economists who contend that lifting the tax yoke on the rich would encourage investment and stimulate the economy. "Wealth creates wealth," Mr. McCain said during a primary debate in Michigan last year.

Under his proposals, Mr. McCain would make all the 2001 and 2003 Bush tax cuts permanent. That would keep the two highest tax brackets at their current rates of 33 percent and 35 percent -- rather than reverting to 36 percent and 39.6 percent, where they were during the Clinton administration.

"They've been law for eight years now, and taxpayers are used to those rates," said J.D. Foster, a senior fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington. "Allowing them to expire would be tantamount to a massive tax increase."

Mr. McCain also has proposed a sharp reduction in corporate taxes. He would pare the highest two corporate tax brackets, 35 percent and 34 percent, down to 25 percent. The top bracket would be immediately eliminated and the 34 percent bracket would be phased down to 24 percent between 2009 and 2014.

He would also maintain the 15 percent tax rates on dividends and capital gains for the highest-tier taxpayers. And starting in 2010, Mr. McCain would substantially reduce the estate tax. He would increase the exemption on inherited funds from $3.5 million to $5 million and sharply lower taxes on remaining wealth from 45 percent to 15%, moves that would enable affluent families to hold on to more of their wealth.

Democratic-leaning economists say Mr. McCain's plans offer little new aid to squeezed middle-class families. And they question whether corporations and wealthy taxpayers would convert McCain-era tax savings into new investments that would bolster the economy.

Mr. Obama's tax plan is aimed at strengthening benefits for lower-rung taxpayers and raising rates at the top. His plan would restore the Clinton-era rates for the highest two tax brackets to 36 percent and 39.6 percent.

In Springfield, Mo. last month, Mr. Obama pledged that if "you're a family making less than $250,000 a year, you will not see your taxes go up."

Mr. Obama would exempt seniors making less than $50,000 from paying any income tax. And he would make the Bush cuts permanent for poor and middle-class Americans, adding tax breaks like a refundable credit for wage earners and a higher education credit for students who agree to work 100 hours of community service.

Under Mr. Obama's plan, the highest corporate tax tier would hold at 35 percent -- a nod to Wall Street, but higher than Mr. McCain's slashed rate. But Mr. Obama would raise the highest rates on dividends and capital gains from 15 percent to 20 percent. And he would keep the estate tax in the same form approved by Congress for 2009, with an exemption for the first $3.5 million and a top tax rate of 45%. That would mean a higher rate on the wealthy than Mr. McCain would allow.


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



318 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday
TWO STAR EDITION


BIDEN ADDS SEASONING TO TICKET;
SEEN AS STRONG IN AREAS WHERE OBAMA ISN'T


BYLINE: JAMES O'TOOLE, PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE


SECTION: NATIONAL; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-1


LENGTH: 1585 words


DATELINE: DENVER


They stood as opponents on the stage at the Des Moines Register debate last December. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr. defended himself against a tough question on whether some of his off-the-cuff statements, including one about Sen. Barack Obama, suggested insensitivity on issues of race.

His rival stepped in.

"I have absolutely no doubt about what is in his heart and the commitment that he has made to racial equality in this country," Mr. Obama volunteered. "So I will provide some testimony, as they say in church."

On the eve of the convention where he will accept his historic nomination, Mr. Obama yesterday provided more profound testimony to his appreciation of the Delaware senator as he united their political destinies by choosing his older, more experienced colleague as his runningmate.

"Joe Biden is that rare mix -- for decades, he has brought change to Washington, but Washington hasn't changed him," Mr. Obama said as he introduced his new runningmate from the steps of the old state Capitol in Springfield, Ill. "He's an expert on foreign policy whose heart and values are rooted firmly in the middle class.

"He has stared down dictators and spoken out for America's cops and firefighters."

Like his trip to the Middle East and Europe earlier this summer, the selection of the foreign policy veteran suggests an effort to shore up a gap in Mr. Obama's own foreign policy credentials. The gamble is that he will reassure some voters about the Democratic ticket rather than reminding them that Mr. Obama is a very junior member of the Foreign Relations Committee panel that Mr. Biden chairs.

The two candidates made repeated references to Mr. Biden's Catholic, working-class roots in Scranton, demonstrating their hopes that he will be the ticket's ambassador to working-class voters. Mr. Obama lost overwhelmingly to Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton in Scranton in the April Pennsylvania primary and was weak everywhere among the white, working class.

Within moments of jogging to Mr. Obama's side on the Springfield stage, to the strains of Bruce Springsteen's, "The Rising," Mr. Biden jumped right into vice presidential candidate's traditional role as aggressor.

While describing Sen. John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, as his friend, he repeatedly tied him to the Bush administration. Trying to reinforce the story Democrats had pushed all week, he said that although many Americans sit at their kitchen tables worrying over their finances, Mr. McCain would have to first figure out which of his seven kitchen tables to sit at.

"We don't have to have four more years of George Bush and John McCain," Mr. Biden said.

Later, Mr. McCain told Katie Couric on CBS News that he believes Mr. Obama picked a good man.

"Joe and I have been friends for many, many years, and we know each other very well, and so I think he's made a very wise selection. I know that Joe will campaign well for Sen. Obama, and so I think he's going to be very formidable. Obviously, Joe and I have been on different philosophical sides, but we have been -- I consider him a good friend and good man."

Mr. McCain's campaigners tried to portray the pick as one that diminished Mr. Obama. Seizing on a slip in which, before immediately correcting himself, Mr. Obama referred to Mr. Biden as "the next president," a McCain spokesman said in a statement, "Barack Obama sounded as though he turned over the top spot on the ticket today to his new mentor.... The reality is that nothing has changed since Joe Biden first made his assessment that Barack Obama is not ready to lead," said Ben Porritt, the McCain spokesman.

He referred to Mr. Biden's observation, made when he was still running against his new partner, that Mr. Obama lacked the experience to be president. Videotape of the remark was fodder for a television commercial the Republican camp had prepared within hours of the middle-of-the-night text message that announced the ticket.

'Pennsylvania's third senator'

Democrats appeared almost uniformly positive about the decision.

Mrs. Clinton said, "Sen. Obama has continued in the best traditions for the vice presidency by selecting an exceptionally strong, experienced leader and devoted public servant."

T.J. Rooney, the state Democratic chairman who had been a Clinton supporter during the Pennsylvania primary, said it was the best choice the nominee could have made -- with the exception of Mrs. Clinton herself. His ally, Gov. Ed Rendell, had argued even before the decision was revealed that the senator from neighboring Delaware would be Mr. Obama's best bet.

Several Pennsylvanians noted that Mr. Biden has often described himself as "Pennsylvania's third senator."

Both candidates hope that their joint venture will be more successful than either of Mr. Biden's previous attempts.

In 1988, his first presidential bid foundered when a rival campaign leaked a videotape that showed that passages of a stump speech delivered at the Iowa State Fair had been lifted nearly intact from a speech by British Labour Party leader Neil Kinnock. Mr. Biden had used the passage on other occasions but had attributed it. He ended up dropping out before the first vote was cast.

This year, he was stopped in the snows of Iowa, failing to break through to the top tier of candidates during the caucuses.

Mr. Biden joked about his long tenure yesterday -- he was first elected in 1972 at the age of 29.

While noting that only four senators had more seniority, he turned and said, "But Barack, I want you to know there's 44 older than me."

Obama's unusual path

In choosing Springfield for introducing Mr. Biden, Mr. Obama was returning yesterday to the spot where he launched his then improbable presidential bid on a cold day in February 2007. Babies that weren't yet born then, Mr. Obama has often joked, are now walking and talking.

During that time, his campaign has also matured amid occasional stumbles.

That Springfield appearance was the official beginning of the campaign, but Mr. Obama's emergence as a plausible presidential candidate came with his heralded keynote address at the Democratic National Convention in Boston four years ago. The Illinois senator will figuratively echo that performance Thursday with his acceptance speech in INVESCO Field, continuing the extended process of introducing himself to American voters.

The site is symbolic of the theme of change that the campaign has sought to make its brand. The audience will include most of the Democratic Party hierarchy that will have gathered over the previous three days in the Pepsi Center.

The bulk of the crowd filling the Denver Broncos' home will comprise voters who didn't qualify for credentials for the traditional party gathering. The contrast is emblematic of the way the Obama forces have built a campaign aligned with but not dependent on traditional party structures.

Pennsylvania is an example. The Obama campaign has made its peace with the majority of state party leaders that opposed them in the spring, but its grass-roots registration and organizing efforts represent a separate if overlapping organization from the pre-existing Democratic Party structure.

The path that led Mr. Obama back to Springfield and on to INVESCO Field was unprecedented. He began as an intriguing long shot, seemingly a remote threat to Mrs. Clinton, the acknowledged front-runner. But his campaign's meticulous organization and command of new media and new voters brought him to a stunning upset in the Iowa caucuses that shattered all turnout records.

But not all of the changes since he last spoke in Springfield were as welcome. In the run-up to the Iowa showdown, where Mr. Biden was a distant also-ran, one common element among Democratic voters was that Democrats were happy with their field of candidates, and optimistic of their chances no matter which one emerged.

That amity wore thin as Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton battered one another through the later primaries. And the party's wide optimism that emerged from their gains in the 2006 congressional elections was tested through the summer by Mr. Obama's failure to put any real polling distance between himself and Mr. McCain.

In that nervous climate, Mr. McCain's halting accounting of his real estate holdings emerged as manna from political heaven this week, a self-inflicted rebuttal to his own campaign's effort to portray Mr. Obama as the candidate out of touch with the mores of the working class.

At the end of this week, it may be difficult to disentangle the effects of the housing exchanges, the vice presidential choice and Mr. Obama's renewed oratory on whatever polling shifts may emerge.

Anticipating the possibility of a Biden choice, a Washington Post-ABC News poll completed just before the announcement found that three-quarters of voters said picking Mr. Biden would not affect their vote. Roughly 13 percent said it would make them more likely to vote Democratic and a nearly equal proportion, 10 percent said it would make them less likely.

Rep. Jason Altmire, D-Bradford Woods, represents a southwestern Pennsylvania district that proved a tough target for Mr. Obama in the April primary.

He predicted the Biden choice would be popular with his constituents, but cautioned that voters are swayed by the top of the ticket not the No. 2.

"It's a good choice for southwestern Pennsylvania, but Sen. Obama still has some work to do," he said of his district's reaction.

That work will continue over the next four days as the Democrats officially make him the first African-American nominee in history.


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Post-Gazette politics editor James O'Toole can be reached at jotoole@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1562.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Alex Brandon/Associated Press: Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Barack Obama, D-Ill., with vice presidential running mate Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., wave at a rally yesterday in front of the old state Capitol in Springfield, Ill. Mr. Obama introduced Mr. Biden as his running mate at the event.
\ PHOTO: Jeff Roberson/Associated Press: Democratic vice presidential running mate Sen. Joe Biden, D-Del., jogs out to meet Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Barack Obama, D-Ill.
\ PHOTO: Mark Cowan/Bloomberg News: Barack Obama, left, his wife, Michelle, Joe Biden, Democratic senator from Delaware, right, and his wife Jill, wave to supporters during a rally yesterday.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



319 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 24, 2008 Sunday


Biden brings 'authority' to Obama's campaign


BYLINE: Mike Wereschagin and Kari Andren


LENGTH: 923 words


SPRINGFIELD, Ill. -- Barack Obama will fight for the presidency beside one of the Senate's happy warriors.

Standing before the Old State Capitol here in Abraham Lincoln's hometown, Obama announced Saturday the selection of Senate colleague Joe Biden as his running mate on the Democratic presidential ticket. Biden, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, brings more than 30 years of domestic and foreign policy experience to a campaign that had been criticized as lacking both.

On the campaign trail, he's described as a pit bull with sharp teeth and loose lips. Biden's aggressive criticisms of his opponents could balance Obama's more staid approach to political combat, although Biden's occasional impertinent statements might cause headaches for Obama's tightly organized campaign.

Biden wasted no time showing both sides yesterday.

One of the least wealthy members of the Senate, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, Biden excoriated Republican presidential hopeful John McCain for saying he didn't know how many houses he owned. Biden said he, like many others, has sat around his kitchen table trying to figure out how to make ends meet.

"That's not a worry John McCain has to worry about," Biden said. "He'll have to figure out which of the seven kitchen tables to sit at."

Minutes later, he seemed to stray off his prepared speech when he described his wife, Jill, as "drop-dead gorgeous," then said she "also has her doctoral degree, which is a problem." He quickly added he was kidding.

"Experience, foreign policy -- those are all pluses," said Jack Treadway, chairman of the political science department at Kutztown University near Reading. But, Treadway said, "The guy's a gaffe machine."

The verbal slips won't outweigh the authority Biden brings to the Democrats' ticket, said Allegheny County Treasurer John Weinstein, who has known Biden for 15 years. Biden once headlined a campaign fundraiser for Weinstein.

"I think, at the end of the day, when you look at what's facing this country -- the economy, the war -- it's more important than any off-the-cuff comment Senator Biden may make," Weinstein said. "You're looking at someone who doesn't need any on-the-job training and can fill any type of void when talking about foreign policy. ... Joe Biden has respect worldwide."

Republicans attacked the choice as verification that Obama doesn't have a background deep enough to run the country, a key charge of McCain's campaign.

"This is really an admission that, really, Obama doesn't think he has enough experience to serve as president," said Rob Gleason, chairman of the Pennsylvania Republican Party.

Within hours after Obama's announcement -- which came about 3 a.m. through text messages to supporters -- Republicans circulated an ad featuring comments last year by Biden, who was seeking the presidential nomination for the second time, that Obama is too inexperienced for the office.

"Voters in Pennsylvania do not agree with Joe Biden on every issue, but they do agree with him on the fact that Barack Obama is not ready to be president," said Paul Lindsay, McCain's spokesman.

However, they weren't as quick to attack Biden. Although he is considered one of the Senate's more liberal members, some of the country's most prominent Republicans have a decades-long relationship with him. McCain called Biden yesterday to congratulate him, according to The Associated Press, and Pennsylvania Sen. Arlen Specter praised Biden.

"I think if it were a race between Senator McCain and Senator Biden, it would be a very different race," Specter said.

Biden, 65, is a Catholic with working-class roots who could help attract blue-collar voters, like the ones that gave Sen. Hillary Clinton a 9-point victory over Obama in the Pennsylvania primary in April. Rather than getting a residence in Washington, Biden commutes there on an Amtrak train in the morning and returns home at night.

"Joe Biden is what so many others pretend to be -- a statesman who doesn't have to hide behind bluster," Obama said.

He's also a tenacious campaigner, said former Democratic National Committee executive director Mark Siegel.

"When he sinks his teeth into your neck, he doesn't let go until you go limp," Siegel said.

Thousands braved the sweltering heat to attend the Springfield event, which took place at the location where Obama announced his candidacy for president 19 months ago.

"This ticket brings real hope that things will change in Washington," said John Holmes, a retired policeman from Chicago who attended the event at Illinois' Old State Capitol with his wife. "Maybe now people will begin to appreciate what Biden has been trying to do."

Holmes said Biden was a "very pragmatic" choice and that selecting him as a running mate was a "very mature judgment move" for Obama.

Amber Traugott, a surgery resident from St. Louis, agreed.

She said Obama needed to choose someone with strong foreign policy credentials who's not afraid to speak his mind.

"I think he'll win it," Traugott said of Obama's chances in November. "It'll be a really interesting race to watch."

Josh Brinkley, a college student from Decatur, said he hoped Obama would choose Clinton as his running mate to bring some of her supporters on board with Obama.

"Hillary supporters are a little uneasy, but I think they will come around," Brinkley said. "I think it's going to be an easy contest."

Mike Wereschagin can be reached at mwereschagin@tribweb.com or 412-320-7900. Staff writer Salena Zito contributed to this report.


LOAD-DATE: August 24, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Tribune Review Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



320 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday


Man's Best Friends Ashamed Of Heritage Reasons To Mourn Fellow Beings Don't Forget People Children Are First National Plan Incorrect Comparison Raise The Limit Help The Aged Pedaling Disrespect Mccain Misconception An Unfunny Joke


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: P; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 2054 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


PUPPY MILLS

Owners of dogs know what most dogs give them: unconditional love and trust (almost a mirror image of God's love for us).

The Zimmerman brothers in neighboring Berks County betrayed that love and trust by shooting 80 helpless dogs. It is bad enough they operated a puppy mill, but to take advantage of an obscure, outdated law that allows owners to destroy their animals is worse. They killed man's best friends in cold blood.

Some puppy mill owners claim they are trying to save the family farm or make some other excuse for their actions. They can save the family farm, but they do not need to be cruel, abusive or neglectful.

The lives of innocent, trusting animals should not be forgotten. Call or write your state senator or House representative immediately. The archaic law allowing owners to destroy their own dogs and cats needs to be abolished. The laws presently are not tough enough to properly punish savages like the Zimmermans.

Gary Hornock, Elizabethtown

As a lifelong resident of Lancaster County, I have always been proud of my heritage - until now. I am ashamed to live in a state and county known as "The Puppy Mill Capital of the East."

The recent slaughter of 80 dogs in Berks County is just one example of the horror experienced by innocent dogs in puppy mills. Mass breeding, cruelty and neglect are common in puppy mills, and hundreds of such kennels are in Lancaster County. These abuses will continue until the health and welfare of dogs are seen as more important than profits. Every person who allows these atrocities to continue devalues what it means to be a compassionate, caring human being.

You can help by contacting your legislators (www.legis.state.pa.us) and urging them to pass House Bill 2525, which would make it illegal for anyone but a veterinarian to euthanize dogs in commercial breeding kennels and improve the conditions for thousands of dogs suffering behind the closed doors of Pennsylvania's infamous puppy mills.

Sylvia Evans, Lancaster

I sympathize with those standing vigil for the slaughtered kennel dogs. I extend this compassion to all creatures that collectively inhabit and support life on earth.

The "green" movement may promise better things, but people and animals have long suffered the effects of our exorbitant lifestyle. Many lives have been lost so that we could be the powerful consumers we are.

Let us remember the atrocities committed to protect our national interest - in Nagasaki and Hiroshima, in Cambodia, Chile, El Salvador and Guatemala. Yet we continue to tolerate half-thought-out, illegal regime changes (Iraq) and support for sleazy governments in which our political and business leaders have friends (Saudi Arabia).

Other developed nations can learn from our dead dogs, too. In one town in Chile, a huge trading partner of the U.S. whose grapes flood our supermarkets, stray dogs are rounded up once a year and disposed of quietly. Witnessing this, I thought, should we invade?

Robert McLane IV, Millersville

For Pennsylvania to put up with the horror of puppy mills for so many years is a sad statement about our state government, lawmakers, and those who elected them. Is this how we teach our youth the value of life ?

This case is so disturbing I have lost sleep, wondering how exactly do you shoot 80 dogs? How many shots did it take to kill each of them ? I am sure the breeders' association is going to have to put some serious spin on this story. I hope their lobbyist is up to the task.

What now for the Zimmermans?

Perhaps a nice roadside stand selling produce, using their discarded product as fertilizer.

Please contact your state representatives and urge them to pass House Bill 2525, which seeks to improve life for dogs living in the state's commercial breeding kennels.

As for the Amish farmers whom tourists find so quaint and charming , it is customary for them to treat their animals like this - not as fellow beings but as commodities to be disposed of like garbage when they no longer have commercial value.

Sherry Wolfe, Lebanon

Animal rights are OK, but when you try to anthropomorphize pets that takes it too far. While many people cite the horrors of dog fighting, people don't seem to realize that human politics can be very similar, and more important.

Politicians around the world do kill each other and torture other countries' peoples- and, ironically, may be invested in by both sides of a conflict. Our country is gambling all right, but not on dogs. The stakes are trillions of dollars this time, and instead of sending those kids to college on a fraction of that money, we sent them to die in ... you finish the sentence.

There are far too many places in the world where human beings are being treated as animals. God gave human beings an ability to reason far above any animal.

Do not let your love of animals become your ignorance of humans.

Chris Trachte, Reamstown

SEX OFFENDERS

This is in reference to the letter to the editor from Fay Hess Aug. 10, "Let Them Alone!" Fay, I think the letter is a disgrace to your womanhood in praising Tom Armstrong and suggesting help for these sex offenders.

These kinds of men are pariahs, not fit to live in our communities or society as a whole. If our courts and laws see fit to keep releasing them, our communities need to pull together and and try to get unfair laws changed. The alternative is to sit these pariahs in the middle of the desert, surrounded by high electric fencing.

Fay, I shiver to even think that one of your children or grandchildren would ever encounter one of these monsters who you seem to think can be redeemed.

Our town is far from perfect, but on the subject of what matters the most, the safety of our innocent children, our town is - praise be to God - right on target.

Lois Elder-Haas, Marietta

TEACHER HEALTH CARE

The lengthy article scrutinizing health care costs within school districts in Lancaster County [Aug. 17] was enlightening to be sure and, as districts are taxpayer-funded, perhaps relevant during such economic times.

But remarks such as those made by Susan Friedman, attorney for several districts, questioning the fairness of providing health care coverage for family members of teachers, are themselves quite unfair and somewhat inflammatory.

Ms. Friedman would have us pit one teacher against the next, predicated on who is married, has children or perhaps has a child in need of special care. What a selfish system that would be, and an insult to one of the core foundations of our society, the American family.

Of course, the true solution to this issue, all the other misery caused by the myriad health care systems this country has, and all the poor souls who go to bed each night worrying whether their illness will be cared for is a simple, complete, national health plan. One group that for the most part opposes such a plan is lawyers, who make a fine living keeping things confused and in court.

Franchot Egry, Ephrata

As a retired teacher from New Jersey, I take serious issue with the statistics quoted in the Aug. 17 article "Teachers assigned more health care costs." By comparing average teacher salaries with average salaries of local workers, the public is again fooled into "teacher-bashing."

Having applied to substitute-teach in Lancaster, I have undergone intense scrutiny of excellent credentials and teaching history. It brings to mind the quality of life one must lead to teach. How then can one compare the salaries paid to those who have lived lifestyles that hold up to such scrutiny to the overall working population, including the many who flip flapjacks, dig ditches and so forth?

Those who deal with our youth must have made frequent lifestyle choices and personal restrictions to qualify. How about comparing teacher wages and benefits with other professional careers?

Teachers have the right to seek the best wage and benefit packages for themselves, just as local taxpayers expect only the highest caliber of individual to be working with their youth.

It is unfair to expect public employees to sacrifice clean lifestyles and records just because it is decided to compare them with "average" workers!

Joan Galloway, Lancaster

SMALL GAMES OF CHANCE

Once a year, the Department of Pennsylvania American Legion holds "Legion college." State police and members of the Liquor Control Board conduct separate classes that day, and many questions are asked on small games of chance. Guess what never gets the same answer from both organizations? Seems to me it is about time for them to get together and get rules printed so all are on the same level.

I don't think the public realizes what the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars help to sponsor with the money generated from small games of chance. They help youth baseball teams, scout troops, school programs, fire companies, ambulance organizations, police departments and many more. With this crackdown on only paying out $5,000 in a seven-day period, organizations have to cut back on the amount they can contribute.

Wise up, Sen. Armstrong. You and others in Harrisburg have cut the budget for the above-mentioned groups, so bring the small games bill out for a vote so the American Legion and the VFW can increase their donations.

Earl B. Rettew, Landisville

OTHER SUBJECTS

At the last public meeting of the Lancaster County Office of Aging, it was announced that more than 300 people are on the waiting list for services.

Is it because there are not enough people to provide these services? No, it is because the funding has been exhausted.

Many of these are very simple issues, such as getting a meal or someone to help you with a bath, or maybe help pay for a Lifeline alert. These people are striving to maintain their independence and just need a little help.

We cannot always look for funding to be provided by federal and state programs. We must start to look locally. Local government, businesses and individuals can help by sending a check to the Lancaster County Office of Aging. I am sending my check today.

David A. Boas, Lancaster

This is in regards to the bike race through Farmersville Aug. 17. I guess it really is a race, seeing as how they did not yield to stop signs and passed buggies and cars that had to slow down due to bikers taking up the entire lane. Also, there was no respect for vehicles sitting at stop signs waiting for a chance to pull out.

I think I am safe in saying most of these bikers also drive cars. If you were treated this way, wouldn't that make you cross?

We all have places to go. So let's use the utmost respect for our fellow citizens on the road.

Mary Beth Zimmerman, Ephrata

Were you paying attention to the "debate" between Barack Obama and John McCain [Aug. 16]? In case you weren't listening, let me repeat:

Q: "At what point is a baby entitled to human rights?"

A: "At the moment of conception. I have a 25-year pro-life record in the Congress, in the Senate. And as president of the United States, I will be a pro-life president, and this presidency will have pro-life policies.

"That's my commitment to you."

No equivocation. No hesitation.

Allow me to translate:If you have an abortion, my presidency will be committed to seeking to charge you with murder of another human being.

No one likes abortion. No one I know is in favor of abortion as a policy. But what John McCain is saying, what the Republican position presents, is that at the moment of conception, no matter what the circumstances, you surrender all your rights to make a decision for yourself about your body.

It seems that there has been some misconception going around that John McCain respects the value of every human being.

Remember that in November.

Jeffrey Thal, Lancaster

Did you hear the joke about the nine Republicans and two Democrats who spent 18 months studying their county government and determined that its 200-plus-year-old form of government is outdated and needs upgrading?

The joke is that both parties appear to support their own political agenda rather than guiding Lancaster Countians to a more representative, responsive government.

It may be a joke, but it ain't funny! When will both parties realize that this charter is good for the people and support the results? Why would they selfishly maintain their good ol' boy politics to the detriment of the public?

There is nothing funny about ineffective government.

Bob Stanley, Elizabethtown


LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



321 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 24, 2008 Sunday


Man's Best Friends Ashamed Of Heritage Reasons To Mourn Fellow Beings Don't Forget People Children Are First National Plan Incorrect Comparison Raise The Limit Help The Aged Pedaling Disrespect Mccain Misconception An Unfunny Joke


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: P; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 2054 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA

It is bad enough they operated a puppy mill, but to take advantage of an obscure, outdated law that allows owners to destroy their animals is worse. They killed man's best friends in cold blood.

The archaic law allowing owners to destroy their own dogs and cats needs to be abolished. The laws presently are not tough enough to properly punish savages like the Zimmermans.

Gary Hornock, Elizabethtown

You can help by contacting your legislators (www.legis.state.pa.us) and urging them to pass House Bill 2525, which would make it illegal for anyone but a veterinarian to euthanize dogs in commercial breeding kennels and improve the conditions for thousands of dogs suffering behind the closed doors of Pennsylvania's infamous puppy mills.

Sylvia Evans, Lancaster

The "green" movement may promise better things, but people and animals have long suffered the effects of our exorbitant lifestyle. Many lives have been lost so that we could be the powerful consumers we are.

Let us remember the atrocities committed to protect our national interest - in Nagasaki and Hiroshima, in Cambodia, Chile, El Salvador and Guatemala. Yet we continue to tolerate half-thought-out, illegal regime changes (Iraq) and support for sleazy governments in which our political and business leaders have friends (Saudi Arabia).

Other developed nations can learn from our dead dogs, too. In one town in Chile, a huge trading partner of the U.S. whose grapes flood our supermarkets, stray dogs are rounded up once a year and disposed of quietly. Witnessing this, I thought, should we invade?

Robert McLane IV, Millersville

For Pennsylvania to put up with the horror of puppy mills for so many years is a sad statement about our state government, lawmakers, and those who elected them. Is this how we teach our youth the value of life ?

This case is so disturbing I have lost sleep, wondering how exactly do you shoot 80 dogs? How many shots did it take to kill each of them ? I am sure the breeders' association is going to have to put some serious spin on this story. I hope their lobbyist is up to the task.

What now for the Zimmermans?

Perhaps a nice roadside stand selling produce, using their discarded product as fertilizer.

Please contact your state representatives and urge them to pass House Bill 2525, which seeks to improve life for dogs living in the state's commercial breeding kennels.

As for the Amish farmers whom tourists find so quaint and charming , it is customary for them to treat their animals like this - not as fellow beings but as commodities to be disposed of like garbage when they no longer have commercial value.

Sherry Wolfe, Lebanon

Animal rights are OK, but when you try to anthropomorphize pets that takes it too far. While many people cite the horrors of dog fighting, people don't seem to realize that human politics can be very similar, and more important.

Politicians around the world do kill each other and torture other countries' peoples- and, ironically, may be invested in by both sides of a conflict. Our country is gambling all right, but not on dogs. The stakes are trillions of dollars this time, and instead of sending those kids to college on a fraction of that money, we sent them to die in ... you finish the sentence.

There are far too many places in the world where human beings are being treated as animals. God gave human beings an ability to reason far above any animal.

Do not let your love of animals become your ignorance of humans.

Chris Trachte, Reamstown

SEX OFFENDERS

This is in reference to the letter to the editor from Fay Hess Aug. 10, "Let Them Alone!" Fay, I think the letter is a disgrace to your womanhood in praising Tom Armstrong and suggesting help for these sex offenders.

These kinds of men are pariahs, not fit to live in our communities or society as a whole. If our courts and laws see fit to keep releasing them, our communities need to pull together and and try to get unfair laws changed. The alternative is to sit these pariahs in the middle of the desert, surrounded by high electric fencing.

Fay, I shiver to even think that one of your children or grandchildren would ever encounter one of these monsters who you seem to think can be redeemed.

Our town is far from perfect, but on the subject of what matters the most, the safety of our innocent children, our town is - praise be to God - right on target.

Lois Elder-Haas, Marietta

TEACHER HEALTH CARE

The lengthy article scrutinizing health care costs within school districts in Lancaster County [Aug. 17] was enlightening to be sure and, as districts are taxpayer-funded, perhaps relevant during such economic times.

But remarks such as those made by Susan Friedman, attorney for several districts, questioning the fairness of providing health care coverage for family members of teachers, are themselves quite unfair and somewhat inflammatory.

Ms. Friedman would have us pit one teacher against the next, predicated on who is married, has children or perhaps has a child in need of special care. What a selfish system that would be, and an insult to one of the core foundations of our society, the American family.

Of course, the true solution to this issue, all the other misery caused by the myriad health care systems this country has, and all the poor souls who go to bed each night worrying whether their illness will be cared for is a simple, complete, national health plan. One group that for the most part opposes such a plan is lawyers, who make a fine living keeping things confused and in court.

Franchot Egry, Ephrata

As a retired teacher from New Jersey, I take serious issue with the statistics quoted in the Aug. 17 article "Teachers assigned more health care costs." By comparing average teacher salaries with average salaries of local workers, the public is again fooled into "teacher-bashing."

Having applied to substitute-teach in Lancaster, I have undergone intense scrutiny of excellent credentials and teaching history. It brings to mind the quality of life one must lead to teach. How then can one compare the salaries paid to those who have lived lifestyles that hold up to such scrutiny to the overall working population, including the many who flip flapjacks, dig ditches and so forth?

Those who deal with our youth must have made frequent lifestyle choices and personal restrictions to qualify. How about comparing teacher wages and benefits with other professional careers?

Teachers have the right to seek the best wage and benefit packages for themselves, just as local taxpayers expect only the highest caliber of individual to be working with their youth.

It is unfair to expect public employees to sacrifice clean lifestyles and records just because it is decided to compare them with "average" workers!

Joan Galloway, Lancaster

SMALL GAMES OF CHANCE

Once a year, the Department of Pennsylvania American Legion holds "Legion college." State police and members of the Liquor Control Board conduct separate classes that day, and many questions are asked on small games of chance. Guess what never gets the same answer from both organizations? Seems to me it is about time for them to get together and get rules printed so all are on the same level.

I don't think the public realizes what the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars help to sponsor with the money generated from small games of chance. They help youth baseball teams, scout troops, school programs, fire companies, ambulance organizations, police departments and many more. With this crackdown on only paying out $5,000 in a seven-day period, organizations have to cut back on the amount they can contribute.

Wise up, Sen. Armstrong. You and others in Harrisburg have cut the budget for the above-mentioned groups, so bring the small games bill out for a vote so the American Legion and the VFW can increase their donations.

Earl B. Rettew, Landisville

OTHER SUBJECTS

At the last public meeting of the Lancaster County Office of Aging, it was announced that more than 300 people are on the waiting list for services.

Is it because there are not enough people to provide these services? No, it is because the funding has been exhausted.

Many of these are very simple issues, such as getting a meal or someone to help you with a bath, or maybe help pay for a Lifeline alert. These people are striving to maintain their independence and just need a little help.

We cannot always look for funding to be provided by federal and state programs. We must start to look locally. Local government, businesses and individuals can help by sending a check to the Lancaster County Office of Aging. I am sending my check today.

David A. Boas, Lancaster

This is in regards to the bike race through Farmersville Aug. 17. I guess it really is a race, seeing as how they did not yield to stop signs and passed buggies and cars that had to slow down due to bikers taking up the entire lane. Also, there was no respect for vehicles sitting at stop signs waiting for a chance to pull out.

I think I am safe in saying most of these bikers also drive cars. If you were treated this way, wouldn't that make you cross?

We all have places to go. So let's use the utmost respect for our fellow citizens on the road.

Mary Beth Zimmerman, Ephrata

Were you paying attention to the "debate" between Barack Obama and John McCain [Aug. 16]? In case you weren't listening, let me repeat:

Q: "At what point is a baby entitled to human rights?"

A: "At the moment of conception. I have a 25-year pro-life record in the Congress, in the Senate. And as president of the United States, I will be a pro-life president, and this presidency will have pro-life policies.

"That's my commitment to you."

No equivocation. No hesitation.

Allow me to translate:If you have an abortion, my presidency will be committed to seeking to charge you with murder of another human being.

No one likes abortion. No one I know is in favor of abortion as a policy. But what John McCain is saying, what the Republican position presents, is that at the moment of conception, no matter what the circumstances, you surrender all your rights to make a decision for yourself about your body.

It seems that there has been some misconception going around that John McCain respects the value of every human being.

Remember that in November.

Jeffrey Thal, Lancaster

Did you hear the joke about the nine Republicans and two Democrats who spent 18 months studying their county government and determined that its 200-plus-year-old form of government is outdated and needs upgrading?

The joke is that both parties appear to support their own political agenda rather than guiding Lancaster Countians to a more representative, responsive government.

It may be a joke, but it ain't funny! When will both parties realize that this charter is good for the people and support the results? Why would they selfishly maintain their good ol' boy politics to the detriment of the public?

There is nothing funny about ineffective government.

Bob Stanley, Elizabethtown

322 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)


August 23, 2008 Saturday


McCain positive his campaign's not negative


BYLINE: By MIKE ARGENTO Lebanon Daily News


SECTION: COLUMNISTS


LENGTH: 791 words


Back in 2000, you might recall, John McCain was running for president against the guy who would eventually become the nation's court-appointed president, and he was the victim of some of the sleaziest politics the world has ever seen.

The campaign of our then soon-to-be-court-appointed president implied that McCain had fathered a black child out of wedlock. It ran what are called push polls, polls which pollsters use to spread rumors. In McCain's case, pollsters were calling Republican voters and asking them, something like, "Would your opinion of John McCain be favorable or unfavorable if you knew he had fathered an illegitimate black child?"

Of course, there was absolutely no truth to it. But McCain had been accompanied on some campaign stops by his wife and their adopted child from Bangladesh, who has dark skin.

It was the brilliant handiwork of our court-appointed president's right-hand man and evil poisoned toad, Karl Rove, who knew that white Republicans in South Carolina didn't cotton to miscegenation and were easily duped into, well, just about anything. Rove has made a career, and millions, by never underestimating the stupidity of the American electorate.

It was reprehensible and accompanied other attacks that implied that McCain was mentally unstable, that his wife was a drug addict, that he was gay, that he had been brainwashed by his Vietnamese captors and was some sort of Manchurian Candidate sent here by the Commies to bring down the United States from within.

McCain lost the nomination, starting in South Carolina.

So as he embarked on his current trivial pursuit of the presidency, with that history, McCain pledged to run an above-board campaign, one that gives voters a reason to elect him, not one aimed at scaring the bejesus out of gullible voters with misinformation, innuendoes and lies about his opponent.

"I have pledged to conduct a respectful campaign," he said. "And I have urged, time after time, various entities within the Republican Party to also do that."

He uttered those words on April 1.

April Fools!

So it should come as no surprise that the McCain campaign has sunk to its current level, essentially accusing Democrat Barack Obama of treason, among other specious charges.

McCain's ads airing here now are full of misrepresentations, innuendoes and flat-out lies. Factcheck.org, a nonpartisan group that monitors the factual accuracy in political ads, lists numerous occasions where McCain ads have lied about Obama's record and proposals.

McCain's ads consistently have contained lies about Obama's tax proposals, including the claim that Obama will raise taxes on the middle class, which is true if you define the middle class as families with annual income above $250,000.

Another ad claimed that Obama declined to meet with wounded troops unless TV cameras could go along. Actually, the visit in question was canceled by the military, and Obama never made the demand that TV cameras had to accompany him. That ad also claimed Obama had time to go to the gym but not to meet with our troops. The ad also featured a shot of Obama playing basketball -- with our troops.

There are loads of other examples.

But the worst accusation wasn't made in an ad. It came from McCain and his lap-dog, former Democratic Sen. Joe Lieberman. McCain has said repeatedly that Obama would rather win the campaign and lose the war than lose the campaign and win the war -- essentially accusing Obama of treason. The other day, at the Toyota Center, Lieberman said the choice in this election is "between one candidate, John McCain, who's always put the country first, worked across party lines to get things done, and one candidate who has not."

On the other hand, McCain might not think he's conducting a negative campaign.

Recently, after the ad comparing Obama to Paris Hilton and Britney Spears aired, after the ad accusing Obama of being un-American aired, after he had repeatedly questioned Obama's patriotism, McCain said, "This is a very respectful campaign. I've repeated my admiration and respect for Sen. Obama. I don't think our campaign is negative in the slightest."

Really?

I guess he's expressed his admiration and respect by hinting that Obama's in league with terrorists and enemies of America.

Then again, McCain might not know what's going on. A couple of weeks ago, McCain appeared on "Meet The Press" and said that increasing taxes to save Social Security wasn't out of the question. Previously, he had pledged that he wouldn't raise any taxes, no matter what.

That reversal prompted a McCain campaign official to tell reporters that McCain doesn't speak for the McCain campaign.

Finally, someone spoke the truth.

------------

Argento writes for the York Daily Record. He can be reached at:

mike@ydr.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
