LOAD-DATE: August 13, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



340 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 13, 2008 Wednesday
CITY-D Edition


McCain says Georgia shows why he's needed


BYLINE: By Thomas Fitzgerald; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: NATIONAL; P-com News; Pg. A01


LENGTH: 804 words


YORK, Pa. - Using the Russian attacks on Georgia as Exhibit A, Republican presidential candidate John McCain yesterday portrayed himself as better prepared to protect the national security in a dangerous world.

"Today, we are all Georgians," McCain told several thousand people at the York Fairgrounds, recounting what he had said in a telephone conversation earlier in the day with the country's president, Mikheil Saakashvili, whom he has befriended during several visits.

"We live in a dangerous world. We never know what's around the corner," McCain said in a veiled rebuke of his vacationing rival, first-term Democratic Sen. Barack Obama.

McCain, an Arizona senator since 1987, said Americans should care about the conflict not only because Georgia is a close U.S. ally but also because it is at a "strategic crossroads" for oil pipelines from the Caspian Sea region to Western markets. He said Russia had "ambitions" to threaten countries that are, like Georgia, U.S. allies.

As he had the day before, McCain urged that vigorous diplomacy be used to halt Russia's actions.

It was a return to a familiar GOP theme - national security - for McCain as he campaigned in York and Lancaster, the heart of the Republican base in Pennsylvania. On the second of a two-day visit, McCain was accompanied again by former Gov. Tom Ridge, the nation's first secretary of homeland security.

Also with them was Sen. Joseph Lieberman (I., Conn.), who was blunter, launching a harsh attack on Obama, though he did not use the Illinois senator's name.

"In my opinion, the choice could not be more clear: between one candidate, John McCain, who's had experience, been tested in war and tried in peace, and another candidate who has not," said Lieberman, the Democratic nominee for vice president in 2000, who introduced the soon-to-be GOP nominee.

The choice, Lieberman continued, is "between one candidate, John McCain, who has always put the country first, worked across party lines to get things done, and one candidate who has not. Between one candidate who's a talker, and the other candidate who's the leader America needs."

Lieberman's remarks came on the same day that Obama's campaign announced a group of prominent Republicans who have endorsed him, led by former Rep. Jim Leach of Iowa.

In a statement, Obama's campaign said McCain's claim to bipartisan leadership was a sham, saying McCain had voted with President Bush 95 percent of the time. The campaign yesterday also launched a Pennsylvania radio ad that accuses McCain of not doing enough to prevent manufacturing jobs from going overseas, and that refers to Harley-Davidson motorcycles, which are made in York.

The ad quotes McCain's comments at a South Dakota biker rally this month: "Not long ago a couple hundred thousand Berliners made a lot of noise for my opponent. I will take the roar of 50,000 Harleys any day." Not "when it comes to his record," an announcer intones. As motorcycles rev up, the ad concludes, "It's time to hear the roar of a strong American economy again."

As the event at the fairgrounds began, a large garage door in the York Expo Center clattered open and McCain's campaign bus rolled up to the stage as that iconic Pennsylvania political song, the theme from Rocky, played at eardrum-bursting volume.

Later, McCain said he relished being behind in the race with Obama, and he vowed to visit as many Pennsylvania hamlets as possible - reminding voters, of course, that Obama once said the state's small-town residents "cling" to guns and religion because they are bitter at their economic plight.

"I'm going to tell them I think they are the heartland of America, that the values they hold dear are the strength and character of America," McCain said. "They're the reason why the people in Georgia today are looking to America . . . a beacon of hope and liberty."

He added: "I think we're going to be up late on election night."

In response to a questioner who worried whether he was conservative enough, McCain stressed his desire to nominate Supreme Court justices who interpret the Constitution strictly.

"There's going to be two, maybe three vacancies on the Supreme Court, according to people that decide these things," McCain said, correcting himself by adding: "People that pay close attention."

When McCain campaigned Monday in Erie, he teased Ridge, who has been mentioned as a potential running mate. The two men are close. Yesterday, however, McCain did not allude to that possibility but praised Ridge for his work as the first chief of the nation's Homeland Security Department.

"It's not an accident that there has not been another attack on the United States of America," McCain said. "For that, we owe a debt of gratitude to Tom Ridge."

Contact staff writer Thomas Fitzgerald at 215-854-2718 or tfitzgerald@phillynews.com.


LOAD-DATE: August 13, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

All Rights Reserved



341 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 13, 2008 Wednesday


McCain reassures GOP voters


BYLINE: David M. Brown and Salena Zito


LENGTH: 674 words


YORK -- Conservative voters' anxiety over John McCain was made plain here Tuesday, when the presumptive Republican presidential nominee was accused of forsaking traditional GOP principles.

"We conservatives believe that you dismissed our serious quest for responsible, limited government," said a woman at the town hall-style meeting at the York Expo Center.

"As a senator, I understand that you have had to adopt a compromising stance with the Democrats to get legislation passed," she said. "But in your quest for the presidency, we want to know if it is in you to become a passionate and forceful leader with a conservative agenda to fight the lure of socialistic programs promoted by Senator (Barack) Obama?"

McCain's one-word response -- "Yes" -- brought a roar of applause from a crowd estimated at nearly 3,000.

The event capped McCain's two-day swing across Pennsylvania with Tom Ridge, the former two-term governor and secretary of Homeland Security, at his side. Another staunch McCain supporter, Sen. Joe Lieberman, I-Conn., introduced McCain as a leader who always put "America first" ahead of partisan ties.

"I am supporting John McCain because he's ready to lead America," said Lieberman, an independent who caucuses with the Democrats.

Republican Sen. Arlen Specter told the crowd that "we have a very high calling" in the state.

"This election may very well be decided by Pennsylvania," Specter said. He added that he believes McCain's reputation as an independent could win over Keystone State voters.

The Obama campaign, seeking to undercut McCain's support in the traditionally conservative central part of the state, released a 60-second radio spot accusing McCain of backing policies that hurt American workers.

With a Harley-Davidson motorcycle engine roaring in the background, the ad says McCain called a law that would have required the U.S. government to buy American-made motorcycles "disgraceful." The York Harley-Davidson factory recently cut 300 jobs, according to the campaign.

McCain, of Arizona, appeared at the Sturgis motorcycle rally in South Dakota last week.

"John McCain should be ashamed of himself, not just for voting against protecting an American company like Harley-Davidson, but then for going in front of a group of motorcyclists in Sturgis and pretending to be one of them," Lancaster Mayor Rick Gray, a Democrat, motorcycle owner and Obama supporter, said in a statement announcing the ad. 

Specter accused the four collar counties surrounding Philadelphia of not pulling their weight in recent elections, in which many voters in the traditionally Republican areas have crossed party lines to vote for Democrats. Voters there have "been derelict in not polling" for Republicans, Specter said.

"John McCain has the ability to carry the Southeast," Specter said. "Combine that with the steadfastness of the 'T' (the traditionally conservative region encompassing central, northeast and northwest Pennsylvania), and he will be the next president of the United States."

A poll released today shows McCain and Obama tied in Central Pennsylvania, which could hurt McCain's chances in November.

Lieberman said McCain can win over those voters.

"If McCain is himself, then he will earn people's respect, which leads to their support and their vote," Lieberman said. "They will know they can count on him."

Daniel D. Graham, a laid-off factory worker from Harrisburg, was among a crowd of onlookers waiting outside the Harrisburg Hilton yesterday morning for a glimpse of McCain boarding the Straight Talk Express, his big blue campaign bus.

Graham, a Democrat who supported Hillary Clinton in the primary, said he plans to vote for McCain.

"I was hoping and praying to God that Hillary would not only win the Pennsylvania primary but also the nomination," Graham said. "McCain is honest and he seems like a good Christian man. He has good character and courage to do what's right.

"I don't like Obama's arrogant attitude. Obama doesn't have the experience in government and qualifications that we need."

342 of 461 DOCUMENTS



York Daily Record (Pennsylvania)


Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News


August 13, 2008 Wednesday


Obama launches Harley ad: Radio spot in York market targets McCain's stance on trade.


BYLINE: Brent Burkey, York Daily Record, Pa.


SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS


LENGTH: 401 words


Aug. 13--Saying its candidate's plan would protect American jobs like those inside York County's Harley-Davidson plant, the presidential campaign of Sen. Barack Obama launched a radio ad Tuesday attacking Sen. John McCain's stance on the issue.

The ad came the day McCain visited York County for a town hall-style discussion at the York Expo Center's Toyota Arena.

According to a script released by the Obama campaign, the ad begins with McCain speaking at a South Dakota motorcycle rally.

McCain says he would take the roar of Harleys over the roar Obama received from a German crowd while touring overseas.

The rest of the ad rebukes McCain for not supporting a requirement to mandate the American government buy American-made motorcycles, saying McCain called the idea "disgraceful."

It also says McCain supports tax breaks resulting in jobs going overseas, with motorcycles rumbling in the background.

The ad itself does not specifically mention Harley's actions this year to cut about 300 union workers in Springettsbury Township from its payroll, but a news release about the radio ad does.

Harley-Davidson has said it has no plans to outsource American workers. At most, it would consider operating facilities near overseas markets it wants to expand business into, the company has said.

McCain declined comment Tuesday about the radio ad, saying his campaign would respond.

Paul Lindsay, spokesman for McCain in Pennsylvania and Ohio, issued a statement late in the day

that said McCain voted against the "Buy America" restriction because he does not believe in protectionist tariffs.

Also, because it would have cost the American taxpayer $5 billion per year, he said.

Lindsay also took his own swing at an Obama policy that could affect "hard-working Americans," citing Obama's vote for next year's budget that would have included a tax hike for Americans making about $42,000 or more per year.

Obama has said in past weeks his budget resolution votes were not tax-hike votes.

bburkey@ydr.com; 771-2035

To see more of the York Daily Record, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to http://www.ydr.com. Copyright (c) 2008, York Daily Record, Pa. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

343 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Mccain Will Be In County Today


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 499 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Republican presidential hopeful John McCain likely will stop in Lancaster County today after a town-hall event in York County, an anonymous Republican official said Monday.

However, just where and when McCain will make the stop remains unknown. And a number of local Republican leaders say they're in the dark, too.

"I know it was something they were looking to do, but when and where they're going to do it, they haven't told me," said Dave Dumeyer, chairman of the Lancaster County Republican Committee.

McCain spokesman Paul Lindsay would only confirm the town-hall meeting scheduled for 11:45 a.m. today at the Toyota Center at the York Fairgrounds. McCain is on a two-day tour of Pennsylvania with former Gov. Tom Ridge.

After speaking in York and making any stops in Lancaster, McCain will depart from Lancaster Airport in Manheim Township, according to Frank Orban III, McCain's co-chair in Lancaster.

Meanwhile, acting on a hunch that McCain will make a Lancaster appearance, members of Lancaster Coalition for Peace and Justice and Lancaster Students for a Democratic Society plan to protest in Penn Square today at 3:30 p.m.

Local Democrats gathered Monday morning with state Democratic Party spokesman Abe Amoros to unveil a new Web ad by the Democratic National Committee aimed at countering McCain's tour of Pennsylvania.

The ad features 40 seconds of ominous piano and string music while twice playing a clip of McCain in a New Orleans town-hall meeting last April in which he said, "I'm not going to keep (all jobs) in America." He was responding to a question from an audience member about how he would retain American jobs and make the country "more self-sufficient."

The ad also features text messages slamming McCain and his campaign adviser, Rick Davis, whose firm once lobbied Congress on behalf of DHL Express, a global packaging company looking to buy Airborne Express and move 8,000 jobs out of southeastern Ohio.

"I think it's a little scary myself, but it's an effective ad," Amoros said.

Blair Latoff, spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said McCain was being blunt with voters in the video and suggested Democrats were just playing politics.

"The DNC and Barack Obama are more intent on politicizing job losses than they are seeking solutions to improve our challenging economic times," Latoff said. "Maybe Barack Obama should take John McCain's lead and meet with the hardworking individuals who risk losing their jobs."

Also Monday, Gov. Ed Rendell, in a conference call with the media set up by the Obama campaign, targeted McCain's record in the Senate, specifically mentioning votes the Arizona senator made to give American companies tax breaks for creating jobs abroad, to provide government subsidies to laid-off workers who lost jobs due to trade agreements and to give oil companies billions of dollars in tax breaks.

"He would do nothing to shorten the gap between America's poorest, more challenged citizens and America's richest citizens," Rendell said.


LOAD-DATE: August 13, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Republican Presidential Candidate, Sen. John Mccain, Center, And Former Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Ridge, Left, Shop At The Bass Pro Shops Outdoor World Monday In Harrisburg. Associated Press


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Mccain Will Be In County Today


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: A; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 499 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Republican presidential hopeful John McCain likely will stop in Lancaster County today after a town-hall event in York County, an anonymous Republican official said Monday.

However, just where and when McCain will make the stop remains unknown. And a number of local Republican leaders say they're in the dark, too.

"I know it was something they were looking to do, but when and where they're going to do it, they haven't told me," said Dave Dumeyer, chairman of the Lancaster County Republican Committee.

Also Monday, Gov. Ed Rendell, in a conference call with the media set up by the Obama campaign, targeted McCain's record in the Senate, specifically mentioning votes the Arizona senator made to give American companies tax breaks for creating jobs abroad, to provide government subsidies to laid-off workers who lost jobs due to trade agreements and to give oil companies billions of dollars in tax breaks.

"He would do nothing to shorten the gap between America's poorest, more challenged citizens and America's richest citizens," Rendell said.

345 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Playing Politics With Energy Future


BYLINE: Editorial


SECTION: A; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 558 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


A Barack Obama TV ad attacks John McCain over his staunch support for storing nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada.

"Barack Obama opposes opening Yucca. He'll protect families," the announcer says ruefully.

But what the ad does not say is that Obama twice voted to fund the proposed repository for spent nuclear fuel and nuclear waste.

The ad also tries to give the impression that McCain is misleading the people of his home state of Arizona, citing a short clip of a TV interview in which McCain seemed to be saying that he would oppose the hauling of nuclear waste through Arizona on its way to Yucca.

But the ad does not include McCain's full comments.

McCain told the Associated Press he believes the transport of nuclear waste could be made safe, and that the current storage situation is dangerous.

"What people forget is the option of leaving this waste in areas outside - maybe unprotected, certainly not well protected - all over America, rather than having a safe and secure repository for it," McCain said. "I preferred not having the status quo. And, I think it is a national security issue."

Obama tries to explain away his voting record on the matter, saying the Yucca funding was part of a comprehensive energy bill which he supported because of its "historic" investment in alternative-energy sources.

In other words, Obama opposes Yucca - sorta.

Obama says he opposes Yucca, but he allows funding for the project to go through - the contradiction is not lost on Nevadans, who oppose the facility by a large margin.

McCain, on the other hand, has been consistent. Some may disagree with him, but they at least can respect his view.

Obama's attack on McCain is calculated to hurt the presumptive GOP nominee in Nevada, a crucial Western state this presidential-election year.

Yet, it also gives political cover for Democrat Obama, who has expressed little interest in Western issues, such as federal ownership of land, water, growth and Native American concerns.

Obama's view, therefore, seems to be more of a political calculation than conviction.

Actually, Obama's view on the entire subject of nuclear energy issue is suspect.

While both candidates include nuclear power in their energy programs, Obama says only that existing nuclear plants must play a role in the country's energy future.

As for new reactor construction, Obama says, "... only so far as it is clean and safe."

How's that for going out on a limb? What candidate for president supports dirty and unsafe nuclear power?

McCain, meanwhile, calls for building 45 nuclear power plants by 2030, saying the technology is safer and cleaner than it has been in the past.

And he supports research into nuclear-waste reprocessing (which could render Yucca unnecessary or have it play a lesser role). Finding a long-term solution for nuclear waste is sure to be one of the challenges facing the next president.

The issue resonates with Lancastrians, because of the proximity - and history - of the Three Mile Island nuclear facility.

Also, Pennsylvania is one of the largest producers of low-level radioactive waste (largely from nuclear medicines).

Short of a nuclear weapon, there is nothing more dangerous to the well-being of the planet than spent nuclear fuel temporarily stored alongside power plants. John McCain has a plan to store this material permanently. Barack Obama has no plan.


LOAD-DATE: August 13, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



346 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Lancaster New Era (Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Playing Politics With Energy Future


BYLINE: Editorial


SECTION: A; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 558 words

Obama's view, therefore, seems to be more of a political calculation than conviction.

As for new reactor construction, Obama says, "... only so far as it is clean and safe."

How's that for going out on a limb? What candidate for president supports dirty and unsafe nuclear power?

McCain, meanwhile, calls for building 45 nuclear power plants by 2030, saying the technology is safer and cleaner than it has been in the past.

And he supports research into nuclear-waste reprocessing (which could render Yucca unnecessary or have it play a lesser role). Finding a long-term solution for nuclear waste is sure to be one of the challenges facing the next president.

The issue resonates with Lancastrians, because of the proximity - and history - of the Three Mile Island nuclear facility.

Also, Pennsylvania is one of the largest producers of low-level radioactive waste (largely from nuclear medicines).

Short of a nuclear weapon, there is nothing more dangerous to the well-being of the planet than spent nuclear fuel temporarily stored alongside power plants. John McCain has a plan to store this material permanently. Barack Obama has no plan.

347 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Tribune Review


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Specter, Lieberman stump for McCain


BYLINE: Salena Zito


LENGTH: 335 words


Republican Arlen Specter and Democrat Joe Lieberman made a surprise visit to the York Expo Center to campaign for fellow Sen. John McCain, who today wraps up his two-day Pennsylvania campaign swing.

Greeted warmly by the crowd of about 3,000 McCain supporters, Specter told the crowd that "we have a very high calling" in the state.

"This election may very well be decided by Pennsylvania," Specter said. He added that he believes McCain's reputation as an independent could win over Keystone State voters.

The campaign of Illinois Sen. Barack Obama, seeking to undercut McCain's support in the traditionally conservative central part of the state, released a 60-second radio spot accusing McCain of backing policies that hurt American workers. With a Harley-Davidson motorcycle engine roaring in the background, the ad says McCain called a law that would have required the U.S. government to buy American-made motorcycles "disgraceful." The York Harley-Davidson factory recently cut 300 jobs, according to the campaign.

McCain, of Arizona, appeared at the Sturgis motorcycle rally in South Dakota last week.

"John McCain should be ashamed of himself, not just for voting against protecting an American company like Harley-Davidson, but then for going in front of a group of motorcyclists in Sturgis and pretending to be one of them," Lancaster Mayor Rick Gray, a motorcycle owner and Obama supporter, said in a statement announcing the ad. 

Specter accused the four collar counties surrounding Philadelphia of not pulling their weight in recent elections, where many voters in the traditionally Republican areas have crossed party lines to vote for Democrats. Voters there have "been derelict in not polling" for Republicans, Specter said.

"John McCain has the ability to carry the Southeast," Specter said. "Combine that with the steadfastness of the 'T' (the traditionally conservative region encompassing central, northeast and northwest Pennsylvania), and he will be the next president of the United States."


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Tribune Review Publishing Company
All Rights Reserved



348 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Q&A with John McCain


BYLINE: CARL LINDQUIST -- The York Dispatch


SECTION: POLITICS; Local


LENGTH: 847 words


U.S. Sen. John McCain met with a small group of reporters, including one from The York Dispatch, after his town hall meeting in York on Tuesday.

Sitting around a table at the back of his blue "Straight Talk Express" bus on his way to Lancaster, McCain outlined his position on topics including the conflict in Georgia, energy and his campaign strategy in Pennsylvania. Joining McCain were U.S. Rep. Todd Platts, R-York County, and Sen. Joe Lieberman, I-Conn.

Here's a transcript of some questions posed to McCain, and his answers.

Some parts have been edited for clarity and length.

Q: Do you think the president is handling the situation well in Georgia?

A: "I think we'll be able to get a better retrospective view of how the situation evolved in the weeks ahead. Everything I've heard so far is that Russians had planned this massive response for a long time. Whether they chose the Beijing Olympics to be the timing for it, I have no idea.

"I have a military background and I don't think you can orchestrate that kid of offensive over a short period of time.

Q: McCain was asked to address the importance of Pennsylvania in his election campaign and how he plans to win considering there are more registered Democrats than Republican, third-party and non-affiliated voters combined in Pennsylvania.

A: "That would be true nationally. According to recent polls, we are a couple of points behind so obviously we have already made inroads in that direction.I really hate to be repetitive and boring, but I say again, we've got a lot of work to do. We are underdogs. I am the underdog. We have a lot of work to do. I don't underestimate the challenge."

Q: How does this trip fit into your campaign strategy in Pennsylvania?

A: I think our campaign strategy is to really do two things: Have town hall meetings and be on the bus. People want to see you, they want to hear from you, they want their questions answered. Suppose maybe I answered 20 questions today, just to take that number off my head. People feel like they've been part of the process. A woman asked about health care. That was on the minds of 500 or 600 of the people there. They got their question answered, responded to. Maybe not answered. At least they got responded to.

Q: How can you maintain support from conservatives while also highlighting your ability to work in a bipartisan manner?

A: I think I've been able to do both, number one. Number two is that the frustration level that Americans feel whether they are conservatives, or moderates or liberals about our failure to act in their interests is overwhelming.

That's why I was talking about the 9 percent approval rating of Congress. They (voters) want us to get things done and they want to do it in view of issues that they don't particularly feel is partisan in nature.

They want us to fix Social Security, like that young man who stood up. What's partisan about fixing social security? What's conservative or liberal? You've got a system that is going broke!

I have to show them (voters) that I have a concrete plan of action for our economy, for housing, for all of these challenges we face.

Q: What are you hearing, what are you learning in Pennsylvania that is unique? Is there anything?

A: No, except that the heartland -- Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan other states -- that experienced great loss in manufacturing jobs. They were hurting before the housing crisis and so their challenges are even greater than some other parts of the country.

I've got a big job to show them I have a concrete plan of action to fix our economy.

Q: Your support of offshore drilling has won support. But what happens to that strength in your campaign if the price of gas drops to, say, $3 per gallon?

A: Three dollars a gallon is incredibly high. Americans because of $4 a gallon...are becoming more and more (aware of) the fragility of the whole supply and demand. They've figured it out.

And I don't know of any expert, maybe there is one, but I have not heard of one or talked to one, who doesn't believe that the price of a barrel of oil will eventually increase over time because you have got two economies, India and China, drawing on a finite resource and that argues for long-term oil independence.

I hope some of us who are old enough to remember, don't want to repeat the mistakes of the '70s.

Q: What's your response to the recently released Obama campaign ad criticizing McCain for not supporting policies that require the U.S. government to buy American?

A: I will have to have my campaign respond. We don't really respond to their campaign ads. We just have other things to do.

Q: You've said a lot of nice things today about former Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Ridge. How much do you think he would help you out in Pennsylvania?

A: I think Tom Ridge is a national figure. As head of Homeland Security, he became well known to a lot of Americans. I think he would be a valuable contribution to any administration that I would be a part of.

(McCain said the process to choose a vice president was ongoing and declined to discuss the viability of particular individuals as his running mate.)


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



349 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Anti-Obama ad misleading on tax plans for family


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 705 words


Anew McCain campaign ad shows pictures of wind-driven turbines while the narrator says: "Renewable energy to transform our economy, create jobs and energy independence, that's John McCain."

But, in fact, his energy plan doesn't specify any new federal spending for renewable energy and says only that he'd "rationalize" existing tax credits to provide incentives.

In the past, however, the Arizona Republican senator and Republican nominee-presumptive has opposed extending such tax credits when paid for by tax increases elsewhere.

The ad also insinuates that Illinois Sen. Barack Obama , his Democratic counterpart, would bring "higher taxes" for "your family," another in what has become a pattern of misrepresentations of Obama's tax plan.

Obama actually proposes to cut taxes for all but the most affluent families. He wants to restore tax rates to pre-Bush levels only for those making over $250,000 a year.

McCain's campaign released its latest spot Aug. 6, criticizing Barack Obama for his stance on the Bush tax cuts and highlighting McCain's plans for "renewable energy." The ad is running in "key states," including Pennsylvania.

His ads, including this one, have featured images of wind turbines, which, like solar, hydropower or biomass projects, tap energy sources that will never run out.

But McCain's energy plan and statements about such renewables are vague and left to interpretation. He's offered more specifics, and federal dollars, for nuclear power and "clean coal" technologies.

A McCain press release says that to develop these and other sources of renewable energy will require that we rationalize the current patchwork of temporary tax credits that provide commercial feasibility.

We're not sure what "rationalize the current patchwork of temporary tax credits" means. And neither are wind or solar industry spokespeople.

Frank Maisano, a spokesman for energy companies including utilities and wind, told us when we read that line from McCain's plan. "It means that they don't want to tell people what that means."

We asked the McCain campaign for clarification and whether the candidate had proposed any new federal spending for renewable energy (none is included in his plan).

The McCain camp replied that the candidate has committed to a generous and reformed R&D tax credit to spur innovation across industries, including the energy sector.

That sounds like McCain supports long-term tax credits, something renewable energy advocates would welcome, though it's not something he has supported in the past -- even the very recent past.

The federal investment tax credit, which provides incentives to businesses and individuals to invest in renewable energy, is set to expire at the end of the year.

Renewable energy groups have lobbied for passage of Senate measures that would have extended the credit for eight years, but the legislation has been blocked eight times by Republicans who object to other tax increases that would cover the cost of the credits. McCain, and Obama, missed the most recent vote on such legislation.

McCain's statements on "rationaliz[ing] the current patchwork" and establishing "a regime of federal support that will remain predictable" don't offer enough detail for renewable energy advocates to say what his proposals would accomplish.

Sara Birmingham, director of western U.S. policy at the Solar Alliance, a state-based advocacy group of solar industry companies, told us: "We absolutely like longer predictability," but she couldn't really say how the group felt about McCain's proposal "until we actually see what he has in mind."

Monique Hanis, director of communications for the Solar Energy Industries Association, said: "He really needs to fill in with specifics like what energy sources should be stimulated, what are his goals, what mix would he want to see by what timeframe."

And while the McCain camp didn't mention this in its back-up material for the ad, we also note that McCain supports a cap-and-trade program that would limit companies' greenhouse gas emissions.

Such a plan could encourage corporations to invest in renewable energy by making the burning of coal, natural gas or petroleum more expensive. Obama also proposes a cap-and-trade program in a different form.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



350 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


August 12, 2008 Tuesday


Obama's new ad pulls Harley into jobs debate


BYLINE: RYAN J. FOLEY -- The Associated Press


SECTION: POLITICS


LENGTH: 406 words


MADISON, Wis. -- A radio ad unveiled by Barack Obama's campaign invokes a signature American product -- Harley-Davidson motorcycles -- to criticize John McCain's economic policies.

The ad blasts the Arizona senator for his long opposition to provisions that require government agencies to buy American-made goods. McCain has repeatedly said those provisions can't ensure taxpayers the best deal and restrict free trade.

The Obama ad takes aim at McCain for opposing such a measure in a 2005 homeland security bill that required the Secret Service to purchase American-made motorcycles. Harley-Davidson is the market-leading U.S. motorcycle company.

The ad features a clip of McCain speaking to thousands of motorcyclists in Sturgis, S.D., last week. McCain noted Obama's recent speech to an estimated 200,000 people in Berlin and then said, "I'll take the roar of 50,000 Harleys any day!"

"But when it comes to his record, American-made motorcycles like Harleys don't matter to John McCain," a narrator says. "Back in Washington, McCain opposed a requirement that the government buy American-made motorcycles. And he said all Buy American provisions were quote 'disgraceful.'"

For Wisconsin audience: Obama campaign spokesman Phil Walzak said the ad was running on radio stations in Milwaukee and was the first of the general election campaign tailored to a Wisconsin audience.

"This ad uses an American icon and a Milwaukee institution to demonstrate some of the differences in this campaign," he said. "Sen. Obama believes that taxpayer dollars should be used to support American jobs and American companies."

The ad comes as Obama's double-digit lead in Wisconsin appears to be shrinking. The Democrat's most recent visit to the state was in June, while his Republican rival stopped here most recently in Racine two weeks ago.

McCain's reaction: McCain's campaign stood by his 2005 description of the motorcycle provision on the Senate floor as "gross examples of protectionist trade policy" that cost taxpayers more money by restricting competition.

Steve Ellis, vice president of Taxpayers for Common Sense, a budget watchdog group, said McCain's position does not mean he's against buying American. Critics who suggest otherwise "don't think American companies can produce the best, most cost-effective products," he said.

"Anybody who has ridden a Harley can say clearly they can compete" with foreign firms for government business, he said.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



351 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Associated Press State & Local Wire


August 12, 2008 Tuesday 8:30 AM GMT


McCain's 'celebrity' taunts are bugging Obama


BYLINE: By CHARLES BABINGTON, Associated Press Writer


SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL


LENGTH: 612 words


DATELINE: HARRISBURG Pa.


In a presidential campaign freighted with war, recession and energy woes, a jibe featuring Paris Hilton, of all things, seems to have struck a nerve in Democrat Barack Obama.

For the second time in two weeks, he aired a TV ad Monday rebutting Republican John McCain's claim that Obama is little more than a celebrity, like the blonde hotel heiress.

The first time, Obama dismissed the assertion as "baloney." On Monday, Obama took a different tack with a commercial that says McCain, not he, is "Washington's biggest celebrity."

The back-and-forth may seem as frothy as a boardwalk milkshake in mid-August. But it suggests McCain is making some headway in trying to fight the campaign on his terms.

For weeks, Obama has tried to frame the election largely as a referendum on President Bush, using every chance to tie McCain to the unpopular incumbent. McCain has tried to make it about Obama by arousing concerns about the first-term senator's experience and depth.

McCain has aired a series of TV ads that showed far more images of Obama than himself, a somewhat risky approach. All of them tried to turn Obama's crowd-pleasing talents against him.

A July commercial blaming Obama for high gasoline prices which the watchdog group FactCheck.org called "a tank full of nonsense" portrayed crowds chanting Obama's name. A subsequent ad mixed images of Obama on his recent European trip with video clips of pop figures Hilton and Britney Spears.

Obama is "the biggest celebrity in the world," the announcer said. "But is he ready to lead?"

Even some Republican strategists questioned whether the strategy was smart or dignified. And Hilton herself produced a video poking fun at McCain that drew large Internet viewership. But Obama's latest ad suggests the "celebrity" taunt has some sting, and efforts to dismiss it as silly have not been effective.

"They woke up this weekend and figured out that that ad resonated and they needed to do something about it," said Terry Holt, a Republican strategist.

Although the McCain campaign was lampooned for its Hilton ad on late night television and blogs, it kept hammering at the celebrity theme. A McCain TV ad introduced last week showed Obama waving to cheering crowds, along with his picture on the covers of the magazines GQ, US Weekly and Vanity Fair.

In his new ad, Obama tries to turn the celebrity theme to his advantage, grafting it to his claim that a McCain presidency would amount to a third term for Bush. That claim has generated a defensive response from McCain.

McCain daily tries to beat back the idea that he'd represent a continuation of Bush, as he did Monday while campaigning in Erie and Harrisburg, Pa. Nearly 85 percent of Americans think the country is on the wrong track, McCain told workers at an Erie manufacturing facility, and "we've got to reform and reform and reform."

The new Obama ad shows McCain hugging Bush while the voiceover says, "as Washington embraced him, John McCain hugged right back."

Obama spokesman Bill Burton said the ad is designed to say voters have a choice between Obama, who stands for change, and McCain, "who overwhelmingly favors the status quo."

Holt, the GOP strategist, said, "If the celebrity issue were not hurting them, they would have ignored it."

An Obama adviser, who talked on background because he is not authorized to speak for the campaign, said the new Obama ad is meant mainly to poke fun at McCain because he is one of Washington's most celebrated and TV-friendly politicians, yet he is calling a relative newcomer a big celebrity.

Associated Press writer Ann Sanner contributed reporting from Washington.

On the Net:

Obama ad: http://my.barackobama.com/page/content/embrace ad


LOAD-DATE: August 13, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire



Copyright 2008 Associated Press
All Rights Reserved



352 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 11, 2008 Monday
FINAL Edition


Letters: Presidential battleground


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; DN Opinion; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 304 words


JOHN McCain's campaign is attempting to divert the real issues involved in the ongoing battle for the White House.

They are saying Obama and his camp are playing the race card. This is what right-wing Republicans do best. They use diversionary tactics to keep the masses distracted from focusing on the reasons why we're in the economic catastrophe we're now facing.

The administration lets corporations like Exxon/Mobil raise gas prices so they can achieve the biggest quarterly profits in history. The working men and women of America again take it on the chin.

It's a sad day when we have to make a choice over filling our gas tanks or filling our families' bellies. It is crucial that we stay focused on the real issues like the state of the economy and the fight for good jobs, and the health-care crisis.

Tony Mastrome, Philadelphia

If Paris Hilton didn't enjoy celebrity, she wouldn't be offered perks such as $1 million just to attend an Australian millionaire's New Year's party, as the New York Post's Page Six reported in 2007.

Unlike Obama, McCain has not produced any commercials that are deceitful. In Obama's first campaign ad, the Wall Street Journal noted (June 26), "Obama claims credit for having extended health care for wounded troops, citing the 2008 defense authorization. That bill passes 93-3, but Mr. Obama was one of only six senators who didn't show up to vote." In his next commercial, Obama lauded his support for welfare reform when in fact he opposed it.

John Edwards was considered egocentric when he decided he deserved to be president even though he decided not to run for re-election after his one term in the Senate. But he did finish his term. Obama had served a mere 142 days in the U.S. Senate when he started an "exploratory committee" for a run for the presidency.

Georgia Makiver

Lansdowne


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



353 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)


August 11, 2008 Monday


Paris in the election buzz -- How shallow can we go?


SECTION: OPINION


LENGTH: 703 words


Ayear ago, it was impossible to get through a day without some mention of Paris Hilton -- the ingenue famous mostly for being famous.

Oh, how we complained. Can't we please have just one day when we don't talk about Paris?!

And then one day, America's prayers were answered. Not only did Hilton disappear, she vanished into a jail cell where she spent 22 days for violating parole.

When finally she did emerge, a repentant and humble Hilton claimed she had found God.

"I'm not the same person I was," she averred. "God has given me this new chance."

Who knew God's messenger would be John McCain.

With his recent ad trying to convey that Barack Obama is just another celebrity whose status is based on a thin resume, McCain effectively resurrected Hilton's career.

Familiar to most by now, the ad shows Obama before a cheering crowd, then the camera pans to Britney Spears and Paris Hilton. "He's the biggest celebrity in the world, but is he ready to lead?" asks the narrator.

Something about higher taxes and foreign oil got lost in the reaction to the ad's allegedly racist imagery. Apparently, a black male cannot be viewed in the same frame with white females without a suggestion of racist undertones.

At least that was my first response to the controversy.

As a white female, I saw the ad as simply dumb and beneath McCain. Too easy. Too cliched. We all get the celebrity bit. But upon further reflection, the ad was subliminally loaded.

It is a fact that few other faces -- black, white, male or female --are as well known as Hilton's and Spears'. It's also a fact that few celebrities, if any, are as comparably well-known for gaining their status without much resume.

But it is a more important fact that the two ladies are perceived as being of questionable character. Their celebrity is based in part on their sexual displays.

Hilton's career was launched with a homemade porn movie. Spears is known to forget to wear undergarments in public. Their value as examples of celebrity is overshadowed by their sexual symbolism, in other words.

The first association upon viewing the ad might well be celebrity, but the second connection is surely sex. Despite racial progress in this country, the black man/white woman sexual taboo still burbles just beneath the surface of America's unconscious mind -- and easily roils to the top in some pockets where racism is still easily tapped.

Did McCain intend it that way? My sense is no, owing to McCain's own profoundly painful experience with a similar tactic in 2000 when his daughter was the target of an ugly racist attack.

Push pollers placed calls in South Carolina saying that McCain's adopted daughter (from Bangladesh) was really his illegitimate black child.

Even if baiting racists would win him the election, it is highly doubtful McCain would allow it. But he did allow this ad, which, at the very least, showed poor judgment.

A subsequent Obama-celebrity ad is missing the missies, but the damage has been done.

McCain's ad, meanwhile, was a gift to Hilton. Her video rebuttal not only is more clever than McCain's original, but she manages to mock the elder statesman.

Seated on a chaise in bathing suit and gold heels, Hilton introduces herself: "Hi, I'm Paris Hilton and I'm a celebrity, too. Only I'm not from the olden days and I'm not promising change like that other guy. I'm just hot."

Because McCain put her in his ad, Hilton says she figures she must be running for president. So she presents her "hybrid" energy plan -- a combo of McCain's drilling and Obama's new technology. Something to tide us over until, you know, the problem's solved.

The unsolved problem for both McCain and Obama is they have too many people telling them what to do. Too many polls, managers and handlers later, they're losing their true selves.

Both were once unique in different ways. Mavericks in their own time, they were original men who each had transcended challenging circumstances, if of different orders.

Politics has become so shallow that a poor little rich girl, America's icon of shallowness, can spoof a war hero and veteran U.S. senator and make him seem silly.

Worse, Paris Hilton is back in the buzz.

E-mail Washington Post col umnist Kathleen Parker at kparker@kparker.com


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC:


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 York Newspapers, Inc.
All Rights Reserved



354 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 10, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


STOP IT!


BYLINE: BARBARA BUSI, McCandless


SECTION: EDITORIAL; ISSUE ONE: OBAMA, MCCAIN, PARIS, BRITTNEY; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 91 words


I am a John McCain supporter, but this latest attack on Barack Obama is just ridiculous ("McCain Says He's Going Humorous, Not Negative," Aug. 2). To compare Mr. Obama to Britney Spears or Paris Hilton makes the McCain campaign look like a bunch of college students who think they can say any derogatory thing they want whether it's true or not -- whether it even makes sense.

I want to hear about the issues; make commercials that make John McCain look good, not ones that try (ineffectively) to ridicule Barack Obama. Stop it! Act like professionals!


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



355 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 10, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


LET THE TRASH TALK BEGIN;
MCCAIN GETS IT STARTED, DRAWING IN PARIS, BRITNEY, OBAMA AND BIKERS


BYLINE: Margaret Carlson


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. G-3


LENGTH: 836 words


Who started it? That's what parents usually want to know when an argument breaks out among siblings. Everyone loses privileges but the instigator suffers most.

So who started the latest dustup between the presidential candidates that has Paris Hilton inserting herself in the middle of the campaign?

Let's go to the videotape. In an ad that John McCain's campaign put up last week, Sen. Barack Obama is compared to Ms. Hilton and, in case people didn't get the point, her evil twin, Britney Spears.

"He's the biggest celebrity in the world," an announcer intones, making Mr. Obama the third of the trio. "But is he ready to lead?"

In a world chock-full of cheesy celebrities, is it an accident that the two most intentionally vulgar, proudly promiscuous and artificially blonde were featured in this one? We'll have to ask the author. The ad ends with the voice of the Republican candidate for president. "I'm John McCain and I approved this ad."

Mr. Obama had the maturity not to respond. Not so Ms. Hilton, who took time out from her busy schedule of shopping, shopping and shopping to notice there was an election in November.

With the help of glossy magazine publisher Jason Binn, she quickly filmed a response to Mr. McCain, whom she called a "wrinkly, white-haired guy." In a cut-out swimsuit, lounging, pouting and posturing by a pool, she announced her plans to make America energy independent and to paint the White House pink.

Team McCain couldn't have been happier. Two, two, two ads for the price of one. Now if they can only get Ms. Spears to take the bait. She's busy at the moment with a photo shoot swimming in a white bikini with the dolphins in Cabo, which she is selling to an unnamed tabloid for $1 million. Surely her agent is busy cobbling together her own riposte, which could double her fee.

The ad is part of the McCain effort to turn Mr. Obama's strength into a weakness, to make large crowds, intense supporters and excited young people bad. More deftly, Sen. Hillary Clinton tried to do the same thing with a hyperdramatic parody of Mr. Obama (celestial choirs will be singing and the heavens will open), but she didn't get two weeks of coverage from one end of cable and the Internet to the other out of it. That takes some trash talk.

With all the noise Team McCain generated with the spot, it's hard to be heard on matters of substance. Perhaps that's why Mr. McCain, once a flyboy celebrity himself known for coming in near the bottom of his class and scoffing at rules, is trying to get some of the attention he darkly accuses Mr. Obama of having too much of.

At a rally of motorcyclists in Sturgis, S.D., Mr. McCain, keeping with his platinum-blonde theme, offered his wife up to the Harley-ites as a potential biker queen. He predicted she could win the contest famous for its competitors going topless and bottomless.

"I told her with a little luck she could be the only woman ever to serve as first lady and Miss Buffalo Chip."

In the middle of all this, it's hard to hear the debate, if there is one, over Afghanistan and Iraq, the subprime-mortgage crisis, or to take stock of the candidates' dueling energy policies.

The latter has been drowned out by the effort to turn a suggestion by Mr. Obama that keeping tires properly inflated will save on gas into the equivalent of that hint from Homeland Security a few years ago in which citizens were advised to use plastic secured with duct tape to protect themselves in a terrorist attack.

It's smart to use the one thing to attack the whole but not if your own side is advocating the one thing.

While Mr. McCain is handing out tire gauges to the press and offering them for a $25 donation on his Web site, the merits of keeping your tires inflated are being pushed by some of his closest allies: Florida Gov. Charles Crist, who's on Mr. McCain's list of potential vice presidential choices; by NASCAR, the race-car circuit, which his wife recently visited; by President Bush's Department of Transportation, which says that a little more air in your tires could save more oil in one year than new offshore drilling could produce in four.

Bush Jr. may have gotten the idea from his dad, with whom Mr. McCain recently shared a golf cart; he advocated the same thing 18 years ago.

The combination of Paris, Britney and the tire gauges finally got Mr. Obama to snap back at Mr. McCain, something he usually avoids. After citing the widely known statistics on gas savings, Mr. Obama said, "It's like these guys take pride in being ignorant."

Ignorance can be bliss when cable clocks hours retailing your ad and this and other columns devote inches to it. Let's hope the candidates' first joint appearance since the end of the primaries at Rick Warren's Saddleback Church this week yields more.

Until then, maybe Mr. McCain should listen to his mother, Roberta. They always talk straight and know who started it. When she was asked about the blonde girls spot, she brusquely labeled it "kind of stupid." Moms always talk straight and they know who started it.


LOAD-DATE: August 12, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Margaret Carlson is a columnist for Bloomberg News (mcarlson3@ bloomberg.net).


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



356 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 9, 2008 Saturday


Come November, It Will Be Your Choice To Vote Or Not To Vote


BYLINE: Ryan Dunn, 19


SECTION: A; Pg. 6


LENGTH: 581 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Teen Editorial

RYAN DUNN, 19

Freestyle Staff Writer

People either old enough to know such things or those young enough to still have hope like to bombard you with statistics about why you should vote in the presidential election this November.

Their rhetoric doesn't seem to vary much, usually just a reference to John F. Kennedy's 1960 defeat of Richard Nixon, or maybe an urging about how important it is to "rock the vote."

Senators John McCain and Barack Obama both have amassed impressive credentials over the years, something commercials will surely remind us about in the next few months, but we're at the point of just treading water until the two debate. In the past few weeks, Obama has name-dropped Lil' Wayne (as a talented rapper, no less) and McCain joked about his opponent being "Dr. No" for not drilling in ANWR (that particular Bond reference is nearly 50 years old).

What matters here is that none of these things do. I love politics and look forward as much as the next guy to a new commander in chief who doesn't leave his final G8 summit by saying "Goodbye from the world's biggest polluter" with an alleged fist-pump. I mean, I even read the insufferable Charles Krauthammer. But when these candidates give speeches or answer questions about establishing a national language or how a "gas tax holiday" is a "good" idea, know that it's all silly.

That's why I think it's OK most people don't vote. For example, I go to college, so I am shouted at daily to sign a petition, donate some money or register to vote. I am registered and do plan on casting my ballot for the first time come November, but I realize it bears little importance in the grand scheme of things.

For all the harassing others do of uninformed and uninterested potential voters, it doesn't change the fact that our voices are rarely heard. To suggest in a nihilistic sense that few politicians care and the Electoral College is an antiquated idea is probably true, but not really my point. There's no gain for anyone by pushing someone who is apathetic toward voting. If differentiating between the candidates is difficult, something admittedly possible in 2004 but not so this year, then why subject yourself to looking for a voting booth?

This is not to say politics can't be fun; the movies "Predator" and "Stuart Saves His Family" prove some of the many races are. Two stars from "Predator," a movie about running through the jungle and shooting numerous rounds at an alien, have been elected governors in the United States. Jessie Ventura of Minnesota and Arnold Schwarzenegger from California were probably not the most qualified to do the job, but definitely the most intimidating. And now Sonny Landham, who had also appeared in the film, is aiming to represent Kentucky in the Senate. If elected, he would work alongside fellow Kentuckian Senator Jim Bunning, famous for throwing a perfect game with the Phillies as well as all that comes with being very Republican.

A little more notorious is Al Franken, who played hapless loser Stuart Smalley on "Saturday Night Live." The Harvard graduate is running for Senate in Minnesota, and seems to have a decent shot. Bill O'Reilly hates him, and that's important to many Democrats. He is not funny, but neither was Rick Santorum, so it hardly matters.

Yep, this is a strange election. You should take part in history if you want to; or just go to class, work and nap on a Tuesday night. Both are equally American, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



357 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 9, 2008 Saturday


Come November, It Will Be Your Choice To Vote Or Not To Vote


BYLINE: Ryan Dunn, 19

Bill O'Reilly hates him, and that's important to many Democrats. He is not funny, but neither was Rick Santorum, so it hardly matters.

Yep, this is a strange election. You should take part in history if you want to; or just go to class, work and nap on a Tuesday night. Both are equally American, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



358 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 9, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


THE SUBTEXT OF RACE IN THIS ELECTION CAN'T BE DENIED


BYLINE: DAVID BEAUDREAU Franklin Park


SECTION: EDITORIAL; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Pg. B-6


LENGTH: 282 words


Regarding the Aug. 4 Ruth Ann Dailey column stating that "the Democrats are playing "the racist card" ("Race Card? What About the 'Racist Card'?"), a closer look may be in order.

While talk radio and the Internet are not under the control of either party or candidate, they certainly have become vicious "allies" of the Republican candidate. An endless loop of blatant lies about race and religion relentlessly circulate to the detriment of the voter who might be seeking the truth. You can fault Barack Obama only for not being specific regarding the source of such racist innuendos and lies. He would not be "without evidence to support the charge."

Subliminal messages conveyed by the juxtaposition of Britney Spears, Paris Hilton, various towers and an African-American man have been a common mechanism of destructive political campaigns for decades.

David Gergen, an adviser to one Democratic and three Republican presidents, got it right last weekend. He said, "I think the McCain campaign has been scrupulous about not directly saying it, but it's the subtext of this campaign. Everybody knows that. There are certain kinds of signals. As a native of the South, I can tell you, when you see this Charlton Heston ad, 'The One,' that's code for, 'he's uppity, he ought to stay in his place.' ... When McCain comes out and starts talking about affirmative action, 'I'm against quotas,' we get what that's about."

In the upcoming debates, if Barack Obama is aggressive and brilliant will he be called "uppity"? Conversely, would he be weak and unpresidential if he were "to stay in his place"?

Anyone who believes race is not a potential make-or-break issue in this presidential race is delusional.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



359 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 9, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


AD SETS THE TONE


BYLINE: MIKE MOORE Mount Washington


SECTION: EDITORIAL; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Pg. B-6


LENGTH: 269 words


As a white American born, raised and educated in the deep South, I have been watching the presidential contest closely, especially in view of its historic inclusion of the first black candidate from a major party. Just recently, the role race will play became absolutely clear to me.

I viewed for the first time the John McCain TV ad that was explained by Mr. McCain as questioning Barack Obama's substance. It purported that Mr. Obama is basically just a celebrity with no substance. To emphasize this, the ad pictures two celebrities who are vapid and troubled people. But did Mr. McCain select two celebrities who might to any degree be compared to Mr. Obama, such as Tiger Woods, Will Smith or some other black "celebrity"? No, instead the ad pictures two young white girls!

As a Southerner, I thought that sent a clear message. The ad showed the pictures of the two white girls and then faded into the picture of Mr. Obama. Could the message to Southern whites have been clearer? The message being, here are these two pretty white girls whom we must protect from the big, black man Obama! Pure unadulterated "race-baiting"! That is the exact type of messages I saw repeatedly as I grew up in the pre- and post-civil rights law days in the Deep South. They were messages of fear and hatred.

So I now know who introduced race and played the race card -- it was John McCain, and in an overtly racist and bigoted manner at that! It is clear to me whom I will not vote for as I seek a united America -- united being the only way we can overcome the serious problems of the 21st century. I will not vote for John McCain.


LOAD-DATE: August 11, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



360 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 8, 2008 Friday


Mccain Tv Ads Flood Lancaster


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: B; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 815 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


About 200 local Democrats, dressed in hippie, casual, hip-hop or business attire, crammed into Obama campaign headquarters in Lancaster city Thursday evening.

"They have to demean him," Mayor Rick Gray said, speaking of recent Republican attack ads aimed at Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential candidate. "They have to reduce him to the lowest common denominator, because if they don't Barack Obama will be the next President of the United States."

Television advertisements by presumptive Republican nominee John McCain and the GOP have aired in recent weeks, often attacking Obama for lacking government experience and for a celebrity-like status at home and abroad.

According to a study released last week by the University of Wisconsin, the media market in and around Harrisburg, including Lancaster, is among the top 10 targeted by both presidential candidates for television advertising. That underscores the region's importance to the Nov. 4 election, not only in Pennsylvania but in the nation.

"Both campaigns see Pennsylvania ... in the sense that it's central to their path to the White House," said Chris Borick, a political science professor and pollster at Muhlenberg University.

McCain is coming to York County Tuesday, and a report from the Allentown Morning Call said he will be traveling with former Gov. Tom Ridge and that they will stop Tuesday in Lancaster, too. The McCain camp did not return messages seeking comment on this.

McCain earlier this week predicted Pennsylvania, with its 21 electoral votes, would be not only a pivotal state in the election but the decisive state, the way Ohio was in 2004 and Florida in 2000.

A candidate needs 270 electoral votes to win the White House, and Pennsylvania has more electoral votes than the other battleground states this year: Michigan, Ohio, Virginia and Colorado.

Between June 3 and July 26, the candidates and the Republican National Committee spent $10.3 million on television advertising in Pennsylvania, the most of any state and about $4 million more than second-place Ohio. The Democratic National Committee did not spend any money on television ads during the same time frame.

"I can tell you from the attention we're getting from the national (Republican Party), we're absolutely one of the focuses, if not the focus of the entire nation," said Michael Barley, spokesman for the state Republican Party.

Abe Amoros, spokesman for the state Democratic Party, said Obama needs to spend millions on television advertising because he lost Pennsylvania's primary to Hillary Clinton in April by about 10 percentage points.

"The smart money always goes into television," Amoros said. "It has an emotional impact as it connects to voters."

A breakdown in the number of commercials and where they air shows the geography of McCain and Obama's strategies. Philadelphia and its suburbs received the most ads of any region in the nation, a total of 3,311, according to the Wisconsin study.

The local media market ranks sixth overall with 2,519 advertisements, the study said. It is ahead of such pivotal regions as Columbus, Ohio; Denver, Colo., and Lansing, Mich.

According to pundits and party officials, Gov. Ed Rendell crafted a winning strategy in 2002 and 2006 by dominating the Philadelphia region, including the suburbs, where the number of Democrats has drastically increased, while performing poorly in the rest of the state.

McCain's strategy, then, would be to weaken Obama's numbers in and around Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, while rallying a strong GOP turnout in the rest of the state - which pundits have taken to calling "the T."

The "T" is roughly the shape of Pennsylvania minus the Philadelphia and Pittsburgh areas. It is considered Republican territory, and if McCain is to win Pennsylvania, he needs high voter turnout in this region, including Lancaster and the rest of the Harrisburg media market.

"McCain can't lose (the Philadelphia area) by 90,000 or 100,000 votes," said G. Terry Madonna, director of Franklin & Marshall College's Center for Politics & Public Affairs. "If he loses it by 15,000 and keeps Obama down in the Pittsburgh region, McCain has a chance."

"McCain needs incredible turnout," Borick said. "He would have to have big victory margins in the T and big turnout, which is anything but certain given the conservatives' lukewarm reception for him. He's never been a darling of the conservatives."

Therefore, all the ads.

Tickets for McCain's town hall meeting will be available at Lancaster County Republican Committee headquarters between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. today and Monday. Headquarters is at 902 Columbia Ave., and the local GOP has only 1,000 tickets to give out.

The McCain event will be held Tuesday at the Toyota Center in the York Fairgrounds. Doors open at 9:45 a.m.

Also Thursday, the Obama campaign opened its local headquarters at 252 Harrisburg Ave. The telephone number is 606-9393.


LOAD-DATE: August 9, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: John Mccain
Tom Ridge


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.



361 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)


August 8, 2008 Friday


Mccain Tv Ads Flood Lancaster


BYLINE: Dave Pidgeon


SECTION: B; Pg. 1


LENGTH: 815 words


DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


About 200 local Democrats, dressed in hippie, casual, hip-hop or business attire, crammed into Obama campaign headquarters in Lancaster city Thursday evening.

"They have to demean him," Mayor Rick Gray said, speaking of recent Republican attack ads aimed at Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential candidate. "They have to reduce him to the lowest common denominator, because if they don't Barack Obama will be the next President of the United States."

Television advertisements by presumptive Republican nominee John McCain and the GOP have aired in recent weeks, often attacking Obama for lacking government experience and for a celebrity-like status at home and abroad.

According to a study released last week by the University of Wisconsin, the media market in and around Harrisburg, including Lancaster, is among the top 10 targeted by both presidential candidates for television advertising. That underscores the region's importance to the Nov. 4 election, not only in Pennsylvania but in the nation.

"Both campaigns see Pennsylvania ... in the sense that it's central to their path to the White House," said Chris Borick, a political science professor and pollster at Muhlenberg University.

McCain is coming to York County Tuesday, and a report from the Allentown Morning Call said he will be traveling with former Gov. Tom Ridge and that they will stop Tuesday in Lancaster, too. The McCain camp did not return messages seeking comment on this.

McCain earlier this week predicted Pennsylvania, with its 21 electoral votes, would be not only a pivotal state in the election but the decisive state, the way Ohio was in 2004 and Florida in 2000.

A candidate needs 270 electoral votes to win the White House, and Pennsylvania has more electoral votes than the other battleground states this year: Michigan, Ohio, Virginia and Colorado.

Between June 3 and July 26, the candidates and the Republican National Committee spent $10.3 million on television advertising in Pennsylvania, the most of any state and about $4 million more than second-place Ohio. The Democratic National Committee did not spend any money on television ads during the same time frame.

"I can tell you from the attention we're getting from the national (Republican Party), we're absolutely one of the focuses, if not the focus of the entire nation," said Michael Barley, spokesman for the state Republican Party.

Abe Amoros, spokesman for the state Democratic Party, said Obama needs to spend millions on television advertising because he lost Pennsylvania's primary to Hillary Clinton in April by about 10 percentage points.

"The smart money always goes into television," Amoros said. "It has an emotional impact as it connects to voters."

A breakdown in the number of commercials and where they air shows the geography of McCain and Obama's strategies. Philadelphia and its suburbs received the most ads of any region in the nation, a total of 3,311, according to the Wisconsin study.

The local media market ranks sixth overall with 2,519 advertisements, the study said. It is ahead of such pivotal regions as Columbus, Ohio; Denver, Colo., and Lansing, Mich.

According to pundits and party officials, Gov. Ed Rendell crafted a winning strategy in 2002 and 2006 by dominating the Philadelphia region, including the suburbs, where the number of Democrats has drastically increased, while performing poorly in the rest of the state.

McCain's strategy, then, would be to weaken Obama's numbers in and around Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, while rallying a strong GOP turnout in the rest of the state - which pundits have taken to calling "the T."

The "T" is roughly the shape of Pennsylvania minus the Philadelphia and Pittsburgh areas. It is considered Republican territory, and if McCain is to win Pennsylvania, he needs high voter turnout in this region, including Lancaster and the rest of the Harrisburg media market.

"McCain can't lose (the Philadelphia area) by 90,000 or 100,000 votes," said G. Terry Madonna, director of Franklin & Marshall College's Center for Politics & Public Affairs. "If he loses it by 15,000 and keeps Obama down in the Pittsburgh region, McCain has a chance."

"McCain needs incredible turnout," Borick said. "He would have to have big victory margins in the T and big turnout, which is anything but certain given the conservatives' lukewarm reception for him. He's never been a darling of the conservatives."

Therefore, all the ads.

Tickets for McCain's town hall meeting will be available at Lancaster County Republican Committee headquarters between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. today and Monday. Headquarters is at 902 Columbia Ave., and the local GOP has only 1,000 tickets to give out.

The McCain event will be held Tuesday at the Toyota Center in the York Fairgrounds. Doors open at 9:45 a.m.

Also Thursday, the Obama campaign opened its local headquarters at 252 Harrisburg Ave. The telephone number is 606-9393.

362 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)


August 8, 2008 Friday


Paris Hilton tosses bikini in ring


BYLINE: By Mary Lou Kelsey Lebanon Daily News


SECTION: COLUMNISTS


LENGTH: 837 words


She wore an itsy bitsy, teeny weenie, yellow polka dot bikini.

Well perhaps it wasn't the itsy bitsy, teeny weenie, yellow polka dot bikini of lore. It was more of a leopard print bathing suit with lots of windows and lots of skin. The body inside that revealing suit was none other than Paris Hilton's.

A pig-tailed Paris was tastefully lying on a lounge chair reading a magazine, which is definite proof that Paris can read. She looked lovely. Her appearance on line was to make a tasteful rebuttal to John McCain's claim that Barack Obama is nothing more than a celebrity like Paris Hilton and Brittany Spears. The McCain commercial implied that Barrack was a publicity seeking celebrity and not ready to lead the country. When you think about it, you had better seek celebrity or no one will know who you are and you won't win the election.

I was surprised that Sen. McCain paid any attention to Brittany Spears and Paris Hilton. My husband doesn't even know who Hannah Montana is. He couldn't get her name in a crossword puzzle. That is being pretty far out of the loop. He began to pay more attention to the teen wonder kid when he found out her father is Billy Ray Cyrus.

The ad caused a fervor. It even caused an on-air fight between McCain's campaign manager Rick Davis and MSNBC's Andrea Mitchell. Mr. Davis explained the purpose of the ad was to portray Obama as frivolous and irresponsible as Hilton and Spears.

I have no true favorites in this race. I did like Mike Huckabee. I didn't approve of his politics, but I thought he was darned funny. He amused me. The two chosen candidates on both sides of the aisle are not particularly amusing. In the beginning, the ad amused me, yet I began to have deeper thoughts. Don't you think the McCain campaign camp should stop reading People magazine and visiting celebrity blogs and spend more time on the issues? It gives me pause that a man who is president spends any of his time thinking about Paris Hilton and Brittany Spears

Do they actually watch the news shows or do they tune into "Entertainment Tonight"? Could it be possible that McCain's

spin doctors are trying to make their candidate seem younger and "with it" because he knows all about this young celebrity buzz?

Paris Hilton's grandfather, William Barron Hilton, co-chairman of the Hilton Hotel Empire, was not amused. He was upset with the comparison between his granddaughter and Barack Obama. I'm not sure how to take that. Was he angry because he thought Obama was far smarter than his granddaughter or was he upset because he thought his granddaughter was far smarter than Obama? They both get the same amount of press although in a celebrity poll Paris is watched more than Obama.

The Democratic senator countered, "The only way they figure we are going to win this election is if they make you scared of me. So they are saying, you know, we are not very good, but you can't risk electing Obama. You know. He is new, he doesn't look like any other president on the currency and, you know, he has a funny name."

That is way too many "you knows." He sounds like a teenager. Besides, Paris Hilton wouldn't look bad on currency.

McCain said that he was proud of the ad. "I respect and admire Sen. Obama, but we have differences that need to be drawn." I imagine he respects Paris and Brittany too or he wouldn't have them in his commercial.

At first Paris ignored the commercial. She then must have had second thoughts. If McCain considers her a celebrity, then go for the brass ring. In Paris' case it would be the platinum ring. Paris Hilton knows how to play the game.

She responded with a poolside spoof aired on the Web site, "Funny or Die." "Hello America. I am Paris Hilton and I am a celebrity too. Only I am not from the olden days. I am not promising change like that other guy. I'm just hot. But then that wrinkly white-haired guy used me in his campaign ad, which means I guess I am running for president. So thanks for the endorsement white-haired dude."

"I want America to know that I'm, like, totally ready to lead."

She enters the debate on the energy crisis and suggests combining McCain's offshore drilling plan and Obama's incentives for new energy technology.

"Energy crisis solved. I'll see you at the debates."

She excuses herself by saying that she has to pick a vice president. Rihanna may be her choice. And then she ends her spoof with her ideas for the White House. "I think I will paint it pink, if that's OK with you guys."

The satire concludes with the signature, "I am Paris Hilton and I approve of this message. I think it is totally hot."

I never thought I would agree with Paris Hilton, but I think it is totally hot too. Good for you, Miss Hilton. Let the candidates think about that. Paris you have chutzpah, a grand sense of humor and a wonderful publicist.

I have been hearing the promises of a fair campaign, which would include respectful ads. When does that part of the campaign begin? The closer these elections loom on the horizon, the closer the real circus is to coming to town.


LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)


August 7, 2008 Thursday


Obama hit often by McCain negative ads


BYLINE: Editor: Lebanon Daily News


SECTION: LETTERS TO EDITOR


LENGTH: 59 words


The presidential campaign is in full swing, and Sen. John McCain seems to be enjoying himself with negative ads on TV about Sen. Barack Obama. We see new ads almost daily in Obama negativity.

There is one line in an ad that Obama could use that would stop McCain in his tracks. And that one line is: "A vote for McCain would be insane!"

Roger Bomberger

Lebanon

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
