383 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 4, 2008 Monday
FINAL Edition


McCain's tactics paying off?;
Obama loses 9 points in national poll


BYLINE: By STEVEN R. HURST; Associated Press


SECTION: NATIONAL; DN National News; Pg. 09


LENGTH: 472 words


WASHINGTON - Intensified attacks by Republican John McCain on the character of his Democratic opponent have coincided with Barack Obama losing a 9 percentage point advantage in a national poll, which showed the candidates running dead even over the weekend.

McCain, who had vowed to avoid the kind of negative tactics that were used against him in the 2000 Republican primary contest with George W. Bush, began attacking Obama during the Illinois senator's trip to Iraq and Afghanistan late last month.

In the course of the McCain offensive, Obama's lead in a Gallup Poll tracking survey slid from 9 percentage points on July 26, when he returned from overseas, to nothing by Saturday, when the poll showed the candidates tied at 44 percent.

The four-term Arizona senator, who backed the war and claims experience with security and foreign policy issues, charged that Obama's promise to withdraw U.S. forces from Iraq within 16 months of taking office amounted to his having chosen to lose a war to promote his run for the presidency.

McCain has not relented even though he took criticism for the remark. It appeared at the time to be a defensive response to the massive attention paid to the Obama visit to the two U.S. war fronts as well as to the Middle East and Europe.

He subsequently ran a television ad that accused Obama of deciding not to visit wounded U.S. troops because he could not take television cameras - a claim that appeared to be false. Next, he issued a commercial that interposed images of Obama with pop-culture figures Britney Spears and Paris Hilton, trying to paint Obama as a celebrity without the experience to lead the country.

That was followed by accusations that Obama, who would be the first black U.S. president, had resorted to racial politics by asserting McCain and other Republicans would try to frighten Americans because Obama did not look like past U.S. presidents whose images are on the country's paper money.

And most recently, in an Internet advertisement, the voiceover calls Obama "The One" and features Obama appearing to describe himself and his presidential quest in grandiose terms. It ends with the late actor Charlton Heston as Moses parting the Red Sea in "The Ten Commandments."

Obama may have given McCain more fodder in recent days by announcing a readiness to compromise with Republicans on offshore oil drilling - which he had opposed - and apparently rejecting McCain's challenge to join him in a series of town hall meetings.

On Saturday, Obama said McCain's campaign was cynical and trying to distract voters from real issues but that he did not believe his opponent and his campaign had engaged in racism.

"In no way do I think John McCain's campaign was racist. I think they are cynical," Obama said. "Their team is good at creating distractions and engaging in negative attacks." *


LOAD-DATE: August 4, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Photograph by: Feed Loader


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



384 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 4, 2008 Monday
SOONER EDITION


MCCAIN ATTACK STRATEGY PAYS OFF IN POLLS


BYLINE: STEVEN R. HURST, THE ASSOCIATED PRESS


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-5


LENGTH: 562 words


DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Intensified attacks by Republican John McCain on the character of his Democratic opponent have coincided with Barack Obama losing a nine percentage-point advantage in a national poll, which showed the candidates running dead even over the weekend.

Meanwhile, Mr. Obama sent a letter yesterday to the Democratic Party's credentials committee, asking members to reinstate full voting rights for delegates from Florida and Michigan when the committee meets at the start of the party's national convention in Denver.

The delegates were originally stripped because the two states violated party rules by holding primaries before Feb. 5. The delegates from each state were given half-votes at a contentious party meeting in May, as part of a compromise designed to give two important states some role at the convention.

Mr. Obama's former Democratic rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, had won both primaries, though Mr. Obama's name was not on the Michigan ballot and neither candidate campaigned in Florida.

The new national poll comes on the heels of a change in tactics by Mr. McCain, who had vowed to avoid the kind of negative tactics that were used against him in the 2000 Republican primary contest with George W. Bush. Mr. McCain began attacking Mr. Obama during the Illinois senator's trip to Iraq and Afghanistan late last month.

In the course of the McCain offensive, Mr. Obama's lead in a Gallup Poll tracking survey slid from nine percentage points on July 26, when he returned from overseas, to nothing by Saturday, when the poll showed the candidates tied at 44 percent.

The four-term Arizona senator, who backed the war and claims experience with security and foreign policy issues, charged that Mr. Obama's promise to withdraw U.S. forces from Iraq within 16 months of taking office amounted to his having chosen to lose a war to promote his run for the presidency.

Mr. McCain has not relented even though he took criticism for the remark. It appeared at the time to be a defensive response to the massive attention paid to the Obama visit to the two U.S. war fronts as well as to the Middle East and Europe.

Mr. McCain subsequently ran a television ad that accused Mr. Obama of deciding not to visit wounded U.S. troops because he could not take television cameras -- a claim that appeared to be false. Next, he issued a commercial that interpose images of Mr. Obama with pop culture figures Britney Spears and Paris Hilton, trying to paint Mr. Obama as a celebrity without the experience to lead the country.

That was followed by accusations that Mr. Obama, who would be the first black U.S. president, had resorted to racial politics by asserting Mr. McCain and other Republicans would try to frighten Americans because Mr. Obama did not look like past U.S. presidents whose images are on the country's paper money.

And most recently, in an Internet advertisement, the voiceover calls Mr. Obama "The One" and features Mr. Obama appearing to describe himself and his presidential quest in grandiose terms. Mr. Obama may have given Mr. McCain more fodder in recent days by announcing a readiness to compromise with Republicans on offshore oil drilling -- which he had opposed -- and apparently rejecting Mr. McCain's challenge to join him in a series of town hall meetings.

But Mr. McCain drew criticism from Miss Hilton's mother yesterday for using Miss Hilton's image on the ad.


LOAD-DATE: August 4, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



385 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


August 3, 2008 Sunday
CITY-D Edition


Sideshow:


BYLINE: By Tirdad Derakhshani; Inquirer Staff Writer


SECTION: PHILADELPHIA; P-com News; Pg. B02


LENGTH: 644 words


The Olsens' literary genius Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen are, in the words of People mag, "gearing up to take the literary world by storm" with the publication of their joint memoir, the 272-page Influence, which purportedly charts the Olsens' spiritual and artistic maturation. (And to think they're just 22 years old.)

The sisters "take readers on a journey through their celebrated young lives, pausing to reflect on what has helped shape them into who they are today," a news release reads. The Olsens include interviews with the 20 people who have helped shape them the most, including fashion designers Karl Lagerfeld, Diane Von Furstenberg, John Galliano and Christian Louboutin and model-actress Lauren Hutton. (Curiously missing are such trendsetters as Leo Tolstoy, the Buddha, Jesus, the Dalai Lama, Jane Austen, Adam Smith, Patti Smith and John Rawls.)

"We want to explain culturally how ideas evolve," Mary-Kate said. The book also features drawings and photographs, and would go beautifully with most standard coffee tables.

Troyer's lawsuit challenged Verne Troyer's ex-gf, Ranae Shrider, told Usmagazine.com Friday that the Austin Powers actor is a liar whose $20 mil lawsuit accusing her of intentional infliction of emotional distress and battery is entirely without merit. Troyer, 39, who is 2-foot8 and 40 pounds, contends that Shrider, 5-5 and 110 pounds, threw him around and beat him.

"When you pick up a 2-foot, 8-inch human being and throw him to the floor, it hurts," Troyer's lawyer tells TMZ.com.

Shrider's rep says the lawsuit is "a transparent attempt to secure as much publicity as he can from his less than average career."

From dolls to kids Actor Jon Voight, 69, tells cable news show Fox & Friends he's surprised his estranged daughter, Angelina Jolie, has so many kids since she had no interest in dolls as a child. (Who says there's a link?)

"She wasn't the kind that played with dolls, and then all of a sudden she has all these kids," says Voight, who goes on to heap praise on his gal. Jolie "loves kids. She's very playful. It's wonderful, just wonderful," he says.

Voight says his newly born grandkids, Knox and Vivienne, are "healthy and doing well, and I'm so happy."

Post-Mercury Queen slog on Queen's first studio CD with front man Paul Rodgers will be out Oct. 14, reports Rolling Stone. This is the band's first studio album since 1995's Made in Heaven, a collection of late singer Freddie Mercury's final songs.

Paris on McCain So just how upset is Paris Hilton that GOP presidential candidate John McCain used her name and image in a campaign ad that attacks Barack Obama for being nothing more than an airhead celebrity (like Paris)?

"She hasn't even seen the ad," an unnamed pal says, "and she doesn't plan to." Paris, it seems, doesn't follow the news, or have opinions one way or the other about the candidates. People mag says her parents, on the other hand, are big McCain supporters.

Spinning Venom off Spidey? The Hollywood Reporter says Sony plans to follow up on the massive success of the three Spider-Man films by making a spin-off around Venom, the photographer-turned-nasty-nemesis played by Topher Grace in Spider-Man 3. But watch out, Topher fanatics: Reportedly, the studio may try to hedge its box-office bets by ditching Topher for a better-known star.

Sharon weighs Paris' talent Poor Paris: Current events and politics puzzle her. But at least the girl has interest and talent in . . . what?

Nothing, says Sharon Osbourne, who is back on TV as a judge on America's Got Talent. Paris has "a look that a lot of younger girls liked and copied, but she has no talent," Sharon tells Parade.com. "I'm sure Paris would tell you that herself. . . . She's a very sweet, nice girl. But that's it."

Contact "SideShow" at sideshow@phillynews.com. This column contains information from Inquirer wire services.

386 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 3, 2008 Sunday
FIVE STAR EDITION


BYLINE: Compiled by Greg Victor.


SECTION: EDITORIAL; CUTTING EDGE: NEW IDEAS, SHARP OPINIONS; Pg. G-4


LENGTH: 730 words


DICTATORS AT WORK

From Meg White at BuzzFlash.com:

"According to a Workplace Democracy Association/Zogby Interactive survey, 25 percent of Americans compare their workplace to a dictatorship. In the most comprehensive study of the phenomenon to date, the poll also found that adopting more egalitarian processes might be the solution.

" ... Interestingly, according to a study released earlier this year by the Bertelsmann Foundation, almost 40 percent of the world's population lives under a dictatorship."

ON DRINKING AND DEMOCRATS

A couple of thoughts on local politics from 414 Grant Street (414grantstreet.blogspot.com):

1) "We like the strategy employed by the [Allegheny] County Council Democrats to head off the referendum to repeal the drink tax. Putting up a second referendum linking the drink tax repeal to property tax increases is a very smart ploy."

2) "Looks like no one will challenge the mayor [Luke Ravenstahl] in the [Democratic] primary next year. Amazing. Even Richard Caliguiri had opposition, as did David Lawrence, who even almost lost a re-election after he made Pittsburghers stop using coal to heat their homes ... which leads us to wonder, was David Lawrence America's first great environmental politician?"

ON DRINKING AND KILLERS

The PGH IS A CITY blog (pghisacity.blogspot.com) is all for moving the Pittsburgh police substation from the bar-filled South Side to the sometimes-fatal hilltop:

"It's good to see the city putting their priorities straight. Murders are more important as a 'quality of life' issue than public urination on a Friday night after the bars close. Congratulations to Mayor Ravenstahl and his cronies for making the bold decision to move the police station away from where the new expensive condos are to a neighborhood that could really use some policing.

"Of course, I'm a bit biased because I live up close and personal with Allentown."

THE PRESIDENT'S PRIVATE ARMY

Writing at TomDispatch.com, Chalmers Johnson riffs on Tim Shorrock's new book, "Spies for Hire," tracing the history of "the wholesale transfer of military and intelligence functions to private, often anonymous operatives" from Ronald Reagan's day to the present. Mr. Johnson sums up:

"The current situation represents the worst of all possible worlds. Successive administrations and Congresses have made no effort to alter the CIA's role as the president's private army, even as we have increased its incompetence by turning over many of its functions to the private sector. We have thereby heightened the risks of war by accident, or by presidential whim, as well as of surprise attack because our government is no longer capable of accurately assessing what is going on in the world and because its intelligence agencies are so open to pressure, penetration and manipulation of every kind."

CELEBRITY CRAZY

Chad Hermann at the local blog "Teacher. Wordsmith. Madman." cuts loose at all sides over the latest McCain TV ad:

"Everyone seems to be talking about that sad and silly and embarrassingly desperate new John McCain celebrity attack ad. ... Partisan bloggers on the left are willfully misreading, then hysterically misrepresenting, the piece. (It's not a failed attempt to suggest Obama is as lightweight and inexplicably adored for dubious accomplishments as Britney Spears or Paris Hilton; it's a coded, subtle bit of racism that suggests the scary, black Obama boasts a taste for young white women!) Partisan bloggers on the right are willfully misjudging, then wildly overpraising, it. (It's not a failed attempt to suggest Obama is as lightweight and inexplicably famous for being famous as Britney Spears or Paris Hilton; it's a shrewd and brilliant and surprisingly savvy way to play the media and get people buzzing about your message!)"

HAPPY PAP

Bruce Levine at AlterNet.org mocks Harvard happiness researcher Tal Ben-Shahar, recounting Mr. Ben-Shahar's visit to "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart":

"Finally, Stewart is no longer able to restrain his amazement that platitudes are considered profound at Harvard nowadays (the 'Six Happiness Tips' on Ben-Shahar's Web site are about acceptance of negative feelings, positive attitude, meaningful activities, being grateful, simplifying life and physical health). Stewart ends the interview in Groucho Marx fashion by saying, 'It's a fascinating subject and one that I can't believe you are getting away with.' "


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



387 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 2, 2008 Saturday
FINAL Edition


Letters: Obama jujitsus John McCain


SECTION: EDITORIAL OPINION; DN Opinion; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 436 words


AFTER WHAT seemed like endless weeks of John McCain's whining about Barack Obama's alleged lack of experience in international affairs and complaining that he had not been back to Iraq for a long time, Sen. Obama decided to call his bluff and make the trip.

But it would appear that McCain got more than what he bargained for.

Obama, all three major networks in tow, met with the prime minister of Afghanistan, then played basketball with U.S. troops. Afterward, he not only met with Iraqi Prime Minister Maliki at his residence, but Obama also got his blessing for his troop-withdrawal program!

Then off to Jordan and Israel, looking quite presidential. But the clincher showed that Obama knows how to beat McCain at his own game.

Recent polls have suggested that Obama is much more popular with our European allies than is McCain, so he extended his trip to England, France and Germany, giving a Kennedyesque speech in Berlin.

Now picture this scene on every evening news, along with literally thousands of well-wishers wildly cheering Obama on, well as you might imagine, McCain is beside himself.

He had to run silly commercials claiming Obama is responsible for the price of gas, and went so far as to threaten to make a major announcement on the day Obama made his Berlin appearance. Then McCain complained that the monster he created, aided by Obama's smarts, is treating him unfairly and ignoring him.

Marc Golde, Merion Station

Missing black music

At first, I thought it was just a case of my favorite artist being overlooked.

Then it happened again and again. Every week I looked for highly anticipated new releases from top R&B and hip-hop artists only to find nothing! And I'm sure I'm not the only one who's noticed it.

After all, this is the No. 1-selling genre in a sagging industry! Is this racist?

Michael A. Grant Jr., PhiladelphiaMake that P2P

In a recent paper, under the At a Glance section, it said, "and a small amount of PCP, used in the manufacture of speed . . ."

Actually, it's P2P that's used in making speed. PCP is usually smoked (besides other ingestion methods) and is known as "angel dust" or "wet."

Bill Paci, Philadelphia

Bad broadcast chemistry

Re the Phillies obvious future plans to replace Harry Kallas with Tom McCarthy:

Almost as bad as replacing Rich Ashburn with Chris Wheeler.

The tandem of McCarthy-Wheeler (Heckle and Jeckle) is both terrible and intolerable, an assault on the eardrums, and every baseball fan in this town knows it. The best broadcast team they've got, Scott Franzke and Larry Anderson, are on the

radio, with a 12-second delay to boot.

Go figure.

John O'Mara, Philadelphia

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
All Rights Reserved



388 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 2, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


MCCAIN SAYS HE'S GOING HUMOROUS, NOT NEGATIVE


BYLINE: NICHOLAS RICCARDI AND STEPHEN BRAUN, LOS ANGELES TIMES


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-8


LENGTH: 744 words


DATELINE: PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla.


At the end of an increasingly contentious week of campaigning, Sen. John McCain yesterday denied that he was going negative against Sen. Barack Obama, even as his camp released a new Web ad that mockingly contrasts Mr. Obama's soaring rhetoric with clips of actor Charlton Heston playing Moses in "The Ten Commandments."

Earlier this week, the McCain campaign unveiled an ad that compared the Illinois senator with celebrities Britney Spears and Paris Hilton. On Thursday, Mr. McCain and his campaign manager accused Mr. Obama of playing "the race card" by warning voters against attacks that he looks different from other presidents on U.S. currency.

"I don't think it's negative," Mr. McCain said at a Panama City news conference. "I think we're drawing the difference between us."

The Obama campaign fired back quickly. "It's downright sad that, on a day when we learned that 51,000 Americans lost their jobs, a candidate for the presidency is spending all of his time and the powerful platform he has on these sorts of juvenile antics," said spokesman Hari Sevugan.

The new McCain spot, entitled "The One," opens in the manner of a Hollywood movie trailer, with a deep-voiced announcer declaring: "In 2008, the world will be blessed. They will call him: The One." It then cuts to some of Mr. Obama's loftier moments -- his declaration that, "We are the ones we have been waiting for," and his speech upon clinching the Democratic nomination promising, "This was the moment when the rise of our oceans began to slow, and our planet began to heal."

Asked about the spot, Mr. McCain said, "We're going to display a sense of humor in this campaign."

Late in the day, Mr. Obama dismissed his opponents' tactics. "They're calling folks names like they used to do in fifth grade. You remember fifth grade? Calling each other names, and petty fights. We don't have time for that. That doesn't lower gas prices and secure people's jobs."

Earlier yesterday, Mr. Obama unveiled a $50 billion emergency economic stimulus. At a campaign stop in St. Petersburg, he called for energy rebates of as much as $1,000, five years of a windfall profits tax on oil companies and $25 billion to replenish the highway trust fund.

Some of the elements of the plan were from Mr. Obama's prior proposals, but on the day the government announced that the unemployment rate hit 5.7 percent, a four-year high, the likely Democratic presidential candidate stepped up the stakes with the energy rebate, more details on the profits tax and the extra funds for highways.

"This [energy] rebate will be enough to offset the increased cost of gas for a working family over the next four months," he said at a town hall meeting.

Noting a headline in the morning's St. Petersburg Times that told of the first recessionary downturn in the state since 1991, Mr. Obama again linked Mr. McCain and President Bush, blaming both men for failing to aid Americans struggling with job loss and home foreclosures.

In an interview yesterday with The Palm Beach Post, Mr. Obama said he would be willing to support limited additional offshore oil drilling if that was what it took to enact a comprehensive policy to foster fuel-efficient autos and develop alternate energy sources.

Shifting from his prior opposition to expanded offshore drilling, the Democrat said he could support a compromise with Republicans and oil companies to prevent gridlock over energy.

Mr. McCain, who earlier dropped his opposition to offshore drilling, has been criticizing Mr. Obama on the stump and in broadcast ads for clinging to his opposition as gasoline prices topped $4 a gallon. Polls indicate that those attacks have helped Mr. McCain gain ground on Mr. Obama.

"My interest is in making sure we've got the kind of comprehensive energy policy that can bring down gas prices," Mr. Obama said. "If, in order to get that passed, we have to compromise in terms of a careful, well thought-out drilling strategy that was carefully circumscribed to avoid significant environmental damage -- I don't want to be so rigid that we can't get something done."

Asked about Mr. Obama's change of heart, Mr. McCain said: "We need oil drilling, and we need it now offshore. He has consistently opposed it. He has opposed nuclear power. He has opposed reprocessing. He has opposed storage."

The Republican said his rival doesn't have a plan equal to the nation's energy challenges.

Today, Mr. Obama will address the Urban League's national convention in Orlando.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: The Associated Press contributed to this report.


GRAPHIC: PHOTO: John Raoux/Associated Press: Marc Morial. left, National Urban League president and chief executive officer, jokes with Republican presidential candidate Sen. John McCain yesterday at the National Urban League Conference in Orlando, Fla.

389 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 2, 2008 Saturday
SOONER EDITION


ISSUE OF RACE COMPLICATES OBAMA'S BID


BYLINE: JOHN MCCORMICK, CHICAGO TRIBUNE


SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A-8


LENGTH: 799 words


The issue of race kept bubbling up in the presidential campaign yesterday, as African-American hecklers charged that Sen. Barack Obama has not been aggressive enough on matters concerning the black community, while the Illinois Democrat's own supporters complained that a new television ad from Sen. John McCain has racial overtones.

Until recently, overt discussions of race had been absent from the campaign between Mr. Obama and Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican. But they erupted this week when a McCain spokesman accused Mr. Obama of "playing the race card."

Yesterday, Mr. McCain said Mr. Obama's speeches are better than his proposals, as he spoke in Orlando before the National Urban League, a group that Mr. Obama is scheduled to address today. Mr. McCain suggested that Mr. Obama is hypocritical for sending his children to private schools and still opposing school vouchers, and his campaign released a new Web video called "The One" that mocks Mr. Obama as messianic.

But a more unusual spectacle played out elsewhere in Florida, where Mr. Obama was confronted by a group of young African-American protesters at an event in St. Petersburg.

The group raised a sign saying "What about the Black community, Obama?" as they stood behind him on bleachers in a high school gym. The sign included the Web site for the International African Revolution, which has a mission of "giving voice to the struggles of the African working class from around the world."

Mr. Obama has dealt with hecklers before and coolly reminded the men that they could ask a question after he finished speaking, and told them to sit down. Then, much of the audience started to chant, "Yes, we can," an Obama slogan.

When the question-answer portion started, Mr. Obama called on one of the protesters to ask the second question, as a staff member held onto the microphone the entire time.

"In the face of all these attacks that are clearly being made on the African community, why is it that you have not had the ability to not one time speak to the interests and even speak on behalf of the oppressed and exploited African community, or black community, in this country?" the man asked, mentioning predatory lending, police shootings of blacks and the so-called Jena 6 case in Louisiana.

"This is democracy at work, and he asked a legitimate question, so I want to give him an answer," Mr. Obama said, as some in the audience booed the protester. "On each of these issues that you mentioned, I have spoken out. I have spoken out, and I have spoken out forcefully. ... I passed the first racial profiling legislation in Illinois. I passed some of the toughest death penalty reform legislation in Illinois."

In another reflection of the issue's complexity, some Obama supporters yesterday said they saw racism at play in new McCain ads featuring Britney Spears and Paris Hilton that seek to suggest that the presumptive Democratic nominee is just a well-spoken celebrity.

They note that the ads feature young white blond women, just as did much-criticized ads that ran in 2006 against Harold Ford Jr., a black U.S. Senate candidate from Tennessee who attended a Playboy party with white women.

"I note with interest today John McCain's new tactic of associating Barack Obama with oversexed and/or promiscuous young white women," blogger Josh Marshall wrote on his Talking Points Memo blog.

It's hardly a surprise that race would become an issue in a presidential contest featuring the first African-American to clinch a presidential nomination from a major party. Mr. Obama has presented his candidacy as moving beyond divisions, yet he has referred to his own race on several occasions, usually in the context of warning his supporters that Republicans will launch race-based attacks.

Earlier this week, a McCain spokesman claimed that Mr. Obama was playing the "race card" when he warned supporters that Republicans would try to convince voters that the Democrat is a risk. Mr. Obama predicted that they would note how he "doesn't look like all those other presidents on those dollar bills."

After initially disagreeing with the McCain camp that that statement had racial overtones, a top Obama adviser conceded yesterday that it did, at least in part, refer to Mr. Obama's racial background. "He's not from central casting when it comes to candidates for president of the United States," David Axelrod said on "Good Morning America" on ABC. "He's new to Washington. Yes, he's African-American."

That brought this response from McCain spokesman Brian Rogers: "They clearly walked away from his statements, and we are moving on."

Throughout his campaign, Mr. Obama's race has had advantages and disadvantages. A Quinnipiac University Poll in July showed him with the support of 94 percent of blacks, a group he has aggressively courted.


LOAD-DATE: August 5, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



390 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Daily News


August 1, 2008 Friday
FINAL Edition


Tattle: Tobacco is way off Keys for Alicia


BYLINE: By Howard Gensler


SECTION: FEATURES; DN Columnists; Pg. 30


LENGTH: 953 words


ALICIA KEYS may be smokin'- hot, but she's not hot for smokin'.

Performing in Jakarta, Indonesia, Keys objected to concert sponsorship by Philip Morris International's A Mild cigarettes and the tobacco giant pulled down its billboards.

The D.C.-based Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids initially drew Keys' attention to PMI's association with her show.

In a letter released by Sony BMG, Keys said she asked the company to stop the branding.

"I am an unyielding advocate for the well-being of children around the world and do not condone or endorse smoking," she said.

"Whether tobacco sponsorship of music events leads to youth smoking is a matter of serious debate," PMI said in a statement. "Having considered the facts in this specific instance, we have decided to withdraw all branding associated with this concert."

Entertainment and politicsJohn Rich, half of the Nashville duo Big and Rich, has penned lyrics for the anthemic "Raising McCain," focusing on the 5 1/2 years John McCain spent as a POW in Vietnam and his refusal of an early release.

"He stayed strong, stayed extra long 'til they let all the other boys out. Now we've got a real man with an American plan, we're going to put him in the big White House," the song says. Its refrain: "We're all just raising McCain."

Rich said he hadn't been involved in politics before but got excited about the Arizona senator's campaign.

He finished the song about a month ago and sent it to McCain's daughter Meghan, who sent it to campaign officials.

Rich said that while he admired Barack Obama, "The entire world is looking for a way to sucker-punch us," he said. "National security is absolutely at the top of the list of issues. That's why I think John McCain is the guy to keep us safe."

* Barack Obama supporter Luda-cris wrote "Politics as Usual" for his guy, but it probably won't be showing up on Obama's iPod any time soon.

The song brags about an Obama presidency and uses an expletive to describe Hillary Clinton, calls President Bush "mentally handicapped" and says John McCain doesn't belong in "any chair unless he's paralyzed."

That doesn't even make any sense. But if Ludacris' goal was to inflame the opposition, mission accomplished.

The lyrics also don't spare the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who recently apologized for making crude comments about Obama. "If you said it, then you meant it," he raps.

"As Barack Obama has said many, many times in the past, rap lyrics today too often perpetuate misogyny, materialism, and degrading images that he doesn't want his daughters or any children exposed to," campaign spokesman Bill Burton said in an e-mail. "This song is not only outrageously offensive to Sen. Clinton, Rev. Jackson, Sen. McCain and President Bush, it is offensive to all of us who are trying to raise our children with the values we hold dear. While Ludacris is a talented individual he should be ashamed of these lyrics."

* Lastly, Britney Spears and Paris Hilton have been thrust into the presidential race in a new commercial for John McCain.

The women don't endorse McCain; they're merely all-style-no-substance celebs whom his campaign compares with Obama.

In a town-hall meeting in Wisconsin, McCain said the commercial was not at odds with the respectful campaign he'd promised.

"We're proud of that commercial," he said.

In other Britney, Paris news . . . L.A. Police Chief William Bratton

said yesterday that a few changes have heped the city with its paparazzi problem:

"If you notice, since Britney started wearing clothes and behaving, Paris is out of town not bothering anybody anymore, thank God, and evidently, Lindsay Lohan has gone gay, we don't seem to have much of an issue," Bratton told KNBC-TV.

Tattbits* India.Arie's Broadway debut in a

revival of Ntozake Shange's "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf," has been postponed following the loss of one of the show's backers.

The play, produced by Whoopi Goldberg and DreamTeam Entertainment, was to open Sept. 8 at Circle in the Square.

* Lucasfilm and British prop designer Andrew Ainsworth both claimed victory yesterday in a legal battle over the Stormtrooper uniforms from "Star Wars."

British High Court judge Anthony Mann ruled that Ainsworth violated Lucasfilm's U.S. copyright by selling replica Stormtrooper uniforms through his Web site to U.S. customers.

But the judge refused to enforce a $20 million judgment Lucasfilm won against Ainsworth in California in 2006. The judge said Ainsworth's U.S. sales of less than $60,000 were not significant enough to make him susceptible to U.S. jurisdiction.

The judge also rejected a claim against Ainsworth under British law, saying English copyright over the suits had expired. Ainsworth's lawyer, Seamus Andrew, said the ruling meant that Ainsworth was now free to sell his replicas everywhere except the United States.

* If you're free Aug. 9

and like big organs, you might want to trek up to Radio City Music Hall.

Retired Air Force Colonel/pipe-organ fan Jack Moelmann is renting out the giant hall at a cost of $120,000 to fulfill a lifelong dream - to perform on the largest theater pipe organ ever built by Wurlitzer.

Tickets to Moelmann's show are $50 and (thousands of) good seats are still available.

* According to TMZ.com, Verne Troyer is taking his ex-girlfriend and sex-tape partner, Ranae Shrider, to court.

It seems as if Ranae liked it rough, and Verne is suing her for physical and emotional distress.

Verne's lawyer, Ed McPherson, told TMZ.com, "When you pick up a 2-foot-8-inch human being and throw him to the floor, it hurts."

Hey, when you throw a 5-foot-8-inch human being to the floor, it hurts. *

Daily News wire services contributed to this report.

391 of 461 DOCUMENTS




Philadelphia Magazine


August 2008


Best of Philly 2008


BYLINE: Edited by Christine Speer and April White


LENGTH: 17356 words


The year was 1974. Rizzo was in office. Bobby Clarke was in the Inky. Blazing Saddles was at the Sameric. And for the first time ever, Philly Mag set out to find the city's softest pretzel, hottest haircut, most reliable plumber, canniest astrologer ... (Hey, it was the '70s.)

A lot has changed since then. Our list of bests has grown (we now have almost 300 winners!) and embraced a new era (see Going Green, page 139), but the mission remains the same: We eat everything, shop everywhere, talk to everyone, so that you, dear reader, can head straight to the best.

This year we celebrate 35 years of Best of Philly with all the hidden gems, can't-miss-meals and hot new spots you want to hear about-and also pay tribute to the classics: that burger we all love, the mascot we adore, the traditions that explain and exalt our city. Plus: an insider's guide to Philly's best-kept secrets (page 147), our fifth annual pick for Best Philadelphian (page 151), the tastiest Tastykake that ever was (page 125), and much, much more.

Shopping and Style

Edited by Ashley Primis, with reporting by Erica Beinlich, Jenna Bergen, Carrie Denny, Emily Gagne, Brian Kirk, Lauren McCutcheon, Jane Morely, Amy Strauss and Janine White.

Center City's eyebrow artiste, a massage worth a trip down the Shore, and hitting the denim jackpot in Doylestown

Eyewear

Don't let their plaid shirts, skinny jeans and fast-talking ways fool you: The hip staffers at Modern Eye aren't too cool to be friendly, funny and honest - important qualities when you're looking for help choosing an accessory for your face. Their selection is thoughtful: Conservatives can go for square mahogany frames; statement-makers like the bright colors and chunkier specs from European designers like Minima and Markus T; and glam fans are able to stock up on Gucci shades. >>> 3419 Walnut Street, 215-386-5953, and 145 South 13th Street, 215-922-3300; modern-eye.com.

Luxe Massage

Try not to weep with pleasure as the therapists at Water Club's Immersion - a tranquil Asian-meets-the-Jersey-Shore spot - begin their choreographed Immersion Four-Hand Massage (which actually feels like eight), kneading out knots, applying your choice of oils where needed, and basically fixing anything and everything that's troublesome in your life. For that 80 minutes, at least ($340). >>> The Water Club, 1 Renaissance Way, Atlantic City, 800-800-8817, thewaterclubattheborgata.com.

Garden Center

If you have to ask, you haven't been paying attention to the buzz: Urban Outfitters' massive makeover of DelCo's stalwart J. Franklin Styer has, within a mere 11 acres, revolutionized - or, some might say, Anthropologie-ized - the garden-store concept. Terrain sells impatiens out of antique wooden carts. Terrain displays hard-cover garden books in lush greenhouses. Terrain stocks chic-ly packaged, eco-friendly seeds, fertilizers and pest control products, and displays its understatedly elegant - never precious - patio furniture outdoors. And its landscaping division is promising the same Styer's-esque attention to service. It might be the best in the country. >>> 914 Baltimore Pike, Concordville, 610-459-2400, terrainathome.com.

Maintenance Massage

At Mellow, a new, no-frills massage therapy center in East Falls, you don't have to schedule your "relax time" weeks in advance. Masseurs and masseuses work from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. six days a week (on Sundays, hours vary), so all it takes is a quick phone call and you're booked for a 30-, 60- or 90-minute great, straight-to-the-point Swedish, deep tissue or sports rubdown. And prices are so affordable, you can make it a weekly habit: An hour-long massage is $75, while a 30-minute pick-you-up is only $40. >>> Sherman Mills of East Falls, 3502 Scotts Lane, building 19, 215-843-2234, mellowmassage.com.

Bookstore

Walk into Queen Village's Head House Books on any given day and you may see something unusual: the store's owner handpicking inventory from a seller. That care isn't all that sets this independent bookseller apart. From the worn Persian rugs to the skylights that bathe the place in natural light, Head House has an earnest charm that chain stores seek to emulate but never seem to master. Don't miss the "community" section displays, filled with books recommended by locals as well as those popular with area book clubs. >>> 619 South 2nd Street, 215-923-9525, headhousebooks.com.

New Boutique, City

With an airier, more casual feel, the revamped Washington Square Pileggi Boutique has naysayers stopped in their tracks. New owner Andrea Chila has kept the standbys - Shin Choi, Diane von Furstenberg - but added funkier cult faves like Thread Social and DaftBird, making this one of the more diverse and exciting boutiques in an emerging hip zone. >>> 715 Walnut Street, 215-922-3526.

New Boutique, 'Burbs

We were surprised, too, that a women's boutique inside Media's B. Gross, an age-old men's shop, would be worth a look. But nine-month-old Per Lei far surpasses expectations. Co-owner Candice Caprice has picked a few of the best options in an eclectic mix of lines: lighthearted dresses from Theory, off-the-catwalk looks from BCBG, flirty skirts from Pink Tartan, sexy sundresses from Trina Tark. Caprice makes monthly buying runs to NYC, so her stuff is fresh. >>> 2 East State Street, Media, 610-566-1254, perleiboutique.com.

Men's Day Spa

Because there's nothing super-girly about the Borgata's Spa Toccare, it's a respectable refuge for a guy between rounds of golf or poker; folks here even had men in mind when they designed the decadent microderm cream facial and a body-sloughing treatment and massage. You'll also find serious deep-tissue rubdowns, spoiling soaks in oversize modern rooms, and - best of all - an over-the-top locker room where cloud-like robes, massaging slippers, fresh fruit and iced teas are only the half of it. Because nap-perfect lounge chairs face plasmas playing SportsCenter, which spa-goers can also see from either of two hot whirlpools after sitting a spell in the steam room or sauna. >>> 1 Borgata Way, Atlantic City, 609-317-7555, theborgata.com.

Lingerie

It's fitting that the second location of Haddonfield's Georgie Girl is housed on the main floor of Marlton's posh Rizzieri Salon & Spa, because the ultra-attentive staff here pampers us just as much as the beauticians upstairs - expertly fitting us for a Josie Natori, guiding us through deliciously soft P.J. Salvage nighties, and keeping records of our purchases - so that next time, when we call ahead, they'll pore over the racks and pull items before we show up. >>> The Shoppes at Rizzieri, Route 73 and Greentree Road, Marlton, 856-596-3343, georgiegirlboutique.com.

Men's Haircut

What he won't admit liking at American Male, a nationwide chain that started here: the gratis paraffin hand dips, scalp massages and mini facials. What he will: the beer, and the post-cut shampoo to banish itchy clips. >>> 512 Haddonfield Road, Cherry Hill, 856-665-6253, americanmale.com.

Linens

Ladies who lounge adore Chestnut Hill-bred and New York-based linens designer Nancy Koltes for her signature line of Italian-woven cotton bedding, sold at high-end boutiques. Now, everyone can rest even easier knowing there's a Main Line outpost of Nancy Koltes at Home, stocked with her breathable, beautiful sheets, duvet covers and shams in ladylike patterns and pretty colors. >>> 379 Lancaster Avenue, Haverford, 610-645-6030, nkah.com.

Shelter Store

City-living heaven. Foster's year-old, all-in-one new Old City location offers 10,000 square feet in which to avail oneself of Chilewich's brilliant shag floor mats and silver-tone Saarinen-esque champagne coolers and Reidel "O" chardonnay sets and Mikado desk globes and all manner of matte nickel bathroom accessories and handsome Adesso trolley carts and geometric Denyse Schmidt quilts and a full collection of everything OXO and brilliant wool Blu Dot upholstered couches and beds and wall decals before heading to the store's back room, a thoroughly functional, idyllically modern mini loft where worn-out customers can - phew - chill out. >>> 399 Market Street, 215-925-0950, shopfosters.com.

Salon, City

Laurentius Purnama - owner of Laurentius Salon, the new, all-white, ultra-modern salon in the Italian Market - has credentials. (He's styled Britney, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Beverly Johnson, to name a few). But he also has a method we like: Rather than drastically changing your look, he and his team concentrate on cuts, color and conditioning treatments that enhance your style. The result (delivered in record time - while you sip chardonnay) is an amped-up, still-recognizable, shiny new you. >>> 815 Christian Street, 215-238-0764, laurentiussalon.com.

Salon, 'Burbs

Raya Haig Salon is dead; long live Haig & Co., with tress guru Alan Gold at the helm as creative director. When Raya Yukhimov and Haig Khararjian parted ways last year, Gold stayed on at the newly named and newly polished Haig & Co. - where he continues to carry off his note-perfect C&C's, teaching his staff to do the same. Longtime fans delight in his updates to a faded decor - a gilding of the reception area, privatizing of the stations - and even the newest patrons are breathing easier, knowing they can look as glamorous and important as, say, the beauty editor of W, who recently asked Gold to execute her wedding-day hair. >>> 401 East City Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, 610-668-5373.

Eyebrow Shaping

Finally! A reputable place to have our eyebrows shaped via threading, an ancient-in-India (and so-five-years-ago in NYC) technique in which a flick of a string removes unwanted hair with more control and fewer ouchies than waxing. Dara King recently opened Thread Beauty Bar about five minutes after graduating from Temple - and already we're in love. King was trained in New York and personally teaches every employee the art of arching in this sunlight-drenched second-floor space. >>> 1903 Chestnut Street, 215-557-1953, threadphiladelphia.com.

Men's Shoes

Tucked inside a corner of KOP's Neiman Marcus is a large but well-edited selection of men's shoes: silver-buckled brown Ferragamo loafers for casual Fridays; shiny Gucci lace-up tux shoes for your daughter's wedding; and a slew of living-on-the-edge (think: shiny and attention-getting) sneakers from D&G and Puma. >>> The Plaza at King of Prussia, 610-354-0500, neimanmarcus.com.

Denim

Holy denim! Doylestown's Shop Sixty Five has more than 20 brands of jeans in 200-plus styles, organized into men's and women's denim bars. Owner Linda Bidlo recently moved into bigger digs (after a major rehab) and built cubby walls where her selections - skinny, bootleg, wide-leg, cropped, trouser, petite - are easy to navigate. >>> 53 West State Street, Doylestown, 215-348-8250, shopsixtyfive.com.

Women's Shoes

In just over a year, adorable Brit-born Elena Brennan has turned Queen Village's petite Bus Stop Boutique into our preferred spot for kicks. Brennan's gift: sourcing styles - think Repetto's iconic ballet flats, Bolo's chunky-chic platform sandals, United Nude's architectural pumps, and F-Troupe's very Chiswick cutout-sided flats - that are just trendy enough to be comment-worthy, while still under-the-radar enough to be unique. >>> 750 South 4th Street, 215-627-2357, busstopboutique.com.

Hair Color

Sweet, giggly Meghan Reilly at Rittenhouse's new AMS Salon loves doing balayage - a freehand, foil-less version of highlights that she spent years perfecting under the auspices of the experts at Salon A.K.S. in NYC. She uses different tones to literally paint color on in skinny little sections, creating a much more natural, textured, sun-kissed look than the dreaded stripes that come from the foil technique. And while we love her balayage, it's her basic understanding of dyes and dedication to detail that make her a top choice for anything color, from going darker to correcting a botched job. >>> 123 South 16th Street, 2nd floor, 215-569-1515, amssalon.com.

Hostess Gifts

Ever since Deanna Muth plunked down her darling shop last year on one of Wayne's busiest corners, that boring old bottle of merlot we used to take to dinner parties has become a thing of the past. These days, all it takes is a quick loop around The Pear Tree's thoughtful inventory of vases, Zents and Trapp candles, locally made Mane Lion serving and dip trays, colorful faux flower arrangements and hand-painted wood trays, and we've all but scored our next invite. >>> 133 North Wayne Avenue, Wayne, 610-688-7202, thepeartreepa.com.

Men's Casual Wear

Quaint Newtown isn't known for avant-garde, but when, in 2006, Katra Michener Longsdorf opened Love Illuminati, she didn't just bring a little edge to the town; she brought in stock that rivals that of city stores. Here, find selections for trendsetters (cardigans from Kill City and retro sunglasses from Initium) and more refined types (Bermuda shorts from Modern Amusement, muted plum button-downs from Plaster), plus stuff that all guys love, like the comfiest-ever hoodies from Brown Sound. >>> 23 South State Street, Newtown, 267-364-5477, loveilluminati.com.

Green Home Source

The earth-friendly wares at three-year-old Environmental Home Store are impressive: recycled, non-toxic, local and sustainable. (Read: All green, all the time.) Owner Todd Ballantyne has stocked his bright corner shop with beautiful countertops, organic-cotton bedding, Marmoleum and cork flooring, and lots more. Plus, his staff is happy to explain why you want a floor made from FSC-certified timber and what exactly recycled fly ash is, so you can impress and inspire your friends when they come over to see your cool new counters. >>> 550 Carpenter Lane, Mount Airy, 215-844-4733, environmentalhomestore.com.

Salon for Black Hair

When she's not on the road with Jill Scott or working on a shoot for O Magazine, stylist Syreeta Scott books the who's who of African-American Philly - and beyond - for cozy, comfortable styling sessions at Duafe, her all-natural, perm-free Brewerytown salon. Scott's only 33, but she and her team of 13 have established quite a following for their cool ringlets, sculpted 'dos, loose curls and sunset colors. >>> 2947 West Girard Avenue, 215-232-6850, dua-fe.com.

Spray Tan

While the idea of a customized spray tan from a spa sounds nice, the truth is that nothing about standing naked with a stranger spritzing you is particularly luxurious. That's why we love the minutes-long, non-streaking Mystic Spray Tan booth at Rittenhouse's Sun Myst Tanning Studios. While spray booths are no novelty, this is special: The spacious three-walled room doesn't have a door, so while you follow the easy rotating instructions (for even coverage), you can actually - and this is a big one - breathe. Seconds later, you emerge with a clear coat of soon-to-darken tan (or insta-bronze, if you wish) - all for as little as $25. >>> 209 South 20th Street, 215-545-5010, sunmysttanningstudios.com.

Knit Wit Dresses >>> Walnut Street's Knit Wit has such a winning variety of dresses - classic and contemporary - that you and your daughter can actually shop here together. She'll head to the back for Marc Jacobs and Rag and Bone, while you'll linger up front, among the DVF and Calypso. You'll point out that you've been shopping here since the '70s, before it was so well-known, before Walnut Street was the sparkling frock-filled Walnut Street your daughter knows today. And she'll roll her eyes. But just wait. In a few years, she'll be singing a similar tune to her daughter, who will roll her eyes as they browse the racks. Because some things just don't change. >>> 1718 Walnut Street, 215- 564-4760; 905 West Lancaster Avenue, Bryn Mawr, 484-592-0576; 8001 Ventnor Avenue, Margate, 609-822-9442; knitwitonline.com.

Men's Shave

Joe McMenamin and his sidekick Sal Mannino at Center City's Groom have spent a combined 88 years perfecting the art - er, craft - of shaving, a signature service in the two-chair shop, now relocated in the old digs of Harry's Barbershop. Joe, who learned from old-world hands, and Sal, a 74-year-old Italian who is old-world, put you at ease with hot towels, a stupor-inducing lathering massage, and classic vanilla Pinaud aftershave. Oh, and a damn-close shave. >>> 1324 Locust Street, lower level, 215-545-2626, groomphilly.com.

Newly Arrived Chain

With the salesgirls sleekly bobbed, coolly fashionable and accessorized just so, Rittenhouse's Club Monaco certainly has a clubby feel to it - and we're all too happy to join. Guys and gals can stock up on trustworthy black and white and punched with color urban basics whose clean lines guarantee hip for work, for parties, for weekends, for whatever. >>> 1503 Walnut Street, 215-567-7071, clubmonaco.com.

Problem Hair Fix

Images Hair Studio in Jenkintown may not look cutting-edge, but the work it's doing sure is. It's the only salon on the East Coast using Technical Hair Volumizing, a non-damaging - no glue, no weaves, no hair-pulling extensions - and undetectable method in which four synthetic strands are tied to a single strand of your hair, eliminating those awful hide-beneath-a-headband areas. >>> 740 Yorkway Place, Jenkintown, 215-887-2284, imageshairstudio.com.

Specialty Store

Kudos to Old City's Pinot Boutique for understanding our love of vino so well that it manages to be a successful wine shop that sells no wine. Instead it stocks gadgets and glasses, accessories like stoppers and decanters, a range of bottle-storage furnishings, and everything else an oenophile could dream up. >>> 227 Market Street, 215-627-9463, pinotboutique.com.

Kitchen Store

Halfway into Grandma's blueberry pie recipe, you realize you don't have a rolling pin for the from-scratch crust. No worries. Just head to Midtown Village's basement-level Kitchenette, the Wawa of culinary shops. The teensy space packs in all the essentials (knives, cutting boards, cookware by Cuisinart), eccentrics (juicers, sold-by-the piece flatware), luxuries (espresso machines) and style (Artland glass, Wilton Armetale serveware). And, oh yeah, rolling pins. >>> 1120 Walnut Street, 215-829-4949.

Beach Gear

South Moon Under stays true to its surfer roots with racks of bikini choices that bear Becca, Trina Turk and Radio Fiji tags. Amidst a hefty selection of mix-and-match separates (good for big and small ta-tas), one-piece suits and tankinis, you're bound to find a suit that fits. And the selection of coordinating cover-ups, beach bags, sun hats and flip-flops means you're Avalon-ready (well, minus the bikini wax). >>> 1731 Chestnut Street, 215-563-2298, and 205 West Lancaster Avenue, Wayne, 610-964-9064; southmoonunder.com.

New Day Spa

Several designs - and years - into the project, the father/son duo of the namesake Joseph Anthony Retreat Spa and Salon have finally opened their European-style oasis. Two floors offer suites of new-to-Philly curiosities, like the Alpine Herbal Steam room, where a mild hay-infused steam relaxes shoulders, and the Brine Light Inhalation room, where a saltwater fountain mists sinuses clear. Exotica aside, it's little touches that make the place stand out: the complimentary foot bath, quiet halls, and attentive staffers who make you feel like you're hundreds of miles away from Route 1. >>> 243 West Baltimore Pike, Glen Mills, 610-459-4663, josephanthony.com.

Green Boutique

A quick spin around Arcadia, Ali McCloud's 10-month-old boutique, reveals chic Nature vs. Future curve-skimming dresses, super-soft Sworn Virgins bamboo dresses and Del Forte organic denim. There's also tons of locally made jewelry and artwork, and even eco-friendly travel tips from the in-house travel consultant (!). >>> 819 North 2nd Street, 215-667-8099, arcadiaboutique.com.

Locally Made Goods

You'll poke through the eclectic goodies at Conspiracy Showroom, vow to start being crafty, give it a week, and then come back here and leave it to the pros. The stuff at this teeny NoLibs shop goes way beyond printed tees - Farmer's Daughter vintage-y bathing suits, fabric earrings by Meljoy, Jody Sweitzer's chunky rings made out of vintage buttons - for a diverse shop where everything is made in our backyard. And trust us: Their version of "handmade" is better than yours. >>> 910 North 2nd Street, 215-925-2153, conspiracyshowroom.com.

Women's Accessories

JKarma is a perfect, budget-friendly go-to for the season's trends: Rachel Wilder's paper-thin hammered silver earrings, Jan Michaels's brass locket ring, you'd-never-know-it's-faux-leather slouchy bags, and, of course, owner Jeanne O'Karma's imported-from-Bali jewelry (a holdover from her former storefront, Ethnics). Then there are the totally wearable but something-special shoes - adorned Sam Edelman flats, comfy All Black wedges and Matiko gladiators. >>> 62 North 3rd Street, 215-627-9625, jkarmaboutique.com.

Women's Workout Clothes

Lucy. Nowhere can we find prettier technical (read: odor-preventing, moisture-wicking) fabrics or such perfectly helpful staffers. (Are you listening, Sports Authority?) >>> Suburban Square, 120 Coulter Avenue, Ardmore, 610-649-2541, and the Promenade at Sagemore, 500 Route 73 South, Marlton, 856-983-1291; lucy.com.

Shopping Center

Powder Mill Square, in a wealthy suburb of Delaware, packs a well-rounded wallop of independent stores, with Lolita (302-656-4049), a favorite fashion-forward woman's boutique; Peter Kate Shoes (302-656-7463), where you'll find every flat, pump, satchel and clutch Tory Burch, Botkier and Bettye Muller have to offer; A.R. Morris Jewelers (302-777-4367), with Roberto Coin or Tag Heuer for that upcoming birthday; and Houppette (302-421-9036), for makeup and perfume from Bond No. 9, Creed and Diptyque. Then get the Express Pedi at Covet Spa (302-888-0700) and a latte at Brew Ha Ha (302-658-6336) before ducking into Oranges & Lemons (302-427-0323) for the Most Darling Kids Stuff Ever, from itty-bitty Patagonia to baby Crocs. And finally, pop into Somethings Unique (302-426-1950) for a gorgeous new European dining room table. It takes a lot more than a few miles on I-95 to shake that kind of shopping high. >>> 3830 Kennett Pike, Greenville.

Facial

A spa with a membership, so you can relax and enjoy a facial once a month? Good idea. A facial that's luxurious and - at $49 a pop - affordable? Great idea. But you'll find that once you settle into the special chair at Facelogic - a chair that takes every ounce of pressure off your spine, allowing you to float worry-free for 50 minutes - the real brilliance of this popular West Coast chain is its ability to deliver on its promise: baby-soft skin. (Bonus: a great upper-body rubdown.) >>> 4829 West Chester Pike, Newtown Square, 610-353-1232, facelogicnewtownsquare.com.

Plus-Size Boutique

Some quality independent plus-size boutiques have recently opened in the area, making it hard to choose our favorite, but Fresh Ayer's Banana-meets-Anthro-esque aesthetic and designer duds for sizes 10 to 24 push it to the top of the list. Parsons grad and owner Elizabeth Ayerle has outfitted the pretty space with the best brands for curvier customers - Abby Z, Kiyonna, Svoboda - and an expansive denim section that helps all us fruit-shaped girls be proud of our apple bottoms. >>> 100 East Lancaster Avenue, Wayne, 610-688-4933, freshayer.com.

Holistic Spa

At tiny Juju Spa & Organics (sister to Juju Salon & Organics), three treatment rooms hold gentle herbal facials, one-person-at-a-time pedicures (spring for the 50-minute spa version), and holistic, heavenly body treatments. Book early. >>> 728 South 4th Street, 215-922-3235, jujusalon.com.

Maternity Clothes

Cherry Hill's Destination Maternity is more than just a store; it's a superstore. Look for A Pea in the Pod, Mimi Maternity and Motherhood Maternity (three sister brands with three different price points) - plus everyday cotton tanks and dresses, plus cult line Seven, plus stretch-mark cream, nursing bras, lingerie, and even classes on breast-feeding and prenatal yoga. A central lounge has time-occupying toys for kids (oversize soft blocks) and husbands (plasmas), so moms can recharge with a free beverage from the juice bar and hit the sale racks in peace. See? Super. >>> Towne Place at Garden State, 901 Haddonfield Road, suite B, Cherry Hill, 856-488-1715, destinationmaternity.com.

Outlet Mall

Montgomery County's new mall, Philadelphia Premium Outlets, is giving KOP a run for our money, mostly because it houses outlet versions of sought-after stores we don't even have originals of, like True Religion, French Connection, Elie Tahari and Miss Sixty. 'Course, we also have love for the other top-notchers with discounted prices, like Kate Spade and Coach. >>> 18 West Lightcap Road, Limerick, 610-495-9000, phillypremiumoutlets.com.

Stylist (and Blowout)

Edmondo Blando, the amiable owner of Walnut Street's Salon Vanity, pays attention when you admit that you don't blow-dry religiously or that your mop usually ends up in a pony. Then he goes to work, combining techniques - dry-cutting for shape and wet-cutting for movement. Then he begins his magical blowout (that will last for days!). He's quick without being hasty, beyond knowledgeable about products, and willing to offer more tricks of the trade than any glossy you'll ever read. >>> 1126 Walnut Street, 2nd floor, 215-925-2211, vanityphilly.com.

Makeup Artist

Put Nick Townshend on speed-dial. The OMG artiste loves makeup, and he understands skin, face shape, feature highlighting and - most importantly - occasion, so you'll be perfectly fresh and glow-y or a smoky-eyed sex kitten. And he'll perfect your brows with a wave of his magic tweezers. >>> 351 Righters Mill Road, Gladwyne, 610-896-0240, omgstyle.com.

Electronics

Since 1955, HiFi House has been providing big-name clients with top-notch equipment, and installing it. (Recent biggies include Comcast, Jefferson, the trendy lounge G, and the Philadelphia Theatre Company.) But HiFi folks still walk us average Joes through their behemoth selection of LCDs, plasmas, DVD and DVR equipment, and everything sound-related, from CD players to home theater systems - and they'll set up a kick-ass universal remote to control it all. >>> 509 York Road, Jenkintown, 215-885-5300; 1001 Sussex Boulevard, Broomall, 610-544-4420; 2304 Concord Pike, Wilmington, 302-655-4780; hifihousegroup.com.

Latrice Evening Wear >>> The mark of a fabulous, stalwart special-occasion store: It can outfit a battalion of eighth-grade girls for a mid-'90s Main Line private-school graduation ceremony ... and then those same girls, more than a decade later, in the most fabulous Tadashi, Vera Wang Lavender Label and Badgley Mischka cocktail dresses. This is why Latrice will always be a go-to spot - and a savior for those same girls' mothers when they're desperately scouring the region for the perfect mother-of-the-bride gowns and accessories, like delicate jewelry, silk sweaters and scarves. >>> 1024 East Lancaster Avenue, Bryn Mawr, 610-525-1109.

Service

Edited by Christine Speer, with reporting by Jenna Bergen, Michael Callahan, Emily Gagne, Jordan Hickey, Robert Huber, Laurie Hungerford, Brian Kirk, Michael McCormick, Lauren McCutcheon, Jane Morley, Jessica Remo, Bridget Salmons, Amy Strauss, Steve Volk, April White and Janine White

The ultimate shoe saviors, Kathy Orr's super-stylist (for hire!), and the house-selling savants who'll help you unload that Main Line manse

Events Florist

Donna O'Brien at Beautiful Blooms has taken a venture that started in the basement of her Bucks County townhouse and grown it into a talk-of-the-town upscale floral and event design firm. She's known for work that's elegant, clever, memorable, and always reflective of you, the client. O'Brien can handle anything, and has - ask her about that Star Trek-themed bar mitzvah. >>> Beautiful Blooms, 1011 North Hancock Street, 215-925-9300, beautifulblooms.com.

Computer Geeks

The sales staff and repairmen at Bundy Computer may specialize in Macs, but they're also all-purpose tech nerds, prepared to (cheerfully, reassuringly) help you through a rough spot with your printer, your digital camera, or dozens of other high-tech toys. >>> 1809 Chestnut Street, 215-567-2500, and 7928 Bustleton Avenue, 215-332-5600; bundycomputer.com.

Tailor

Roberto Bartilomo at Malvern Cleaners & Tailors can take any article of clothing you bring him - wedding gown, leather coat, bikini - and just make it better. His business, a teeny family-run company that his father-in-law opened in 1957, has become such a lifeline of good fit for clotheshounds over the years that Bartilomo actually gets shipments of outfits from clients who have long since left Malvern, and some who've even left Pennsylvania, but who can't bear to leave their tailor. >>> 5 East King Street, Malvern, 610-644-1770.

Dog Groomer

Chez Bow Wow, c'est magnifique. This friendly Northern Liberties groomer features an attentive and caring staff - pros who are honest about what your pet needs and extra-sweet with skittish breeds. Their digs are clean and bright, the atmosphere is calming - as Zen as your own spa - and Fifi always comes out with a happier trot and that certain je ne sais quoi. >>> 1040 North 2nd Street, unit 501, 215-923-2992.

House Stager

One-year-old, two-person Voila Designs has upped the ante among veteran stagers, pulling from Philly's burgeoning artisan, artist and architect communities to set up color-correct, floor-planned, elegantly styled homes and condos, and doing whatever it takes (including delivering food to the open house) to help you sell your place in a down market. >>> 267-886-0317, voiladesignservices.com.

Invites/Announcements

Designer Joy Deangdeelert Cho of Oh Joy! Studio is locally based but nationally lauded for her custom-designed letterpress notes, invites and stationery: Details like patterns pressed on envelope flaps, bold colors and arty icons (instead of checking entrée choice, put an 'X' next to the picture of a fish, steer or carrot) are inspiration enough to throw that party or even - almost - marry that boy. >>> 215-561-0896, ohjoystudio.com.

DIY Go-To

Owner Peter Bender's quaint Moorestown Hardware brings the throwback neighborhood hardware store to life, all wrapped up in Petticoat Junction packaging (including retro tunes piped in as you look for that new garden hose). The folksy sales help and sit-a-spell vibe will have you swearing off ever setting foot in a Home Depot again. >>> Moorestown Hardware, 300 Mill Street, Moores-town, 856-235-0800.

Hand Car Wash

It's like the invasion of the killer ants: Eight red-shirted guys descend on your dusty wheels at Spring Garden Wash & Lube as if they're in a timed contest to eat all dirt. >>> 1111 Spring Garden Street, 215-763-9000, washnlube.com.

Custom Framing

What with the catch-as-catch-can hours and, ahem, leisurely pace, it seems like it might take less time to paint a portrait than to have one framed at Burholme's Karl Moegerle Paints. So why bother? Meticulous hand-craftsmanship, über-friendly service and really reasonable prices. They'll treasure your pictures as much as you do. >>> 7237 Rising Sun Avenue, 215-745-7815.

Going Green

We admit we're not ready for composting toilets. (Scary!) So we appreciate third-generation interior designer Lili Wright's home-greening approach: Her firm, Wright Design, offers services - like one-day room makeovers - that don't require a total lifestyle overhaul. And best of all, she thinks that eco-friendly design principles fit every style, and brings her clean, classic European aesthetic to a Kennett Square farmhouse and Rittenhouse townhomes alike. >>> 20 East Sunset Avenue, 215-242-3149, 831-236-0846, wright-design.net.

Ballroom Dance Lessons

Dancing's like sex: It usually involves two people, and everyone wants to make it appear effortless. But when it comes to fox-trotting, help is a little easier to find. Fred-and-Ginger hopefuls head to Society Hill Dance Academy for private lessons with pros who are generous with patience, encouragement and, mercifully, humor. >>> 409 South 2nd Street, 215-574-3574, societyhilldance.com.

Landscapers

At the helm of Groundswell Design Group is sexy David Fierabend, who gives postage-stamp courtyards and rolling estates equal attention, and gets his hands dirty alongside a well-trained crew that makes sure colorful yards, artful sculpture gardens and thoughtful Zen landscapes will thrive long after they leave (though you'll still catch Fierabend driving by months later "just to check" on a finished job). >>> 187 Lyndbergh Road, Hopewell, 609-466-8100, groundswelldesigngroup.com.

Halloween Jewelry Design (and Re-Design) >>> If Halloween, that lavish treasure trove of a jewelry store, is eccentric (have you seen the pearl brooch in the shape of a cowboy?), then owner Henri David is downright flamboyant. He answers the phone with a singsongy "Trick or treat!" He throws a Halloween party - every year for 40 years now - and invites the entire city. He's designed jewelry for Elton John, and for crazy Stevie Nicks. The man is friends with John Waters, for Pete's sake. But he's also a true talent, and old-school when it comes to honest dealings and customer service. David and his staff have earned our trust - and their icon status - with quality, beautiful work. They'll duplicate any design, clean and refurbish your grandmother's hand-me-downs, and work with any budget to make your jewelry at least as memorable as the place it came from. >>> 1329 Pine Street, 215-732-7711.

Yoga, 'Burbs

Ask any yogi: An instructor makes or breaks the class. But at Power Yoga Works in Malvern, you never have to worry. Every instructor at this little strip-mall spot is excellent, which means you know exactly what you'll get each time you unroll your mat in this sparse, serene space: a challenging 90-minute workout that will stretch you, tone you, and leave you both centered and sore the next day. >>> 81 Lancaster Avenue, Malvern, 610-889-9642, poweryogaworks.com. (There's also a Philly location: 3527 Lancaster Avenue, 215-243-YOGA.)

Yoga, City

For busy people, it doesn't really matter if the yoga instructor is the most flexible in the city; what you really need is Philly's most flexible studio. That's Wake Up Yoga. With locations in Fairmount and West Philly and almost four dozen classes a week, there's something for every schedule and style, from strenuous vinyasa to chill-out restorative yoga. For the record: We've seen owner Corina Benner stand on her hands and arch her feet toward the crown of her head, chatting cheerfully the whole time. >>> 2329 Parrish Street and 4916 Baltimore Avenue; 215-235-1228, wakeupyoga.com.

Personal Trainers

What do a former Eagles linebacker with the body of the Hulk and a Temple grad with a degree in electrical engineering have in common? They both want to kick your ass. Carlos Bradley and Terrence Gill are two outstanding members of the primo personal training posse at the Aquatic and Fitness Center. While they can't guarantee you'll have the hard bodies they do, they do promise to put you through your paces - and make it fun! - until you get back into those slim-fit jeans. >>> The Aquatic and Fitness Center, 601 Righters Ferry Road, Bala Cynwyd, 610-664-6464, afcfitness.com.

Art Repair

The upstairs toilet flooded, and now Nana's portrait (circa 1890) is ruined. Or maybe not. Philip Rosenfeld and his team at the Pennsylvania Art Conservatory have tackled the worst calamities (rips, rotting canvases) for more than 30 years for collectors and big-name museums (the Dali Institute, the Warhol Foundation). They can handle every period and style, and you don't need to worry that they'll change your masterpiece into their own. Says Rosenfeld, "We do as little as possible, everything can be reversed, and it's guaranteed for a lifetime ... unless someone puts a foot through it." >>> 636 Lancaster Avenue, Berwyn, 610-644-4300, paconservatory.com.

Home Organizer

Long before Oprah et al. arrived at the home-improvement party, Organizers, Inc., a two-woman West Chester firm, was producing neater closets and streamlined spaces from Delaware to Bucks and beyond. Principal Susan Sabo describes her mission as "a combination of psychological and physical help," meaning they don't just make your entryway clutter-free or overhaul your filing system: They teach you the thought process, handing you permanent providence over your private province. For proof of success, check out the orderly desks at clients Vanguard, Sunoco and Comcast. >>> 610-738-9220, organizersinc.com.

Pilates, Purist

Boy, that Brie Adina Neff is a stickler. The queen of Romana's Pilates - a type of Pilates dedicated to the method as Joseph Pilates conceived it, with no twists and no newfangled updates - teaches intense 45-minute private sessions at Equilibrium Pilates, scrutinizing even practiced students, pushing, pushing, pushing for precision. The payoff: Clients feel energized (and taller!), and closer to the ballet body that Pilates promised. >>> 424 South 2nd Street, 215-923-3669, equilibrium-pilates.com.

Pilates, Personalized

Aimee Baker is watching you. With Zen-like calm, the Colorado transplant is sizing up your body - posture, breathing, weight shifts, even foot strength - long before you ever step onto a mat. And while the environment at her Bodylogic Personal Training Studio is casually homey, the private, prescriptive sessions are serious business. After an initial consult, you'll get 55 minutes of undivided attention (there's a

one-customer-per-room rule) in a program specifically tailored to address the aches, pains and weaknesses that can be fixed and alleviate the ones that can't. >>> 25 Elliott Avenue, 2nd floor, Bryn Mawr, 610-316-5742, bodylogicpilates.com.

Image Consultant

When Nancy Amoroso says, "I'm gonna Nancify you," look out. The woman responsible for the HDTV-ready looks of Eyewitness News's on-air personalities (including new-and-improved Kathy Orr!) is an ageless, tell-it-like-it-is stylist who transforms wardrobes, accessories, hair and makeup to make her hush-hush list of private big-name patrons look - and feel - important. ("Important is more important than expensive," she says.) >>> 610-608-8100.

Bartender

A good bartender is more than just the drinks he serves - he's a guy you want to drink 'em with. Like Ron Johnson, on the second floor of Northern Liberties watershed Standard Tap. He's mixing cocktails for the ladies, cheerfully pouring local drafts for the friends who met over MySpace, regaling the nouveaux bohemians assembled at the mahogany. And sometimes, you'll find him there on off nights. On a totally dead one not long ago, Johnson - a Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts grad, and a sometimes professional painter by day - whipped out the ink wash and brushes he's known to keep behind the bar and painted tiny masterpieces on customers' coasters. >>> 901 North 2nd Street, 215-238-0630, standardtap.com.

Body Repair

Why everybody who's anybody (if that body is hurting) goes to physical therapist and trainer Joe Zarett: He fixes you. You can take the word of this magazine's editor, Bad-Back Larry Platt, who's gone to Zarett for that and for tendonitis and for general help pumping up (snicker) "the guns." Or you could ask the Penn tennis team, or Advanta CEO Dennis Alter, or über-lawyer Paul Rosen, or just about any Rittenhouse or Main Line weekend athlete who's suffered the agony of injury or aches of aging. The pain gets a body in the door of Zarett Rehabilitation Associates, and then restorative therapy leads to a workout routine.The come-for-rehab-stay-for-health drill is so popular that Zarett nearly doubled his patient load last year; this month, he unveils an expanded space that fits four times the state-of-the-art equipment - and way more bodies. >>> 520 South 19th Street, 215-731-1449, zarettrehab.com.

Stonework

We don't know what happened to your marble floor. Maybe it's natural wear and tear. Maybe it was your kids and a bowling ball. Whatever. The pros at Classic Marble and Stone Restoration - now in their 28th year in business - will fix it (and also your terrazzo countertop and the crumbling stone wall in the garden), leaving the work in prime condition and the work site pristine. >>> 204 Sussex Boulevard, Broomall, 610-356-4100, marblerestore.com.

Delivery Florist

Restaurateurs Audrey Claire Taichman and Kristina Burke are just two of the picky customers who swear by Fitler Square's Pure Design when it comes to blooms for their dining rooms. Here's why: Owner Michael Haschak is artistic, but self-effacing and laid-back. His work - edgy, clean, simple - stands out from the crowd. And his flowers - which he carefully handpicks every Monday - are arranged in charming vessels that you'll reuse. >>> Pure Design, 500 South 22nd Street, 215-546-6666.

Barton & Donaldson Ltd. Custom-Made Shirts >>> Sigh. Men these days. In better times, there were Bogie and Cary Grant and Dean Martin, in tuxes. Today, women get besneakered rappers as the kings of cool, and shirtless Texans as sex symbols. If it weren't for Clooney, we'd just give up. Well, Clooney and Don Donaldson, whose Center City shop still turns out beautiful custom-made dress shirts for men. That Donaldson has continued to find new devotees after 40 years in business gives us hope that men are realizing how far a little old-fashioned quality goes toward sexy. (See: Cary Grant.) And, guys, ask any of the shop's clients: Nothing beats the feeling of wearing something that was literally made to fit you - to say nothing of the way you look. (Dapper!) >>> 1635 Chancellor Street, 215-546-2324.

Classic Cars

We know. Even though it's corroded and shot through with rust, that 1954 Jaguar is still your baby, your favorite someday-hobby, if you ever find the time. Well, the guys at Ragtops & Roadsters have the time, and 135 years of combined experience working on British and special-interest autos. And these fellas offer such detailed records and estimates that it's almost like you're working right there with them. >>> 203 South 4th Street, Perkasie, 215-257-1202, ragtops.com.

Gem Cleaners Dry Cleaner >>> Tom Vecchione, owner of Mount Airy's Gem Cleaners for 12 years (ever since his father passed, and he owned it for 58 years before that), is the man to whom you send the clothes you want to have forever. Prices run higher than at most cleaners, but most cleaners don't return that vintage Chanel suit looking - we swear! - better than ever, and can't take the white coat drenched in tomato sauce and make it gleaming-new. And not only is he a miracle-worker; he's a miracle-worker who does pickup and delivery. >>> 546 Carpenter Lane, 215-848-6190.

Pet ... Everything

Whatever your pet needs might be, PhilaPets.com probably provides them. Puppy playdates? Check. Administering medicine? Check. Overnight stay? You bet. The initial appointment is crazy-thorough, and the staff is well-trained, punctual, and full of animal lovers. Plus, the website has a super-cute "client" picture gallery. (Check out Bud the iguana.) >>> PhilaPets.com.

Alternative to Modern Medicine

In 2006, Swarthmore resident Phyllis Bookspan gathered a homeopathic physician, a nutrition counselor, a holistic RN, a couples therapist, a Reiki master, and a slew of yoga and Pilates teachers to create holistic wellness center Ryah. The focus here is on a healthy mind-body connection and preventative health care, so instead of pills and pinpricks, they set you on the path to good health with a nutrition consultation, a chance to vent about his mother for 30 minutes, and then a massage. (Beats a flu shot, no?) >>> 424 East Elm Street, Conshohocken, 610-834-1551, ryahyoga.com.

Kids

Edited by Sandy Hingston, with reporting by Victor Fiorillo, Vicki Glembocki, Ashley Primis and Christine Speer.

An enchanting princess parlor, the tutor to get Junior into Penn, and inside the heart (thump-thump) of the Best Exhibit Ever

Playground

Smith Memorial Playground & Playhouse in Fairmount Park, 109 years young, has just undergone serious renovations, with a new labyrinth and a refurbished giant slide, plus a renovated playhouse in the works. A city treasure. >>> East Fairmount Park, 33rd and Oxford streets, 215-765-4325, smithplayhouse.org.

Babysitter
