The University of Pennsylvania doesn't exactly advertise the fact (and the website is downright antediluvian), but if you know where to look, Penn offers kids lessons in everything from fencing to music to gymnastics, plus a wide range of summer camps (animation, nanotechnology, anthropology ... ). >>> 3451 Walnut Street, 215-898-5000, summeratpenn.upenn.edu.

New Toy Line

Wallingford mom Martina McConnon hates, hates, hates plastic toys for the space they take up in your house, in your yard, then in landfills. So she found a German company that makes really cool white cardboard toys and started her own company, Creative Toyshop, to market them. There are sturdy, button-cute steamships, race cars, airplanes and dinosaurs for as little as $6.99 apiece, and more elaborate villas, palaces, treehouses and forts that top out at $24.99. (Cheap!) Pre-cut, easy to assemble, ready for kids to color with paint or markers ... and they're recyclable. Thanks, Martina. >>> Creativetoyshop.com.

Music Class

Anything taught by dynamic Penn grad Marcia Goldschmidt Kratz of the Kids' Music Round outposts in Cherry Hill and Mount Laurel. "Extraordinary," one mom raves. "She's not afraid to dump a million toys on the floor and let them play, and the kids get to strum her guitar, and she knows every single name by the end of the first class." >>> 856-278-0473, kidsmusicround.com.

Dance School

At Premiere Dance Studio in Pottstown, co-owner Patti Croner is the mother and wife of Lifetime's Your Mama Don't Dance reality show winners Noelle and Doug Croner - and this is where Noelle learned her moves. >>> 1494 North Charlotte Street, Pottstown, 484-945-0550, danceatpremiere.com.

Outing With Mom

Longwood Gardens. Thinking garden clubs and blue-haired old ladies? Try fireworks fountain displays, a new indoor children's garden, glam treehouses to explore, the chance to build a tree fort, and ice-cream concerts. >>> 1001 Longwood Road, Kennett Square, 610-388-1000, longwoodgardens.org.

Outing With Dad

Nicholas Smith Trains, in Broomall, has been cuckoo for choo-choos for 99 years. Great train displays, every imaginable brand, and a toy shop, too. >>> 2343 West Chester Pike, Broomall, 610-353-8585, nstrains.com.

Mom Hang

The Friday morning New Moms Group at Ali's Wagon in Fairmount is so well-attended, they have to beg you to leave your stroller at home. >>> 2017 Fairmount Avenue, 215-787-0611, aliswagon.com.

Future Nobel Prize-Winner Shop

Spectrum Scientifics owner Matt Kriebel is seriously into geek toys - and unrepentant about it. He's filled his shop with telescopes, chemistry sets, robotry, meteorology devices, and a host of other stuff that makes science seem fun. Snap up a baking-soda submarine. You know you want it. >>> 4403 Main Street, Manayunk, 215-667-8309, spectrum-scientifics.com.

Jump-Start for Your Future Reality-TV Star

A whole shop full of tiaras, magic wands and crystal slippers awaits at Little Fairy Godmother, plus princess-themed birthday-party packages with makeup, hair styling, manicures and runway fashion shows for your princess and friends. Tyra, is that you? >>> 613 Bethlehem Pike, Glenside, 215-402-9474, littlefairygodmothers.com.

New Destination

The three-times-the-size reincarnation of the Please Touch Museum in Fairmount Park's Memorial Hall is the best marriage ever of site - a civic white elephant left over from the 1876 Centennial Exhibition - and content. It doesn't open till October, but when it does, you'll find new attractions such as a replica arm and torch of the Statue of Liberty (assembled, full-size, out of toys and trash), flying machines, the historic Woodside Park Dentzel Carousel, and a down-the-rabbit-hole Wonderland with a maze and riddles, plus familiar favorites like the SEPTA bus, at the breathtaking new digs. >>> 4231 North Concourse Drive, 215-963-0667, pleasetouchmuseum.org.

Place to Buy Sneakers

The new Philadelphia Premium Outlets, which are actually (ahem) in Limerick. Outlets for Nike, Adidas, Reebok, Skechers, Pumas, Keds ... you get the picture. >>> 18 West Lightcap Road, Limerick, 610-495-9000, phillypremiumoutlets.com.

Accessories and Clothing Shop

Scarlet Fiorella has the cutest tees, raincoats, lunch pails and backpacks. Evah. >>> 113 South 13th Street, 215-922-1955, scarletfiorella.com.

Comedian for Kids

The Great Holtzie bills himself as "the only actual kids' comedian in the United States," and it's true: He's like Steve Martin for five-year-olds, complete with zany props, help from the audience, and cultural references for the kindergarten set. Parents think he's cool, too. Terrific for parties. >>> 267-879-0090, thegreatholtzie.com.

Summer Camp

At day sessions or overnight weekly stays at the Summer Music Programs at Harcum College, kids 11 to 17 are assigned to a rock, jazz or classical music group according to aural interests. They practice every day, choose a songlist and band name, record a CD at a professional studio, and put on a culminating concert complete with sound system and lights. You can also sign the whole band up! Rockin' the house for 15 years. >>> 610-526-6114, summermusicprograms.com.

Way to Keep Your Teens Off the Streets

Studio LuLoo in Oaklyn rents everything that teen wannabe rockers need to put on a show - venue, sound system, lighting - and puts on free coffeehouse concerts for parents and kids Tuesdays at noon, and has cool open-mike sessions on Tuesday nights for the whole family. >>> 916 White Horse Pike, Oaklyn, 856-428-4444, myspace.com/studiolulooartscenter.

The Franklin Institute Science Museum Place to Spend a Rainy Day >>> Maybe it's because most of us first visit in fourth grade, when we're just awakening to the wonders of the opposite sex, and whom Jill or Bruce sits with on the bus ride over is suddenly of vital interest. And then we arrive, giddy from the fact that we're playing hooky, and wander through the giant heart in the semi-dark, giggling and nervous, following close behind Bruce or Jill while the thump-thump, thump-thump resounds in our ears and chests, and what's meant to be a science exhibit somehow becomes erotically charged, so that love and longing and this heart and our hearts (thump-thump! Thump-thump!) are forever entangled, leaving generations of Philadelphians with a misty nostalgia for an oversize fiberglass organ. >>> 222 North 20th Street, 215-448-1200, fi.edu.

Party Venue

Kix & Giggles Children's Playland, in the Great Northeast, features a foam forest, spiral slides, a rock wall, two moon bounces, a web bridge ... and every Wednesday, from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., owners Frederick and Nicole Rabena, whose daughter Isabella has Down syndrome, let special-needs kids play free. >>> 9356 Old Bustleton Avenue, 215-677-4140, kixandgiggles.com.

Antidote for Colic

Metropolitan Moms, a social resource for moms and moms-to-be, offers mother-and-child classes like digital photography, chocolate tastings, stroller walking tours of the city, and private showings of collections at the Art Museum - with on-site child care. >>> 215-667-8977, metropolitanmoms.com.

SAT Tutor

Avery Snyder, founder and director of Educational Services, with offices in Wayne, Wyndmoor and Kennett Square. Average increase: 241 points. 'Nuff said. >>> 610-687-0627, prepwithes.com.

Breast-Feeding Resource

Amazing Newborn, run by a certified lactation consultant, has everything you need (including advice) when you want to nurse. Terrific for baby gifts that go beyond onesies and bibs. >>> 4019 Skippack Pike, Skippack, 610-584-6111, amazingnewborn.com.

Extracurricular

Owner Steve Mountain calls his Summit Sports Training Centers "learning schools" for athletes. That his students range from 'tweens and teens of varying skills to the Sixers is a testament to just how good a teacher this guy is. He focuses not on the winning, but on creating more focused, balanced athletes. Whether your kid wants a shot at being an All-American or just to finally make the team, Mountain and staff train him - literally - with the pros, in small groups where everyone works on the same skills (with age-appropriate adjustments). The third and newest outpost in Villanova is the best of the bunch, packed with state-of-the-art equipment (hockey treadmills!), but you'll still be most impressed by the change you'll see in your kid's skills - and in your kid. >>> 789 East Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, 610-525-2300; 1490 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, 856-216-9090; 700 Lawrence Road, West Chester, 610-436-1600; summitsportstc.com.

Penn's Museum of Anthropology and Archaeology Brush With Mortality >>>The collections here span the world, but it's the mummies that kids remember. For many of us, this is where we first saw dead people - and though they might be shriveled, they're undeniably human, somebody, a guy just like you, whose stomach probably rumbled at lunchtime, and now he's here in this glass case, and you're staring at him, which is really creepy, because, you know, he's been dead for, like, 5,000 years, and they pulled his brain out of his head through his nose. >>> 3260 South Street, 215-898-4000, museum.upenn.edu.

The Children's Boutique Classic Kid's Store >>> For more than 40 years, this place has defied the chaining of Walnut Street, with a whimsical, fairy-tale atmosphere that makes any visit as memorable as, say, a trip to F.A.O. Here, you'll find preppy-classics from Italian designer Eddie Pen, booties from Ugg, jackets from Juicy, and a smattering of toys - the collectible kind, like gorgeous sit-in antique-replica fire trucks and Ferraris that are more Gatsby than Disney. >>> 702 Walnut Street, 215-732-2661, thechildrensboutique.com.

People and Power

Edited by Tom McGrath

The ultimate political dream team, the most devoted Phillies fan ever, and Stephen Colbert's local sidekick

Business Concept

We didn't go to business school and all, but we've heard that sex sells. Which is why the lovely ladies to your right are the nuts and bolts (or dare we say T&A?) of men's salon Style of Man's successful business plan. Owner Kathy Thomas unabashedly admits that her stylists are smokin', but claims it's more than their magazine-worthy looks-one stylist, Lauren Harris (pictured, center), actually is an FHM model-that keeps fellas coming back for more: They listen to girlfriend woes and suggest anniversary gifts, have easy-going, bubbly personalities, and always, always make guys laugh. Which is why, over the past 20 years, SofM has become a rite of passage. >>> Shops at Liberty Place, 1625 Chestnut Street, 215-561-2887; 4448 Main Street, Manayunk, 215-487-2820; 1007 Orange Street, Wilmington, 302-984-1902; styleofman.com.

Local Radio Show

WXPN's Funky Friday. From 5 to 7 p.m. every Friday, the whitest station in America parties like it's 1979. The perfect yuppie segue into the weekend.

Sports Radio Personality

Or maybe that should be sports radio non-personality, since there are days when we wonder whether WIP's wonderfully apathetic Al Morganti is even registering a pulse. The morning show co-host-who years ago masterminded the jump that he and Inquirer buddy Angelo Cataldi made from print to radio-is the perfect low-key complement to the loudmouthed Cataldi. In fact, his refusal to get riled about nearly anything lends some much-need perspective to the ridiculous arguments that break out on the show. Whatever. It's just sports.

Most Patient Woman in Radio

The Preston & Steve Show's Kathy Romano puts up with all the wisecracks, hijinx, and generally ridiculous (and hilarious) behavior of her on-air buddies, and she does it with grace and charm (not to mention her own occasional zaniness). God bless you, Kathy-a lesser woman might have blown her brains out by now.

TV Newscast

None. Are we the only ones who've basically stopped watching? (Judging by the slowly deflating ratings, apparently not.) The Web, wi-fi and the 24-hour news cycle have finally finished what two decades of it-bleeds-it-leads journalism started: making local TV news utterly irrelevant.

TV Weather Person

Ignore that previous item, Kathy Orr. We still think you're swell.

TV Performance

Joe Torsella and Stephen Colbert. The highlight of Pennsylvania's star turn in the presidential primaries was Torsella giving the Colbert Report host a televised tour of the Constitution Center (where he's president and CEO). Torsella was not only the perfect straight man, but the two got into a hilarious mock wrestling match when Colbert repeatedly tried to sneak his book into various exhibits. Civics hasn't been this funny since Ricky Mariano was on City Council. See Phillymag.com/colbert.

Local TV Show

Daily News Live. For some reason, we just can't get enough of a bunch of ugly sportswriters sitting around talking about mediocre sports teams.

College Coach

It took heart and balls for Fran Dunphy to trade his sweet gig coaching hoops at Penn for the far more challenging one at Temple, but in his second season Dunphy put his stamp on the program, winning the Atlantic 10 championship and returning the Owls to the NCAA tournament.

Pro Coach

He looks more like a rising young associate at a Center City law firm than like a hockey coach, but John Stevens got his team to play hard when it counted. Tough call between him and the Sixers' Mo Cheeks for best coach, but the Flyers' unexpected run to the conference finals tips the scales in favor of Stevens.

Attempt to Stave Off Extinction

Ads are down, circulation is down, influence is down. But editor Bill Marimow and his Inquirer team continue to fight the good fight with limited resources. Here's hoping they prevail; Philly will be poorer without a proper paper.

Part-Time Philadelphian

Though he last played for the Sixers 16 years ago, Charles Barkley still keeps a home on the Main Line; in the summers, he's here, bludgeoning area golf courses and eating at Chops steakhouse in Bala Cynwyd. When he's not here or at his house in Phoenix, he can be found on TV, where he's become the best and most entertaining talking head in the world of sports.

Heist of Fund-Drive Dollars

WHYY president and CEO Bill Marrazzo was already one of the nation's highest-paid public broadcasting execs-despite leading a station that defines mediocrity (and that's being generous). Now it seems that Mr. Bill is going to receive a lump-sum payment next summer of at least $280,000-on top of his already lofty salary. Remember that next time WHYY holds one of its beg-a-thons-and keep your checkbook closed.

Sequel to Voters Electing Michael Nutter

Voters not electing Johnny Doc. Okay, people, this marks two consecutive years that you've done the right thing. What the hell's going on around here?

Champions for a Cause

Chase and Jen Utley. The new It Couple. They aren't just young, hot and hyper-talented-they've committed enormous time, energy and money to protecting Philly's abandoned and injured pets. (See page 116.)

Self-Promotional Newspaper Stunt

The Philadelphia Gay News. When Barack Obama declined the paper's interview requests (as he did with local gay media around the country), Mark Segal and Co. ran blank space where Obama's words should have gone. Cheap? Silly? Self-aggrandizing? All of the above. But in an era of increasing newspaper irrelevance, it got attention, made a point, and achieved its purpose: At press time, Segal was in talks with the Obama camp, who wanted to set up an interview.

Op-Ed Columnist

Trudy Rubin's warnings in the Inquirer about the folly of the Iraq war back in 2003 came off as a little schoolmarmish, but history has shown her to be absolutely correct. We hope Obama and McCain are reading her latest stuff on Iran.

Blog

Penned by Daily News staffer Will Bunch, Attytood is practically the granddad of local blogs. (Bunch started it in 2005.) It continues to offer a thoughtful liberal perspective on national and local politics.

Metro Columnist

The Inky's Monica Yant Kinney hit her stride earlier this year with a series of columns on electricians union boss Johnny Doc and his run for State Senate. And she did it while expecting her second kid. (Probably a lucky thing-not even a Local 98 goon would take a baseball bat to a pregnant lady.)

Most Fitting Legacy of the Street Administration

The much-scaled-back plan for city-wide wi-fi. To recap: Excitement and high hopes at the beginning, crushing disappointment by the end.

New City Council Members

Maria QuiÃ±ones-SÃ¡nchez and Bill Green have different styles-he's brash and ballsy, she's a quiet collaborator who does her homework-but they're both refreshing new voices.

Sportswriter

Jason Weitzel is the man behind Beer Leaguer, the best Phillies blog out there. (Find it at Beerleaguer.typepad.com.) Great mix of analysis, detailed info that obsessive Phillies fans die for (including coverage of the team's minor league system), and fairly intelligent comments from diehard fans.

Sports Executive

Billy King. It took a lot of patience, but the moves made by the Sixers president finally coalesced into a young, hungry, entertaining, and definitely on-the-rise ball club. Hey, Ed Snider, we say it's time to give this man a raise and possibly-

Worst Firing

Billy King. Never mind, Ed.

Phillie

Pat Burrell. If he continues to be as productive as he's been for the past 150 ball games, Burrell could end up as one of the most beloved players in Phillie history-a guy who stoically withstood several seasons' worth of boos before turning his game around. If there's anything Philly loves more than a winner, it's a loser who knows he's a loser but keeps fighting and turns into a winner, even though secretly he might still be kind of a loser. (See: Balboa, Rocky.)

Eagle

Brian Westbrook. Please. Don't. Get. Hurt.

Sixer

Say "4.3" around the typical NBA locker room, and most of the players will think you're talking about their assists-per-game average or the number of women by whom they've fathered kids. But 4.3 was Thaddeus Young's high-school GPA, and in his rookie season he showed, with his smarts and athletic ability, that he's a player worth watching.

Step Forward For Race Relations

Obama's race speech at the Constitution Center. Historic.

Reminder That We Still Have a Lot of Stepping Forward to Do

Indicted casino licensee Louis DeNaples's comment: "To me, all black people look alike." Sigh.

Fun Couple I

Jocelyn Kirsch and Edward Anderton (a.k.a. Bonnie and Clyde). Oh, to be young, good-looking, and in possession of other people's Social Security numbers.

Fun Couple II

Jim Matthews and Bruce Castor. The two Republican Montco commissioners loathe each other so much that Matthews-who once said Castor's ego is so big "it could float the Titanic"-turned his back on his running mate and made a governing alliance with Democrat Joe Hoeffel.

Fun Couple III

Chris Matthews and Arlen Specter. That could be the matchup for U.S. Senate in 2010-at least, if you believe the comments the Hardball host (and brother of Jim) has been making lately. And if you don't think it would be something to watch, just check out this quote from Matthews, as he postponed an interview with the New York Times's Mark Leibovich: "I promised a bunch of Koreans I'd get my picture taken with them, so that's where I'm going. I'll be right back." Oh please God, let it happen.

Sports Announcer

No disrespect to Harry Kalas (who's a legend) or Tom McCarthy (said to be Harry's heir apparent), but the best way to catch a Phillies game is on the radio (1210 AM), with 36-year-old Scott Franzke calling the action. His laid-back style and wry sense of humor remind of us of Fox's Joe Buck.

Phillie Phanatic Sports Mascot >>> There have been years-entire decades, almost-when the Phillie Phanatic was the only reason to take yourself out to the ball game. Thankfully, that's not the case these days, but our love for the big green furry guy is stronger than ever. From his debut in 1977 (the Phillies' answer to the San Diego Chicken) all the way up to today (he has his own MySpace page), the Phanatic has shown spirit, spunk, a sense of humor, and the ability to look good even while not wearing pants. Indeed, he now transcends the team he represents. The Phillies could leave town tomorrow, but you, Phanatic, are a Philadelphian for the ages.

Fun & Games

Edited by Victor Fiorillo, with reporting by Christy Speer and Jess Remo.

The coolest new reason to hit A.C., the hottest burlesque show in the U.S., and a foolproof place to find love in the city (or get buzzed trying)

Kitschy Fun

Grudge races, Mustang drag races, motorcycle races, $25,000 amateur races, classic car races, motorcross ... And that's just this month at Atco Raceway, 30 minutes over the Ben Franklin. >>> 1000 Jackson Road, Atco, 856-768-2167, atcorace.com.

Highbrow Fun

Since 1986, local composer and Temple grad Andrea Clearfield has hosted monthly salons in her Center City loft, featuring an array of talent that can best be described as eclectic. Case in point: At the September 28th salon (she's taking a break for the summer), your $10 suggested donation gets you a violinist who has performed at Carnegie Hall, an Eastern European female a cappella group, twin-brother folk musicians, a couple of jazz pianists ... and that's not even half the lineup. If you want in, e-mail aclearfi@aol.com for an invite.

Movie Theater

In the late '90s, the Ambler Theater seemed destined for the wrecking ball. But $5 million in renovations later, the 1928 cinema has been transformed into a modern movie palace. Owners preserved much of its architectural glory (terra-cotta tiles, a dramatic proscenium arch, a 30-foot neon replica of the original sign), and overhauled the rest with plush new seats, state-of-the-art technology, and creative programming that includes not only art-house fare and the occasional first-run blockbuster, but also an impressive repertory lineup. This month, look for Blue Velvet, The Maltese Falcon and Annie Hall. >>> 108 East Butler Avenue, Ambler, 215-345-7855, amblertheater.org.

Frugal Culture

That declining portfolio doesn't mean you can't enjoy a night of high art. The Kimmel Center offers day-of $10 rush tickets for most events, as well as free performances in its Commonwealth Plaza. Theater buffs should sign up for Theatre Alliance's e-mail list, which tips you off to discounts on some of the best shows in town. >>> Kimmelcenter.org; theatrealliance.org.

Nostalgic Fun

Remember a time, long before Wii and Guitar Hero, when flipping a little silver ball around a pinball table was enough to entertain us? Truth is, pinball is still a whole lot of fun - for you and the kids - though it's practically impossible to find a machine in good working order these days. But Montgomery County's Pinball Parlour - about a half-hour north of King of Prussia - has dozens, including 1981's Hyperball, 1964's Zig Zag, and the 1990s favorite The Addams Family. Six bucks gets you unlimited play for one hour. >>> 808 Allentown Road, Earlington, 215-723-5505, pinball-parlour.com.

New Weekend Destination

It's not just that the Borgata's new Water Club hotel is cool and clean and crisp by Atlantic City standards (it is) - it's that the 43-story addition to the five-year-old casino resort is so luxe and lovely, it's like a little stretch of South Beach magically moved to the Jersey Shore. Consider: Each of the 800 rooms features a water view and 400-thread-count sheets; a staff of 800 caters to your every need (nightly bed turndowns, fresh newspapers brought to the pool, room service cuisine by chef Geoffrey Zakarian); five immaculately kept pools - indoor and out - are gorgeous and inviting; and the Immersion spa offers, among other services, a blissful four-handed massage (see page 130) and what may be the most gratifying facial you'll ever have (ask for Irina). And if by chance you tire of all the blissful calm, you're connected by the shop-filled walkway to the Borgata's casino and top-notch restaurants. >>> 1 Renaissance Way, Atlantic City, 800-800-8817, thewaterclubatborgata.com.

Place to Find Love I

Romance has been known to bloom over glasses of merlot at the Wine School of Philadelphia. (True story: Founder and instructor Keith Wallace met his girlfriend at one of his courses.) Student ages range from mid-20s to 50s (though Wallace says most would-be oenophiles are in their 30s), and reasonable prices bring in a decent range of people. And hey, even if you don't find your soulmate, you'll leave with a new understanding of wine ... which will impress future dates. >>> 2006 Fairmount Avenue, 800-817-7351, winelust.com.

Place to Find Love II

Who really meets anybody worthwhile at a bar? To find someone fun, sign up for one of Meet Market Adventures' singles outings. Sure, everyone looks better after a few martinis, but Meet Market's fencing classes and rock-climbing excursions show you what the potential parent of your children is really made of. >>> 877-688-MEET, meetmarketadventures.com.

Place to Indulge Your Inner Board-Game Nerd

If you haven't already memorized the two-letter and q-without-u word lists, do so before heading to the Philadelphia Scrabble Club's weekly Wednesday-night games. These players are fierce, with individual scores regularly topping 600. >>> PIC Center, 42nd and Locust streets, 215-983-8662, phillyscrabble.com.

Billiard Hall

Twenty immaculately kept tables, 7,000 square feet of roominess, a 52-inch TV and fireplace for lounging, and a friendly but still fiercely competitive crowd make the recently renovated Classique Billiards perfect for channeling your inner Eddie Felson. (Remember The Hustler?) Preferably without the alcoholic girlfriend and heartbreak. >>> 275 Schuylkill Road, Phoenixville, 610-935-2939, classiquebillards.com.

Woody's Gay Hang >>> Since 1980, Woody's has attracted gay men galore (avec fag-hags). Downstairs, older gents hold court with wickedly strong drinks, while upstairs, young bucks cavort over Latin dancing (Thursdays), country-line (early Fridays), and the standard pulsating dance-club fare (late Fridays and Saturdays). Members of the gay intelligentsia have complained that lately, Woody's is soooo very yesterday. But judging by the never-ending crowds and the fact that it's the state's single largest purchaser of booze, this Gayborhood stalwart isn't going anywhere anytime soon. >>> 202 South 13th Street, 215-545-1893, woodysbar.com.

Roller Coaster

Picture yourself at the base of the PECO building. Then picture yourself being hurled straight up it at 128 mph, only to plummet back down the other side. Three-year-old Kingda Ka at Great Adventure is the tallest, fastest coaster on the planet - and 50 seconds of sheer terror. >>> Route 537, Jackson, 732-928-1821, sixflags.com.

Place for a Laugh

Nobody can touch the Borgata. With its reliably funny nightly Comedy Club lineup and ability to bring in heavy hitters, the place has single-handedly revived the stand-up experience in the region. This month: Chris Rock (August 15th), Andrew Dice Clay (August 22nd-23rd) and Carlos Mencia (August 31st). >>> 1 Borgata Way, Atlantic City, 609-317-1000, theborgata.com.

Bar Competition

Maybe we're just too old for Quizzo and Bob and Barbara's Drunken Spelling Bee. Lately we've been liking the monthly First Person Story Slams at L'Etage. Audience members from all age brackets and backgrounds sign up to tell five-minute true stories - some hilarious, some tearjerker - about their lives that are in line with the night's theme, announced ahead of time. (The August 26th theme is "Worst Ever.")Judges score for content and presentation, and the winner gets bragging rights and the chance to compete in November's Story Slam Championship. >>> 624 South 6th Street, 215-592-0656, firstpersonarts.org.

Piano Bar

We're not sure what's so hard about running a piano bar, but with Jolly's gone and Cascamorto just generally disappointing, it must be more difficult than we think. Thank God we still have Tavern on Camac, where the gay, straight and uncertain have been packing in for liquor-fueled sing-alongs for decades. >>> 243 South Camac Street, 215-545-0900, tavernoncamac.com.

Dive Bar

Though Fiume excels at being a dive (no phone, $3 beer-and-shot special, ramshackle decor), it also has 50 bottled beers, an impressive top-shelf bourbon selection, un-surly and smart bartenders who actually use said bourbon to create very respectable manhattans, and a friendly, diverse crowd. >>> 229 South 45th Street, 2nd floor.

Citizens Bank Park Date Night >>> We can't imagine how many of those kid-toting parents in the stands at Phillies games started out as hand-holding daters at the Vet. But the romance continues at Citizens Bank Park. >>> 1 Citizens Bank Way, 215-463-1000, phillies.mlb.com.

Reason to Take a Walk

Landmark Tours, brought to us by the Philadelphia Society for the Preservation of Landmarks, offers fascinating architectural tours of not just historic downtown Philly, but also of Norristown, Haddonfield, Media and West Chester. The hour-and-a-half excursions cost a mere $10. >>> 215-925-2251, philalandmarks.org.

Guys' Night Out

Start with martinis (gin, of course) and hulking hunks of meat at old-school Saloon in the Italian Market, then head east to digest at boxing mecca New Alhambra for a little mano-a-mano. Finish the night over good scotch, Coronas (the cigars, not the insipid Mexican beer) and cheap laughs at Walnut Street's Mahogany, still the only smoking bar in Philly that you actually want to go to. >>> Saloon, 750 South 7th Street, 215-627-1811, saloonrestaurant.com. New Alhambra, 7 West Ritner Street, 215-755-0611, newalhambra.com. Mahogany, 1524 Walnut Street, 215-732-3982, phillycigarbar.com.

Girls' Night Out

First, poolside massages at Harrah's Red Door Spa, then shopping at - where else? - the Pier Shops at Caesars (BCBG, Bottega Veneta and more), then back to your modern digs at the Chelsea, A.C.'s newest, coolest, casino-less boutique hotel. Follow sushi at Borgata's new Japanese spot Izakaya, with what is still the best party around - Murmur. >>> Red Door Spa and the Pool, 777 Harrah's Boulevard, 609-441-5333, reddoorspas.com. Pier at Caesars, 1 Atlantic Ocean, 609-345-3100, thepiershopsatcaesars.com. The Chelsea, 111 South Chelsea Avenue, 866-393-3285, thechelsea-ac.com. Izakaya and Murmur, 1 Borgata Way, 609-317-1000, theborgata.com.

Chickie's & Pete's Place to Watch the Game >>> There's nothing like surrounding yourself with the hundreds of Philly fans crammed into Chickie's & Pete's, all running on cold beer, crack-like crab fries and, above all, a gut-wrenching, heart-pounding, all-consuming desire for victory. And while we've all known years of agonizing defeats, at this bar, we also know there will always be lots of fellow fans with whom to commiserate - and, occasionally, celebrate. >>> Five area locations; chickiesandpetes.com.

Sexy Fun

Strip clubs are out. Not only is the Peek-A-Boo Revue the region's most sophisticated way to package good old-fashioned T&A, but according to the judges of Miss Exotic World 2008, it's the best damn burlesque troupe in the world. Catch this slow, sultry brand of striptease at World Cafe Live on September 20th. >>> Peekaboorevue.com.

Weekend Road Trip

They say Pennsylvania is Pittsburgh and Philadelphia with Mississippi in the middle, but Central PA has its charms. Put the top down and head north on Route 61 in Reading. Stretch your legs with an abandoned coal-mine tour in Ashland; go to Centralia to see smoke seep from the 47-year-old underground fire. Stop in Pottsville for the Yuengling tour (and a beer), and finish the day on a wooden roller coaster at retro Knoebels amusement park. >>> Pioneer Coal Mine Tour, 19th and Oak streets, Ashland, 570-875-3850, pioneertunnel.com. Underground fire, Route 61, Centralia. Yuengling Brewery, 5th and Mahantongo streets, Pottsville, 570-622-4141, yuengling.com. Knoebels Amusement Resort, 391 Knoebels Boulevard, Elysburg, 800-487-4386, knoebels.com.

Food and Drink

Edited by April White, with reporting by Victor Fiorillo, Joy Manning, Marnie Old, Ashley Primis, Bridget Salmons and Christine Speer

Luscious cupcakes, Philly's most scrumptious chef, and killer cheesesteaks in your 'hood

Sliders

Blue Sage proves that expensive kobe beef isn't the key to Philly's new favorite sandwich, the slider. (Besides, who could top Barclay Prime at its own beefy game?) At this Bucks County veg spot, meaty hunks of grilled eggplant and zucchini are topped with crisp baby arugula leaves, sprinkled with a salty Maytag blue cheese, and sandwiched in a miniature sesame brioche roll generously coated with the house-made chipotle mayo. All that and the accompanying mound of cooked-to-order yucca fries will satisfy even the staunchest carnivore. >>> Blue Sage Vegetarian Grille, 772 Second Street Pike, Southampton, 215-942-8888, bluesagegrille.com.

Wine List

Since 1990, Ristorante Panorama's wine list has been one of the best in the country - and one of Philadelphia's best-kept secrets. How could Philly wine drinkers overlook the bar's astonishing wall of wine, a high-tech preservation system that allows Panorama to offer 120 wines by the full glass and in tasting portions? The bar is tucked discreetly into the Penn's View Hotel on a quiet Old City block, but that's no excuse for bypassing the immense Italian and international offerings, all at memorably modest prices. >>> 14 North Front Street, 215-922-7600, pennsviewhotel.com.

New Chef

Philly has a reputation for losing its brightest rising stars to cities with bigger opportunities. But hometown girl Jennifer Carroll, chef de cuisine at 10 Arts in the Ritz-Carlton, proves that sometimes they bring their talent back home. After a five-year run at Eric Ripert's Le Bernardin, Carroll jumped at the chance to helm his new outpost here. The chefs worked together to develop a Philly-flavored menu that Carroll executes with formidable skill. Dishes range from the unpretentious and craveable pretzel bites served with house-made dips to the sorts of elegant seafood preparations that have made Le Bernardin so famous. (Try the Pennsylvania trout in brown butter sauce.) Carroll could have landed a job almost anywhere. We're ecstatic she's back in Philly. >>> 10 South Broad Street, 215-523-8273, 10arts.com.

Brunch

There's bacon-and-eggs-and-pancakes brunch, and then there's brunch at Lacroix. Here, brunch means an expansive dining-room buffet of foie gras ganache, fennel ceviche, oysters mignonette, scallop sausage and pork belly fried rice. Meanwhile, in the kitchen, carving stations and chafing dishes fan out, offering roasted capon, lamb gyro, individual frittata, tomato and lobster bruschetta ... There are more dishes than anyone could sample in one visit to this gastronomic playground - but don't let that stop you from trying. >>> 210 West Rittenhouse Square, 215-790-2533, lacroixrestaurant.com.

New Restaurant, City

Before opening Zahav, restaurateur Steve Cook and chef Michael Solomonov took the kitchen crew on a tour of Israel to inspire the cooking. Their excitement is contagious. The pan-global cuisine of Israel, Solomonov's native country, is shockingly simple for fare so delicious, and while there's a laid-back vibe in Zahav's airy dining room, where meals are served family-style, the food is flawless. Passion is palpable in every bite of the crisp, bright salads, creamy hummus and earthy skewers that make up a meal at the city's best new restaurant. >>> 237 St. James Place, 215-625-8800, zahavrestaurant.com.

New Restaurant, 'Burbs

Maia is easily the Main Line's most anticipated venue of the decade. (We have been expecting it to open since early '07.) Buzz surrounding the restaurant's ambitious organic-European-Nordic menu was exceeded only by the scope of its concept: It's a cafe, a market, a bistro, a meeting venue and a fine-dining restaurant. When chefs (and brothers) Patrick and Terence Feury finally opened the doors this summer, the restaurant delivered, from the cafe's lattes and pastries, to the beer and charcuterie at the informal bistro, to the all-out feast in the seafood-focused fine-dining restaurant. >>>789 East Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, 610-527-4888, tastemaia.com.

Classic

Marra's Everyday Pizza >>> East Passyunk Avenue has seen a dramatic revitalization in recent years. But in the midst of welcome new shops, bars and restaurants, there's one place that should never change: Marra's has been serving the same recipes for thin-crust pizza since founder Salvatore Marra arrived in Philadelphia from Naples 80 years ago. Today, his grandchildren helm the brick oven (the restaurant's original, built from bricks imported from Mount Vesuvius), and the exterior was recently renovated, but the pies, with their slightly charred crusts and traditional toppings, still bring pure pizza nirvana. >>> 1734 East Passyunk Avenue, 215-463-9249, marras1.com.

Beer

The best beer around (and there are a lot of them) comes from a can. Sly Fox's brewers know that modern cans protect their pale German-style lager Pikeland Pils better than a bottle. We know that cans chill faster, the better for an afternoon spent relaxing with this seriously good brew. Its citrusy hops, malty barley core and bracing, bitter finish are sure to make you forget that other lager. >>> Available at Sly Fox Brewing Company, 519 Kimberton Road, Phoenixville, 610-935-4540, slyfoxbeer.com, and other area beer distributors.

New BYOB

Finally, a new BYOB with the polish to compete with the city's liquor-license holders. Husband/wife duo Gene and Amy Giuffi scrubbed up and remodeled the tiny Café Sud storefront before launching cash-only Cochon (translation: "pig"), with a menu of hearty French classics like a slow-braised pork shoulder topped with a runny poached egg, which has become the signature dish here. But even non-porcine preparations (like perfectly cooked scallops) show a deft hand at the stove reminiscent of the days when BYOBs were more famous for their food than the freedom from bar tabs. >>> 801 East Passyunk Avenue, 215-923-7675, cochonbyob.com.

Fried Chicken

The fried chicken search was an exhausting one, but dozens of legs, breasts and thighs later, BYOB Ms. Tootsie's Soul Food Cafe is the where-have-you-been-all-my-meals winner. Skip the Southern-sweet sides and head straight for the meat of the matter: A shatteringly crisp and pleasingly salty crust coats tender and juicy chicken. >>> 1314 South Street, 215-731-9045, kevenparker.net.

Bar Trend

Hate the pretentious pseudo-scientific word - mixologists - but love the drinks. This new class of talented and adventurous bartenders - Katie Loeb at Bella Vista's Chick's Café, Stephen Seibert at Old City's Amada, the crew at Midtown Village's Apothecary - is mixing up smart cocktails with the same careful attention to quality that we've long expected from the city's chefs.

Steakhouse

The imposing doors and dim entryway add to the exclusive vibe of Barclay Prime, the corner Rittenhouse steakhouse that feels novel no matter how many times you've been. But the food and service are what really send this steak place - in a chophouse-laden region - to the top of our list: attentive waiters, first-rate beef, and lick-the-plate sides, like creamed spinach and house-made tater tots. >>> 237 South 18th Street, 215-732-7560, barclayprime.com.

Indian

Our gratitude abounds for Bindi, Marcie Turney's sleek new Indian BYOB in Midtown Village. Her creative interpretations of traditional curries fill a gap in Philadelphia's international food scene with modernized, upscale Indian eats. Complex dried spice mixtures, ground daily, are an authentic - but not overheated - backdrop for inspired updates on vindaloos and masalas. >>> 105 South 13th Street, 215-922-6061, bindibyob.com.

Entrée

We loved Pif, David Ansill's now-defunct tiny French gem, but we might love "Pif Night" even more. Each Sunday (on hiatus until after Labor Day) at his current restaurant, Ansill, the chef resurrects Pif with a $45 three-course French prix-fixe menu that often includes the best dish we've tasted all year: Ansill's rack of lamb with potato galette. The perfectly cooked and tender lamb rests on a crisp-creamy potato pancake, and the whole dish is drizzled with lamb jus infused with rich bone marrow. It's homey, hearty comfort-food perfection. >>> 627 South 3rd Street, 215-627-2485, ansill-foodandwine.com.

BYOB

Le Bec-Fin meets the BYOB at Gilmore's, and we couldn't be happier with the odd marriage. The food - both classic and contemporary dishes - shows all the careful refinement you'd expect from a Perrier protégé, but the atmosphere is Wednesday-night-dinner relaxed. And the prices: There are entrées at Le Bec that cost more than Gilmore's weekday $35 four-course bistro menu. >>> 133 East Gay Street, West Chester, 610-431-2800, gilmoresrestaurant.com.

Small Plates

The small-plates trend is here to stay, despite those who decry the meager portions, inflated prices and lack of imagination of some tapas-takeoff restaurants. But no place executes small plates better than Supper. Supper's genius lies in its inherently American dishes. Sure, irresistible nibbles like Moroccan-spiced boneless chicken wings flaunt international influences, but their core of deliciousness is completely familiar. Ditto the ham and butter tartine, sea scallops with uni butter, and pork belly with lentils and wine sauce. Unlike less successful variations on tapas, these dainty dishes deliver real satisfaction. We guarantee you won't want a slice of pizza after dinner's over. >>> 926 South Street, 215-592-8180, supperphilly.com.

Restaurant Trend

Adding more seats to an already busy restaurant can overtax a kitchen, but we applaud this year's smart and smooth restaurant expansions - Osteria glassed in its outdoor patio, Tinto broke through a wall, and La Viola rented more space across the street - all designed to make diners more comfortable and reservations easier to score. Now, if only Talula's Table, that 12-seater in Kennett Square, would get into the expansion act ...

Restaurant, City

What's left to say in praise of Osteria, Marc Vetri and Jeff Benjamin's Italian gem that has, improbably, brought Center City nightlife to North Broad Street? Nothing. But we'll happily repeat our usual dinner order: the exuberant but exactingly cooked vegetable antipasto plate, a thin-crust pizza from the fiery brick oven, a quirky ceramic bowl filled with tangles of house-made candele pasta, and the bundino, that brilliant, sweet hazelnut-and-cream take on, yes, polenta. >>> 640 North Broad Street, 215-763-0920, osteriaphilly.com.

Restaurant, 'Burbs

Let's be honest. When someone raves about a BYOB in Conshohocken, next to the Great American Pub, you think: Sure, it's good ... for Conshohocken. That reaction is the only reason we can still get reservations at miniature Blackfish. Charles Roman's simple dining room and confident cooking - bouillabaisse with crusty bread, house-smoked salmon over a deep-fried egg - would earn raves in any neighborhood. >>> 119 Fayette Street, Conshohocken, 610-397-0888, blackfishrestaurant.com.

Farmers' Market

The farmers' market isn't a new phenomenon in Philadelphia - thank you, Food Trust and Farm to City, for years of neighborhood markets - but the Trust's year-old Headhouse Farmers' Market is the gold standard. Sunday morning finds the Headhouse Square shambles filled with local and delicious everything: Griggstown chicken potpie, sunflowers from Young's Garden, prosciutto-gruyère croissants from Wild Flower Bakery, and all the perfectly ripe produce you can carry in your canvas bag. >>> Sunday, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., 2nd and Lombard streets, thefoodtrust.org.

Cupcakes

Maki Evans and Heather Carter of Cupcakes Gourmet only have one location, in a nondescript Frazer strip mall, but the duo is whipping out cupcakes so sweet, they're worth the drive from anywhere: Sturdy cake in more than 20 flavors stands up to a heavenly, heavy buttercream icing made with real Madagascar bourbon vanilla and cream cheese. Just be sure to get enough to last you the ride home. >>> 288 Lancaster Avenue, Frazer, 484-318-8057, cupcakesgourmet.com.

Power Lunch

Yes, you'll still see members of the Old Guard noshing at the Palm, but the new game in town is at the sleeker, more intimate Capital Grille, where, as one local player puts it, "You don't have to have your caricature on the wall to belong." Look for the Mayor presiding over grilled salmon and diet Cokes (he saves the chardonnay for happy hour), Wachovia prez Hugh Long talking numbers as he downs a filet-topped Caesar, and indicted State Senator Vince Fumo, who of course has his own booth, where, we hear, he's laying off the red meat post-heart-attack in favor of the grilled chicken. >>> 1338 Chestnut Street, 215-545-9588, thecapitalgrille.com.

Dessert

Someone forgot to tell the pastry chef at Nineteen that this city lives on crème brÃ»lée and molten chocolate cake. An excellent oversight. Instead of the usual, finales here include dramatically deconstructed carrot cake, a delicate steamed lemon genoise (the result is halfway between a pudding and a cupcake), and a trippy take on the banana split. The banana crème brÃ»lée at the bottom is as close to classic as the menu gets. >>> Park Hyatt at the Bellevue, 200 South Broad Street, 19th floor, 215-790-1919, parkhyatt.com.

Tomato Pie

No disrespect to Sinatra - the name Tony Roni gives to its mozzarella-and-basil-topped version - but when it comes to tomato pie, basic is best, nowhere more so than here. The thin-crusted Originale is simply the tomato-iest tomato pie we've tasted. >>> 4504 City Avenue, 215-877-7664, tonyroni.com.

Gourmet Pizza

Not long ago, Osteria chef Jeff Michaud taught a pizza-making class. Ha! The only thing you need to know is this: If you want these thin, crisp, flavorful pizzas - ingredients include a special blend of Italian flours and a 650-degree wood-fired oven - you just have to go to Osteria. Topped with tender scallops and house-made sausage or bright tomatoes and creamy fresh mozz, these perfect pies will change the way you think about pizza. >>> 640 North Broad Street, 215-763-0920, osteriaphilly.com.

Butcher Shop

Main Line Prime isn't your everyday butcher shop - unless you're lucky enough to be eating richly marbled Duroc pork and gamey, grass-fed Jamison lamb for a Tuesday-night meal - but there's no better place to find luxury dinner-party meats, well chosen, well cared for and well cut, than Derek Davis's surprisingly unpretentious Main Line shop. >>> 18 Greenfield Avenue, Ardmore, 610-645-9500, mainlineprime.com.

Inventive Cocktails

How perfectly Philly: modern cocktails served up in an old-fashioned tin-ceiling taproom. At Chick's Café, you'll find mixologist Katie Loeb behind the bar - and behind the fresh and flavorful cocktail menu. Her house-made herb infusions and seasonal fruit syrups star in standout summer refreshers like the Provençal martini, a gin-based number laced with lavender syrup and grapefruit bitters, and the Front Stoop lemonade, spiked with gin and fragrant with Thai basil syrup. >>> 614 South 7th Street, 215-625-3700, chickscafe.com.

Steak

This fall will see an invasion of steakhouses in Philadelphia, already a carnivore heaven. But it's hard to believe the cow has anything better to offer than the enormous, lush porterhouse/T-bone combo on the menu at Rae. At well over two pounds (for $180), this slab of steak, sourced from Pennsylvania's justly famed Four Story Hill Farm and served with mounds of smoked onion rings and fingerling fries, can feed a whole table - though chef Daniel Stern reports that most people refuse to share. >>> Cira Centre, 2929 Arch Street, 215-922-3839, rae-restaurant.com.

Beer Bar

Teresa's Next Door is everything we want in a bar - great vibe, great beer, great food. The connoisseur's menu of little-known draft beers is as impressive and varied as the pages-long bottle list, so you'll find the perfect suds to wash down a dinner of crispy artichokes with a lemon vinaigrette, garlicky mussels, and cinnamon-rubbed oven-roasted wings. >>> 126 North Wayne Avenue, Wayne, 610-293-0119.

Wine Bar

There was a time when the words "wine bar" had negative, nose-in-the-air connotations. Then came Tria, with its casual approach to the grape. Fanciful, evocative descriptions make this wine list a pleasure to read, and careful editing ensures every wine on it - from the "zippy whites" to the "sociable reds" - is a pleasure to drink. Plus: Beer and cheese get the same loving treatment. >>> 123 South 18th Street, 215-972-8742, and 1137 Spruce Street, 215-629-9200; triacafe.com.

Chef

Marc Vetri. See "Best Restaurant, City," "Best Italian Restaurant" and "Best Gourmet Pizza."

Tapas

In 2005, Jose Garces brought the small-plates craze to Philadelphia with his flagship Spanish tapas outlet Amada. And three years later, his freshly sliced charcuterie and perfect tortilla EspaÃ±ola still rule the genre. Fans of this food have only multiplied over time; prime Saturday-night reservations are still booked six weeks out. >>> 217 Chestnut Street, 215-625-2450, amadarestaurant.com.

Appetizers

A multi-course meal at James is worth the splurge, but a low-key nosh in its classy lounge ranks as one of the city's top treats. The best taste of chef James Burke's talents: the seasonal canapés, a treasure trove likely to include miniature portions of soup, candied vegetables, ceviche, pÃ¢té and house-cured charcuterie. Other must-have apps include handmade pastas and artisanal cheeses. >>> 824 South 8th Street, 215-629-4980, jameson8th.com.

Milkshake

Tiny lunch counter Snow White proves that a milkshake doesn't need to be fancy-or expensive-to be delicious. Jack and Jill vanilla ice cream, chocolate syrup and Lehigh Valley Dairy milk are the only ingredients in the city's best black-and-white. The secret is the patient staff, who never rush things, mixing ingredients until they meld into a sweet and creamy shake. >>> 901 Chestnut Street, 215-569-0909.

Bagels

When Square residents reminisce about the bagels they used to get at Rittenhouse Market-small, chewy rounds a world away from the pillowy bagels popular these days-they're talking about Roling's. Thankfully, the hand-formed bagels can still be found in the bins at Roling's small basement bakery in Elkins Park-and early on Friday mornings at Maxx's Produce near Rittenhouse. >>> Roling's, 7848 Montgomery Avenue, Elkins Park, 215-635-5524. Maxx's Produce, 225 South 20th Street, 215-735-3644.

Yangming Chinese >>> Michael Wei at Main Line mainstay Yangming has consistently delivered sweet-and-spicy gunpowder shrimp, saucy sesame chicken and elaborate Peking duck-with a fork or chopsticks, no judgment-in a comfortable, take-the-parents setting that's been host to birthday, anniversary and graduation celebrations for more than 15 years. >>> 1051 Conestoga Road, Bryn Mawr, 610-527-3200, yangmingrestaurant.com.

Mexican

Xochitl is a delicious challenge to our notion of what Mexican food is, with dishes centered on lamb, duck and blood sausage, and innovative drinks with cilantro and ancho. But the charming Headhouse Square spot also gives diners the Mexican flavors they crave in killer margaritas, perfectly simple guac and crisp churros. >>> 408 South 2nd Street, 215-238-7280, xochitl-philly.com.

Cheese Shop

The options at Downtown Cheese rival any in the city, but it's the knowledgeable and sample-generous staff, led by opinionated owner Jack Morgan, that makes this a must-stop in both the Reading Terminal and Ardmore Farmers markets. >>> Reading Terminal Market, 12th and Arch streets, 215-351-7412, and Ardmore Farmers Market, Suburban Square, 120 Coulter Avenue, Ardmore, 610-649-8449.

Le Bar Lyonnais French >>> If you're a regular at Le Bec-Fin, this intimate space below the famed dining room has been your pre- (and post-) dinner cocktail destination for almost two decades. But even if your budget rarely allows for Le Bec, Le Bar Lyonnais is your entrée into a rarified world where you can hobnob with the city's classiest over champagne and escargots. >>> 1523 Walnut Street, 215-567-1000, lebecfin.com.

Chocolates

The reasons we can't resist Christopher Curtin's Éclat chocolates can be summed up in one bite: winey dark chocolate enrobes a deeply caramel center, the nutty sweetness sharpened with a touch of sea salt. >>> 24 South High Street, West Chester, 610-692-5206, eclatchocolate.com.

Cheese

Fans of Shellbark Hollow Farm's Dry Sharp Goat Cheese include brother-chefs Patrick and Terence Feury of Nectar and Maia, the cheesemongers at Di Bruno Bros., and Talula's Table owner Aimee Olexy. Add us to the list. This West Chester-produced cheese is well-balanced and smooth, with a slightly tangy flavor. >>> Di Bruno Bros., 1730 Chestnut Street, 215-665-9220, and 930 South 9th Street, 215-922-2876; dibruno.com. Talula's Table, 102 West State Street, Kennett Square, 610-444-8255, talulastable.com. Fair Food Farm Stand, Reading Terminal Market, 12th and Arch streets, 215-627-2029, white-dogcafefoundation.org.

Crabcake

Every morning at 4:30, Dan Redner, owner of Star of the Sea Seafood, drives from his West Berlin store to the seafood market on Packer to pick up the freshest domestic crabmeat for his superb, surprisingly healthy crabcakes. You probably already love this no-mayo cake-found at some Jersey Whole Foods and Shore faves like Sea Isle's Mike's Seafood-but we were thrilled to learn that the Redner recipe is available straight from the source, too. >>> 1004 Industrial Drive, West Berlin, 856-767-5474.

Sushi

It's the simplicity of the sashimi and sushi that has kept us coming back to Sagami for 30 years. In the low-ceilinged, utilitarian dining rooms of this BYOB, carefully sliced sashimi is served without pretense, and maki rolls are-most unfashionably-more about the fish than overwhelming sweet and spicy sauces. >>> 37 Crescent Boulevard, Collingswood, 856-854-9773.

Gourmet Store

The second outpost of Carlino's Specialty Foods, significantly larger and more ambitious than the original Ardmore location, can be overwhelming. But focus on the house-made stuff-fresh and frozen pastas and dozens of sauce options, plus soups, salad dressings, sausages, and an array of delicious antipasto-and you'll have the best-stocked pantry in the city. >>> 128 West Market Street, West Chester, 610-696-3788, carlinosmarket.com.

Upscale Outdoor Scene

In a city where dining alfresco generally means a table perched on a sidewalk three feet from moving cars, the traffic-free tranquility of Fairmount Park's Water Works Restaurant is like a mini vacation: a place to see the sunset, a place where people-watching is second to bird-watching, a place where even the Schuylkill is romantic. >>> 640 Water Works Drive, 215-236-9000, thewaterworksrestaurant.com.

Casual Outdoor Scene

Think about the best barbecue you ever hosted. Now pretend you made kick-ass jerk instead of burgers, and served fried beef patties instead of potato chips, and you've basically got the Jamaican Jerk Hut. The place is super-casual (a grassy lot on South Street with a deck and painted picnic tables), super-cheap (two people can sup for under $30) and super-fun (BYO coolers of beer; reggae on weekends). Plus: We're not kidding-kick-ass jerk. >>> 1436 South Street, 215-545-8644, jamaicanjerkhutinc.com.

Event

Even after the buzz wore off, it was clear that the 10-day-long debut of Philly Beer Week was a great success. If you weren't among the 15,000 who sipped their way through 300 brew-focused dinners, seminars and tastings, plan now for next year (March 6th-15th) and ensure that the city lives up to the festival's proud claim that Philly is, of course, "The best beer-drinking city in America." >>> Phillybeerweek.org.

Barbecue

The long lines of Friday-night takeout customers at Pig Daddy's are testament to the rightfully devoted following this three-year-old meat haven has earned for its slaw-slathered Kansas City-style pulled pork sandwiches, brisket, St. Louis spare ribs, succulent sides-like collards and CJ's BBQ Baked Beans-and bargain prices. >>> 693 Burmont Road, Drexel Hill, 610-622-6441, pigdaddysbarbecue.com.

Salad

Swallow's shaved fennel, mushroom and Parmesan salad starts with an intriguing texture: Each ingredient is shaved to transparency, then tossed with just enough lemon vinaigrette to marry the earthy and sweet flavors. >>> 1030 North American Street, 215-238-1399, swallowbistro.com.

Classic Cocktails

Southwark's long mahogany bar has a retro feel, and one sip of co-owner Kip Waide's way-back libations-think manhattans and Sazeracs-will have you toasting the good ol' days. Waide has amassed one of the area's most extensive selections of rye and gin to faithfully recreate the beverages of bygone eras. >>> 701 South 4th Street, 215-238-1888, southwarkrestaurant.com.

Wine

Locavores, take note: This juicy Chaddsford Pinot Noir 2006 delivers what you've been waiting for-local wine that doesn't taste local. Silky-textured and sheer, this lightweight $15 summer red is packed with lip-smacking red raspberry flavors and subtle peppery aromatics, perfect for alfresco dining. >>> Available at Chaddsford Winery, 632 Baltimore Pike, Chadds Ford, 610-388-6221, chaddsfordwine.com, and some Pennsylvania state stores.

Davio's Cheese-steak Spring Roll >>> It was way back in 2002 that Davio's David Boyle, on a whim, rolled up the heart of the Philly classic and dunked it into a deep fryer. His recipe-chopped steak, provolone, parm and Philadelphia cream cheese tucked inside a lightly fried, paper-thin crust-is so good, it's trademarked. >>> 111 South 17th Street, 215-563-4810, davios.com.

Food You Don't Know

The falooda at Palace at the Ben is, well, a noodle milkshake, an Indian dessert as obscure as it is tasty. Noodles and milk are combined with fragrant rose syrup and basil seeds for an odd but incredible dessert that requires a fork, a spoon and a straw. >>> 834 Chestnut Street, 267-232-5600, thepalaceattheben.com.

Classic Cake Bakery >>> Robert Bennett-you know his name from Le Bec-Fin, Le Patisserie, and his impressive cakes and chocolates-has reinvigorated this well-known South Jersey bakery. This year we'll celebrate our birthdays with tender shortbread, rich cheesecakes, decadent tiramisu and classic carrot cake. >>> 480 East Evesham Road, Cherry Hill, 856-751-5448, and 100 Hurffville-Cross Keys Road, Sewell, 856-262-7400; classiccake.com.

Service

After nearly six years running the Center City Palm, Chops owner Alex Plotkin knows how to treat his clientele, and he expects the same from his impeccably trained servers. They miss nothing. They explain the many specials expertly, make drinks appear at the perfect moment, attend to your every whim, and do all of this without your noticing. >>> 401 East City Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, 610-668-3400, chops.us.

Gastropub

Carolynn Angle's blackboard menu is pub-perfect, which makes you wonder why no other bar has managed to capture Standard Tap's flavors: garlicky pulled pork piled high on a rustic roll, a beet salad good enough to make you order seconds, and the city's best steak frites. >>> 901 North 2nd Street, 215-238-0630, standardtap.com.

Comfort Food

It's a Philly Mag tradition. The first snow of the season-or even flurries in the forecast-sends the staff to Jones for the unbeatable snow-day combination of tomato soup (here, thick but not too creamy, dressed up with a dot of basil oil) and buttery grilled cheese. >>> 700 Chestnut Street, 215-223-5663, jones-restaurant.com.

Newly Arrived Chain

The sorta-fast-food concept that is Pei Wei, the quick-serve version of popular PF Chang's, is a new favorite for rushed weeknight dinners or anytime you've got the kids in tow. Order at the counter-we'll take the chicken lettuce wraps and toothsome orange shrimp-and after it's wok-tossed, they'll bring the food to you. >>> 950 Baltimore Pike, Springfield, 610-549-9060; 4040 City Avenue, 215-594-8230; 2050 Route 70 West, Cherry Hill, 856-792-9260; peiwei.com.

392 of 461 DOCUMENTS



Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)


August 1, 2008 Friday
SOONER EDITION


OBAMA SLIPPING IN PA., OHIO, FLA., POLL SHOWS


BYLINE: JAMES O'TOOLE, PITTSBURGH POST-GAZETTE


SECTION: STATE; THE ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE; Pg. A-5


LENGTH: 675 words


Illinois Sen. Barack Obama held a slightly reduced lead over Arizona Sen. John McCain among likely Pennsylvania voters, as new poll results showed movement toward the Republican in three key states.

A Quinnipiac University Poll conducted from July 23 to July 29, after Mr. Obama's trip to the Middle East and Europe, depicted the Democrat with a lead of 49 percent to 42 percent in the Keystone State. The same organization had reported his Pennsylvania edge last month at 52 percent to 40 percent.

The difference between the two findings was not much more than the surveys' 2.7 percentage point error margin, but previous Obama leads also eroded somewhat in Ohio and Florida, resulting in a virtual tie between the presidential contenders in those closely watched states. The Quinnipiac researchers found Mr. Obama leading by 46 percent to 44 percent in each.

New national polls showed similar slippage in Mr. McCain's direction. The Gallup organization's latest daily tracking poll showed Mr. Obama and Mr. McCain in a virtual dead heat, with 45 percent favoring the Democrat and 44 percent for the Republican. A national survey average compiled by the Web site, Pollster.com, showed Mr. Obama leading, 47 percent to 42 percent. A similar aggregation by Realclearpolitics.com puts the average at 46.8 percent for Mr. Obama and 43.9 percent for Mr. McCain.

In Pennsylvania, Mr. Obama led among both men and women. Independent voters broke in his favor by a margin of 49 percent to 38 percent. The candidates were essentially tied among white voters, with 46 percent for Mr. McCain and 45 percent for Mr. Obama. White men in the Pennsylvania sample narrowly favored the Republican, 48 percent to 45 percent, while Mr. Obama was favored by white women, 45 percent to 44 percent. Black voters continued to support the Democrat by the overwhelming margin of 91 percent to 1 percent.

Mr. McCain had substantial leads in the center of the state and in its northwest corner. Mr. Obama's strongest regions were Philadelphia and its suburbs. The Democrat was ahead in the state's largest city by 70 percent to 16 percent. In the suburbs, it was 54 percent to 38 percent in Mr. Obama's favor.

Perhaps surprisingly, Mr. Obama led in Allegheny County by the bare margin of 47 percent to 45 percent, the same result found in the generally more rural and socially conservative counties elsewhere in southwestern Pennsylvania.

"Senator Obama still has a comfortable 7-point lead, but, as in the primary, he still is struggling among white, blue-collar workers," Clay Richards, assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, said in a statement released with the survey.

In a week in which race flared in the charges and counter-charges of the campaigns, 9 out of 10 likely voters in all three states said the fact that Mr. Obama could be the first African-American president made no difference in their decision. And those who acknowledged race as an influence in their choice were about as likely to cite it as a positive as a negative factor.

Mr. McCain's age, in fact, was significantly more likely to be cited as a negative factor than Mr. Obama's race. Twenty-five percent of Pennsylvania voters said the Republican's age made them less likely to choose him, a finding similar to the results in Florida and Ohio.

Reflecting their close contest, the presidential rivals elicited similar favorable-unfavorable ratios in all three states. In Pennsylvania, 54 percent of those surveyed said they had a favorable impression of each candidate, while 27 percent said they had an unfavorable view of Mr. Obama, and 28 percent an unfavorable view of Mr. McCain.

Four years ago, the Democratic challenger, Massachusetts Sen. John Kerry, carried Pennsylvania narrowly over President Bush. By a small margin, Mr. Obama was doing a better job of holding onto the Kerry voters than Mr. McCain was in retaining Bush supporters. The Bush voters now favor Mr. McCain, 77 percent to 16 percent, while Mr. Kerry's former backers broke 80 percent to 13 percent for Mr. Obama.


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


NOTES: Post-Gazette politics editor James O'Toole can be reached at jotoole@post-gazette.com or 412-263-1562.


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper



Copyright 2008 P.G. Publishing Co.



393 of 461 DOCUMENTS



The Philadelphia Inquirer


July 31, 2008 Thursday
CITY-D Edition


He finds purpose in political rock


BYLINE: By Dan DeLuca; Inquirer Music Critic


SECTION: FEATURES MAGAZINE; Inq Col Dan DeLuca; Pg. E01


LENGTH: 1005 words


Max Bernstein had a band, the Actual, with a catchy song called "This Is the Worst Day of My Life," a slot on the Warped Tour, and a gig opening for heavy hitters Velvet Revolver on a national tour.

What he lacked was a sense of purpose.

"Somebody once asked me, 'Why are you in a band?' " says the Los Angeles singer and guitarist, who will bring his new Internet-distributed agit-rock outfit, Max & the Marginalized, to the Trocadero tomorrow and the Reef in Wilmington on Monday.

"And I really didn't have an answer. 'I don't know. We're another band that wants to make some good songs and have people like them'? When we were out on the Warped Tour with eight million other bands, trying to get something self-aggrandizing going, it just seemed a little vapid to me."

So when the Actual came off the road last October, Bernstein, 28, who's the son of former Washington Post reporter Carl Bernstein and author-screenwriter Nora Ephron, sat down and wrote three bracing, politically agitated rock songs.

"I wrote the songs really fast and recorded them right away," he recalls. "And I immediately knew that this is what I wanted to do."

Thus was born Max & The Marginalized, which Bernstein describes as "an op-ed in the form of a rock band" and also includes bassist Dave Watrous and drummer Jon Ryggy. As its Web site explains, M & M is "a band and a blog" that posts a newly written and recorded topical song on Thursday or Friday of every week.

The tunes - which can be found at www.huffingtonpost.com/max-and-the-marginalized - make no bones about reflecting the political point of view of Bernstein, which he describes as "pro-choice, anti-death penalty, for good immigration reform, low taxes for poor people, high taxes for rich people: the standard progressive platform."

Those first three songs - of 43 posted so far - get Bernstein's drift. "Standing in the Driveway Holding Cardboard in the Rain" opposes the death penalty. "No Kisses, No Cameras" is about the military's not allowing photographs of coffins of American soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan as they arrive at Dover Air Force base in Delaware.

And with "Even When It Ends It Won't Be Over," Bernstein - who has a day job in L. A. as a new media consultant for a veterans' rights organization - details the hardships that veterans of the country's two current wars will face even after the conflicts end.

(A fourth early tune, "Dana, Dana," showcased Bernstein's not-so-serious side: It's about the moral complexities inherent in a left-leaning wag having a crush on White House press secretary Dana Perino.)

M & M doesn't have a record deal, which is fine, Bernstein explained in an interview from a tour stop in Boston. "It was nice having an agent and a manager and being on Scott Weiland's label" - Weiland, then with Velvet Revolver, put out the Actual's 2007 album, In Stitches - "but it's also nice having songs that have a bigger purpose."

Bernstein, who grew up in New York, mostly with his Sleepless in Seattle-scriptwriting mother (rather than his Watergate-scandal-exposing father), says he's even happy that "Worst Day" never became a hit. "I heard Lemmy say how much he hates playing 'Ace of Spades,' and how if he had one wish it would be to never play it again."

He knew posting his often amusing songs on the Web was the way to go. "If you're going to be a political band, you need to respond quickly to things. We don't have a huge audience [the band's blog hits typically number in the hundreds] but let's say that we did. How can you write a song that has a chance to make a difference, and then sit on it for six months and wait for the album to come out?"

If M & M approached it that way, songs like "Consider the Source," which assails John McCain's credibility (as the candidate's nose grows, Pinocchio style, in a video), or "Not the Thing That I Bought," which voices buyer's remorse over Barack Obama's shift to the political center, would have passed their sell-by date before they were loosed on the public.

On his list of favorite political artists, Bernstein names Ted Leo, Nas, the Clash, Billy Bragg, Public Enemy and especially Australian rockers Midnight Oil, which he considers "the best political band of all time. They wrote great songs about aboriginal rights in Australia and sold millions of records doing it, because they were awesome."

The band is called Max & the Marginalized, he says, because "normal voices of dissent - and I'm a normal voice, not a radical one - have been pushed to the margins." He also likes that "it sounds like a '50s rock band or something that's really punk-rock."

And though M & M's sound doesn't move far from mainstream, Bernstein says that, "ideologically speaking," they're punks. "We're about immediacy and message more than execution," he says. "And we're off the cuff and spontaneous with no regard for commercial viability." The band sells T-shirts and CDs at shows and takes PayPal donations on the Web, but as expected, "the economic model is not working out. Nobody gets into this business to make money."

There are other protest bands about - Leftover Crack, for whom M & M will open at the Troc, is one. But they are relatively uncommon, considering the United States has been at war since 2001. The reason is simple, Bernstein says: There's no draft.

"In America, most rock-and-roll is made by upper-class white kids like myself," Bernstein says. "There are exceptions, but for the most part, the people who are fighting the war are not coming from the same communities. The war is out of sight from the culture."

Bernstein is a fan of political cartoonists such as Tom Tomorrow, Pat Oliphant and Jeff Danziger. "They're really my heroes. That's what I aspire to be doing. I'm not out to break a story," he says, adding with a laugh. "I'm just another person who wants to voice his opinion and not do research."

Contact music critic Dan DeLuca at 215-854-5628 or ddeluca@phillynews.com. Read his blog, "In the Mix," at http://go.philly.com/inthemix.


LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2008


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
